webTitle: Leeds arrive in Turkey to the silence of the fans

fields.headline: Leeds arrive in Turkey to the silence of the fans
fields.trailText: Chris Morris reports from Istanbul as a massive security operation swings into action in preparation for tonight's game.
fields.body:
There seemed to be a constable on every corner here last night as, for all the understandable desire to depict tonight's match as just another game, the city's police mounted what one officer described as their biggest operation since President Clinton came to town.

But the signs were good as the Leeds team flew in yesterday to a warm welcome with hardly a Besiktas fan in sight, unlike on past occasions when Turkish fans have mocked visiting teams at the airport and, particularly, when Leeds were last here in April and two of their fans, Christopher Loftus and Kevin Speight, were stabbed to death in the city centre.

The main problem yesterday, as the team bus was escorted by a convoy of police cars, was the pack of Turkish film crews pursuing the coach through heavy traffic to the hotel.

Several thousand police officers will be on duty for tonight's Champions League match and the security operation means opposing fans will have almost no chance to meet.

"We've taken every precaution," said a Besiktas official. "We are as convinced as we can be there won't be trouble."

British and Turkish security officials have been working closely together in the run-up to the match. British police have been on stand-by for several days at Istanbul airport, where unwanted visitors will be turned away. There are no indications, police sources say, that large groups of English fans will try to attend the game independently.

The official party of Leeds supporters, due to arrive on a charter flight this afternoon, will be escorted to a pleasure boat near the airport and taken, whether they like it or not, on a cruise along the Bosphorus. A helicopter will keep watch overhead. The boat will, officially, be alcohol-free and no travelling fans will be allowed into the city.

Less than an hour before kick-off the boat will dock next to Besiktas's Inonu stadium, where a police cordon will escort the fans inside. Immediately after the game they will be taken back to the airport.

Even if the match does pass peacefully the events of last April will cast a long shadow. Most Turks were deeply embarrassed by the brutal murders the night before Leeds took on Galatasaray in a Uefa Cup semi-final.

Twenty men are on trial in connection with the deaths, five charged with murder. The next hearing is due next week. The Turkish authorities still claim there was provocation before the fighting but they are also trying to clean up their patch. A database of known troublemakers has been set up by the police. It includes nearly 1,000 names, about half of them from Istanbul. Eventually the fingerprints of any fan with a record of football violence will be available at every police station in Turkey.

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to editor@footballunlimited.co.uk

fields.headline: Duisenberg in double trouble
fields.standfirst:
Special report: economic and monetary union
Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Pressure on Europe's top central banker, Wim Duisenberg, after his comments caused a euro sell-off was compounded yesterday when inflation in the single currency zone hit a six-year high.
fields.body:
Pressure on Europe's top central banker, Wim Duisenberg, after his comments caused a euro sell-off was compounded yesterday when inflation in the single currency zone hit a six-year high.

Policymakers rallied to the defence of the president of the European Central Bank. The European commission said it had "complete confidence" in Mr Duisenberg, while the German finance minister, Hans Eichel, saw no reason to become involved in a public discussion about Mr Duisenberg's position.

The ECB emphatically dismissed rumours that Mr Duisenberg had resigned. "He has not even considered resigning. Why should he?" a bank spokesman said.

But with the ECB due to hold a press conference in Paris tomorrow, Mr Duisenberg will be unable to avoid a further grilling on remarks in a newspaper interview which were seen as playing down the chances of intervention to support the single currency.

He will also have to explain the ECB's strategy for keeping inflation - its main policy focus - in check after yesterday's figures showed the annual rate rose to a six-year high of 2.8% last month, well ahead of the ECB's 2% target.

The tensions triggered by Mr Duisenberg's comments were underlined by a split in the Italian government. Labour minister Cesare Salvi was openly critical of both the ECB and its president. "It is unacceptable that the only body which makes decisions in Europe is the ECB, which follows an ultra-monetarist theory and acts with superficiality and improvisation. As far as superficiality is concerned, I am thinking of yesterday's [Monday's] declarations."

He was slapped down by treasury minister Vincenzo Visco who said people should confine themselves to issues "on which they are informed and competent".

France's finance minister, Laurent Fabius, avoided commenting on Mr Duisenberg's position. The governor of the Bank of France, Jean-Claude Trichet, would be favourite to succeed Mr Duisenberg if he stepped down.

The euro tumbled on the foreign exchanges on Monday after Mr Duisenberg said intervention would be inappropriate in the face of currency turbulence caused by an external shock such as war in the middle east. Yesterday the euro was within half a cent of its all-time low of 84.40 cents.

fields.headline: Richard Vinen's top 10 history books
fields.trailText: Richard Vinen is the author of A History in Fragments: Europe in the 20th Century
fields.body:
Richard Vinen is the author of A History in Fragments: Europe in the 20th Century (Little, Brown)
Buy A History in Fragments at Amazon.co.uk

1. England your England by George Orwell (1941)
The best history is always written by non-historians and no one has had more of an impact on the way in which we see modern Britain than George Orwell. This essay (first published in 1941 and reprinted in Inside the Whale and other Essays) manages in a very Orwellian, perhaps very English way, to be both sentimental wartime propaganda and a caustic scrutiny of national myth.

2. An Anthropologist among the Historians and Other Essays by Bernard Cohn (1987)
Bernard Cohn is another non-historian. Here he not only has much to say about Indian society but also about the rituals and superstitions of historians themselves.

3. Ce Que J'ai Cru Comprendre (What I thought I understood) by Anne Kriegel (1991)
Anne Kriegel is very much an academic historian but her work is also informed by her personal experience as a Jewish girl in occupied Paris, and as a communist militant. Her memoirs reflect an uncomfortably fierce intelligence.

4. Oni: Stalin's Polish Puppets by Teresa Toranska (1987)
A work of oral history based on encounters between a young Solidarity activist and the old men responsible for establishing communism in Poland. It captures the almost surreal atmosphere of meetings where, for example, a Polish politician danced a waltz with Molotov as Stalin worked the gramophone.

5. Strange Death of Liberal England by George Dangerfields (1997)
Dangerfields is wrong about everything but wrong in an interesting way.

6. Christ Stopped at Eboli by Carlo Levis (1981)
A moving account of the experiences of a Milan intellectual who was exiled to a small southern village by Mussolini. It is about witchcraft, sex, fascism, America (half the village's male population had emigrated) and many other things.

7. Dark Continent. Europe's Twentieth Century by Mark Mazower (1998)
This is an excellent book with particularly strong chapters on national/racial tension and constitution-making in the 1920s.

8. Peasants into Frenchmen: the Modernisation of Rural France, 1870-1914 by Eugen Weber (1977)
Even more ambitious than its title suggests. It backs up sweeping answers with a wealth of telling, often very funny, details and continues to raise questions even for those who disagree with Weber's answers.

9. A People's Tragedy: the Russian Revolution, 1891-1924 by Orlando Figes (1996)
Stalin said that one death is a tragedy and one million deaths is a statistic. Figes manages to find the individual tragedies and a lot of grotesque comedy behind the mass slaughter of the period.

10. Night Frost in Prague: the End of Humane Socialism by Zdenek Mlynr (1980)
Mlynr, a Czech Stalinist turned reformer turned dissident, was remarkably prescient in his account of the Prague spring and its aftermath. His views are particularly interesting because he was, until 1967, an associate of Mikhail Gorbachev.

webTitle: Working Lives: How world leaders worked

fields.headline: How world leaders worked
fields.standfirst: Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: From Thatcher to Mao...
fields.body:
Margaret Thatcher

Worked like a coal heaver, sleeping just four hours a night. It was only the fact that she was up burning the midnight oil, instead o fslumbering in her suite at the Grand Hotel, which saved her from harm in the Brighton bombing of 1984.

Harold Wilson

"I believe the greatest asset a head of state can have is the ability to get a good night's sleep," said the Labour prime minister, believed, like Callaghan, to have been a frequent catnapper during his eight years at Number 10.

Ronald Reagan

Once famously said: "It's true hard work never killed anybody, but I figure - why take the chance?". Rumour has it he would never work after 3pm. (Nor would he work with animals or children.) He liked key policy issues to be explained in cartoons. John F Kennedy, by contrast, believed that "we must use time as a tool, not as a couch". President Eisenhower liked to delegate so he could spend more time practising his golf.

Mao Zedong

Remained leader of Communist China until his death in 1976, but for the final 20 years effectively ruled from his bed, with a constant supply of food, reading matter and (reputedly) young women.

Adolf Hitler

Awake for 21 hours a day, rising at six and retiring at 3am. Required medication to help stay awake, and further drugs to send him to sleep.

Joseph Stalin

Rose around midday then worked until late in the evening before eating dinner and hitting the vodka, frequently going to bed at around 4am.

Mahatma Gandhi

The legendary proponent of non-violence actively encouraged photographs of himself asleep in the belief that it promoted an image of peace and tranquillity.

fields.headline: Marisa Monte's extravagant camp
fields.standfirst:
Marisa Monte
Royal Festival Hall, London ***
fields.trailText:
Marisa Monte
Royal Festival Hall, London ***
fields.body:
There seems to be an unwritten rule among Brazilian musicians at the moment, that staging and showmanship need to be larger than the music. Marisa Monte has pushed the boat out. The set for her sell-out show was so extravagantly camp that it would have upstaged her had she not outmanoeuvred it with her charisma, panache and musicianship.

Large gauzes, stretched across and anchored to the stage, loomed like huge splodges of chewing gum, but served as projection screens for moving image projections. Video pictures swirled across them as Monte, wrapped in a black gothic dress with huge red roses stitched to her breast and crowned with an outsize and even blacker wig piece, sashayed onto the stage to Serge Gainsbourg's Je T'aime.

Monte, an energetic yet sensitive singer, has been f ted outside of Brazil and embraced by some of the New York art musician set. She has also worked with the Brazilian greats, including Gilberto Gil and Caetano Veloso.

She has a fantastic voice. She struck up her nine-piece band - which included a four-strong percussion team that confidently rippled complex rhythms across the stage - to open the show with Amor I Love You, the first track on her most recent album, Memories Chronicles and Declarations of Love.

The album formed the backbone of the performance, which seemed to prove another rule - that given some electric guitars and the chance to rock out, a Brazilian band simply can't resist. The results can be fatal.

Her voice is so dynamic and expressive that it can handle almost any material and her new songs gave her the chance to strap on a guitar herself.

fields.headline: Future visions of a sculpture clash
fields.standfirst:
Hollingsworth/Heyer
Fruitmarket Gallery, Edinburgh ***
fields.trailText:
Hollingsworth/Heyer
Fruitmarket Gallery, Edinburgh ***
fields.body:
For the third of its Visions for the Future series, the Fruitmarket has paired two sculptors. At first glance, gender stereotypes seem alive and well, with Steve Hollingsworth working with bikes and cars, Annette Heyer with organic things like plants and natural light. But Hollingsworth is just as fascinated by light. His Electric Chair, a neon structure, is a thing of horrible beauty, with its fly-killing, Death Row references, while two video works, 6-0-1 Bike Wheel and The Language of Signs, show the artist in playful form during a residency in Japan.

In one, he rides round and round in a park at night, a neon tube attached to his bike. He moves in and out of the frame, powering the light with his pedalling, the circular motion and reddish glow suggesting a heartbeat. It is an oddly comforting work, hypnotically so in fact.

The second work is funnier, madder. He pushes the wheel of a bike round city streets, again with neon embellishments - but again there is a warm charm to the result. A wobbly handheld camera filming at shin level gives the video a childlike quality in keeping with the childishness of the game he has entered into.

Altogether more grown up is his exploration of existentialism, with a nod to Camus's Myth of Sisyphus. Well, the reference is grown-up, but the result - crushing a Vauxhall Astra in to a white ball - is in keeping with the general air of playful profundity. The ball rocks softly from side to side, as if there might be someone within. Hollingsworth quotes Camus: "There is no more dreadful punishment than futile and hopeless labour." The results of futile labour on show here couldn't be less like a punishment.

Heyer, by contrast, is less engaging, cooler in the chilly sense of the word. A table of lemon geraniums is the only sign of life, "a living equivalent of the time-lapse film" is how the explanatory leaflet puts it, a bit carried away with itself. More affecting is a miniature greenhouse, echoing the gallery's own form. Devoid of function, it makes you think of Crystal Palace, or fragile structures like piers, and how they are held together.

The artist takes up this concern again, by placing a series of reversed half-arches along the gallery walls. A generic architectural form suddenly without context, function - they are emphatically not linking or bridging anything - they are a dramatic interrogation of form and function, and the strongest work in Heyer's show.

They make you think, "why?" just as Hollingsworth rather more playfully makes you think, "why not?"

Until November 18 Details: 0131-225 2383.

fields.headline: Hades
fields.standfirst: Theatre Space, Dublin  ***
fields.trailText: Theatre Space, Dublin ***
fields.body:
Writer-director Declan Gorman returns to his native Monaghan town - just south of the Irish border, yet still very much in the old province of Ulster - in this play about the uneasy dawn of peace, after 30 years of the Troubles plunged the local countryside into a shadowland existence, isolated by road blocks and border bridges blown up by the British military.

Gorman overlays a Greek underworld on his fictional, depressed border town of Ballinascaul. The local wino and unlikely oracle, Nickie Nixon, is cast as the doomed Ixion. There's a ferryman somewhere in the kindly taxi driver who seems to specialise in picking people up off the street; even a Cerberus of sorts in the two bouncers at the nightclub, Tataros, where the youth of the town get laid, take E and spew their drunken guts out.

The "peace dividend" funds are beginning to flow, but the place is still gridlocked by paramilitarism and parish-pump politicians. It's a tall order, but a cast of five quadruple up as a huge menagerie of characters: hotel workers, local widows, a philandering tycoon; the former boxing champion whose ailing ostrich farm is repossessed; or the Monsignor who, on the brink of being ordained bishop, backs out on account of a son he fathered years ago. The satiric topicality stretches to the local council chamber, where the Sinn Fein councillor is blamed for water pollution, supposedly caused by the bodies of people "disappeared" by the IRA.

For all the angry satire, this is upbeat, morally didactic, peace propaganda. It was warmly received on its first outing in 1998 in border towns and in Belfast, where it won the Stewart Parker award. The ambition of the piece is vast, and certainly overstretches the resources of Gorman's Upstate company, although his cast manage to switch fairly effectively between their tally of characters. They are often fighting insurmountable odds in a script that seems confused between its instincts for ludicrous comedy and keen, on-the-level tragedy.

Ultimately the freestyle production, which cleverly redefines the stage every three minutes, rather chokes the continuity of the piece. Gorman certainly should have edited his script severely but, that said, something about his constant, skewering humour leaves you with a lop-sided grin.

Until May 21. Details: 00-353-1 984 4227.

fields.headline: We Love UK
fields.standfirst: Rocket, Leeds  ****
fields.trailText: Rocket, Leeds ****
fields.body:
Three different acts, one of them extraordinary, under the collective banner of the new We Love You label. Kings of Convenience are the kind of winsome, woolly scarf, acoustic duo that has been illegal in most countries since the 1960s. They play four songs. Mind-bogglingly drippy, the pair depart whimpering about "the next 10 days on the tour bus", and will hopefully end up as the butts of cruel jokes, and being used by other bandmembers as a dartboard.

Three weeks ago I criticised American Shawn Lee's Monkey Boy album on the grounds that the production had taken most of the feeling and emotion out of the songs. Now it's obvious that they must have laboured to get some emotion in. Live, his ridiculously mannered singing voice (Elvis impersonator meets wounded water buffalo), preening ego ("We're in for a night of great music") and showbiz schmaltz would actively embarrass Barry Gibb. "Hit it!" breezes perma-grinning, portly muso Shawn, to deafening silence. A long career beckons as in-house entertainer on Transpacific cruises.

The prospect of a third act looms as invitingly as another round with Prince Naseem, but I Am Kloot are astounding. Mancunian Johnny Bramwell is one of the most natural frontmen I have ever seen on a British stage. With one foot up on a milk crate, guitar strung to his hip, he effortlessly recreates the driven rocker stance perfected by Gene Vincent; there is something timeless and ghostly about him. Drenched in (equally Vincent-like) echo, Bramwell's staggering, scornful voice manages to be early Lennon, the La's Lee Mavers, and Liam Gallagher all at once.

Backed by casually haunting bassist Peter Jobson and a real jazz-tinged gem of a drummer, Andy Hargreaves, his songs, too, have the unmistakable air of the classic. Obviously steeped in the Kinks, the La's and maybe even the early, sardonic Lilac Time, Bramwell's stunningly dark lyrics ("I love you, there's blood on your legs") make this music his own.

Between songs he's surprisingly funny, which makes his sociopathic anthems even more beguiling. Potential saviours of British music, miss I Am Kloot now at your future cool's peril. Although, given the supporting cast, make sure to arrive fashionably late.

At Roadmenders, Northampton (01604 604222), tomorrow, then touring.

fields.headline: Bill's up for office surfers
fields.standfirst:
Work Unlimited
Net news
fields.trailText: Office workers who while away their time at work trading shares, booking holidays or shopping online could cost businesses as much as $35m (£25m) a year, according to a software snooper specialist.
fields.body:
Office workers who while away their time at work trading shares, booking holidays or shopping online could cost businesses as much as $35m (£25m) a year, according to a software snooper specialist.

The findings of a recent Surf Control survey, based on a thousand employees spending one hour online for personal use, were reiterated by the company as it reported better than expected first-quarter results for the period to the end of August this year.

The survey found that 59% of office internet use is not work-related. Employees who traded in shares, played sport, shopped and bought holidays on the internet cost companies the most.

Pornography, according to chief executive Steve Purdham, is still the biggest concern, but only accounts for 2%-4% of non-work-based use. SurfControl, whose software monitors the websites employees visit and allows managers to restrict access, said there was increasing demand for its products.

The company also said it would be moving into the mobile phone market as technology developed. Mr Purdham said: "There is an increasing awareness that the internet is a significant but highly seductive resource that needs to be proactively managed."

Revenues rose to $6.7m this year from $2.3m for the year before. Internet filtering products now form the company's core business, accounting for $5.8m of total revenue.

Mr Purdham said: "Strong demand, expansion into new geographical markets and our good timing in taking our products to the relevant markets, have resulted in a performance that has exceeded our high expectations."

First-quarter losses reached almost $20m but before interest, tax, depreciation and amortisation the figure was $3.1m.

This sum beat Deutsche Bank's predictions of an underlying loss of $5.4m.

SurfControl, formerly JSB Software Technology, has $26.1m in the bank, and recently acquired Cyber Patrol and CSM Security Management.

Deutsche Bank analysts say the money should be sufficient for the everyday operations of the company.

The share price yesterday rose 115p to 1,750p.

webTitle: One woman's vision offers loan lifeline

fields.headline: One woman's vision offers loan lifeline
fields.standfirst:
Street UK is a new bank that hopes to give struggling firms access to cash
Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Rosalind Copisarow used to embark on hours of fraught negotiations over 250-page loan agreements before lending millions of pounds to governments and big business. Now she is aiming to get the process down to one page as she embarks on a project to lend money to some of Britain's more impoverished businesses.
fields.body:
Rosalind Copisarow used to embark on hours of fraught negotiations over 250-page loan agreements before lending millions of pounds to governments and big business. Now she is aiming to get the process down to one page as she embarks on a project to lend money to some of Britain's more impoverished businesses.

The aim is to tackle social and financial exclusion - one of the main planks of government policy which is causing dissent among the leading banking groups. While the government and banks bicker over attempts to set up a universal bank in post offices or create basic accounts without overdrafts, Ms Copisarow is pressing ahead with her plan to help small businesses.

The concept struck her as she was on her way to negotiate yet another multi-million pound loan. Her eye was drawn to an article about a bank in Bangladesh which had changed the lives of 2m people, predominantly poor women, who had never had access to cash before. Her life was never to be the same again either.

"It was an incredible realisation. From my own point of view it felt like I saw the point of banking, the point of money. It was as if this banking career of mine was removed from the fundamental route of credit. It was as if these 250-page loan agreements I was negotiating had to be put in place because of the lack of trust," Ms Copisarow said.

Her vision is to bring the idea to Britain through a new lending institution known as Street UK. Based in Birmingham, Ms Copisarow and her team hope to issue their first loans next month to small businesses which would otherwise never be able to borrow money. By next year, she hopes to sell shares in Street UK so that shareholders could recoup their investment in a few years.

It is six years since Ms Copisarow, who worked at multinational banking groups such as Citicorp, the now reformed MidlandMontagu and JP Morgan, gave up her life as an investment banker. The Oxford-educated 42-year-old took the micro-finance idea to Poland, where she was based after the fall of the Berlin wall. She opened up eastern Europe to international finance. She set up Fundusz Mikro, which has now issued 30,000 loans and opened branches in 33 cities in Poland.

Banking for all

She hopes to secure backing from government and if she achieves her goal, Big Issue sellers on the streets up and down the country could soon have bank accounts. It is what she sees as the first step along the road to saving and the basis for a sounder financial footing.

Street UK is based on micro-credit, devised by Professor Mohammed Yunus who eventually formed what became Grameen Bank in Bangladesh. Micro-credit sounds evangelical and all too worthy. It requires mutual trust, and it is based on developing a network of friends to support each other. The more people who apply for loans, the lower their rate of repayments.

The catch is that they must guarantee each other's loans. Failure by one in the group requires the others to pay. No more than seven are allowed in each group and loans can be granted to individuals on their own, provided they have three outsiders to act as guarantors.

"What we're trying to tap into is the circle of support people naturally have around themselves and the informal information banks would never get. We know when you choose someone to be in your group you wouldn't dream of having them there if you thought you'd have to pay up or they wouldn't pay for you," she said.

Higher interest rate

The loans will be charged at rates of interest perhaps two percentage points higher than banks charge small businesses. But, as far as Street UK is concerned, this is a small price to pay as the borrowers would be denied credit without its loans, which would be about £2,000 and involve repayments over nine months or so.

The alternative might be loans from money lenders, who usually lend money to individuals rather than businesses, or loan sharks, whose rates can reach exorbitant levels.

The borrowers are likely to be small businesses, probably sole traders, in local communities, where self support - watching each other's stalls in a street market, for example - is a way of life. "What we're trying to do is make them highly motivated to repay, making them feel they want to repay because this is an organisation that believes in them," she says.

To cynics, who might regard Street UK as yet another well intentioned attempt - doomed to failure - to tackle the politically charged issue of financial exclusion, Ms Copisarow reels out statistics. By 1993 in Bangladesh 2m of the world's poorest people had been lent money by Grameen Bank with default rates of only 2%. In her venture in Poland, Ms Copisarow's brainchild now employs 94 people and has lent approximately £30m.

Street UK will not hold a banking licence but aims to offer bank accounts through a new arrangement through the Bank of Scotland.

Ms Copisarow hopes that 80% of all loans made by Street UK will go to groups of seven or less because it should generate simultaneous, mutual growth. "The main attraction initially will be the [lower] interest rate of repayment within a large group. After a while [individuals] will look for richer and richer guarantors so that they can grow in synch with them," she says.

fields.headline: Prokina/ Skigin
fields.standfirst: Wigmore Hall, London ****
fields.trailText: Wigmore Hall, London ****
fields.body:
We haven't seen or heard much of Elena Prokina of late. The Russian soprano, whose Katya Kabanova at Covent Garden and Tatiana at Glyndebourne rank among the unforgettable operatic experiences of the last decade, hasn't graced these shores for several years.

Mercifully, her Wigmore Hall recital was worth the wait. Prokina's glamour is undiminished, and when she walked on stage - seemingly sewn into a spangled purple sheath that left nothing to the imagination - there was a gasp from the audience.

She trained in the theatre before turning to music, and may best be described as a singing-actress of great power. Occasionally, you're conscious of flaws in her vocal methodology. The sound is fierily voluptuous, though the tone occasionally hardens under pressure. All this is insignificant, however, compared to the excitement she can generate.

Schubert's Gretchen has been seduced, impregnated and deserted by Faust. Prokina begins her famous spinning song clutching her belly, then abandons herself to a flood of delirious erotic reminiscence before recovering her poise. She gives us Schumann's version of Goethe's androgynous Mignon, stuck in emotional hell between a wimpish lover and a domineering father, bringing the music to the edge of hysteria.

Schumann also set five of Mary Stuart's (not very good) poems. Prokina responds by producing the most complete musico-dramatic portrait of the Queen of Scots that I've yet encountered.

She devotes the second half of her programme to Reinhold Glìre, whose music she has championed and extensively recorded. He has the reputation of being the arch-socialist realist of Stalin's Russia, and his big public statements are the dreadful epitome of totalitarian high camp. His songs, however, formed a canon of intensely private works conceived out of the glare of the communist spotlight.

Both in subject matter and style, they're full of all the things a socialist realist isn't supposed go anywhere near. Tragic erotic passion, tender sentiment and nostalgia for the idealised orient of the Imperial Caucasus are their themes.

Wagner (bucket loads of Tristan und Isolde), Strauss, and Debussy underpin their chromatic yearnings. Prokina immerses herself in their heady atmosphere with the grace of an elegant, yet savage animal waiting to spring.

She's some lady. Let's hope we don't have to wait quite so long before we get to hear her again.

webTitle: Consumers start to get a conscience

fields.headline: Consumers start to get a conscience
fields.standfirst: Shoppers are beginning to get more concerned about ethical issues - prompting further growth in a market already worth £8bn
fields.trailText: Shoppers are beginning to get more concerned about ethical issues - prompting further growth in a market already worth £8bn.
fields.body:
A third of UK consumers claim to be seriously concerned about ethical issues when shopping - although only half of that number put their principles into action and buy (or boycott) products because of the manufacturer's reputation.

The MORI research, commissioned by the Co-operative bank, also found one in four consumers claim to have investigated a company's social responsibility at least once, and one in two shoppers say they have bought a product and recommended a supplier because of its responsible reputation.

The report shows a heightened awareness of ethical issues amongst the UK public and a boom in the market for ethical products and services. The ethical consumer market, which encompasses a whole range of products, from investments to eggs, is worth an estimated £8bn per year, and growing.

Of those surveyed, 5% were identified as ethical hard-liners. The most dedicated ethical shoppers, this group includes affluent professionals aged between 35 and 55 years old who live mainly in the southeast. They are members of campaign organisations and regularly buy and boycott on ethical grounds.

Some 50%, often elderly, people, said they had ethical concerns but did not feel powerful enough to influence suppliers

Around 18% said their main concern was quality and price. They were not concerned with brands and would consider ethical issues if the price of the product were right.

Brand obsession accounted for 6% - these were unlikely to consider ethical issues when shopping.

A further 22%, made up largely of younger people from the lower social classes, seemed the least concerned with environmental and social issues.

The report said a variety of actions define ethical consumerism, including: recycling, shopping locally, discussing a company's behaviour with friends and family and avoiding products because of a company's behaviour.

Moneyunlimited will be producing a guide to ethical money in the near future. Watch this space for more details.

webTitle: Theatre review: The Dispute/ The Critic

fields.headline: The Dispute/ The Critic
fields.standfirst: Royal Exchange, Manchester  ***
fields.trailText: Royal Exchange, Manchester ***
fields.body:
Theatre has always been fascinated with itself, but the current interest of theatre in theatre is beginning to amount to an unhealthy obsession. This year, Edinburgh was full of plays about writing plays or putting on plays, and in the last month I've seen six productions that fall into that category.

This double bill of 18th-century comedies adds another two to the tally. Matthew Lloyd's oddly paired plays are linked merely by the fact they were written in the same century and have a play within a play. They demonstrate that some plays can, even when they were written centuries ago, still speak to us today. They also prove that some plays about the theatre just disappear up their own smug backsides.

Marivaux's The Dispute, written in 1749 and translated with a spiteful brilliance by Neil Bartlett, is dark and multi-layered, holding a mirror up to us that reflects back our own narcissistic image. It is both seductive and horrible to watch.

Sheridan's The Critic, written 40 years later, about spin-doctor Mr Puff who is premiering his play The Spanish Armada, may have been topically satirical in its day but is now no more than a mildly enjoyable panto that panders to the audience's knowing laughs about spin without telling us anything we don't already know.

In contrast, The Dispute is a deeply unsettling, almost Sadeian drama. It tells of a prince who, wishing to settle an argument with his lady about which is the more fickle of the sexes, has had the foresight to set up an appalling experiment. Four young people, two girls and two boys, have been brought up since birth in complete isolation from each other and the rest of the world except for two servants. When they are let loose on each other, Eden quickly turns to hell as astonishment and wonder at themselves and this brave new world turns to love, betrayal and anger.

The play is playful, deliciously funny and has a desperate, needling quality. It is like seeing the history of the world and one's own personal relationships pass by in a flash. All the time you are wondering at the youngsters' puppy-like antics you are also worrying about the motives of the experimenters.

I could have done without The Critic. There is enough art and lessons from life to be had from The Dispute to render the second half of the evening obsolete, even though Adam Godley is in fine form as Puff.

Until November 11. Box office: 0161-833 9833.

fields.headline: Pru to cut pension charges
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Prudential, Britain's second-biggest life insurer, is to cut personal pension charges by up to 30% in a move that will benefit more than 1m existing customers.
fields.body:
Prudential, Britain's second-biggest life insurer, is to cut personal pension charges by up to 30% in a move that will benefit more than 1m existing customers.

The change will bring its personal pensions more into line with stakeholder pensions, the new low-cost plans available from April next year. While it declined to disclose the cost of the move, the company said it would have little impact on its profitability.

But the Pru dashed hopes that it would follow three of its rivals and issue a promise to worried mortgage endowment customers that these policies will meet their targets provided certain conditions are met.

Prudential also yesterday revealed that for the first time, more than half of the group's sales came from overseas. Total new insurance and investment sales rose 5% to £1.3bn in the first nine months of this year.

webTitle: Working Lives: Tricks of the trade

fields.headline: Tricks of the trade
fields.standfirst: Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: Work Unlimited
fields.body:
Richard Hunter, 32 - company director

As a boss, away weekends and Christmas lunches are the only times you are allowed to be yourself. When I come into the office, I'm different from when I'm at home and I'd like my employees to meet the Richard-at-home every now and then. Away weekends are perfect for this, but only as long as you make sure that, come Monday, it's back to work - you have to show that you are in charge of your chameleon nature. As the boss, I'm quite happy to get squiffy with the rest of them, but I have a policy of going to bed by 2am because that's when things start to get messy. If people are rowing drunkenly while you're in bed, it is not your responsibility. My advice is always to deal with these things in the morning.

Alison Parker, 39 - chief executive

I went on an away weekend at which an esteemed and rather drunk colleague professed undying love. I didn't see it coming, but he confessed his adoration in front of everyone, which produced much mirth. Luckily, I went on two weeks' holiday straight after, so when I got back, it had all blown over. People regress on away weekends - it's almost like being a student again, where everyone gets drunk at a party and lets themselves go. If anyone did bring the subject up, I'd defend mycolleague, blaming the whisky. Every ensuing year, when the subject of away weekends came up, I'd look across at him but get no reaction. I suspect he didn't remember a thing.

Richard Gough, 55 - financial director

One thing I have learnt is that you cannot run an away weekend and participate in it. It's a recipe for disaster because you can't keep colleagues on the straight and narrow while throwing your views into work discussions. The only way to get round it is to employ a trained facilitator to run the thing for you. They then control the group dynamics and get people to focus on the day's objectives and enjoy it. On our last away weekend, we were looking to improve our creative thinking skills and the facilitator came up with some very good interactive schemes. He created debating points, we all sat in booths linked by email and in an hour we'd come up with 600 ideas.

Robert Saunders, 27 IT manager

Our company organised a big powwow for the organisation's regional offices. The idea was that we got to know each other and it was all lovey-dovey as we worked together in little teams. Well, the weekend was full of good intentions but nothing came of it. We all tried to communicate with each other for the first month afterwards, but as there was no monitoring by the bosses, things just went back to normal. I think away weekends are like being at school. You've got to relax and be cool. Anyone who's too enthusiastic just gets labelled teacher's pet and people gang up against them. That's why I think they don't really work. No one wants to be seen to be putting in too much effort.

Katie James, 42 - project manager

Away weekends are a minefield. Often you're stuck with your colleagues in some hotel in the middle of nowhere and the only recreation on offer is the bar. As a result, it can get a bit intense and people always overdo it. But I never start the evening by propping up the bar and I'm always in bed by 11.30pm. And while some people use away weekends to fuel gossip, I use them to find out about new colleagues. You can discover exactly what makes them tick when you're sober and they're telling you their life story after one too many vodkas.

 The employment tribunal lawyer is on maternity leave.

webTitle: Working Lives: six-hour days, long lunches and evenings

fields.headline: Nice work if you can get it
fields.standfirst:
George W Bush claims his six-hour days, long lunches and evenings of leisure make him more efficient. Could he possibly be on to something? Merope Mills investigates

Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: George W Bush claims his six-hour days, long lunches and evenings of leisure make him more efficient. Could he possibly be on to something? Merope Mills investigates...
fields.body:
Who would have thought that the biggest distinction between candidates in the race for the White House would come down to a trivial old thing like working hours? In a two-party system often criticised for offering voters few choices, a survey of George W Bush's work schedule showed possibly the most marked difference in attitude between the rivals so far.

While Al Gore promises to work for the American people every hour of every day if he wins, the Republican candidate has taken a more lackadaisical approach to campaigning, rolling in not a moment before 9am, taking a two-hour lunch break at 11.30am, and knocking off around five.

In a nation where working hours now exceed those of Japan, it could prove a controversial revelation, and one that might easily turn off several million workaholic American citizens - if they find time in their hectic schedules to vote in the November elections, that is. But it will also prompt the question from stressed-out workers everywhere: if he can, could we? Has the death of the nine to five as an efficient way of getting things done been exaggerated?

As governor of Texas, Bush's aides argue he crams more into his working hours by delegating, focusing and avoiding details. To this end, somewhat alarmingly, he sanctioned 245 executions in less than 15 minutes each; and few of his meetings last more than 10 minutes.

It is an approach that is growing in popularity among those making decisions of a slightly less life-or-death nature. The list of chief executives embracing the shorter-hours culture - famously spearheaded in the UK by Gerry Robinson, chairman of the Granada group - includes Charles Allen, chairman of Granada TV and LWT, Bill Marriott, chairman and chief executive of the Marriot hotel group, and Professor Sissi Closs, founder and director of Comet Computers. Pin this breed of executive down long enough to ask them how they do it, and the claims to efficiency they make echo the justifications of Bush's team.

Peter Ellwood, chief executive of the Lloyds TSB group, is strict with himself: as chair of the Employers' Forum for Work-Life Balance, he has to be. "I do go to the gym a couple of times a week, so often don't get in until about 9am. When I don't have an evening meal I usually finish at about 7pm," he says.

"I certainly take all my holiday, and I certainly think weekend activities are sacred. It's a state of mind, of saying to yourself and your staff: 'Look, if we're not careful we'll spend all our lives working.' Working 20 hours a day, seven days a week is not a macho thing to do ... You can't be efficient that way. Long hours does not equal effective hours: quite the reverse."

Fellow banker Gerry McGinn, head of the Bank of Ireland's operations in Northern Ireland and Britain, is rarely to be found working beyond 6pm. "Sports days and school reports and school plays are sacrosanct," he claims. "The personal things go into my diary as well as the business things, and once they're in the diary I commit to them in the same way as I would to a business commitment." He may start early, but his early evening cut-off time ensures he is home in time to see his three sons before bedtime.

A recent report by the National Work-Life Forum argued that support from the top is one of the most powerful forces for changing attitudes and perceptions to the way people work: leading by example and arguing for a do-as-I-do policy is much more likely to instil limits on a workforce than mere rhetoric. Yet if chief executives and chairs manage to get by through delegation and detail-avoidance, surely there will be a trickle-down effect for the minions whose desks are then piled with a bigger workload?

That was the fate of Richard Edelman's colleagues at Edelman Public Relations Worldwide in America. When Edelman himself boasted to the Washington Post of his lack of overtime work, his comments were later checked by his vice-president Bob Ambrose, who came forward to say he got up at 3am in order to read newspapers and answer emails for his boss. "Because I am here, I can take some of the pressure off," he told the paper.

Ultimately, the newly-fashionable short day is an option only for the elite, according to clinical psychologist Oliver James. "For the sort of group that are in the culture of contentment - the top two-thirds - it's absolutely an option to be much less driven and to be more concerned to make the most of the fantastic affluence that they enjoy," he says. Stress-management consultant, Judi James, is similarly unimpressed by managers who make an early exit.

"Obviously our bosses should be role models - but to see a person who has landed you with a bulk of work skulk off early to play golf is going to stick in your throat a bit," she says.

"The British worker is prepared to put up with a lot if they think everyone else is suffering, but if they get the impression someone else is having an easier ride it doesn't go down well at all."

Early evenings can quickly become co-opted into the hierarchy of perks. "For much of the 80s, the more elevated position you kept, the less work you seemed to do," says Richard Reeves, director of futures at the Industrial Society. "Obviously, that's not what we want. But equally we don't want this clocking on, clocking off mentality of strict office hours that was borne out of the days of factory working. The fact that Bush has recognised quantity does not equal quality is commendable, but the fact that he is still taken with such a stringent distinction is not. We should be looking to cater for the individual worker, providing choice, and reflecting the varying needs of pace for productivity."

In a recent survey of British employees, 50% said they wanted to choose what hours they worked, compared to 20% that wanted to do a fixed day. At Lloyds TSB, a flexible working package has been introduced with a compressed hours scheme to reduced the length and number of working days: 18% of management are already taking advantage of it.

Choice may be the byword for future years, but workers who put in long hours - like the man Bush hopes to replace in the White House - are unlikely to change their patterns. "The simple fact is that people who work the longest hours enjoy their jobs most," says Reeves.

Perhaps this, then, is where the American electorate should take note. If George Bush Jnr plans a similarly laid-back timetable for his putative White House years, it may not say much for his enthusiasm for the job.

fields.headline: Closely observed lavatories
fields.standfirst:
Paul Graham
Anthony Reynolds Gallery, London ****
fields.trailText:
Paul Graham
Anthony Reynolds Gallery, London ****
fields.body:
Paul Graham's exhibition, entitled Paintings, is a show of photographs. They are not even photographs of paintings - although a cursory glance might mislead the viewer - but close-up photographs of graffiti on lavatory walls. All male readers will be familiar with the desperately drawn bodies and genitalia, the confessions, fantasies, appointment times and implorings. I can't speak of female loos, but informants tell me that graffiti in female loos is of another genre entirely.

Seen from a distance (something one cannot do within the confines of the toilet cubicle), cropped and beautifully mounted, some of Graham's colour photographs look like photographic reproductions of abstract paintings. With their immaculate sheen and presentation, they could almost be taken for works by Cy Twombly, or the earlier abstract impressionist paintings of Philip Guston, as inadvertant Rothkos.

But these are smear artists, golden shower Pollocks, morbid muralists and cottage conceptualists of the smallest room. It is, ostensibly, an exhibition about painting, and in particular the work of the abstract expressionists and their allies. The catalogue even opens with a letter of intent, sent to the New York Times in 1943, signed by Barnett Newman, Adolf Gottlieb and Mark Rothko, outlining the aims of the nascent movement: "Our work must be an insult to anyone who is spiritually attuned to interior decoration".

That these unknown bathroom Basquiats and tinkletown Twomblys occasionally show glimmers of humour, of wayward artistic talent, or a misguided literary bent, is unsurprising. You shouldn't be surprised to find cabinet ministers, playwrights or even art critics amongst the denizens of these gloomy confessionals. Remember Joe Orton's diary records of toilet bacchanals, or MP Tom Driberg's brushes with the law in loos near Parliament Square.

Graham has turned himself into a bloke with a camera and a good if unlikely alibi. Explaining himself away might raise a few vice squad eyebrows, but this kind of "research" is meat and drink to the sophisticates of the art world who, like the cops, have seen it all. For those who prefer the reek of industrial strength disinfectant to the smell of turpentine and paint, these images undoubtedly have a certain piquancy and frisson all their own. There are, doubtless, connoisseurs of these grim walls just as there are of art. I read these traces on lavatory walls as murmurs of loneliness, as much as semi-public accounts and illustrations of extreme fantasies and acts. The trouble with toilet graffiti is that one can't help reading it, looking at it, wondering at it, on those occasions when a visit to the gents is unavoidable.

Likening toilet graffiti to the heroics and sensitivities of a certain way of painting is to play on the meaning of the word "expression", and what it came to mean in art in the late modernist period. More critically, what Graham's Paintings do is to raise the question of intention, and the difference between looking at something, and reading its internal meanings and codes.

It is a question, then, about surface and content, and about taste and abhorrence. What these works conspicuously do not do, is say anything about the authors of these texts, the fantasists, exhibitionists and cottagers themselves, and they messages they send.

Until October 28. Details: 0207 491 0621.

fields.headline: Twelfth Night
fields.standfirst: Lowry, Salford, ***
fields.trailText: Lowry, Salford, ***
fields.body:
A shipwreck, some cross-dressing, one or two cases of mistaken identity, a clutch of romantic resolutions, and a drunken huddle of scheming fops, Twelfth Night is a frivolous conceit ideal for a touring production. Directed by Bill Alexander, the Birmingham Repertory Theatre vaguely aims for modernisation with costumes (according to the programme notes) following a 1940s theme, but aside from demob suits and raincoats, there is little else to suggest a radical updating of the play.

Instead, the company skips through the whimsical plots and sub-plots with a levity suggesting either glee or an urgent desire to get to the end. Rakie Ayola is an exuberant if slightly over-pitched Viola, estranged from her brother, and now dressing as a man to serve Duke Orsino.

Orsino, played with casual assurance by Pal Aron, is in love with Lady Olivia, and he sends Viola (now renamed Cesario) to woo the lady on his behalf. Jayne McKenna is excellent as the graceful yet insecure Olivia, resplendent in an evening gown of scarlet and black. When Olivia falls in love with Cesario, McKenna is all trembling limbs and suppressed desires, caught forever just a few steps away from an all too revealing embrace. Cesario's love for her master, Orsino, is less convincing.

Most of the fun, though, is reserved for Andy Hockley's bibulous Sir Toby Belch and his half-wit accomplice, Sir Andrew Aguecheek. With erratic hair and thick goggles, Jamie Newall as Aguecheek goes all out for absurdity, with a fine display of mincing words and walks, which are destined to keep him leagues away from the woman he desires, also Lady Olivia.

And just in case that isn't enough dandyism, Gerard Murphy as the sadly deluded Malvolio - "sick of self-love" - is as camp as Christmas, and just as brightly coloured. Indeed, Murphy's breathlessly funny performance begins to dominate the play, while Feste the jester, looking like grandpa from Only Fools and Horses, strolls and plays harmlessly in a strong Northern accent.

When all the vanity and dissembling is resolved via the Bard's knack for quick and scarcely credible conclusions (in this case, plenty of instant loving), this sprightly production just about survives with its dignity intact.

Twelfth Night is at the Alhambra, Bradford (0127-475 2000), until Saturday, then tours.

Directed by Bill Alexander, the Birmingham Repertory Theatre vaguely aims for modernisation with costumes (according to the programme notes) following a 1940s theme, but aside from demob suits and raincoats, there is little else to suggest a radical updating of the play. Instead, the company skips through the whimsical plots and sub-plots with a levity suggesting either glee or an urgent desire to get to the end. Rakie Ayola is an exuberant if slightly over-pitched Viola, estranged from her brother, and now dressing as a man to serve Duke Orsino. Orsino, played with casual assurance by Pal Aron, is in love with Lady Olivia, and he sends Viola (now renamed Cesario) to woo the lady on his behalf. Jayne McKenna is excellent as the graceful yet insecure Olivia, resplendent in an evening gown of scarlet and black. When Olivia falls in love with Cesario, McKenna is all trembling limbs and suppressed desires, caught forever just a few steps away from an all too revealing embrace. Cesario's love for her master, Orsino, is less convincing. Most of the fun, though, is reserved for Andy Hockley's bibulous Sir Toby Belch and his half-wit accomplice, Sir Andrew Aguecheek. With erratic hair and thick goggles, Jamie Newall as Aguecheek goes all out for absurdity, with a fine display of mincing words and walks, which are destined to keep him leagues away from the woman he desires, also Lady Olivia. And just in case that isn't enough dandyism, Gerard Murphy as the sadly deluded Malvolio - "sick of self-love" - is as camp as Christmas, and just as brightly coloured. Indeed, Murphy's breathlessly funny performance begins to dominate the play, while Feste the jester, looking like grandpa from Only Fools and Horses, strolls and plays harmlessly in a strong Northern accent. When all the vanity and dissembling is resolved via the Bard's knack for quick and scarcely credible conclusions (in this case, plenty of instant loving), this sprightly production just about survives with its dignity intact. Twelfth Night is at the Alhambra, Bradford (0127-475 2000), until Saturday, then tours.

fields.headline: Shearer shot sparks Boro humiliation
fields.standfirst: Newcastle go third as Bobby beats Bryan in battle of the Robsons
fields.trailText:
Middlesbrough 1 - 3 Newcastle
Bobby beats Bryan in battle of the Robsons as Newcastle move up to third.
fields.byline: Dominic Fifield at the Riverside stadium
fields.body:
The North-East was gripped in early winter chill last night, but the swathes of Newcastle fans did not feel the icy cold as they basked in smug victory.

Goals from Alan Shearer and Alain Goma warmed Geordie cockles before Kieron Dyer thumped home Lomana Tresor Lua-Lua's knock-down with a minute remaining. Middlesbrough, disjointed and thoroughly outclassed, gained a late consolation from Brian Deane but were left to mope from the field to a chorus of boos.

The talk in the build-up was less of the 97th Tyne-Tees derby - handbags at 50 miles compared to the close-knit, bitter Tyne-Wear rivalry - and more of a pair of Robsons tipped to answer their country's call.

The Newcastle manager Bobby Robson spent eight occasionally successful years in the England hot seat grooming his midfield namesake Bryan as a successor. But a decade since Gazza's tears in Turin and Captain Marvel is still refusing to fulfil his apparent destiny.

Perhaps he wants to taste club success first. His side's wretched home record this season prior to the Toon's visit - two points from four games - has swelled the fans' discontent, not that their frenetic start suggested they have been struggling to exploit home advantage. With Newcastle players slipping and sliding on the sodden surface, Gianluca Festa forced a full-length save from Shay Given as early as the third minute.

Bobby Robson had clearly anticipated such an early roasting and mirrored the home side's five-man midfield in an attempt to nullify their threat, with Nolberto Solano asked to operate in an unlikely wing-back role. Luckily for him, though, the home side's dominance was shortlived. After 13 minutes his team went on the attack, as Kieron Dyer dummied Solano's free-kick and Alain Goma's skimming shot was turned round the post by Mark Crossley.

The 31-year-old goalkeeper, making his home debut after a summer move from Nottingham Forest, should have conceded his first Riverside goal 14 minutes later. Dyer slipped Didier Domi inside Curtis Fleming and the Frenchman's low cross was converted by Daniel Cordone. The Argentine striker, level with the last defender as he slid the ball home, rose to see a linesman's flag to prompt whoops of derision and no little relief from the home partisans.

Middlesbrough unveiled an eight-foot bronze statue of their former inside forward Wilf Mannion before the game, but their current golden boy Alen Boksic was struggling to make his mark.

Instead, the Croatian watched enviously as another striking elder statesman gave the visitors a deserved lead seven minutes before the break. Solano's high cross was headed down by Gary Speed, climbing high above Festa, and Shearer - granted the freedom of the penalty area - smashed his third goal of the season past a despairing Crossley.

In a stadium endorsed by a mobile phone company, the lack of communication in the home defence was staggering. Boro, notably, are still awaiting their first clean sheet of the season. A half-time reshuffle had negligible effect as Newcastle continued to waltz through Boro's gaping rearguard. First Speed danced into space, then Shearer was allowed to advance unchallenged only to see his drive touched wide at Crossley's near post.

Their luck did not hold. Cordone, given a second chance to cross, spun a wicked centre into the Boro area and Goma, springing from the melee, planted a stunning header into the far corner, his first goal for Newcastle. Chants of "Bryan Robson on the dole" from the visiting fans were echoed angrily among the home support.

The Teessiders were in complete disarray and their shooting grew increasingly desperate. Dean Gordon smashed into the upper tier, while even Boksic proved wasteful, volleying over at the far post after a rare mistake from Given.

But such incision was rare as Boro wallowed in their inadequacies. The former Real Madrid midfielder Christian Karembeu, who Bobby Robson once tried to sign for Barcelona, was eclipsed by Dyer's livewire running and retreated into defence. His supermodel girlfriend, watching from the stands, must have been longing for sun-drenched afternoons at the Bernebeu.

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to editor@footballunlimited.co.uk

webTitle: Ridsdale's lingering fears as Leeds revisit Turkey

fields.headline: Ridsdale's lingering fears as Leeds revisit Turkey
fields.standfirst: Club chairman is still haunted by Istanbul deaths, reports  Daniel Taylor
fields.trailText: Leeds chairman Peter Ridsdale talks to Daniel Taylor about the sense of foreboding hanging over the club's return to Istanbul and tells how he is still haunted by the deaths of two supporters in the city.
fields.body:
Every time Peter Ridsdale's mobile phone rings over the next couple of days, the Leeds United chairman will, he confesses, be consumed by a nauseating sense of foreboding. His heart will skip a beat and a knot will tighten in the pit of his stomach. For tomorrow night his team return to Istanbul for the first time since the tragic events of last April.

Six months ago on a muggy night in Istanbul the Leeds chairman was dining beside the Bosphorus, a guest of Galatasaray's directors, when he was interrupted by a phone call. The message left him cold to the bone.

Later that night Ridsdale was there when the bodies of Christopher Loftus and Kevin Speight were formally identified. When he finally left Taksim hospital, he had to pass through bloodstains in the corridors. The memories, grotesque and vivid, will live with him forever.

This morning, as the Leeds squad, management and directors leave for Istanbul once again, this time to face Besiktas in the Champions League Group H, it will be a return that has come sooner than they dared even anticipate. For Ridsdale it will be a gruelling 48 hours. Much as he would like to conceal his anxiety, it is an impossible task.

"It is the one game in my life where I am considering all aspects, the safety, the security, everything," he says. "How will the supporters react? Will we be safe getting there? Will we get through the game? I have never felt like this about a football match before.

"What will happen I don't know. I just hope we can get through and that by the end of the week we're asking ourselves: 'Why did we have any sort of fear?'

"But the memories are very fresh and nothing will ever, ever repair the damage that was done in April. As far as the two families are concerned, there is nothing that can ever change. What happened has damaged their lives forever.

"You can't erase it from your memory and pretend it's like going to Barcelona or Milan. I would be a liar if I said it was a normal game. I just sincerely hope that, when we come to Thursday morning, any misgivings I have now will have been misplaced."

For all the lingering fears, Ridsdale has found the dialogue with Besiktas "encouraging". This, he says, is the chance for a new beginning.

"Football desperately needs to demonstrate that it can take place safely. We all know 99.9 per cent of games are safe, secure and entertaining but the incidents last April set everything back. Wednesday is a chance to correct that."

Paradoxically, Ridsdale says they are treating it like "any other game in Europe". Leeds will not employ their own bodyguards out of concern that it could be seen as provocative. But when has a normal game required 20 police officers for every away fan?

What passes for the norm in Turkey has long been unacceptable elsewhere, anyway. Galatasaray's supporters have a squalid reputation and the atmosphere when Leeds arrived at the Ali Sami Yen Stadium for their ill-starred Uefa Cup semi-final was bordering on the poisonous. Everyone has seen the pictures of Turks running their thumbs under their throats to mock the two fatal stabbings. What went largely unreported was the dart that was thrown into Nigel Martyn's goalmouth.

Besiktas, too, have their lunatic fringe and Ridsdale's fears will not have been eased by the news that a Turkish youth was stabbed before a recent league game at the 45,000-capacity Inonu stadium.

Leeds are still waiting for an apology from Galatasaray but Ridsdale insists he is not bitter. "To be frank I don't blame them. If something had happened on the day of a game at Leeds we would not wish to be accountable for the actions of individuals we didn't know. So I have no blame, no concern about Galatasaray. I may have done things differently but different cultures do things differently.

"My concern is how to handle the families of Christopher and Kevin. I hope we dealt with that in the most appropriate way. We are still in constant contact with them and this is a game that will hopefully build for the future, without being disrespectful to the past."

 Manchester United could be without Andy Cole when they face PSV Eindhoven tomorrow in the Group G Champions League game at Old Trafford. The England striker did not train yesterday but United's other doubts, David Beckham and Gary Neville, have been declared fit.

fields.headline: Advocaat pays Klos attention with Hagi in mind
fields.trailText: Six points adrift in the Scottish Premier League, Rangers could have done without the loss of Giovanni van Bronckhorst for tonight's match as they attempt to keep their European adventure on track.
fields.body:
Dick Advocaat, the Rangers manager, is hoping that an inspiring mix of bruised limbs and bruised pride might propel his team closer to the second phase by seeing off the Turkish champions Galatasaray at Ibrox this evening.

Yesterday, though, Advocaat could scarcely have heard worse news when learning that he must do without Giovanni van Bronckhorst, whose groin strain still has not cleared. The Dutch midfielder has been one of nine Rangers players out of action recently.

Advocaat and his men felt an uncommon sensation at the weekend when Hibernian dealt the champions a 1-0 defeat that left them third in the league, four points behind Hibs and six adrift of Celtic. Tonight they hope the old adage is correct about domestic toils foretelling greater European success.

On Saturday Advocaat was also without Stefan Klos, Arthur Numan, Michael Mols, Ronald de Boer and Fernando Ricksen. Klos will return this evening but with an ankle injury that will still require careful protection. "He certainly won't be able to take goalkicks," said Advocaat, giving an impression of an all-hands-on-deck scenario.

Galatasaray will provide intriguing opposition. There was bad blood two weeks ago between Advocaat and the Turks' Romanian coach, Mircea Lucescu, who slagged each other in a feud that resembled a playground dispute over bubble-gum. Lucescu got the better of Advocaat in Istanbul and tonight, the Turks will also have their fiery talisman back.

Glasgow is preparing to bid farewell to Gheorghe Hagi, who at 36 might be appearing in these islands for the last time. Advocaat has no doubt about his talent. "He is a major influence on them and is not the sort of player we can mark. You can see very clearly the influence he has, wherever he chooses to play," he said.

Victory would give Rangers 10 points from four games and a very realistic chance of reaching the latter stages.

Rangers (probable, 3-5-2): Klos; Porrini, Vidmar, Konterman; Reyna, Ferguson, Tugay, Albertz, McCann; de Boer, Dodds.

Galatasaray (probable, 4-5-1): Taffarel; Fatih, Popescu, K Bulent, Hakan; Umit, A Bulent, Ergun, Hasan, Emre; Jardel.

Referee: M Merk (Germany)

fields.headline: Italians hatch a papal plot
fields.trailText: Arsène Wenger hopes a counter-attacking style tonight will deliver the three points needed to secure Arsenal's passage into the second round, despite Lazio's attempt to gain some papal inspiration.
fields.body:
As if Arsenal do not have enough to deal with on the pitch, they can also expect opposition tonight from above. At the weekend a Lazio delegation, including the coach Sven Goran Eriksson and four players, presented the Pope with a club shirt. Its number 80 referred to the pontiff's age rather than the goals they would like.

There is still time for Arsenal to redress the balance, given that the Queen is here on a state visit, but the word is that instead the Arsenal manager will put his faith in the more traditional virtues of tireless running, physical battling and sharp finishing which brought a 2-0 win over the Champions League favourites at Highbury three weeks ago.

That victory suggested attack is the best form of defence against Lazio, and another three points this evening would take Arsenal into the second round. Arsène Wenger's tactics will be more cat and mouse than catenaccio.

"If Lazio have a weak point it would probably be defensively," he said. "It would be a mistake to adopt an entirely defensive strategy. That would be almost suicidal because Lazio have so many top players who can score goals and we must try to catch them out with our breaks."

Certainly this city seems to have as many world-class strikers as historic monuments. Gabriel Batistuta, Francesco Totti and Marco Delvecchio need not worry Arsenal since they play for Roma. But Hernan Crespo, Marcelo Salas and Simone Inzaghi are eager for revenge.

The world-record £54m strike force of Lopez and Crespo was unleashed for the first time on Saturday against Perugia, though the indications last night were that Crespo had suffered a recurrence of his thigh injury and that Inzaghi would start alongside Salas.

Wenger knows Lazio will be sharper than they were at Highbury now Serie A is under way; he would be delighted with a draw. That would send his team through from Group B if Shakhtar Donetsk win at home to Sparta Prague.

Tony Adams is a minor doubt with a back strain and Dennis Bergkamp, who set up both Freddie Ljungberg's goals at Highbury, has not made the trip because of his fear of flying.

In his absence Wenger is likely to revert to a rigid 4-4-2 formation, calling on his midfielders to get forward when the chance allows. "We do not have enough people in the box when the ball is out wide," he said. "It's something we are trying to rectify."

An intriguing sub-plot is the battle between Eriksson and Wenger: neither has ruled out taking the England job when their contracts expire in June 2001 and the following summer respectively.

Arsenal's vice-chairman David Dein, part of the advisory panel for the new appointment, said he would "drop out of the discussion" if Wenger's name cropped up, but added: "I have no doubts Arsène will complete his remaining two years."

Arsenal (probable): Seaman; Luzhny, Keown, Adams, Silvinho; Ljungberg, Grimandi, Vieira, Pires; Henry, Kanu.

Lazio (probable): Peruzzi; Negro, Nesta, Mihajlovic, Pancaro; Stankovic, Simeone, Veron, Nedved; Salas, Inzaghi.

Referee : Hellmut Krug (Germany)
1 Lazio kick-off on a rain-soaked night in Rome's Olympic Stadium.
2 Nedved creates some space for himself. His looping shot richets out for a corner. Lucic, who tonight becomes the oldest player to appear in the Champions League, does well to block the subsequent cross.
4 Grimandi and then Luzhney out-grapple fiesty attacking runs from Inzaghi and Salas.
6 Ljunburg pokes the ball down the left flank. But before he can cause any mither, the bald Swede is body-checked by Nesta. Free-kick.
7 Grimandi loses his marker at the near post to dispatch a firm header just wide of the mark.
8 Arsenal enjoy their first spell of possession. The ball is knocked into the galloping Grimandi who directs a well-struck drive straight into the keeper's arms.
11 Henry shimmies and skins Nesta, who then drags him back to concede a foul. The resulting free-kick is wasted.
12 A moment of hesitation between Keown and Luzhney allows Nedved to put the willies up Lucic. However, his cross/shot across the goal fails to be met by any of his teammates.
15 The match livens up after early jousting. Viera and Veron vie for midfield supremecy.
18 Much to annoyance of Lazio's notoriously demanding home support, Arsenal begin to boss the tempo of the game. But with one deft touch, Veron demonstrates his capacity to change a game in an instant.
21 Arsenal continue piling on the pressure with Kanu getting his groove on, Henry cruising into wide spaces and Silvinho threatening to run in on goal from the left wing.
24 GOAL! Fluke. Salas and Inzaghi bobble the ball to each other unconvincingly outside the Arsenal penalty area. A misdirected pass to Nedved invites a challenge from Silvinho. Somehow the ball balloons up and over the stranded Lucic. A red-faced Nedved claims the goal, but his was not the decisive touch.
29 Kanu seems determined to break his duck. He might be trying a bit too hard.
34 Good spell of pressure from Arsenal. Both teams invest much effort in getting an early cross into the box. Yet both teams are getting defenders back in numbers.
35 Off on one of his trademark teasing runs down the left, Silvinho cuts inside and swerves past two Lazio defenders. The young Brazillian finds himself one-on-one with the goalkeeper. But his delicate chip is smoothered by the flailing limbs of Peruzzi.
39 Parlour skips into space, deep inside the Lazio half. But 'ginger locks' fires into deep space.
41Lazio are awarded a free-kick on the right side of the penalty area. Lucic does very well to bat away Mihajlovic's unholy curler .
43 BOOKING. Big Ron says: "Freddie must be fuming!" Attempting to see out a stray forward pass, Nesta uses his body to shield the attentions of Ljungberg . But, fearing he may lose the ball to the determined Swede, the Italian resorts to sly fakery - voluntarily falling over and winning a free-kick. Ljungberg earns a caution for protesting his innocence. Half-time.
46 SUBSTITUTION. Claudio Lopez on for Dejan Stankovic.
46 Inzaghi finds himself in acres. But his clips the ball well-wide to the relief of the ageing stand-in goaly.
48 Nedved and Ljungberg almost tear off each others clothes as they battle for the ball. The Lazio hero wins a corner. Lucic does well to get a fist to the inswinging cross.
50 The game opens up with chances at either end. Yet as Arsenal chase the equaliser and throw men forward they looking increasingly susceptible to the premier poaching abilities of Lopez, Salas, Inzaghi et all.
53 The arrival of Lopez gives Lazio much better delivery from the left.
54 FIGHT! The match descends into a ugly brawl. Simeone looks mighty irrate as blood spurts from a gash by his eye. The slow motion replay reveals that Grimandi planted a right hook into the Argentinean's mush. After much pushing and shoving, Nesta finally gets a yellow card that has been a long time coming.
56 Simeone, who went off to bandage up his wound, returns to the field in a vengeful state of consciousness. Grimandi better watch his back. Maybe his bravery has been bouyed by the presence of big John in goal.
58 Arsenal's players seemed to have been unnerved by Simeone's aggresive antics.
63 The game returns to the open attacking pattern it assumed early in the second half.
65 Big Ron asks : "This Veron is supposed to be one of the best players in the world... where is he?" Indeed.
68 SUSTITUTION. Crespo- the world's second most expensive striker- comes on for Inzaghi.
69 SUBSTITUTION. Lauren on for Grimandi ; cock of the Gunners chickens out.
70 Lazio win a series of corners. Up steps the hit-and-miss Mihajlovic. His first corner swings in, bang on target. A spooked Arsenal defence scrambles the ball away. His second almost hits the opposite corner flag.
71 Lazio get the ball into the net after a neat exchange of passes between Crespo and Salas. But the ref rightly calls it offside.
74 SUBSTITUTION. Wiltord on for Ljungberg
76 Lauren makes his first meaningful contribution to Arsenal's campaign with a meaningless cross.
78 Big Ron declares : "The game is calling for a little bit of devil from an Arsenal man." Nobody does it better than that jeweled man with the fake tan.
80 That Luzhney has looked impressively nimble, covering for the tiring Tony Adams.
82 Kanu finds himself with the goal at his mercy. His shot is blocked. The big Nigerian recovers the ball but flicks it into his own face before being tackled. At times he personifies grace. At times, he displays Wanchope-esque clumsiness
87 GOAL! Wiltord gets hold of the ball after Arsenal defend a corner. The Frenchman does extremely well to spot the break-neck run of Pires down the right wing and make space for himself to deliver an inch-perfect pass to his compatriot. Pires collects the ball in his stride, balances himself and unleashes a storming right-footed scoop into the top corner.
90 A last minute fright for Arsenal. Somehow Keown conspires to fumble the ball into his own goal. But luckily, the ref spots an earlier infringement and disallows the goal.
93 Full-time.
94Grimandi and Nesta exchange a bit of afters.
95 The Arsenal players applaud their supporters following a well-earned away draw.
