fields.headline: England given olive-branch reception
fields.standfirst: Hussain finds spirit of harmony after MacLaurin hits the wrong note
fields.trailText: It was all smiles and diplomacy as England arrived in Pakistan for their first Test tour of Pakistan in 13 years - despite Lord McLaurin's best efforts to the contrary. Paul Weaver reports from Karachi.
fields.body:
Despite the waving of many olive branches here yesterday there was little relief from the fierce sun for the England squad when they arrived in 31-degree heat for their first Test tour of Pakistan in 13 years.

Nasser Hussain, the England captain, was all smiles and diplomacy. Moin Khan, his opposite number, made a sincere little speech of welcome.

They exchanged cricket bats as a goodwill gesture. Moin gave Nasser one made of solid brass, so heavy it was hard to lift off the ground but it gleamed magnificently. Hussain, a little sheepishly, gave Moina Duncan Fearnley willow.

No one mentioned the war. Well, Nasser did, briefly, but only to say that he was just a schoolboy back in 1987 and did not know what was going on. The infamous umpiring was not mentioned.

Unfortunately this came only hours after England's leading official, Lord MacLaurin, apparently hit a raw nerve. The chairman of the England and Wales Cricket Board is unwilling to play his part in this bridge-building exercise; in fact he seems to view such bridges in the same way that Alec Guinness viewed the Bridge over the River Kwai.

At the weekend MacLaurin called for the International Cricket Council to ban Wasim Akram, and other Pakistan players mentioned in the Qayyum Report on match-fixing, from the coming Tests against England.

This evidently angered Moin. "The player concerned will play in this series," he said. "What has been said will inspire them. It will give Wasim an extra incentive to perform."

The Qayyum Report was published five months ago and resulted in life bans for Salim Malik and Ata-ur-Rehman. But others got off lightly.

The ICC has said it will consider further punishments but not until after the three-Test series against England ends on December 11. "It's ridiculous," said MacLaurin. "If someone is under suspicion he should be removed from the game until his case is heard and his innocence proven."

Wasim might argue that he has been punished enough. His reputation has been stained, he has lost the captaincy of Pakistan and also been ordered to pay a fine of £3,750, though he has not yet done so.

Four other Pakistan players were fined after the Qayyum Report and of these Saeed Anwar, Waqar Younis and Inzamam-ul-Haq are all likely to feature in the coming series. Recently Wasim and Saeed have been in outstanding form.

England's campaign effectively to cull the Pakistan team has echoes of the attempt, during Mike Brearley's 1977-78 tour here, to banish the host country's Kerry Packer players. Hussain's virgin soldiers, none of whom has played a Test in Pakistan, need every bit of help they can find: England have won only one Test match in this country in more than 40 years.

Today they are likely to have their first encounter with the grassless pitches and energy-sapping conditions in a practice session, prior to Friday's "warm-up" against a President's XI here in the National stadium.

The tour party will stay in Sind for a week before moving on to Lahore and Rawalpindi for the second and third one-day internationals that precede the first Test, starting on November 15 in Lahore.

"We are very pleased to be here," said Nasser. "It's a great country to tour." In that case, the obvious question was, why have England been away so long? Thankfully, no one asked.

webTitle: Cronje threatens to sue over ban

fields.headline: Cronje threatens to sue over ban
fields.trailText: Hansie Cronje has threatened to sue South Africa's United Cricket Board over the life ban from all cricket imposed on him for taking payments from bookmakers.
fields.body:
Hansie Cronje, the disgraced former South Africa captain, has threatened to sue the country's United Cricket Board following his life ban from all cricket for taking payments from bookmakers.

His lawyers have given the UCB until today to withdraw the ban or face legal action. Leslie Sackstein, one of Cronje's lawyers, said: "We believe that the resolution was unlawfully taken and our letter also invites the UCB to inform the International Cricket Council of our view."

He declined to say on what basis the resolution was viewed to be unlawful, claiming this was privileged information.

Cronje has admitted to receiving thousands of dollars from gamblers and bookmakers on five separate occasions between 1996 and 2000. He also confessed to offering team-mates money in exchange for underperforming in Test matches.

The allegations against Cronje originally surfaced in India, where the federal Central Bureau of Investigation charged him and three team-mates with "cheating, fraud and conspiracy" during a one-day series in India in March.

The CBI's investigation has continued and the country's sports minister, Sukhdev Singh Dhindsa, yesterday announced that an interim report is to go before Parliament next month, at the start of the winter session. He refused to be drawn on whether any more high-profile cricketers are to be named in the report. "I do not know anything about it as yet," he said.

The International Cricket Council will be publishing its own interim report on match-fixing in April or May next year. The report is being compiled by its newly formed anti-corruption unit, under the former metropolitan police commissioner Sir Paul Condon.

Speaking at the ongoing ICC executive meeting in Nairobi, Condon said: "My terms of reference are by April next year: I put in an interim report about my impressions of what has happened, or I think might still be happening, and what needs to be done about it. Around May, April next year there can be some interesting decisions on cricket for ICC to take."

webTitle: Help squads ready for NHS trouble spots

fields.headline: Help squads ready for NHS trouble spots
fields.standfirst: Ministers' winter warbook audits health and social services' readiness  for seasonal pressures
fields.trailText: Health ministers have taken delivery of a "winter warbook" identifying trouble spots in the NHS that could flare into crises in the wards after Christmas unless early action is taken to reorganise the service.
fields.byline: John Carvel, social affairs editor, The Guardian
fields.body:
Health ministers yesterday took delivery of a "winter warbook" identifying trouble spots in the NHS that could flare into crises in the wards after Christmas unless early action is taken to reorganise the service.

Officials said Alan Milburn, the health secretary, was preparing to send in help squads to tackle the most serious problems that could be exploited by the Conservatives to damage the credibility of his NHS reform plan in the run-up to the general election.

His confidential dossier on the strengths and weaknesses of every part of the NHS, private hospitals, nursing homes and social services was put together over the weekend from reports sent in by the 99 health authorities in England.

The volume was said to be "at least six inches thick, with more pages than a telephone directory." Each authority has completed a vulnerability audit of every public and private service in its area to assess whether they are at high, medium or low risk of a winter emergency.

Health authority managers will be expected to provide regular updates of their planning for winter, including estimates of how close they are to targets for trolley waits and flu vaccinations.

"This is the biggest planning exercise for winter that the NHS has ever seen," a Department of Health source said. "We are making sure we are forewarned about the likely hotspots and able to send in teams in advance to minimise the problems."

The dossier was being called a warbook because ministers thought the Tories and some sections of the media would use winter pressures to declare war on the NHS, he said.

Earlier this year Mr Milburn allocated £60m for social services to provide alternative provision for older people who might otherwise stay too long in hospital. He set aside £630m for the NHS to deal with winter pressures, including £150m for critical care facilities.

As a result there will be more than 250 extra critical care beds this winter. For the first time for many years, there will be more general and acute beds, although the spread across England is patchy.

Preliminary health department figures indicate there are 30,000 more people working for the NHS than two years ago, including 10,000 more nurses and 2,800 more therapists. But ministers are not try ing to deny the danger that the service will continue to have capacity problems pending implementation of the NHS plan over the next five years.

In a presentation to the "winter planning group" of health ministers, Mr Milburn said: "There will be problems in some parts of the NHS this winter. It would be foolish to pretend otherwise. fields.headline: Analysis
fields.standfirst: After the third serious rail accident in three years, transport editor Keith Harper asks who is to blame
fields.trailText: After the third serious rail accident in three years, transport editor Keith Harper asks who is to blame.
fields.body:
Stevenage could not have come at a worse time for Britain's rail industry. After Southall and Paddington this is the third serious accident in just over three years, and public confidence in the industry is shattered.

Stevenage has come at a point when the industry at last appeared to be embarking on a recovery. The government is to invest over £30bn in the industry over the next five years, and passenger numbers, which have risen by 30 per cent since privatisation four years ago, are forecast to rise by a further 50 per cent over the next 10 years.

But fragmentation has led to poor control. Railtrack, which operates both track and signalling, has been a law unto itself, a private monopoly which bristles at regulation; the Shadow Strategic Rail Authority (SSRA), a hybrid son of British Rail, has no strategy; the 25 rail companies are either dominantly healthy or about to call it a day.

Southall and Paddington both highlighted dramatically the gross deficiencies in the railway. At Southall, not only did a driver pass through a red signal, but the safety devices on his train which could have prevented the accident were not working.

Paddington exposed even more critically the limitations of the privatised railway. An ill trained driver passed through a red signal and was unfamiliar with the key section of line outside one of Britain's biggest main line stations. The track outside Paddington had been re-modelled to incorporate the new Heathrow Express train, and Railtrack and the industry did nothing to deal with expressions of concern about signal siting at Paddington and the number of signals passed at red. In other words, the new loosely knit industry messed up.

The crashes at both Paddington and Southall have exposed the lack of investment in safety in the industry. Instead of installing the expensive but superior system recommended 11 years ago after the Clapham rail crash, the industry and the government are still tinkering with a cheaper, less reliable alternative. It costs around £400m to install and it will be another three years before it is adopted on wide sections of the railway. Relatives of those killed at Paddington have called for the adoption of automatic train protection (ATP), at a cost of between £1-2 bn. It is widely used in Europe, but the British are waiting for a more sophisticated model.

Another important aspect of recent rail disasters is the inordinate time it takes to discover the cause of the diaster and then to aportion blame. It took two years before the final chapter was written on Southall, and while the process has been speeded up at Paddington, it will take at least 18 months before Lord Cullen's inquiry has fully reported.

The role of the railway inspectorate has also been exposed. Pitifully undermanned, the inspectorate has belatedly been told by the government that it can double its numbers from 70 to 140 between now and 2002. But this action has been forced on ministers after the inspectors were exposed for not being able to carry out their job in the lead-up to Paddington.

When it comes, Lord Cullen's report is bound to draw attention to the failure by the inspectorate to deal more decisively with the growing incidence of signals passed at red. Warnings were issued to Railtrack by the inspectorate but they came too late to avoid Paddington.

Another common thread running through the sorry history of Southall, Paddington and now Stevenage, is under-investment. Parts of the railway are still worse than before privatisation, and Guardian reports over the past three years have constantly underlined how railway staff have been struggling to maintain an inadequately funded industry.

The government must also take its share of the blame. After Paddington, the deputy prime minister John Prescott declared that money would be no object in ensuring the safety of the railway.

What the government should have said when it took office was that it could not transform the industry overnight. Ministers misled the public into thinking that it was about to undo the evils of privatisation. But having set its face against re-nationalisation, it was in a powerless position. The rail companies have been given watertight franchises for between 7 and 15 years which cannot easily be undone, as well as continuing subsidies, allowing the better off among them to make good profits.

Second best safety equipment, ageing rolling stock and a poorly maintained track expose the frailities of the system as a rising number of passengers use it.

The government would dearly like a short term fix on the railway, but Sir Alastair Morton, chairman of the SSRA, says that he cannot throw money at it and expect overnight miracles. Mr Prescott would like to have seen tangible improvements on the railway before the next election, but he will not get them.

The sad fact is that in spite of new large scale investment, it will take some years before passengers see a marked improvement in performance. The railway is going to get worse before it gets better, as official statistics from the SSRA confirm.

The investment on such projects like the west coast main line is ring fenced, but passengers will have to wait until 2002 to see any benefit in new trains. The lesson of Paddington, Southall and Stevenage yesterday for the government is that it cannot delay much longer before taking a more interventionist approach. It is, after all, handing out taxpayer's money.

fields.headline: Nurses launch winter hotline
fields.standfirst: RCN will work with nurses and ministers to ease staff shortages
fields.trailText: The Royal College of Nursing has launched a hotline for nurses, which it is hoped will prevent staff shortages in NHS hospitals.
fields.body:
The Royal College of Nursing yesterday launched a hotline for nurses, which it is hoped will prevent staff shortages in NHS hospitals.

Christine Hancock, the general secretary, said most health authorities had not yet put into place flexible shifts and self-rostering schemes to allow staff to adjust work to fit family life.

Through the scheme, RCN officials will work with nurses in areas of extreme pressure. If they find local NHS managers obstructive, they will tip off ministers who can be expected to read the riot act to prevent shortages over the winter.

Ms Hancock said: "Last winter was a tough time for the NHS. We got through it, but patients didn't get services they expected and many staff were pushed to breaking point. We hope this campaign will help frontline nurses know that it does not have to be bad. By giving examples of successful schemes, we can let staff know how other places have made it different."

She said recruitment and money from the government was having a big impact on nursing shortages but it would take time for the results to be seen.

"I think the number of applicants in nurse training has gone up faster than any academic discipline other than computer studies. It takes three years to produce a qualified nurse, and five of six years to produce an experienced nurse. I think the big challenge is not recruitment but retention."

The RCN said the most common problems were rigid shift systems, lack of coordination between health and social care services, and poor communication between managers and staff. The NHS was "a 24-hour health system attempting to work in a nine-to-five environment".

The college yesterday published a resource pack of solutions. It was presented by nursing staff at University hospital in Lewisham, south London, who have pioneered flexible working.

webTitle: Majority regard cannabis as no worse than drink

fields.headline: Majority regard cannabis as no worse than drink
fields.trailText: A clear majority of British voters believe that using cannabis is no worse than smoking or drinking, according to the latest Guardian/ICM opinion poll.
fields.body:
A clear majority of British voters believe that using cannabis is no worse than smoking or drinking, according to the latest Guardian/ICM opinion poll.

The survey also shows that the overwhelming majority also believe that smoking dope should not remain a criminal act in Britain. Some 43% even go so far as saying that its personal use should be legalised completely - a far higher proportion than previously recorded on Guardian/ICM opinion polls.

The findings confirm the view that a change has taken place in British public opinion about the future legal status of cannabis and that Ann Widdecombe was out of tune when she proposed replacing a policy of police cautions with a mandatory £100 fixed penalty fine. Only one in five voters believes that possession of cannabis should remain a criminal offence.

Opinion is most pro-cannabis among the 25 to 34 age group, some 50% of whom believe its personal use should be legalised. Two-thirds of this age group believe that smoking cannabis is no worse than smoking tobacco or drinking alcohol. This is higher than even the 65% of 18-24 year olds who subscribe to the same view. Indeed, the only age group to disagree with this proposition is the over 65s some 49% of whom were against. Even among these "grey voters" one in three agrees that cannabis is no worse than alcohol or tobacco.

Despite the fact that politicians in recent days have contrasted the experience of middle class youngsters at university with what goes on in "the real world" of inner city council estates, there is little difference in view across social class about cannabis law reform. Some 45% of DE voters - the unskilled and unemployed - think it should be legalised as do 44% of AB voters - the professional classes.

The poll does however show a clear divide between those who want to see the decriminalisation of cannabis but are not yet prepared to see it fully legalised. While 22% said they believed the personal use of cannabis should remain a criminal act, some 30% said the police should not make prosecution a priority and it should effectively be decriminalised. The issue has polarised opinion with only 4% of voters saying they had no opinion on the matter.

The findings of this poll, combined with weekend surveys also showing large majorities for decriminalisation, will put Tony Blair and Jack Straw under further pressure to reassess the government's policy on drugs.

The next opportunity will come when Home Office ministers give evidence to the Commons home affairs select committee on why they dismissed within hours of publication the Police Foundation report on cannabis published in March. The report, which included two chief constables among its membership, recommended that prison should no longer be used for cannabis possession.

Some 4,500 people were imprisoned last year after being convicted of cannabis charges.

webTitle: Plum job for Welsh Lib Dems

fields.headline: Plum job for Welsh Lib Dems
fields.standfirst: Special report: devolution in Wales
fields.trailText: October 17 2000: The Liberal Democrats were yesterday handed the prized economic development brief in a restructured Welsh cabinet, as the Labour leader, Rhodri Morgan, brought three new faces into the heart of government in Wales.
fields.body:
The Liberal Democrats were yesterday handed the prized economic development brief in a restructured Welsh cabinet, as the Labour leader, Rhodri Morgan, brought three new faces into the heart of government in Wales.

Despite disquiet among Labour activists about the terms of the three-year coalition deal, the Liberal Democrat leader in the national assembly, Mike German, has been confirmed as deputy first minister and will assume Mr Morgan's previous responsibility for all aspects of economic development in Wales.

The second cabinet post promised to the Liberal Democrats in the partnership agreement has gone to Jenny Randerson, who takes on the culture and sports portfolio.

Mr Morgan, who lost one cabinet member in protest at the pact, yesterday axed two more - the local government secretary, Peter Law, and the pre-16 education secretary, Rosemary Butler - to help make way for the changes.

His decision to appoint the former deputy presiding officer, Jane Davidson, as minister for education means the nine-strong cabinet will again include a majority of women.

Mr Law yesterday said he viewed his dismissal as a necessary evil.

fields.headline: Paxman sent stolen Enigma code-breaking machine in the post
fields.trailText: Newsnight presenter Jeremy Paxman has received in the post a machine believed to be the wartime Enigma code-breaking machine stolen earlier this year, writes Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
Newsnight presenter Jeremy Paxman has received in the post a machine believed to be the wartime Enigma code-breaking machine stolen earlier this year.

Mr Paxman confirmed that the machine, which was taken in April from the wartime code-breakers' HQ at Bletchley Park, had been sent to him at the BBC's Newsnight offices.

"It looks like the original, it's got the G312 code on it," he said. "But we're waiting to hear from the cops whether it's the real thing."

Mr Paxman added that he did not know why the machine had been sent to him. He is known to be a good friend of author Robert Harris, who wrote a book about the British code-breakers who used the machine to break Nazi codes during the second world war.

fields.headline: How to keep faith
fields.standfirst: Stephen Hoare reports that ICT is becoming part of the old-fashioned struggle between good and evil
fields.trailText: Stephen Hoare reports that ICT is becoming part of the old-fashioned struggle between good and evil
fields.body:
Buffy the Vampire Slayer has a lot to answer for, judging from the classroom discussions recounted by RE teachers! The cult TV series deals with spirituality at a superficial level that appeals to children and young adults. But clued-up RE teachers are using ICT to fight back by encouraging young people to find answers to the big questions in life that religious education poses.

The national curriculum embraces the six main religions - Christianity, Judaism, Islam, Buddhism, Sikhism and Hinduism - and syllabuses are agreed at local education authority level. Thanks to the wealth of information on CD-Rom and the internet, factual content is less of an issue and teachers can concentrate instead on asking those big moral questions like: Why am I here? Why is the world full of suffering? What is sacrifice?

Teachers are also moving the debate online. Materials like RM's interactive classroom software Discourse, for example, enables the teacher to manage a virtual discussion from a computer console, saving pupils the embarrassment of sharing deeply held personal beliefs with the rest of the class.

Ray Fleming, secondary schools manager at RM, says: "It gives RE teachers a completely different interaction with the class. The teacher can pick up on the most thought-provoking responses rather than being influenced by a few individuals."

The internet is a great asset for teachers looking for information on the different faiths and for pupils researching projects. With such a plethora of source material, the key is to get children to detect cant masquerading as gospel truth.

Paul Hopkins, lecturer in education at the Open University and author of the RE Revision Site (www.paulhopkins.org.uk/re) says: "Information handling and interpretation skills are becoming very important. We are asking children to become critical readers and not to believe everything they read on the internet. I came across a site which said the Holocaust never happened. It was cleverly written and looked plausible. But it was malicious, nasty rubbish."

Surf with care! Just as good attracts its opposite, so evil can lurk in the most unlikely places. Rosemary Rivett, an RE teacher from Worcestershire, says: "If you look up Christianity on Yahoo, you're two clicks away from a Satanism page. There's no doubt that evil - the forbidden - will always have an attraction for some people. Teachers have to be very vigilant."

It is just as well that RE has some of the best-managed educational websites in the curriculum. The two key gateway sites are RE-XS managed by the University College of St Martins, Lancaster (re-xs.ucsm.ac.uk) and the Culham College religious website, the RE Site (resite.org.uk). Both have extensive links to sites giving information on the six main religions. The virtual teachers' centre has also joined the ranks of the enlightened. It has a new section devoted to the RE syllabus which includes information on the use of ICT in RE, including a new six-page guide from Becta (www.vtc.ngfl.gov.uk/re).

New Opportunities Fund training will bring all subject teachers up to speed, but many RE teachers have been ahead of the game for some time, helped by the dedicated efforts of REfIT (RE from IT), a network of technically clued-up teachers keen to proselytise on the use of ICT to support their subject area. Under the umbrella of the Professional Council for Religious Education's RE Futures Project, RefIT has been running for the past five years. REfIT director Jeremy Taylor says: "We've been acting as a catalyst for training. We are a virtual community that teachers can tap into for help, advice and best practice."

ICT also has a major role to play in freeing the RE teacher from the burden of admin with assessment software and automatic report writing. Teaching a statutory subject that may be timetabled for an hour a week and working alone or in a department of just two people, the RE teacher is likely to write three times as many reports as their colleagues teaching maths or English. Paul Hopkins says: "There are some sophisticated assessment database software packages around. An RE teacher can process a year's reports in an evening - and they won't just be full of bland statements."

But it is at key stage four that ICT has had its biggest impact. Whether it is due to the popularity of Buffy the Vampire Slayer or not, RE has apparently never been more popular or more accessible. Jeremy Taylor says: "RE was languishing until RefIT came on the scene and we explained how the subject could be accredited. Now the short course GCSE is the fastest-growing subject - up from 20% takeup to nearly 50% in three years."

RE 1: Building religious bridges

John Pering is the ICT coordinator at Ellacombe Primary, which has 360 pupils, and an advisory teacher in Torquay

Torquay is a great place to live but it's not the ideal location if you're trying to teach a class of primary children about faiths other than Christianity - the local culture is Anglocentric! We are setting up an internet link with a group of London schools where there are children from different faith backgrounds. It's very important for them to learn that they're part of a wider multi-faith world.

With only one or two computers in each classroom, ensuring all children get access to ICT for RE is quite an issue, especially as it's timetabled for just three-quarters of an hour to an hour a week.

As a tool, ICT allows pupils to present work neatly; this is especially useful for children with special needs who can use spellcheckers and RE word banks. The internet and CD-Roms provide access to a much wider range of information. Websites such as theresite.org.uk run by Culham College and RE-XS are very good starting points because they have links through to other sites.

Most importantly, ICT enables pupils to communicate. When our link is set up, pupils will be able to use it to extend their understanding of other faiths - particularly Hinduism and Judaism as required by our syllabus at key stage two. They'll be able to email other pupils about their thoughts, beliefs and practices.

RE 2: What you can do on an intranet

Rosemary Rivett is head of RE at South Bromsgrove High School Technology College, Worcestershire, serving 1,200 pupils aged 13-18

There's an old saying that life begins at 40 and that's when I discovered computers! I was overwhelmed with the volume of RE resources I found on the internet so I thought I'd build an RE website to operate on the school's intranet. My website is now 67 megabytes and gives the pupils the chance to access internally produced curriculum materials as well as carefully selected internet sites. The school filter ensures security, and all lessons are carefully planned to meet RE attainment targets.

ICT is a tool which can stimulate and motivate pupils of all abilities. It can motivate boys who are reluctant to read books, and help pupils learn key concepts and ideas for their exams. For example, I developed a series of multiple choice religious quizzes which are marked on screen and give immediate feedback and a sense of success. ICT used imaginatively can raise the standard of coursework.

The school has three IT rooms with networked PCs and drop-in areas where pupils can do their homework on computer. For whole class teaching I use PowerPoint presentation - projecting an image from my computer onto a screen or electronic whiteboard. PowerPoint is also an excellent medium for pupils to present work. My favourite RE projects were an email link with a school in Linden, Germany; and a GCSE group communicated directly with pupils of their own age to gain insights into Orthodox Christianity.

I started teaching in this school in 1987 when we didn't even have a computer room. Now we have an internet suite for 30 pupils. When I'm using the internet with a class I use a "cascade" system. I'll demonstrate the search technique to two pupils who will then teach two other groups, and so on.

I've been using ICT now for seven or eight years. Currently I'm working with year nine on an internet-based project comparing Christian confirmation with Bar Mitzvah and its female equivalent, the Bat Mitzvah. We use a variety of sources: Aspects of Religion, an interactive CD-Rom from Granada Learning which has a good video archive and is one of the most popular packages used at secondary level. And I get the class to do an internet search: a lot of young Jewish boys create their own Bar Mitzvah sites.

I also get year nine to give a PowerPoint presentation as part of their project on Martin Luther King or Mother Teresa. It is not just about learning to handle ICT: pupils learn to select words and images. Pupils take pride in producing quality work.

fields.bodyText: Buffy the Vampire Slayer has a lot to answer for, judging from the classroom discussions recounted by RE teachers! The cult TV series deals with spirituality at a superficial level that appeals to children and young adults. But clued-up RE teachers are using ICT to fight back by encouraging young people to find answers to the big questions in life that religious education poses. The national curriculum embraces the six main religions - Christianity, Judaism, Islam, Buddhism, Sikhism and Hinduism - and syllabuses are agreed at local education authority level. Thanks to the wealth of information on CD-Rom and the internet, factual content is less of an issue and teachers can concentrate instead on asking those big moral questions like: Why am I here? Why is the world full of suffering? What is sacrifice? Teachers are also moving the debate online. Materials like RM's interactive classroom software Discourse, for example, enables the teacher to manage a virtual discussion from a computer console, saving pupils the embarrassment of sharing deeply held personal beliefs with the rest of the class. Ray Fleming, secondary schools manager at RM, says: "It gives RE teachers a completely different interaction with the class. The teacher can pick up on the most thought-provoking responses rather than being influenced by a few individuals." The internet is a great asset for teachers looking for information on the different faiths and for pupils researching projects. With such a plethora of source material, the key is to get children to detect cant masquerading as gospel truth. Paul Hopkins, lecturer in education at the Open University and author of the RE Revision Site (www.paulhopkins.org.uk/re) says: "Information handling and interpretation skills are becoming very important. We are asking children to become critical readers and not to believe everything they read on the internet. I came across a site which said the Holocaust never happened. It was cleverly written and looked plausible. But it was malicious, nasty rubbish." Surf with care! Just as good attracts its opposite, so evil can lurk in the most unlikely places. Rosemary Rivett, an RE teacher from Worcestershire, says: "If you look up Christianity on Yahoo, you're two clicks away from a Satanism page. There's no doubt that evil - the forbidden - will always have an attraction for some people. Teachers have to be very vigilant." It is just as well that RE has some of the best-managed educational websites in the curriculum. Both have extensive links to sites giving information on the six main religions. The virtual teachers' centre has also joined the ranks of the enlightened. New Opportunities Fund training will bring all subject teachers up to speed, but many RE teachers have been ahead of the game for some time, helped by the dedicated efforts of REfIT (RE from IT), a network of technically clued-up teachers keen to proselytise on the use of ICT to support their subject area. Under the umbrella of the Professional Council for Religious Education's RE Futures Project, RefIT has been running for the past five years. REfIT director Jeremy Taylor says: "We've been acting as a catalyst for training. We are a virtual community that teachers can tap into for help, advice and best practice." ICT also has a major role to play in freeing the RE teacher from the burden of admin with assessment software and automatic report writing. Teaching a statutory subject that may be timetabled for an hour a week and working alone or in a department of just two people, the RE teacher is likely to write three times as many reports as their colleagues teaching maths or English. Paul Hopkins says: "There are some sophisticated assessment database software packages around. An RE teacher can process a year's reports in an evening - and they won't just be full of bland statements." But it is at key stage four that ICT has had its biggest impact. Whether it is due to the popularity of Buffy the Vampire Slayer or not, RE has apparently never been more popular or more accessible. Jeremy Taylor says: "RE was languishing until RefIT came on the scene and we explained how the subject could be accredited. Now the short course GCSE is the fastest-growing subject - up from 20% takeup to nearly 50% in three years." fields.headline: Religious teaching resources
fields.trailText: We may live in a secular, sex-obsessed society, and the internet may reflect that somewhat tawdry reality, but there's no shortage of religion on the Net.
fields.body:
Websites

We may live in a secular, sex-obsessed society, and the internet may reflect that somewhat tawdry reality, but there's no shortage of religion on the Net. Running a search under the terms religion and religious brings hundreds of thousands of responses - and therein lies the problem for teachers hoping to use the internet as a research tool in their lessons. Where to start?

Another problem is that a few sites are as undesirable as the pornography the school's web server is probably programmed to avoid. Responsible teachers will want to steer children away from cults and from some of what passes for religion on sites devoted to far right-wing politics. An essential bookmark should be for the PCfRE at: www.pcfre.org.uk the subject teacher association for RE professionals in primary and secondary schools and higher education. The association provides a focal point for RE teachers' concerns, a representative voice at national level and publications and courses to promote professional development.

Next on the list should be the NGfL's virtual teachers' centre at: vtc.ngfl.gov.uk where RE teachers will find a range of resources and links. It has been designed by Becta in consultation with a curriculum group for RE. Teachers can discover how ICT enhances RE, read case studies showing how ICT is being used in RE, access lists of resources and participate in online discussions.

The RE NET site is based, appropriately enough, at Christchurch Canterbury College and is a New Opportunities Fund-accredited training provider for ICT and RE. It offers professional development support for RE teachers, along with resources and links.

A valuable research facility is offered at bible.gospelcom.net/ where surfers can search the Bible by keyword or phrase.

World religions are well covered on the net, but the content on most sites requires a high reading age and teachers would need to give a lot of support to children using them for research.

Hinduism Today at www.hinduism-today.com has a wealth of content and is worth a visit, despite being aimed at an older audience.

The beautifully designed Sikh site www.sikhs.org is also aimed an an older surfing public, but the graphics are magnificent and this is a good site for older pupils.

About Islam is another good destination for children with questions to ask, as is the Virtual Synagogue.

School websites all too often fall into the trap of using the net as a brochure, with RE policies and departmental details cluttering up too many sites. A few do use the net as a shop window for children's work and Huntingdon School and St Mary's Primary School in Canterbury at show what can be done.

Any discussion of religion ought to allow space for the non-believer, so teachers should bookmark the British Humanist Association at: www.humanism.org.uk/schools.htm whose site reflects their view that humanism is a means to ask the right questions, rather than a source of infallible answers.

CD-Roms

Aspects of Religion

This CD offers an audio-visual tour of the eight world religions focusing on beliefs, community, festivals, people, places, scriptures and worship. Aimed at key stages 3 and 4, it also considers values and attitudes towards issues like: Crime and Punishment, War, Peace, Life, Living and Prejudice. It features personal views, including interviews with an Islamic factory worker and an Anglican priest. Navigation and indexing is quite clear, but good reading levels would be needed to use the resources to the full. The software has a high level of interactivity. A feature called Trail Saver enables users to customise presentations. Another feature, Assessment Manager, operates in the tutorial or test mode and can be used as a study aid for revision purposes, or to help test pupils' knowledge.
 Price: £49 (single user); additional user £10; £289 site license (25 copies). Contact: Granada Learning/ Semerc, tel: 0161 827 2927

World Religions
This illustrated encyclopaedia from Sparrowhawk and Heald covers the six major faiths most frequently studied in religious education at key stages 2 and 3. There are over 600 articles under 11 topic headings and a timeline showing the relative ages of the faiths. A glossary explains the specialist vocabulary for each faith; this and the headings can be read aloud if the sound icon is selected. There are usually half a dozen cross-references to any one entry. This means that information is provided in bite-sized chunks, but a lot of moving about inside the program is required and search facilities are limited. Support material includes eight photocopiable worksheets.
 Price: £49.50 plus vat (single user); £99 plus vat (network license). Contact: REM, tel: 01458 254700

Living Stone

This is based on scenes from the history of Christianity in Britain. It introduces pupils to John Wesley, St Augustine and St Columba as well as to groups, places and periods of church history. It's not new, having been first released in 1997, but its light-hearted approach and lively animation makes it a must for any RE teacher's CD stack for 8- to 14-year-olds (key stages 2 and 3). The main narration comes from actor Colin Baker, an ex-Doctor Who, who represents a master builder about to design a church building, exploring the past in order to build the future. There is a lot of material, much of which can be printed out. Games challenge pupils' knowledge on the 12 sections and children can play the Gargoyle, Saints or Martyrs versions depending on difficulty. Points are awarded and the games are timed, with a voice over for added effect. The accompanying manual supports teachers by suggesting a wide variety of classroom exercises from role play to games, with suggested curriculum links to history and music.
 Price: £41.99 inc vat (site licence included). Contact: CEM 01332 296655

fields.headline: Big mother is watching you
fields.standfirst: John Crace on software to monitor your child's progress, and keep them happy
fields.trailText: John Crace on software to monitor your child's progress, and keep them happy
fields.body:
MyChildAtSchool.com

If you've ever wondered what your kiddies get up to at school, this website may be the answer to your prayers. Instead of mumbling "nothing much" to all queries, MyChildAtSchool.com can give you the full, up-to-date lowdown on attendance, grades and behaviour. A password ensures security for your child's information; you can even email teachers and pay online for school expenses. The system will only work if the school subscribes, and if teachers key in all the data on a daily basis. The manufacturer says it will save teachers huge amounts of administrative work and they will be thrilled to participate, but I am not so sure. One to keep an eye on.

brainworks.co.uk

There are now so many educational computer games - all of which promise to make your child an instant genius - that most parents tend to go brain dead when called on to make a choice. brainworks.co.uk aims to take the strain on your behalf by evaluating the best games, describing exactly what key stages and subject matters they cover and, best of all, offering them for sale at significant discounts. To take advantage of these discounts you have to sign up to a Home Learning Plan which entitles you to up to four CD-Roms at introductory discounts with a commitment to buy a further four CDs over the year.

urbia.co.uk

urbia.co.uk set its stall out a while back to become the most family-friendly site on the net, so it's no surprise to find it adding a new magazine section on education to complement those on health and relationships. The problem is the content, which is all terribly familiar. There is nothing wrong with giving advice on topics such as choosing schools and helping your child with maths, provided you're adding to information more easily accessible elsewhere. This is not the case here: the obvious is restated at length. If you're already a regular user of the urbia portal, the new section may be your cup of tea, but I can't see it becoming any parent's first education stop.

kidsevents.co.uk

Given that most half-terms and holidays arrive to a chorus of "What are we going to do?", any site that can offer a few worthwhile suggestions has got to have something going for it. Lastminute.com it isn't, so don't expect any deals to far-flung places from kidsevents.co.uk Instead it tends to concentrate on lesser-known attractions closer to home. The site is well laid out with a wealth of ideas plus a facility to key in your own dates and locations for a personalised search. The site only covers the south of England, though it will be going national next month.

Oz: The Magical Adventure (ages 4-7)

Most four-year-olds would need to be Mensa candidates to play the games some manufacturers claim are aimed at them. This is an exception. Child-friendly graphics loosely based on the Wizard of Oz, clear signposting to the different games and simple instructions meant my four-year-old could navigate his way round with minimal adult interference. So he stayed interested for longer. With three levels of difficulty, there is something there for older children, too. My (just) eight-year-old didn't have too many problems with the most advanced level; but never underestimate a child's enthusiasm for endlessly repeating problems he or she knows how to solve. The games themselves are the usual mish-mash of sorting objects by shape, measuring, counting and weighing; but no worse for that and, although both children had their suspicions that the CD had an educational purpose, they didn't seem to mind.

Millie Metre and Her Adventures in the Giant's Belly (ages 4-8)

Given most children's limitless fascination with farting, pooing and other bodily functions, you would have thought a game taking you through the human digestive system would be a sure-fire winner. You would be wrong. The graphics are confusing and it's a matter of luck whether you find any of the games. The farting and pooing bits raised a predictable snigger, but the educational stuff on diet, nutrition and the internal workings of the human body managed to bypass my two children. My four-year-old wasn't sure what he was looking at, while my eight-year-old couldn't relate it to what she had already been taught. There may well be a way of making this information accessible to children, but this isn't it.

Furby Babies Nursery School (ages 2+)

You can rely on kids to have the most appalling taste. This game has almost all the ingredients most adults detest - cutesy pastel graphics and saccharine musak - but my children couldn't get enough of it. No matter that it said 2+ on the outside, they were riveted and nattered about it non-stop on the way to school the following day. The games themselves were what you might expect - pattern and shape recognition, letter sequencing, with a few singalong nursery rhymes chucked in - and they were all easily navigable. To me the game seemed no better or worse than others like it, but given my kids' response, it could be one to swallow your pride for.

webTitle: Slum children get free internet accesss

fields.headline: slums.surfing.com
fields.standfirst: Hole in the wall has a whole new meaning in New Delhi. David Cohen reports on   a remarkable initiative to provide free internet access to slum children
fields.trailText: Hole in the wall has a whole new meaning in New Delhi. David Cohen reports on a remarkable initiative to provide free internet access to slum children.
fields.body:
A few feet away from the hi-tech offices of New Delhi-based NIIT - a computer training and software services company - stands a tall, yellow wall. For years it has been an anonymous barrier separating internet-haves from the penniless have-nots living in the neighbouring Kalkaji slum in the south of the city. But now the wall has been breached. NIIT engineers installed a kiosk in the wall containing a Pentium PC connected to the internet which gives free net access to any passer-by. The first to tinker with the kiosk were kids.

"Straightaway children approached and began learning how to operate the computer," says Sugata Mitra, director of research and development at NIIT. "No one showed them how to use it. They came on their own, because they were curious, and learnt by a process of trial and error." Within an hour they had learnt how to manipulate the mouse through the touch pad. Mitra had set up the web browser pointing at www.altavista.com and moments later they worked out "almost by accident" how to click and surf the web. Grown-ups showed no interest. But, despite their lack of education, groups of children aged 6-12 swarmed around the machine all day.

Most slum children do not go to school, are very poor and speak only Hindi. Many did not even know what the computer was - they just called it 'the thing'. Yet through Mitra's lassez-faire approach, they taught themselves how to use a mouse, browse the net, play games and even download and play Hindi music files. Mitra installed a video camera on a tree nearby to watch over the kiosk and observe what the children did. Through the NIIT computer network he also monitored their surfing and computer usage habits to see where they went and which programs they spent their time using.

"Disney.com is very popular with them because they like games," says Mitra. The children found a game starring Mickey Mouse, whom they affectionately re-named 'the rat'. "They also use Microsoft Paint. It's very, very popular with all of them," says Mitra. The children come from very deprived areas and often do not have easy access to paper and paint. One day Mitra intervened and played an MP3 digital music file in front of a group of children. "They were astonished to hear music come out of the computer and asked: 'Does it work like a TV or radio?' In keeping with my no instruction approach, I said: 'Well, I know how to get there but I don't know how it works.' Then I left." Within seven days they had discovered what MP3 was, downloaded free players, found where Hindi music was on the web and played it non-stop.

"As usual they didn't know what any of it was called," says Mitra. "But they figured out exactly how to use it." Most of the children could not read English and invented their own names for objects on the screen. Computer, mouse and icon are all English words born of Western ideas. Mitra was fascinated by the terms the kids employed to describe the new technology they were encountering. The hourglass - used to show the computer is working - is an alien term in India. "The kids use the word damru," says Mitra. "The god Shiva has a drum that he shakes - the drum is called damru in Hindi - and it's shaped just like an hourglass. So that's the word they came up with." The kids called the on-screen pointer, 'sui'. In Hindi this means 'needle'. When the computer is busy, the sui turns into the damru. "Who cares if they don't know what the correct terms are?" says Mitra. "The terminology is not as important as the metaphor."

These are just some of the surprises that Mitra and his colleagues discovered during the project. Another two experiments are now running in other poor areas with similar results. India's population recently passed one billion, yet there are just one million internet users in the country to date. These experiments have led Mitra to speculate on a grand scheme to educate India's children to use the net. "One kiosk, which taught some 160 children, cost 150,000 rupees (£2,343) to build plus the same again for the dedicated internet connection and maintenance. If we built 100,000 kiosks it would cost US$2bn (£1.4bn) to keep them running for five years. In that time, assuming 200 children learn from each kiosk each year, 100 million children would become computer literate.

"The 13 year-olds of today would be 18. They would vote. I think we would have irreversible social change in India." The British social think tank, the Institute for Social Inventions, applauds Mitra's vision. This summer it awarded the project the prize for social invention of the year because of its novel method of empowering large numbers of people in a lasting way. It's a resounding affirmation of the idea, but whether the project really breaks down the poverty barrier around the slum for these and other slum children only time (and money) will tell.

This and other awards are detailed in the Book of Inspirations (£15), published by the Institute of Social Inventions, tel: 020-8208 2853.

fields.headline: Beep: you're wrong
fields.standfirst: Fancy a bit of conversational Spanish? Evening classes are old hat. The latest software allows you to learn via live videoconferencing over the net, says John Bald
fields.trailText: Fancy a bit of conversational Spanish? Evening classes are old hat. The latest software allows you to learn via live videoconferencing over the net, says John Bald.
fields.body:
Online tutoring for language learners, whether via 'live' sound and text or text only, is a major step on from CD-Roms. It is opening up study in our homes, provides help on hand for homework and will hopefully bring Britons closer to mainland Europe. Netlearn Languages has come up with a net tutoring program that connects users by video and sound to a tutor. I tried a lesson in Spanish from scratch, checking I had a soundcard, a headset and a fast enough computer (333 Pentium is ideal but it works with a little less memory). I then downloaded Microsoft Netmeeting from Netlearn's website (free, and it took 10 minutes).

My teacher, Ines, appeared live on the Netmeeting screen via a videocamera and opened a whiteboard next to it. This was set up with the Spanish alphabet, and a series of nouns, articles and verbs which Ines had prepared as an introduction. Watching and listening to her alongside the whiteboard made it easy for me to link the sounds and the writing. Ines used a highlighter to pick up points I specially needed to work on, and typed in additional notes. This let me concentrate exclusively on her explanations (often in English, and quite right too, as I could ask questions and understand the answers), and had my notes ready-made by saving the whiteboard. Homework was built into the lesson if I wanted it, but most Netlearn clients don't. By the end of the lesson, I could compose simple sentences in Spanish, and had a basic idea of how the language hangs together.

Netlearn's website suggests it takes 500 hours' work to learn a language to near-native speaker level, which includes considerable private study time. It's not cheap at £29.50 an hour for individual lessons or £9 per hour for work in a group of six (minimum two hours per week and two hours homework on this system), but for pupils wanting to swot up for GCSE or A-level and needing some extra coaching, with no travel involved, it could be a life-saver. My lesson was skilfully taught, with a nice personal touch. The company offers English, Spanish, Italian and Russian, plus certificated courses in teaching English online at £295 to £345, depending on your choice of format.

Tutoring online
Richard Colebourn looks at other software

For a text-only version, again with tutors live online, try Aurolog's Tell Me More - The Solution. 'Aah beentot,' the demonstrator said into his headset, mimicking the worst British effort at French pronunciation. On the screen a red light flashed, indicating that the computer had failed to understand, and two waves showed the difference between his attempt and the correct way.

The program uses the net and email to allow the student to work with a tutor, regardless of where either are located. In addition to conventional reading, writing and listening exercises, the programme detects poorly pronounced words within sentences. Students who are struggling with individual sounds can view an animation to see how the mouth moves to articulate them. Buy the software and you are allowed two weeks' free tutoring; after that you pay around £12 a month. You can use it offline to complete the exercises in a customised programme. If in difficulty, email your tutor. Along with the question, tutors automatically receive a record of your work direct from the program, so they can advise you on any mistakes and adjust your study programme accordingly. Communication is by text only - though Auralog claims tutors will proactively encourage students and monitor their progress, students do need to communicate with their tutor for their latest progress record to be sent to them.

Students can also log on to the Club Auralog website ( www.club.auralog.com), designed to create a community of learners who can use a chatroom to practise their written skills and find penpals. Programs can be customised so that tutors can hold virtual classes and students' progress can be reported to their teacher. Tell Me More - The Solution is available in English, Spanish, French, German and Italian at £49.99 (inc headset).

learn.co GCSE French

For GCSE students who want something free, comprehensive, strong on grammar and using the latest tricks in online graphics, the Guardian's French language pages on its new school resources site learn.co.uk take some beating. They carry the complete French syllabus for higher grade GCSE and offer two sets of French grammar lessons, with or without sound. The text-and-pictures section is clearly presented and offers useful explanations, examples and exercises, complete with feedback. It uses many different approaches, including listening and reading tasks, comprehension, true or false exercises and matching headlines to paragraphs.

"Boys will like it," says Anneli McLachlan, the site's language teaching adviser. "Kids don't like being put on the spot, so being on the internet with a computer that will not censor you in public must be good." She said it will also help the confidence of many gifted kids who don't think they are any good. Web pages for the other two GCSE tiers and key stage three are being prepared.

BBC for beginners

For language beginners, the BBC's languages site at www.bbc.co.uk/education has free interactive video clips supported by comprehension tasks in French, German, Italian, Spanish and Welsh. Any would provide good practice for younger secondary school pupils. The comprehension tasks are clearly thought out and easy to use - you click a button, send in your answers, and they come back marked.

Sixth-form fast track

Michel Thomas's CDs (French, German, Spanish and Italian, Hodder, £60 each) are recordings of lessons with with two adult beginners. They are quicker to use and to cue than tapes; the main use for these in schools would be for older pupils wishing to start a new language.

Year of languages

For the latest news of events planned during the EC's European Year of Languages (2001), try: www.cilt.org.uk/eyl2001 which includes several ICT-based activities, including the Goethe Institute's 'Manchester: the German Connection' (0161-237 1077). The EC will shortly open an interactive website offering funding for projects, with priority given to ICT schemes.

Clicker French

www.clicker.co.uk has a free French writing grid for John Crick's award-winning Clicker program. Click on words or phrases in the bottom half of a screen to hear them spoken in French, and then click to insert them into a word processor on the top half of the screen to make sentences. This ingenious device, which can also be adapted for advanced learners, has been created with the help of Becta's special needs working party.

Software centre

If you seek information on a vast range of software directed at every level of language learning, you could try www.talkfast.com. It's a specialist online retailer and, of course, the material on offer is not free - OUP's TV Aktuell, for example, costs £85 for its 16 clips of German TV - but the company will accept returns within 14 days for a refund. It also has a lot of information on training and professional organisations.

fields.headline: A thing of sound and fury
fields.standfirst: From the sublime, to the not so sublime. Bethan Marshall on English CD-Roms
fields.trailText: From the sublime, to the not so sublime. Bethan Marshall on English CD-Roms.
fields.body:
You can tell that the CD-Roms produced by Headstrong Interactive are written by an English teacher. They have lessons in mind. Silver Hooks and Golden Sands: An introduction to poetry and prose in English 1360-1900 is ambitious. Devised to support key stage 3, this CD-Rom intelligently combines the informative with the practical. Poets, for example, are linked thematically, under author and poetic conventions. You can read the ballad Edward, Edward and then use the text to analyse the poetic form. The activities let pupils focus, for example, on the use of repetition.

The rhythm and rhyme sections allow pupils to play with the stresses in poems and hear them read aloud. The digital display of sound with these readings helps pupils see as well as listen to the rhythm. There are even sections on phonemic awareness, dialect and standard English. Again, Silver Hooks combines sound as well as useful tasks and this section is linked back to poets and prose writers like Burns and Walcott who use dialect in their poetry. The illustrations are wonderful and the glossaries helpful, with a wealth of source material for the hard-pressed teacher.

The same can be said of Headstrong's Over the Nightmare Ground: British poetry from two world wars. The most obvious use for this CD-Rom is with the Assessment and Qualifications Alliance exam board's new A/AS level syllabus, but it would be accessible to pupils much further down the school. It combines readings of the poems, sometimes by the authors themselves, with beautiful reproductions of war artists and interesting sections such as the one, for example, on films of the two wars. As with all the publisher's CDs, teachers can write tasks for groups within a class to carry out. You weave between Edward Thomas's biography, the influence of Robert Frost and then see this illustrated in his poetry. Click onto Charles Causley and you are given access to readings of the poems, a recording of an interview with Causley on each of the featured texts, the printed text of the interview and drafts of the poem in question. This CD fully exploits the medium. It enables teachers to do things in the classroom that they would not otherwise be able to or would have far more difficulty reproducing.

This cannot be said of Cromwell Productions' The War Poets (£75). The focus is far greater - war poetry from the 14th century on, but the ambition is less. It does include a number of photgraphs from the First World War and drawings and pictures from other eras, but there is no commentary or connection between the artist and the poets' vision. You can hear some of the poems read, but as with everything here, the readings are accompanied by an infuriating sound track. There are essays on the major war poets but the level of analysis is weak and there are no links to any other section of the CD-Rom. As with Cromwell's other CD-Roms on The Canterbury Tales, Paradise Lost, Great Expectations and Macbeth (£75 each), the most useful facility is that each reproduces the whole text along with a search engine. It was interesting, for example, to find that the word 'expectation' appeared in a more concentrated form in the centre of the novel than at the beginning or end. This could be particularly useful as a whole class resource if a projector was used. It would allow the teacher to draw attention to certain features of the text or, again, highlight certain themes.

This is equally true of Great Expectations and Macbeth CD-Roms in Longman's GCSE literature series (£12.76 each). But as the price suggests, these provide even less material. There are snippets of videoed drama and interviews on the Cromwell versions as well as essays. It is possible that the cartoon synopsis of the stories on Longman's may provide useful support for those who struggle to read the text, but showing pupils a film would be a richer experience than either of these CD-Roms. The analysis of character, particularly on the Longman's CD-Rom was superficial, bordering on the banal. Lady Macbeth, we are told, has no imagination because she does not foresee the consequences of her actions. And that is the extent of the analysis. Unlike the Headstrong Interactive activities, virtually all the tasks on the Longman and Cromwell CD-Roms involve nothing other than factual recall of events or quotations. This limits enquiry to the type of question that can be answered in that way. It is not enough to provide zingy sounds and busy graphics if the learning is superficial. Given the potential for learning that CD-Roms provide it is a shame that more companies do not take more seriously, as Headstrong Interactive does, the educational aims of their software.

 Headstrong Interactive, tel: 01484 660770

 Longman, tel: 01279 623623

 Cromwell, tel: 01789 415187

fields.headline: Whatever the weather it's fine
fields.standfirst: Latest news from the grid, with Louis White
fields.trailText: Latest news from the grid, with Louis White
fields.body:
One of the latest sites to be approved by the National Grid for Learning is the Met Office's education site at met-office.gov.uk/education. This site offers a variety of information on the weather and aims to educate children on the world's climate. The curriculum learning centre section is the most practical for teachers as it is divided into primary, secondary, leaflets and did you know? sections. Each has worksheet activities for children to learn as they go. Every section within the website, including Historic Weather Events, Inside The Met Office, Teacher Training Centre and Education Resources, helps children understand, prepare for and become aware of the weather and its impact.

 Schools connected to local government-led broadband consortia are allowed to buy NGfL managed services. Fears have been expressed that they might have been precluded from taking on managed services.

 Seven additional NGfL managed services-certified suppliers were announced earlier this year. All of them were throughly evaluated by Becta: Capita Education Services, Dan Technology, Ramesys, Ergo Computing, International Computers (ICL), Time Computer Systems and Viglen. fields.headline: Eyes on the board, please
fields.standfirst: Cheaper, improved products mean teachers can make computers work for them at front of class, says John Davitt
fields.trailText: Cheaper, improved products mean teachers can make computers work for them at front of class, says John Davitt.
fields.body:
Harold Wilson's 'white heat of technology' has finally arrived nearly 40 years late - and it's in the classroom. Government figures published last month show some 86% of primary schools can access the web - 12,500 more than in 1998 - and 92% of secondaries are online.

Average expenditure from central government on ICT for teaching and learning was £41,800 per school in 1999. So how is the future shaping up? Firstly, in schools that have moved ahead most in ICT, developments have been driven by empowered and connected teachers confident enough to shape ICT to meet their classroom. Secondly, the progress of ICT in whole class teaching points to the end of 'computer room mentality', and wireless communication and portable computers have played a major part here. Last month the Isle of Man bought 500 Airport wireless networking cards for the teachers' Apple laptop computers so they can move about the class with their machines and still stay connected to the internet and network printers. And in Cornwallis School, Maidstone, over 100 Acer laptop computers are now linked to a school-wide wireless network.

Thirdly, new collaborative learning software and permanent high speed access to resources over the internet is allowing inter-school conferencing and communication to grow, using voice and image tools alongside text. In five years' time 'computer rooms' will be as old hat as separate rooms for the TV or the slate. Computers are coming to the classroom, not vice-versa.

New types of collaborative learning software like RM's Discourse are starting to emerge. Here students and teachers can collaborate and question as they build their own bodies of knowledge over school computer networks. It gives a digital alternative to the 'hands up' method of classroom interraction with obvious benefits for those too shy or unsure to go public. Whole class teaching with ICT has taken hold in many schools thanks to a rise in quality and a drop in price of the data projector - a device that takes the computer display and projects it onto any wall or screen so that the whole class may see and share. To help teachers further, many companies provide interactive whiteboards - in effect giant touchscreens through which teachers can operate the computer.

Joanna Felton, ICT co-ordinator at Eastwood junior school, Southend-on-Sea, enthuses about her interactive whiteboard from Time Computers. 'It gains the pupils' attention instantly and motivates the pupils wonderfully. A colleague has been using the Virtual Whiteboard tools to plan stories with the whole class who take it in turns to write on the board with the electronic pen.'

Interactive whiteboard specialist Promethean has just announced a further level of interactivity for its ACTIVBoard whiteboards by adding an infrared tablet to the basic system. This allows students to take control of the front of class display so that they may add their comments or point out areas about which they are unsure. Schools may also buy hand-held voting pads so that every student can take part in contributing to questions - just the thing for end-of-lesson review summaries. Such systems cost around £4,000 but cheaper options are emerging. One of the most revolutionary is the Mimio, a £350 sensing device with software, which can be fixed to any ordinary whiteboard via two stout sucker pads. Sensors record any writing or drawing on the board onto the screen of a connected computer - work that can be saved as web pages for perusal later.

This tool has amazing potential to record key lessons for later use and distribution on school networks. The Mimio can also be used with a projector to mimic the effects of a full, interactive whiteboard - although my test model did not match the accuracy or the sophistication of these devices. Even so, teachers and parents need convincing that this sort of approach is right. Last week in Hammersmith I sat a little humbled as the visiting expert at Larmenier Infant School, while the head, Sister Hannah, and parents detailed their vision of how ICT could be adapted as a whole class teaching tool with resources like interactive whiteboards for students aged 4 to 7.

The school had not imposed an idea of the future - it was having an open debate At 9.15pm I counted 52 parents and teachers in the audience, all there to discuss, argue and cajole until they reached an understanding on how ICT could best meet the needs of their children. Some parents spoke powerfully about the danger of too much screenwork - others detailed quiet moments at home when they sat at the computer with their children. At the end of the session, though, the teachers felt they had the parents' approval to proceed with the learning aims of whole class teaching assisted by ICT. The revolution starts here when schools like Larmenier take control of developments and shape them to their ends.

Whole class 1: Whiteboard wizard

Wendy Bowe is head of ICT at North Cumbria Technology College, which is trying out a ground-breaking device

We have been using two Mimio devices for several months now to turn two ordinary whiteboards into large touch screens. The Mimio is a sensor which fixes to the side of an ordinary whiteboard and detects the movement of a pen on the screen which it sends back to the computer. When run in mouse mode it converts any touch on the screen to a click on the computer to which it is attached.

It's ideal for demonstrating CD-Roms or web pages. When used with a computer projector, it allows us to use resources straight from the web with whole class groups. Using projectors with computers in the past has often caused problems as it divides pupils' attention between the screen and the teacher who had to sit behind a computer. With the Mimio the teacher is at the front so the pupils are focused on them.

At present, we are piloting some excellent online resources from the BBC. These provide much of the content for geography at KS3 and students work through them on their own computers. When new concepts emerge, however, it's essential that the whole group can be brought back together and taught as a class; with the Mimio and the projector we are able to do this. Unless we call students together to teach key points we are not making the most of the opportunity. The school is connected to the internet using a fast ISDN connection; we have also set up our own media server to store video clips and sound which staff can use in their lessons. With these approaches we can put the teachers back at the centre in the world of digital media.

Whole class 2: Symbols at the front

Sally Adds, a mother of five, has always wanted to write software for handicapped children. She now works part-time at Woodlands Special School, Chelsmford

My motivation comes from my daughter Helen, who can't talk or understand speech. I was determined to tap into her understanding by using photographs and video, and so I bought myself a digital video camera and an Apple Macintosh computer. Next I learned Flash animation software, with the help of Geoff Dellow, a tutor who I call on the phone for lessons. He talks me through the software, helping me to solve problems as he introduces new skills. One day I looked at some printed symbols we use all the time as a communication device and it clicked that I could improve them by making them move.

I started to develop animated symbols so children could see more clearly what they represented from the real world. I now have a library of walking symbols showing basic skills like sitting down and eating. Working part-time at Woodlands, I help students by bringing movement to a world that has been static. The headteacher, Oliver Caviglioli, has just written a book called Mapwise which looks afresh at how learners' understanding transcends the limitations of linear text . By using his ideas and an interactive whiteboard we are now building complete maps of understanding using video and symbol animations. Teachers use these with whole class groups. Sometimes it feels as if I'm the only one out there but I know it's worth it. Helen is nearly 14 and with these tools I want her to be able to say what she needs.

Whole class 3: Networking music

Philip Wright is head of music at John Henry Newman, a large Catholic comprehensive in Stevenage

In the summer the school was networked and connected to the internet. Each department was given two network connections and we put one in our main teaching classroom. This is proving invaluable. During a lesson with year 10 on contemporary dance music, I wanted to illustrate an earlier form. From the site mp3.com I accessed and played a copyright-free minuet - pausing it to make my points on form. I saved it to the network so that students could access it for their coursework. The file moved from the internet onto the airwaves and it all took less than two minutes. I am now building a library of files for the choir. We regularly download midi files which students play through our keyboards and adapt. Starting with an existing melody helps them be more creative in the early stages. Next I want to use interactive whiteboards to introduce composition to whole class groups.

Whole class 4: A test of understanding

Sean O'Reilly is head of ICT at Ashcroft High school, a large comprehensive in Luton, Bedfordshire.

The school has been using Discourse software from RM which allows students to ask and answer questions as part of a normal lesson or an end-of-module test. I was struck by the potential of Discourse the first time I used it. Since it is based on Internet Explorer, it runs easily over the school network and staff and students feel familiar with the interface. As I am able to send messages to target and get feedback from every student it means that there is no room for students not participating.

I am now using the software with students from year 7 to 11. A major strength is that Discourse is content-free, so suitable for any subject area. It generates open-ended questions, which means that lesson preparation time is not a concern. It's an ideal tool for testing understanding and challenging misconceptions. The software also helps to build knowledge in a structured way. Discourse is a great step forward in using ICT to help teachers by monitoring every student in their class.

It's a superb example of extending ICT as a teaching tool. Other staff are using the software; one recently remarked that the best thing about this approach to online learning is that Discourse allows them to see which students understand and which students don't understand what the hell I'm trying to teach them. There is no hiding with Discourse. Once teachers build their confidence in using the software they are able to use a student's written answers immediately as a basis for their next question or to make a point for the whole group.

 Classroom of the Future Report at: futureclass.ngfl.gov.uk

 Time Computers, tel: 01282 777799 www.timeeducation.com

 Promethean, 01524 298526 www.promethean.co.uk

 RM, 0870 9086868 www.rm.com

 Mimio: www.mimio.com Virtual Ink, 0870 458 3344

 John Davitt is a freelance ICT in education adviser davitt@rmplc.co.uk
