Women are less likely to get breast, ovarian and cervical cancers if they breastfeed and can (we are told) lose the pregnancy flab quicker that way. And if the thought of a stomach like Madonna's won't persuade us all to whip out our boobs, the message that breastfeeding is convenient and "easy" (nothing to sterilise, buy or remember) surely should. But it is not that simple. "There are," says Finch, "wide and varied reasons why women stop breastfeeding." One that will ring a bell for many new mothers is that breastfeeding is not always as easy as it looks. "It may be natural," says Finch, "but it's not instinctive." This seems to go against the antenatal message. Listen to any group of new mothers, and some will be saying how breastfeeding was not the idyll they had expected. We are, it seems, simply not prepared - psychologically as much as physically - for the difficulties that can arise when we try to do the "natural" thing. This was certainly my experience. I was told by midwives that on day three postpartum my boobs would swell to the size of watermelons and start gushing real milk instead of the gloopy colostrum that feeds the baby in its first few days. They showed me various positions. They gave me a breast pump. I waited with a growing sense of hysteria and inadequacy for the engorgement to happen. It never did. This did not mean that I could not breastfeed. It just caused unnecessary angst. Most of us learn something of the physiology of breastfeeding before we give birth. It goes roughly like this: when the baby is born, a hormone, prolactin, tells the cells in the breasts to start making milk; the baby's sucking then sends messages to the pituitary gland in the brain, which triggers the release of another hormone, oxytocin, which in turn makes the muscular walls of the milk-producing cells contract; this ejects the milk down the duct and out through the nipple. It is what they call "supply and demand". But it does not always work so smoothly. My friend Rachel gave birth to twins recently. Like me, she was reassured that her milk would "come in" (they said on day five). It didn't. "I was distraught," she says. "I spent several days in hospital with hungry and upset babies." When her milk supply still hadn't come in a few days later (like mine, it took a fortnight to become properly established), she had to start "supplementary feeding": that is, to breastfeed, then give her twins a bottle of formula. "I was absolutely devastated," she says. "I felt like a bad mother. I felt like I was feeding them junk. I cried for a week." This may sound extreme, but according to Eleanor Jackson, a breastfeeding counsellor, it is incredibly common: "So many women feel like failures when breastfeeding goes wrong, and so often it's just a matter of confidence. Breastfeeding," she stresses, "is a learned art." Government statistics bear this out. The chief reason we give up (48% of us) in those early months is "insufficient milk supply". We either believe or are told that our breasts are failing to produce enough milk. In reality, says Jackson, it is extremely rare for women to be physiologically unable to breastfeed (reasons for this may include breast reduction surgery that has damaged the glands or a retained placenta in the first week or so after birth). The problem is that breasts do not always look or feel like they are producing milk, and breastfed babies can guzzle frequently and voraciously. This can be alarming if you were expecting to gush milk and have a baby that takes efficient four-hourly feeds. Breastfed babies do not always gain weight in the same way as bottlefed babies, either. According to Jackson, "There is a huge 'normal' weight range for breastfed babies." The health visitor's growth chart, then, can be worrying reading for a breastfeeding mother. When - as happened to me - a health visitor informs you that your baby has not gained enough weight and that you should "top up" with a bottle after each feed, it is easy to panic. My health visitor did not discuss my diet, my rest or how often I was feeding my three-month-old baby. Nor did she suggest places I could go for support. Instead, I was sent to the chemist, feeling I had failed when, with support, I could have taken measures to increase my milk supply. OK, so there are worse things in life than feeding your baby from a bottle. But if you are expecting your body to do it all automatically then setbacks can be profoundly undermining. "I asked the midwife in my antenatal group whether I'd have enough milk for two," says Rachel. "She told me, 'Nature's a marvellous thing - of course you will.' " It was after the problems set in that a health visitor admitted to Rachel that: "In all her time she'd only met one person with twins who'd been able to breastfeed exclusively. And she had two nannies." Of course, childbirth educators and health professionals do not want to put us off. But surely it would help if we were told beforehand that our breasts might not do what is expected of them; that it is common for boobs or ache, or block up, or get engorged, or nipples to crack; that our babies may not gain weight exactly as the chart says; and that in the first six weeks they may feed up to 12 times in 24 hours. To present us instead with a picture of erotic mother-infant bliss is, surely, setting us up for a fall? Janet Fyle, a midwifery policy adviser to the Royal College of Midwives, says midwives are not to blame: "Midwives aren't raising expectations," she says. "The expectations women have come from within. Midwives don't set women up; they give them information and, when difficulties arise, offer support, listening and reassurance." Wherever our expectations come from, it is clear that the support is not always there afterwards. Another friend of mine, Tracy, experienced severe, burning pain each time she fed her newborn. She was told by midwives, health visitors, breastfeeding counsellors and her GP that nothing was wrong. "You're just the kind of person who wants things to be perfect," said one breastfeeding counsellor. Two months later, Tracy was diagnosed with thrush in her nipples. It cleared up with some cream, and she had no problems from then on. So yes, of course we need to be encouraged; and yes, we need to be told how valuable breastfeeding is. But we also need to know - in advance - how "normal" problems are. Antenatal realism might not solve the whole breastfeeding issue - it is too complicated for that. But it might help countless women feel better about themselves, whether they choose to continue or not. And that cannot be a bad thing, can it?

fields.headline: Sarah Boseley
fields.standfirst: On drugs for Alzheimer's
fields.trailText: On drugs for Alzheimer's
fields.body:
A news editor once asked me to write an article provisionally entitled "Are we all going mad?" Had he been talking about schizophrenia, depression or any of the other mental health problems that people struggle to live with, he would have been well out of order. But he wasn't. He was talking about a fate that awaits many of us as we grow old. He was talking about dementia.

There is not the same sort of stigma attached to dementia and its most dreadful manifestation, Alzheimer's disease - perhaps because you don't live with it, but die with it. There is terror, instead. We recognise that this madness could await any of us.

Around 500,000 people have Alzheimer's, the degenerative brain disease that savagely strips down the memory until a grandmother cannot recognise her own daughter and grandchildren. It is one of the most distressing of medical conditions, in which the body of someone who is dearly loved remains, but their true self has moved out. Small wonder, then, that families are desperate for help from doctors and that doctors badly want to be able to treat the disease.

In 1997, Aricept arrived. It was the first drug in the UK to treat people with Alzheimer's. Now there are two more, with the brand names Exolon and Galantamine. All three are the same type of drug, called choline-sterase inhibitors.

Last week, the drug companies launched a survey showing that more than half the UK's health authorities will not pay for them. The National Institute for Clinical Excellence (NICE) is currently investigating whether they offer sufficient returns on our money to be prescribed across the whole of the NHS.

These drugs are not a cure. In fact, they may not even help. According to the respected Drug and Therapeutics Bulletin, Aricept does not work. It has little effect on cognition - the thought processes such as memory that are so damaged by the disease.

But patients, their families and the doctors won't accept this. Harry Cayton, chief executive of the Alzheimer's Society, said at the survey launch that the drugs brought about an improvement in mood. David Wilkinson, a consultant in old-age psychiatry at Southampton University, said the drugs had meant that doctors could now go out and diagnose the disease without fear - because there was a treatment.

This is a million miles from cost-effectiveness calculations. We're talking medicine that has a social function. Alzheimer's becomes a disease we can recognise. Some of that fear of incipient madness dissipates. Doctors and families feel a lightening of the sad burden of looking after Alzheimer's patients. And maybe the patient feels a bit happier, too.

Although it won't please the Treasury, perhaps these are good enough reasons for the NHS to shell out £1,000 per patient per year for these drugs. A similar argument can be made for beta interferon for multiple sclerosis. But if we are going to accept that medicine can have a social function, we are either going to have to redraw the rigid scientific-value-for-money boundaries of NICE, or politicians will have to overrule it.

Is it time to throw out the All-Bran? A study published in the Lancet last week looked a good enough reason to stop pretending that a bowl of something that looks like floor sweepings can be any fun at all in the morning. We've been told in a nannyish sort of way that fibre is good for us for so long that it comes as quite a shock to find that, not only does it not guard against a recurrence of bowel cancer - as everyone thought - but that it may even make it more likely. (Another study, published this week, suggests that a glass of wine a week may be a better form of prevention.)

The research on fibre comes from the European Cancer Prevention Organisation Study Group, which did a trial involving 665 patients who had suffered from bowel cancer. Some were given calcium supplements, some took fibre supplements (ispaghula husk, which is also used as a laxative) and the rest had a placebo. The fibre-eaters did worse than the placebo group, with 29% suffering another cancer, compared with 20% in the latter. The calcium group's result was not statistically significant.

Nutritionists and doctors rushed to qualify the unpalatable message. The patients were given a powdered fibre supplement, which is not the same thing at all as the fibre in real food, they said. Don't stop eating cereals, fruit and vegetables - because they definitely protect against heart disease.

But it's a bit of a blow, not least because bowel cancer was one of the few cancers we thought were preventable. Back to the drawing board, then - but personally I'll skip the All-Bran.

fields.headline: Dear doctor
fields.standfirst: Dr Ann Robinson
fields.trailText: Dr Ann Robinson
fields.body:
Lasers and safety

Q. I'm 46, moderately short-sighted, and considering having laser treatment to correct my vision, but I know little about the success rate or long-term effects of this procedure. My optician has only ever seen four patients who have had the treatment, two of whom were very short-sighted and had their vision improved rather than completely corrected, one whose sight was restored to perfection, and one who regained perfect focus, but with some peripheral blurring. However, my optician stressed that these might have been atypical cases.

His only reservation concerned the "experimental" nature of the procedure; having only been practised for around 30 years, the treatment may have unknown long-term effects. Do you know of any statistics on the overall success rate for this operation? And is there a professional body I could contact for impartial advice on the matter?

A. The most commonly used technique is called LASIK. A thin flap of outer corneal tissue is lifted up using a tiny instrument like a carpenter's plane. The laser is directed at the inner part of the cornea and the outer flap then flipped back into place. There are no stitches, minimal or no discomfort after the operation, and rapid recovery of vision with hardly any haziness. Up to 60% of those treated won't need glasses or lenses at all after the operation. There is no standard list of professionals offering LASIK, but an opthalmologist whom I asked said that Optimax, the largest organisation offering LASIK in this country, appears to meet the required standards.

Avoiding scars

Q. I have a basal cell carcinoma on the end of my nose. I am trying to find out the very best method of treatment with the least scarring. The only treatment available around here (Brighton, East Sussex area) is scraping, which will leave quite a scar. Would laser treatment (available in London) leave less of a scar and be effective? All my local enquiries on this matter seem to be hitting a brick wall of "don't know".

A. Basal cell carcinomas (BCCs), also known as rodent ulcers, need to be removed, because they tend to enlarge and eat away at surrounding tissues. The British Association of Dermatologists recommends seeing a specialist for BCCs on and around the nose, rather than letting your GP remove them, because they tend to recur unless fully destroyed. They can be cut off, scraped (curettage), or burnt off or destroyed using laser or radiotherapy. All methods, including laser, may leave a scar, but it's usually minimal and far less unsightly than an untreated BCC. Your local dermatologist should be able to discuss the pros and cons with you, but you could get a second opinion from a dermatologist or plastic surgeon before going ahead with treatment. Your GP really should help you find one. Remember to use sunblock in future and limit exposure to the sun - BCCs are commoner in fair-skinned people and related to sunburn and time spent in the sun.

Less fat, more sugar

Q. When I buy low-fat desserts, such as custard, I note on the carton that although the fat content is low, the sugar content is very high. Is it a false economy then to feel happy to enjoy liberal helpings of 95% fat-free custard - does all that sugar become fat, or can you really enjoy it?

A. Everything you eat or drink in excess turns to fat. Sugar is a carbohydrate and contains the same number of calories per gram as protein, which has about half as many calories per gram as fat. So low-fat, high-sugar custard will have fewer calories than high-fat, high-sugar custard. You can reduce calories further by eating low-fat custard with artifical sweetener, but it would probably taste so disgusting that you wouldn't want to bother. Personally, I'd rather eat a smaller amount of proper food than gorge myself on nasty substitutes.

 These answers are intended to be as accurate and full as possible, but should never be used as a substitute for visiting a doctor and seeking medical help. If you have a question for Dr Robinson, email drann@dircon.co.uk or write to her c/o The Health Editor, The Guardian, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER. She regrets that she cannot enter into personal correspondence.

fields.headline: A stab in the dark
fields.standfirst: It's flu jab time again. But do you really need one?  Dr Luisa Dillner has some advice
fields.trailText: It's flu jab time again. But do you really need one? Dr Luisa Dillner has some advice...
fields.body:
Would you want to be vaccinated against a virus that killed 12m people worldwide in 1919 - more than died in the first world war? A virus that puts you flat on your back for at least a week, with a raging fever, sore throat, hacking cough, aching muscles and such weakness that using the TV remote control is too much effort? A virus that, if you already have a medical problem or have reached retirement age, can land you in hospital? Now is the time for influenza vaccinations, and the start of the season of flu surveillance by doctors in the northern hemisphere, who are keeping their fingers crossed against another epidemic.

But however debilitating the illness - and once you've had it, you never again confuse it with a bad cold - there is only enough vaccine in Britain for 11m people. So while some employers offer it to their workforce to avoid the risk of everyone taking flu leave, most healthy people may find it tough to get vaccinated. The government intends the vaccination to be given free only to people aged 65 and over and those at high risk: a category including anyone with a serious medical condition, such as diabetes, chronic respiratory disease (including asthma) or kidney or heart disease, and those with impaired immunity.

The vaccine will also be given to people in residential or nursing homes because it is in these vulnerable and enclosed communities that flu - which is spread by droplets, for example in coughing - wreaks havoc most rapidly. This is the first year that the government has lowered the minimum age for free vaccination from 75 to 65.

"The main reason for preventing flu is to prevent the complications of flu," says a spokeswoman at the Public Health Laboratory Service in London. "The people being targeted by the Department of Health are those at high risk of bronchitis and pneumonia, which are the serious complications."

A new vaccine against flu must be given each year because the flu viruses cunningly change at least annually. Each vaccine is made from killed strains of the three main flu viruses, decided upon by the World Health Organisation each February after examining several thousand influenza viruses from its laboratories in London, Atlanta and Melbourne. But there is still a slight risk of epidemics because the viruses can mutate in mid-season.

Production of the vaccine starts in March, and GPs are encouraged to place their orders in the summer. But in an ideal world, wouldn't it be worth everyone getting vaccinated? "It is worth having a flu jab if you are a fit, healthy adult," says Dr Joe Neary, a GP and chair of the clinical and special projects network for the Royal College of General Practitioners.

Neary cites a paper in the New England Journal of Medicine in 1995 which compares the amount of sick leave taken by two groups of fit working adults (there were more than 400 in each). One group had been vaccinated, the other had not. Those given the vaccine took almost half the amount of sick leave and had a quarter of the the rate of sore throats, fevers and coughs. The economic savings of vaccination were modest (about £30 per person), but the health benefits were arguably more significant.

"You can look at whether you'd benefit from a flu jab in the same way as having a gamble," says Neary. "The stake is the cost of the vaccine" - around £7.50 from some chemists - "and its side effects are a sore arm and sometimes flu-like symptoms for a few days. Only people who have a serious allergic response to eggs shouldn't have the vaccine. The odds on whether you would get flu depend on your job - there's a higher risk if you touch lots of people who might be infected.

"The vaccine also offers only between 80-90% protection - but if you do get flu after being vaccinated, the chances are you'd be able to struggle on with it. The payout is that you don't get what is a very incapacitating illness that can last two weeks."

But Neary accepts that unless more vaccine is produced, then government priorities are right. "You can't afford to do everything for everyone. For some people flu is an inconvenience, but for others with impaired health it is life-threatening."

Neary pays for his own flu jab every year, despite being able to justify having one on the NHS because the health service virtually collapses when its staff get flu. "It's just that when my patients who aren't eligible for a free jab ask for one, I wouldn't be able to look them in the face if I didn't pay for my own vaccination," he says.

 Further information is avaiable from www.phls.co.uk/seasonal/influenza, and www.nhsdirect.nhs.uk.

webTitle: The issue explained: the Ebola virus

fields.headline: The Ebola virus
fields.standfirst: International agencies and desperately ill-equipped local health workers are struggling to contain a new outbreak of the deadly Ebola haemorrhagic fever in Uganda. Derek Brown examines the facts and explains the issues around the latest attack
fields.trailText: International agencies and desperately ill-equipped local health workers are struggling to contain a new outbreak of the deadly Ebola haemorrhagic fever in Uganda. Derek Brown examines the facts and explains the issues around the latest attack.
fields.body:
What is Ebola?
It's known to virologists as a filovirus, a group of viruses about which scientists know lamentably little. It was first identified in German in 1967, when two laboratory workers fell ill. The Ebola strain was first identified in Zaire, Africa, in 1976.

How infectious is it?
Extremely. The only way to prevent it spreading is strict isolation of victims and those in contact with them. The Ugandan government has now imposed draconian restrictions on movement in the affected area. Schools have closed and traditional funeral rituals banned. But there are disturbing reports that the deadly virus has already spread.

How common is it?
In all, nearly 1,100 cases have been documented since the virus was identified in 1976, and of these 793 people have died. All cases have been found in rain forest regions in Africa, though scientists really have very little clue about Ebola's natural origins.

What are the effects?
Disgusting and awful. Put crudely, the victims' insides liquefy. Death can follow within 48 hours of the first signs of illness. The most severe symptom is massive internal haemorrhaging, which causes patients to bleed from every orifice.

Is death inevitable?
Not everyone dies. With intensive nursing and medical support, around a third of those infected can survive. However, Uganda has the infrastructure for only the most basic medical support.

Why do we know so little about Ebola?
It was identified comparatively recently, and research is extremely hazardous, even in state-of-the-art laboratories. Obtaining and analysing blood samples poses particular risks.

What are the dangers of nursing Ebola patients?
Anybody in contact with a patient is at extreme risk. At least three nurses treating the Ugandan victims have died. The World Health Organisation (WHO) recommends the most rigorous standards of isolation and protection. It says that all medical, nursing and paramedical staff should wear gowns, masks and gloves, which should never be re-used without being thoroughly disinfected.

Is there anything particularly frightening about the latest outbreak?
Never before has Ebola struck such a densely populated area. Last week, the authorities imposed quarantine restrictions for 20 miles around the northern provincial capital of Gulu. But new cases have been reported, including two in crowded refugee camps north and west of Gulu.

Can Uganda cope?
It's going to need all the help it can get - and quickly. The WHO has already rushed experts to the affected area, along with a shipment of protective clothing. But it may not be enough to contain the latest outbreak.

fields.headline: Analysts welcome ONdigital results
fields.trailText: 1.30pm: Analysts were generally happy with ONdigital's results, which saw the digital terrestrial pay-TV operator's subscriptions rise by 13%, but thought a question mark remained over its churn figures. By Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
Analysts were generally happy with ONdigital's latest results, which saw its subscriber numbers rise by 13%, but thought a question mark remained over its subscription renewal figures.

When asked about churn - the proportion of customers who do not renew their subscriptions - a spokesman from ONdigital said: "We haven't published any churn figures because we keep introducing new services, systems or products. We don't want to issue figures that vary wildly."

However he added that ONdigital expected the churn rate to settle at 15-20%, and this was built into the business plan. "If you look at the level of cable and mobile telephony churn, it's similar and sometimes higher," he said.

One analyst said: "Average TV churn rates in cable are 23-25% while telephony is around 20%, although these are coming down around 2-3% year-on-year." He suggested it was more useful to compare ONDigital's churn rate to that of BSkyB. A spokesman for Sky said the churn rate stands at 10.5% for both analogue and digital, while digital alone stands at 3.5%.

Earlier this month, Merrill Lynch issued a report on Carlton Communications, 50% shareholder in ONdigital, questioning the increase in churn from 4% to 20% as early subscribers come off 12-month contracts.

Analysts, however, are not overly anxious given that it is still seen as early days for ONdigital and most are comparing the pre-pay contracts to mobile contracts - where churn is even higher.

The ONdigital spokesman added: "While subscribers are relatively new to us, they are always more likely to churn at the end of their first year. We would expect people to stay longer as the subscriber base becomes more mature."

Neil Blackley, analyst at Merrill Lynch, said he expected the churn rate to remain at 20% for a year, and that the results today were better than he expected. He said it was still feasible for ONdigital to float at the start of next year, but that it would need to find an ADSL partner.

Granada and Carlton are refusing to confirm whether a decision about a flotations has yet been made, but they are said to be watching the markets very closely.

fields.headline: Four die as train derails
fields.standfirst:
 Emergency helpline number: 0845 944 1551
Chronology: Britain's worst train crashes
fields.trailText: Four people have been confirmed killed in a train derailment at Hatfield in Hertfordshire, and some reports say there have been six fatalities. Hertfordshire fire service say at least 19 people were seriously injured and police said there were 80 walking wounded.
fields.body:
Four people have been confirmed killed in a train derailment at Hatfield in Hertfordshire, and some reports say there have been six fatalities. Hertfordshire fire service say at least 19 people were seriously injured and police said there were 80 walking wounded.

Emergency services were called to the scene after the high-speed 12.10pm London King's Cross to Leeds GNER service derailed, with some 100 people on board. The fire service described the accident as a "major incident". Up to 10 overturned carriages are reported to be lying along the track.

Hertfordshire Police said the train derailed at 12.24pm between Welham Green and Hatfield. A Railtrack spokeswoman said that the train was travelling close to the line speed of 115mph for that section of track. "The buffet car is reported to be on its side. As far as we know at the moment, only one train was involved."

A spokesman added: "It appears that at least one of the carriages is on its side. "All the emergency services are in attendance."

A Channel Four News reporter, Justin Rowlatt, who was a passenger on the train, said there were rumours that at least one person had been killed.

Mr Rowlatt said: "I was told by somebody who has been down there that there was at least one body. He saw a person lying next to the train. "The damage to the train was so severe that I wouldn't be surprised if there were more and a GNER woman said six of her colleagues were still missing."

Mr Rowlatt, Channel Four's Northern reporter, described how the train came off the rails and skidded along gravel at the side of the tracks.

"The roof has been completely ripped off the restaurant car. There is a guy with a broken leg [] and two people with severe gashes. The first class carriages have completely come off the rails.

"The carriages at the back of the train looked like they were whipping around and have gone into some of the supports for the electric rails.

"I can see mangled seats, newspapers and bags in there - further down I'm told you can see dead bodies lying by the rails."

Eight casualties have arrived at the Queen Elizabeth II Hospital in Welwyn Garden City, a spokeswoman for East and North Hertfordshire NHS Trust said. Two of the casualties were "serious", she said.

Emergency services had yet to get inside one of the crashed carriages, she said. Hospitals in the area have instituted their emergency procedures.

webTitle: Ford buys into digital radio group

fields.headline: Ford takes stake in digital radio group
fields.trailText: 3.45pm: Ford UK is to take a stake in the MXR digital radio consortium, writes Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
Ford UK is to take a stake in MXR, the digital radio consortium led by media group Chrysalis.

The carmaker is understood to have taken a 5% stake in the consortium, which was formed in July this year by Guardian Media, Capital Radio, Chrysalis and Jazz FM. As part of the deal Ford is to fit digital radios to all its models by 2004.

In a statement Phil Riley, chairman of the MXR consortium, said: "This represents the single biggest positive step for the uptake of digital radio in the UK (and perhaps more widely in Europe), and MXR is committed to making its partnership with Ford work for the success of digital radio as a whole across the UK."

Ford UK's chairman and managing director, Ian McAllister, added: "As a consumer-focused company, Ford actively pursues affordable technologies it believes can deliver practical benefits to its customers."

fields.headline: Sir Jeremy Isaacs launches Artsworld
fields.trailText: 3.30pm: Sir Jeremy Isaacs has launched his digital arts channel, Artsworld, with a pledge to fill the cultural void, says Matt Wells.
fields.body:
Former Channel 4 chief Sir Jeremy Isaacs has launched his digital arts channel, Artsworld, with a pledge to fill the cultural void left by traditional broadcasters.

Sir Jeremy, who is chairman of the new channel, said" "There are less arts programmes on British television than there were 20 years ago, yet the huge hunger for the arts grows apace."

Artsworld, whose investors include the Guardian Media Group, will be available on Sky Digital for a £6 monthly subscription fee. It will offer five hours of programming a night, which will be repeated the following afternoon. There will be a nightly arts magazine programme, followed by an evening of performances, documentaries and other cultural shows.

The success of Tate Modern, Billy Elliott and Classic FM showed there is a great demand for culture, Sir Jeremy said. The channel, which launches on December 2, aims initially to attract a modest "few hundred thousand" subscribers.

A number of familiar names will be associated with the channel, with Sheena McDonald, Richard Coles, Charlie Lee-Potter and Tim Marlow presenting the daily magazine show Focus.

Clive James is to interview the Australian poet Les Murray, while Bel Mooney will present a show in which guests talk about pictures that have influenced them.

Artsworld, which has signed an exclusive three-year deal with Italian broadcaster RAI to show opera and ballet from Milan's La Scala, has said that 30-40% of its programmes will be original commissions.

fields.headline: Jigsaw puzzles
fields.standfirst: All you need to know about big jigsaw puzzles, especially a certain £1m jigsaw puzzle
fields.trailText: All you need to know about big jigsaw puzzles, especially a certain £1m jigsaw puzzle
fields.body:
1. Christopher Monckton is said to have one of the best minds in the country. He used it to advise Margaret Thatcher in the 80s. More recently, he dredged from it a 209-piece puzzle of fiendish complexity called Eternity.

2. It's less of a jigsaw, more of a mosaic in which the irregular pieces fit into a dodecagonal frame. Twelve-sided, since you ask.

3. When Eternity was launched in June last year, Monckton said he would give £1m to anyone who solved it within four years.

4. He's just lost his dosh.

5. Monckton is selling his home to help raise the wind. It should go quite a long way: Crimonmogate House in Aberdeenshire has 67 rooms and a couple of hundred acres.

6. When he first talked of selling the house, it was valued at £1.5m. Now the agents are coyly asking for offers.

7. The fishing around Crimonmogate is excellent.

8. Bit of a prob with the local fauna though: there have been two recent sightings of big cats in the area.

9. While Monckton dreams up Eternity II - one hopes with a less expensive gimmick to launch it - puzzle fans still have plenty to work on, including conventional 5,000- to 12,000-piece monsters. Three-dimensional jigsaws are also popular.

10. Jigsaws are big business. They also have a short but fascinating history.

fields.headline: Britain's rail disaster history
fields.standfirst: The worst train crashes in Britain in recent years
fields.trailText: The worst train crashes in Britain in recent years.
fields.body:
March 10 2000: Up to 30 people were hurt when a passenger train hit stationary carriages at London's busy Waterloo station.

October 5 1999: The worst train disaster in a decade occurred when two trains collided near London's Paddington station killing 31 people. One of the trains had gone through a red signal.

June 23 1999: A Glasgow-bound inter-city train crashed into a stationary commuter service outside Winsford in Cheshire, injuring about 30 people.

January 8 1999: Seven passengers, including a pregnant woman, were rescued by crane after two trains collided outside London Bridge station.

September 19 1997: Seven people were killed and 150 injured when an express train from Swansea in Wales smashed into a freight train at Southall, west London.

August 8 1996: One woman was killed and 66 people were injured when a commuter train crashed into an empty train travelling in the opposite direction in Watford, northwest London.

March 9 1996: One person was killed and 24 were injured when a mail train collided with a cargo train near the central English town of Stafford.

January 31 1995: One person was killed and another was seriously injured when a passenger train crashed into the rear of another train which had been derailed by a landslide in a remote valley in northern England.

July 22 1991: Four people were killed and more than 20 injured when two suburban trains collided head-on in Scotland.

January 8 1991: One person was killed and 248 were injured when a train hit the buffers at London's Cannon Street station.

April 20 1989: An engine driver was killed when his locomotive crashed into a freight train in southern England.

March 6 1989: Two people were killed and 44 were injured when two trains collided head-on near Glasgow.

March 4 1989: Six people were killed and at least 50 injured when two passenger trains smashed into each other in Purley on the southern outskirts of London.

December 12 1988: Thirty-five people were killed in a crash involving three trains at Clapham Junction in London. The crash, the worst train accident in Britain in recent times, was blamed on slack safety measures.

fields.headline: WPP wins worldwide Boots account
fields.trailText: 11.15am: Boots is consolidating its £80m global advertising and marketing business into WPP, reports Jade Garrett.
fields.body:
Boots is consolidating its entire £80m global advertising and marketing business into the WPP network.

In the UK the deal means MindShare takes over the £60m media planning and buying account from OMD UK.

J Walter Thompson already handles the creative advertising account, but WPP agencies will now also handle public relations, market research and brand consultancy for Boots.

The appointment aims to improve the consistency of communications across Boots' increasing range of products and services. It will simplify the management of marketing services and reduce cost and complexity.

Steve Russell, chief executive of Boots, said: "This is a strategic decision, signifying greater focus and increased efficiency for Boots. In choosing to manage the Boots brand in this way we are confirming its importance in our strategy for the future growth of the company and our commitment to maximising the value of our major asset.

"Boots is a very strong brand indeed in the UK health and beauty markets and is the most trusted brand on the high street. We are certain we can translate this success into the global arena with the help of WPP."

webTitle: EastEnders and Weakest Link to boost BBC1

fields.headline: Frank Butcher leaves and Anne Robinson arrives on BBC1
fields.trailText: 3.15pm: EastEnders specials and the promotion of Anne Robinson's hit BBC2 quiz show, The Weakest Link will form the backbone of the new-look BBC1 schedule, reports Jason Deans.
fields.body:
EastEnders specials and, as expected, the move of the cult quiz show, the Weakest Link, will form the backbone of BBC1's new-look, according to draft schedules released today.

As revealed by MediaGuardian.co.uk, Anne Robinson's hit BBC2 quiz show will be promoted to BBC1 in a bid to boost ratings through primetime in just two weeks' time. BBC1 schedules have also pencilled in EastEnders specials to continue the effort to mark the departure of Frank Butcher.

The Weakest Link will make its BBC1 debut at 8pm on Tuesday October 31 immediately after EastEnders, maintaining the fierce ratings battle launched this week when the Nine O'Clock News was switched to 10pm.

The quiz show will be followed at 8.40pm by a 30-minute EastEnders special, leading into Pete Postlethwaite drama The Sins at 9.10pm. On Thursday November 2, an extended 60-minute EastEnders will be followed at 8.30pm by The Weakest Link, with Lenny Henry drama Hope and Glory at 9.10pm.

It is believed that The Weakest Link, which launched on BBC2 during the summer, will continue on BBC2, with a series of specials ordered for the new-look BBC1.

An ITV spokesman today accused the BBC of "stunt scheduling". He said: "BBC1 is being dominated by soaps and quiz shows. Where is the richer mix of programmes they promised?" He added: "We're seeing a worrying slide towards out-and-out populism on BBC1 and away from public service values. It's a depressing trend for viewers."

But a BBC spokeswoman said it was usual practice for BBC1 to schedule EastEnders specials when a key character is departing. She added: "I'm surprised ITV are so rattled by one week of specials."

BBC1 medical drama Holby City will be taking a two-week break from its 8pm Thursday night slot. Next week it will be replaced by live Match of the Day Uefa Cup coverage. Previously a ratings success, Holby City has been ruthlessly targeted by ITV with Who Want to be a Millionaire? and Coronation Street specials since returning this autumn and its audience figures have dipped.

But a BBC spokeswoman insisted that the show's two-week break had been planned before the 10pm news move was agreed, to make way for live football and the extended EastEnders.

BBC1 sitcom My Family will be moving from Tuesday at 8.00pm to Monday at 8.30pm to make way for The Weakest Link. The show opened with promising ratings in its Tuesday slot, but has dropped back in subsequent weeks.

The way the Commons decides is crucial
Special report: Parliament
fields.trailText: Next Monday the House of Commons meets to elect its speaker. It is an event which in the past has shown the chamber at its best and its worst. MPs are mindful of heritage: there are not many other legislatures that committed regicide and lived to tell the tale.
fields.body:
Next Monday the House of Commons meets to elect its speaker. It is an event which in the past has shown the chamber at its best and its worst. MPs are mindful of heritage: there are not many other legislatures that committed regicide and lived to tell the tale. But MPs are often a supine bunch, cowering under party whips, tied by cobwebby precedent. By such precedent the outgoing Betty Boothroyd will hear two nominations for the position and they will be voted on. Beyond that Commons standing orders - which of course could be changed by a determined and mutinous band of MPs - barely go.

Unless the boat-rockers muster, MPs will be presented with a choice between Michael Martin, veteran Labour MP for Glasgow Springburn, and Sir George Young, ex-Tory minister transplanted in 1997 from downtown Acton to leafy Hants. This will a beauty contest shot through with those clubby considerations Westminster loves: Mr Martin was kind to tyros in the tearoom; Sir George once had the temerity to vote against Thatcher. The process may manage altogether to ignore the candidate who would do the job best: the respected Liberal Democratic veteran, Menzies Campbell.

The postholder's power is symbolic but the speaker is one of our constitution's few recognised officers, and the election thus counts within the wider gauge of public confidence in representative democracy. Hacks have in the past occupied the speakership with distinction. But MPs might pause over the next few days to ask how they will use this infrequent chance of giving parliament a personal mask. It may not signify that neither front runner is a conspicuous moderniser - though Sir George does have a website. The election itself does, however, matter. Here is an occasion to display MPs' confidence in fair, open and heartily-contested contest. We all lose if it is a merely partisan stitch-up.

fields.headline: Both sides claim victory as BBC1 unveils new-look schedule
fields.trailText: 2pm update: It was first blood to BBC1 last night with One Foot in the Grave beating ITV's Who Wants to be a Millionaire? in one of the fiercest ratings battle of the year. By Jason Deans.
fields.body:
It was first blood to BBC1 last night with the first episode of the final series of One Foot in the Grave beating ITV's Who Wants to be a Millionaire? in one of the fiercest ratings battle of the year.

And the BBC triumphantly declared a victory in the TV news wars, with its first 10pm news bulletin pulling in almost six million viewers.

BBC1 controller Lorraine Heggessey said: "I couldn't have had a better first night"

But in an unsurprising war of words, ITV insisted it had won the battle with its powerful combination of Millionaire and Coronation Street guaranteeing it the higher audience share on the night.

More than 15 million tuned into Coronation Street to catch up on the aftermath of the Freshco siege and shooting. That delivered ITV a huge 63 per cent share of the audience, boosting its overall peak time viewing share between 7pm and 10.30pm to 38%.

The BBC, which rolled out the first episode of the last series of one Foot in the Grave and the first episode in a new series of The Royle Family, won 32.7% for peak time, according to unofficial overnights.

Grumpy Victor Meldrew, a viewers' favourite, pulled in 10.2 million, pulling off a rare feat for a BBC1 show - beating Millionaire.

The Chris Tarrant quiz show came a narrow second with an audience of 9.4m - share of 36 per cent share - for the half-hour it went head-to-head with One Foot in the Grave.

In its second half, Millionaire climbed to a quarter-hour high of 11.1m and averaged 10.2m or a 39% overall share.

That was enough to give ITV a comfortable lead over BBC1's The Royle Family, which nonetheless turned in best ever figures of 8.4m or 32% share of viewing.

The first ever BBC1 Ten O'Clock News averaged 5.9m or 29% share. But the combination of news about Israel, floods in Italy and a special report on Aids was not enough to lift the BBC's ratings above ITV, which fought Michael Buerk's debut at 10pm with The Frank Skinner Show.

Staff on the bulletin were happy with the performance. In its last week, the Nine O'Clock News had an average audience of 5m, almost a million below last night's figures.

Audience levels also compared well with this year's average viewership for the Nine O'Clock news of 5.1m or 22% this year, with 5.6m/24% on Mondays. However, in the same week last year, the bulletin had 7m on Monday night.

BBC director of television Mark Thompson said: "Although it's very early days in a very long game, it is very encouraring to see that a significant number of viewers will turn to a Ten O'Clock News."

BBC director general Greg Dyke, who persuaded the board of governors to rubber-stamp the lightning change to the TV schedules, will have been pleased with the performance of its new-look schedule.

In the 90 minutes after 9pm, BBC1 pulled in a massive 8.2m viewers, or a 33%, share - 10 percentage points up on last Monday's audience of 5.1m. ITV was also up in that 90-minute period week-on-week with an audience of 9.2m, compared with 7.4m thanks to Millionaire and the inheritance it gave The Frank Skinner Show.

An ITV spokesman said: "Last night ITV remained Britain's most popular channel despite the BBC throwing their strongest programmes at us. It was the one night they thought they would win. They must be disappointed."

A spokeswoman for the BBC said said: "We did everything we set out to do, delivering a broad range of quality programmes to our viewers."

webTitle: Man charged in connection with Omagh bombing

fields.headline: Man charged in connection with Omagh bombing
fields.trailText: A man has been charged and two others arrested in connection with the Omagh bombing in August 1998.
fields.body:
A man has been charged and two others arrested in connection with the Omagh bombing in August 1998.

Colm Murphy, a publican and builder from Dundalk, County Louth, has been charged at Dublin's special criminal court with conspiring to cause an explosion.

Three men in their twenties were arrested after 8am at locations in County Louth and County Monaghan, a police spokesman said.

They were being questioned at Monaghan Police Station as part of the ongoing investigation into the atrocity two years ago, in which 29 people were killed.

Last week four men, including Murphy, were named by the BBC's Panorama programme in connection with the bombing.

The documentary produced evidence which it claimed linked the four to mobile telephones used in Omagh on the day of the atrocity.

fields.headline: Feltz to front celebrity chat show
fields.trailText: 9am: Vanessa Feltz is returning to BBC1 daytime with a new celebrity chat show, reports Jason Deans.
fields.body:
Vanessa Feltz is returning to BBC1 daytime later this year with a new chat show format with each episode focusing on a single celebrity guest.

The 30-minute show, which is being produced by Lion Television with the working title Vanessa Meets..., is due to go out in a late morning slot from early December.

Jane Lush, the BBC's head of daytime, has ordered a 10-part, two-week run of the show. Ms Feltz's two-year exclusive deal with the corporation runs out at the end of the year.

Ms Feltz has already fronted two BBC1 daytime shows this year. Talking TV, which took a light-hearted look behind the scenes of the TV industry, went out in the spring; while I Will Survive, in which Miss Feltz interviewed a celebrity and a member of the public about coping with a traumatic experience, was scheduled for a week-long run earlier in the autumn.

The BBC has been trying to develop a successful daytime format for Ms Feltz since the high-profile Vanessa Show was axed after only six months in July 1999. The show's ratings never recovered after revelations that fake guests had been booked to appear.

Ms Feltz's BBC deal is said to be worth £2m.

fields.headline: WPP boosts Australian presence with research acquisitions
fields.trailText: 12.15pm: Marketing services group WPP has strengthened its Australian presence by buying two market research agencies, writes Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
WPP has strengthened its presence in Australia with the acquisition of two market research agencies.

The acquisitions were made though Research International, a wholly-owned subsidiary of WPP that specialises in custom market research.

The two companies are Research Partners, a Sydney-based retail research specialist, and Strategic Horizons, which is based in Melbourne and specialises in sales training programmes for consumer goods clients. The two already work together in a strategic alliance. They had combined revenues of A$4.5m (£1.7m) in 2000 and combined net assets of A$352,000 (£212,000) as at June 30.

Research International is the world's biggest custom market research agency with offices in more than 50 countries.

fields.headline: The Way You See It
fields.trailText: George Weah: Liberian girl, or badly-treated genius?
fields.body:
George Weah: Liberian girl, or badly-treated genius?

Last night George Weah claimed that Manchester City manager Joe Royle showed him "a lack of respect" while he was at Maine Road. Lee Calvert, for one, is not impressed. "Who the hell does Weah think he is?" he says, attacking the former world, European and African footballer of the year. "I am a life long Oldham Athletic fan and still have a very soft spot for Joe Royle, and anyone who knows anything about him knows that he is in no way "dishonest and disrespectful". In fact, if you ask anyone in football they will tell you he is one of the most honest and honourable men in the game.

"Methinks that maybe Weah expected to play all season in what he saw as a second rate side and finish his career as a hero. Unfortunately football does not quite work like that you mardy-arse! I'm sure Joe treated him no different to any other player, and they aren't moaning."

Andrew Parker agrees. "George Weah: what a moaning, spoilt, little rich boy," he says. "Let's face it. He doesn't like Manchester, and who can blame him. It's grim, it rains all the time, and Alex Ferguson works there. I'd much rather be in Milan sitting in the town square somewhere drinking a cappuccino. Still, we can't have everything we want, can we now?"

Meanwhile Paul Act has a different suggestion. "After reading about Mr Weah leaving Man City, I believe that he should drop down a couple of divisions and join Uncle Sam at Cardiff City! All the boyz will make him welcome and we will take him out for a couple of pints down The NIN and then for a kebab down Caroling Street, I'm sure we will make him feel at home!" Well, down-town Cardiff could pass for war-torn Liberia on a particularly heavy Saturday night, perhaps...

Hoddle or Howard or Harry? More thoughts on the vacant England manager's job

Another day, another batch of emails about the vacant England manager's job - including one, surprisingly, from a glenn_hoddle. "Are you interested in playing eleven a side football?" he writes from his hotmail account. "I'm looking for local guys to play regular eleven a side football for a team (nothing too serious). I urgently need new players as the team frankly at the moment is crap.

"Players get free use of the local gym, and I can get you a discounted rate at an exclusive golf course. We even have a sponsor who funds us to travel abroad to play competitive games, but frankly if we keep playing as craply as we do at the moment it'll just be embarrassing and we'll have to knock that on the head. Match fees will be paid based on ability.

"If you're interested come down and see me. We usually train, Thursdays 8 o clock, Wembley Stadium. Cheers Howard Wilkinson, Temporary Manager, Team England."

Meanwhile Jarrod Lythgoe has a slightly less wacky idea. "Please tell me why even though some managers names have been dropped more times than a cross by David James including such "greats" as Bryan Robson and Joe Royle (someone even mentioned Joe Kinnear!), no one has commented on Harry Redknapp's ability to turn a dire team great again (and then dire once more admittedly).

"Furthermore, due to West Ham's legally binding contract which demands their self-deposition in any cup competition longer than the third round, I'd go as far to say that old Harry could do it in his spare time. With his eyes shut."

However Malcolm X (unfortunately he didn't send us his surname) offers another spin on the whole debate. "Why all this talk about a foreign manager," he asks, "when what the England team really needs is foreign players."

Not good enough: your views on our First Division match reports

The Guardian's coverage of the First Division is getting some of you down. "More 'close enough is good enough journalism' for the first division," sighs a disappointed Mick Delaney. "Your match report for the Fulham v Blackburn indicates that Lee Clark was felled by Gary Flitcroft late in the first half. I wonder if your journalist was at the match as Flitcroft actually felled Luis Boa Morte."

"Anyone can make an error in identifying a player from half-way across the pitch but Lee Clarke is a short, white, Geordie. Boa Morte is tall, black and Portuguese. Was your man really there or just watching it on Sky in a pub and missed the action (and the many replays) because it was his round. Check his expenses."

But at least Mick managed to read a proper report about his team. Watford fan Yaasen Dalal is extremely disappointed his side - who are, as he points out, unbeaten in the league all season - only merited a small mention in the First Division round up section. And Simon Kirby is equally incensed that the Wolves weren't mentioned at all in the Bolton - Wolves match report. "The Observer piece was much better," he reckons.

Meanwhile Steve Jackson is unhappy with this morning's Middlesbrough v Newcastle report. "What an absolutely awful match report," he says. "Get someone better to do it next time."

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to editor@footballunlimited.co.uk

webTitle: Israel, Palestinians agree to end violence

fields.headline: Israel, Palestinians agree to end violence
fields.trailText: US President Bill Clinton has announced an eleventh-hour deal between Israeli and Palestinian negotiators, aimed both at bringing an immediate end to the violence which has swept the West Bank and allowing negotiations towards a full peace settlement to continue.
fields.body:
US President Bill Clinton has announced an eleventh-hour deal between Israeli and Palestinian negotiators, aimed both at bringing an immediate end to the violence which has swept the West Bank and allowing negotiations towards a full peace settlement to continue.

Standing before Israeli Prime Minister Ehud Barak and Palestinian leader Yasser Arafat, who signed no formal agreement and made no statement themselves, Mr Clinton said both had agreed to make a public statement unequivocally calling for an end to the violence in the West Bank and Gaza.

The brutal clashes have so far killed more than 100 people in two weeks, most of them Palestinians.

The agreement came at the end of two days of talks brokered by Mr Clinton, with UN Secretary General Kofi Annan. According to the Palestinian international cooperation minister, Nabil Shaath, it follows Israeli agreement to two Palestinian demands: one was for an international inquiry into the causes of the violence and the other for the lifting of a blockade on the Palestinian territories.

"The announcement would provide for an apparatus for ensuring the end to violence and a springboard for continuing the discussions in this difficult and complicated diplomatic process," Israel's acting foreign minister Shlomo Ben-Ami said.

The closing session came against a backdrop of more violence in Gaza, as hundreds of Palestinians threw stones and firebombs at an Israeli border crossing, drawing return fire that injured 10 demonstrators.

Mr Arafat left the summit after Mr Clinton's announcement, while Mr Barak remained at the summit venue where he was expected to give a news conference, according to the Reuters news agency.

The talks, in the resort of Sharm el-Sheikh on Egypt's Red Sea coast, had appeared to be set to end without success. Negotiations on a lasting settlement will resume between the two sides in two to three weeks, after the Arab summit to be held this weekend.

webTitle: Wanted: publishing manager and ad sales executive for Wisden Cricket Monthly

fields.headline: Wanted: publishing manager and ad sales executive for Wisden Cricket Monthly
fields.standfirst: Wisden Cricket Monthly invites applications for the following positions,  which may become vacant as a result of a possible reorganisation of staff  and responsibilities
fields.trailText: Publishing manager
fields.body:
Publishing manager

The publishing manager will be responsible for managing all non-editorial aspects of the magazine including marketing, circulation, subscriptions, budgeting and management reporting. The position requires a strategic thinker able to come up with innovative ideas for taking the magazine forward, while respecting Wisden's traditional values. Applicants must have experience in magazine publishing. An interest in cricket would be an advantage.

Advertisement sales executive

The ad sales executive will be responsible for display, classified and sponsorship sales. The ideal candidate will have energy, ambition and at least a year's experience selling advertising. In addition, he or she will have a good knowledge of cricket and be presentable, personable and well-organised. Good computer skills are essential for both positions.

Applications with full CV to Lynda Wheeler, The New Boathouse, 136 Bramley Road, London W10 6SR.
Please state current salary.
Closing date for applications October 31, 2000.

fields.headline: Vincent Canby
fields.standfirst: Influential US critic whose wry judgment could make or break movies
fields.trailText: The respected New York Times film critic for 35 years, from whom a bad review meant the death knell for any independent, or foreign, film in the United States, has died aged 76
fields.body:
Vincent Canby, who has died of cancer aged 76, was one of the most powerful film critics in America. A bad review from him in the New York Times, for which he wrote for 35 years, was the death knell for any independent, or foreign, film in the United States - the largest and potentially most profitable market in the world. A good one could have almost as profound an effect.

What Canby thought about a film was often regarded as the received wisdom, not to be counteracted by anyone save Pauline Kael, of the New Yorker magazine.

He began reviewing films for the New York Times in 1965, and was its senior critic from 1969 to 1993. From 1994 until 1996, he was the paper's chief theatre critic. He was hard to nobble, worked at a relentless pace and delivered his verdicts as if totally unaware of his power to make or break. He once wrote not one, but two bad reviews of a film by the British director Terence Davies, which effectively ruined its chances for American distribution.

When asked why he had bothered to slate a small British film a second time, he replied that he wanted to correct the impression, given by other American critics, that it was worth seeing. He did, however, champion the films of other distinguished film-makers, such as Mike Leigh, James Ivory, Rainer Werner Fassbinder, Spike Lee, Jane Campion and Woody Allen.

Canby's reviews were never academic, and were often invested with a wry humour. He wrote that Michael Cimino's Heaven's Gate, shortened for re-release after a disastrous opening at full-length, "looks like a fat man who has been on a crash diet". And he once described the physique of the young Arnold Schwarzenegger as "something the actor might want to shed in order to slip into something more comfortable".

Canby cut a typically east-coast American middle-class figure. He did not look or sound like a champion of radical cinema, though his reviews were often sympathetic to more difficult work. There were times, however, when he seemed more comfortable with orthodox fare; as often as not, he gave Hollywood the benefit of the doubt.

Because of his power, he was often courted. But he invariably maintained a dignified distance from those who sought to influence him. He could not be moved to write anything other than his own thoughts, whatever the entreaties might have been. If he often seemed a remote figure, he never yielded to any kind of pressure.

Born in Chicago, Canby was initially raised in Lake Forest, Illinois, before being educated at Christchurch school, in Alexandria, Virginia. During the second world war, he served as a naval officer in the Pacific. After the war, he briefly freelanced in Paris, and then read English at Dartmouth, the New Hampshire Ivy League college.

Writing once about his work as a critic, he said: "The basic difference between the critic and the member of the public who attends movies on a more or less casual basis, is that after a certain length of time spent watching movies, the critic can no longer be entertained by simply sitting back and allowing the movie to roll over him like a tank made of feathers. He wants to assume an active role, that's his entertainment."

Canby never married but was, for many years, the companion of his fellow critic, Penelope Gilliatt.

Vincent Canby, critic, born July 27 1924; died October 15 2000

fields.headline: The Mandelson loan scandal
fields.standfirst: The home loan scandal, which forced Peter Mandelson to resign as trade and industry secretary two years ago, has come back to haunt him. The man who gave him most of the money, the former paymaster general and millionaire Geoffrey Robinson, claims in his new memoir that Mr Mandelson solicited the loan. Why does this matter? Mark Oliver and Julian Glover explain
fields.trailText: The home loan scandal, which forced Peter Mandelson to resign as trade and industry secretary two years ago, has come back to haunt him. The man who gave him most of the money, the former paymaster general and millionaire Geoffrey Robinson, claims in his new memoir that Mr Mandelson solicited the loan. Why does this matter? Mark Oliver and Julian Glover explain.
fields.body:
What is the core issue?
The Northern Ireland secretary, Peter Mandelson, and the former paymaster general, Geoffrey Robinson are in dispute about who made the running in the conversations that culminated in a loan of £373,000 from Mr Robinson to Mr Mandelson, allowing the latter to buy a house in London's trendy Notting Hill.

What do they agree about?
What is not contested is that the pair had dinner at Mr Robinson's penthouse flat in May 1996, and discussed Mr Mandelson's desire to find better London accommodation. Mr Mandelson denies he angled for the loan or forced Mr Robinson to give it to him. Mr Robinson wants it on the record that he was not trying push the money on the minister - arguably prime minister Tony Blair's closest confidant - in a bid to help his own political career. The affair prompted Mr Mandelson's resignation as trade and industry secretary in December 1998, shortly followed by Mr Robinson's resignation.

What is Mr Robinson's version of events?
"We met, he brought the whole matter of his house up, and the rather straitened circumstances in which he felt he lived... He said he would like to buy somewhere, he mentioned Notting Hill, it was clear that was what he was most interested in, but he didn't have anybody who would help him... I replied that I was financially well placed and might be able to help if that was what he wanted. At that point nothing further was said. I imagine he was mulling the situation over in his own mind. But the next morning at 9am, the phone rang and it was Peter saying quite openly, 'Would you really help me buy a house', to which I replied, 'Yes, if that's what you want.' "

How has Mr Mandelson responded?
He has described the suggestion that he forced Mr Robinson into giving him a loan, or went to dinner with him for this express purpose, as "ridiculous". Mr Mandelson says: "As a friend of many years standing, he volunteered his financial help if needed. I later took him up on his offer and I was grateful to him... I gave a full, faithful, and factual account to the House of Commons standards committee, as did Geoffrey himself. They accepted it and I regard the matter as closed."

What did Mr Mandelson say to the Commons standards and privileges committee on May 18 1999?
He said: "I did not go to him [Robinson] with the intention of asking him to loan me some money. I told him I was looking for a house or a flat. He asked how I was going to pay for it. I said I was going to sell my property and my mother would help. He said, 'Well, if you need any help you know I will help'."

Is Mr Robinson calling Mr Mandelson a liar?
Yes and no. Yes, in that he says Mr Mandelson solicited the loan, rather than simply accepted it. No, in that he agrees with Mr Mandelson that he first suggested the idea of lending the money. The Daily Mail used the word "lied" in one of its headlines. Mr Robinson says he does not agree with this and that he thinks Mandelson should not resign again.

Why does any of this matter?
Because Mr Robinson's new version of events is, arguably, at odds with Mr Mandelson's statement to the Commons committee. This is important for two reasons, both related to the impression it gives of Mr Mandelson having lied. The first reason is that Elizabeth Filkin, the parliamentary standards commissioner, is likely to reopen her file on the affair. She may conclude that the Northern Ireland secretary acted improperly. The second reason is that Mr Mandelson's speedy rehabilitation - he returned to the cabinet just 10 months after resigning - was made possible by the fact that he appeared not to have sought the loan. Had Mr Robinson's version of events been known at the time, it would have been tricky for the prime minister to reappoint his friend. The impression of sharp practice is hard to avoid.

Does the affair have any wider significance for Tony Blair?
In his memoir, An Unconventional Minister, Mr Robinson labels Mr Mandelson a "divisive and destabilising figure" who caused rows between Mr Blair and chancellor Gordon Brown. He says: "It is, in my opinion, something he should control, it is something the prime minister should help him control, and I believe the administration of his government would be more effective if he was able to do so." Yesterday, the education secretary David Blunkett condemned Mr Robinson for "self-indulgent" sniping at Mr Mandelson, challenging the businessman to reveal how much he had made from the serialisation of his book, and donate it to the Labour party or a charity.

How damaging is this affair to Mr Mandelson?
Mr Mandelson was politically damaged when the affair broke because he had kept the loan a secret from Mr Blair and had not been forthcoming to his building society when he applied for a further £150,000 loan. But he has since clawed his way back to one of the top jobs in the cabinet. Today, there are renewed calls for Mr Mandelson's resignation but he is nothing if not a survivor. The main charge against him is the allegation that he lied to the standards and privileges committee. The Sun, the Daily Mail, and the Daily Mirror all splashed the story on the front page. The shadow treasury minister, David Heathcoat-Amory, has called for the Commons standards and privileges committee to review the affair. But the smart money is on Mr Mandelson weathering the storm, with Downing Street sitting tight on the hope that the memoirs will be a "one day wonder" in the media and the resignation calls will fade. It is, however, another unwanted negative story for a government that is highly sensitive to sleaze allegations ahead of the general election.

fields.headline: Eduardo Guedes
fields.standfirst: His creative energy widened recognition of the independent film-maker's art
fields.trailText: The Portugese film-maker, whose contributions to the film collective Cinema Action of the late 1960s galvanised independent cinema in Britain, has died aged 59
fields.body:
Independent cinema in Britain is unthinkable without the achievements of the innovative film collective Cinema Action, which was set up in the late 1960s by Ann Guedes and crystallised around a core of three cultural dynamos: Ann Guedes herself, Gustav Lamche and Eduardo Guedes, who has died aged 59, and whose deep love of cinema energised them all.

Born in Lisbon, the son of a judge, Eduardo graduated brilliantly as a chemical engineer from Lisbon University in 1961, but, refusing to take part in the Portuguese colonial wars, left that year to study film-making at the International Film School in London. After graduating in 1964, he continued to work as a tutor at the school.

In 1965, he went to Brazil. There, he made three documentaries, one of which, Rio Araguaia, was later networked by the BBC and French television. Back in London, he worked from 1968 to 1971 as a freelance film editor, collaborating with the theatre director Peter Brook, and with Jeremy Isaacs, then controller of features at Thames Television.

In 1971, Eduardo joined Cinema Action, becoming a key contributor to its work, which embraced much more than making, distributing and exhibiting films - both their own and the work of a burgeoning community of independent film-makers the world over. This was a time of great economic upheaval and industrial conflict, captured through the beautiful grainy lens and the rich intellectual and political debate that characterised Cinema Action's work.

The group was a key component in the organisation of the Independent Film-makers Association between 1974 and 1976, which campaigned, among other things, for airtime for independents on Channel 4, when it began transmission in 1982. The IFA helped to persuade the new channel's founding chief executive, Jeremy Isaacs, to appoint a commissioning editor for independent film.

In 1981, closely collaborating with Ann Guedes, Eduardo shot and edited the extraordinary documentary, So That You Can Live, which she directed. It opened Channel 4's independent film slot, and told the story of three generations of a matriarchal family in a small Welsh town, as they struggled to keep control of their lives, and to understand and survive the closure of the coal mines and the decimation of their community.

Cinema Action's first feature, Rocinante (1987), starring John Hurt and the late Ian Dury, was written and directed by Ann and Eduardo, and produced by Gustav Lamche. Rocinante showed what the aesthetics of independent film-making in Britain could look like - visually enthralling, emotionally and intellectually complex, politically astute and farsighted. Their second feature, Bearskin (1990), a fairy-tale metaphor of contemporary Britain, starred Tom Waits and Ian Dury.

Eduardo and Ann Guedes then divided their time between London and Lisbon. They were forced to sell their next feature to Miramax, but while fighting cancer, Eduardo made two more features in Portugal: the quietly beautiful, and dryly humorous, Pax (1994), starring Amanda Plummer and Isabel Ruth, and the outstandingly successful Knives And Angels (2000).

Supported by Ann and by her children - Cinema Action's second generation (Pascale, Tag and Burn Lamche) - Eduardo Guedes continued doing what he loved most besides fishing: making films, until his last breath. As a director, his work exudes the warmth, intellectual acuity and emotional generosity - as well as the sheer love of storytelling - that characterised him as a man. His life and work will remain an example to us for a long time to come.

He married Ann Guedes in 1984. She survives him, as do his three stepchildren.

Paul Willemen

Eduardo Luis Santos Correia Guedes, film-maker, born April 21 1941; died August 29 2000

fields.headline: News in brief
fields.trailText: Slasher classic gets tv debut at last, Spy Game relocates out of Israeli war zone, Madonna wins domain name rights, rappers to be immortalised on film, Jada Pinkett signs on for Matrix sequels and Green Mile's gentle giant goes ape
fields.body:
 One of the slasher originals, The Texas Chainsaw Massacre, is to be broadcast on Channel 4 as part of its scream season, called FilmFear. The movie was denied a certificate by the BBFC on its 1975 release, a decision which was belatedly retracted last year. A Channel 4 spokesman said: "The Texas Chainsaw Massacre is a classic of the horror genre. It's based on the same real-life story that inspired Hitchcock's Psycho and the film successfully implies fear and horror while showing less than the viewer has imagined."

 Tony Scott's espionage thriller The Spy Game, which stars Robert Redford, Brad Pitt and Catherine McCormack, has been forced to relocate near London after disturbances between Israelis and Palestinians made the planned Tel Aviv shoot too dangerous. A spokesman for the film, which has been under pre-production in the Middle East for several weeks, told newspapers: "You have to think of not just the safety of the stars, but the entire crew. In any case, I think the money and the insurance have been jumping up and down, going nuts at the prospect of filming in a war zone."

 Madonna has won her legal battle for the rights to the web domain name madonna.com after an international arbitration panel evicted an opportunistic New York businessman from the site. The World Intellectual Property Organization concluded that defendant Dan Parisi had failed to prove legitimate interest in the domain name after the diva filed the complaint in July. Serial cybersquatter Parisi also owned domain names such as wallstreetjournal.com.

 Two books exploring the lives and controversial killings of rappers Tupac Shakur and Biggie Smalls are being adapted for the screen. The books, by investigative reporter Cathy Scott, will be developed under the single title Record Wars.

 Mrs Will Smith, Jada Pinkett, looks likely to star in the second and third instalments of the Wachowski brothers' The Matrix, as love interest to Laurence Fishburne's Morpheus character.

 Michael Clarke Duncan, Oscar-nominated for his performance in The Green Mile, will appear alongside Tim Roth, Helena Bonham Carter and Mark Wahlberg in Tim Burton's remake of Planet of the Apes. Duncan will play an ape warrior.

webTitle: Collymore in more trouble at Leicester

fields.headline: Collymore in more trouble at Leicester
fields.trailText: Stan Collymore seems to have hastened his departure from Leicester City today after reports emerged of a fracas involving Collymore and a team-mate during a reserve team fixture at Filbert Street last night.
fields.body:
Stan Collymore seems to have hastened his departure from Leicester City today after reports emerged of a fracas involving Collymore and a team-mate during a reserve team fixture at Filbert Street last night.

The club have announced they will be conducting an inquiry into the incident alleged to have taken place during the first half of the Premier Reserve League South match against Charlton Athletic. Collymore is reportedly became involved in a row with one of his team-mates in the first half, a row which spilled over into the changing room at half time, after Collymore had been substituted. He is then believed to have left the ground in disgust.

"We can confirm we are investigating a half-time dressing room incident which took place at last night's reserve game at Filbert Street", Paul Mace, Leicester's director of media and communications said. "We will not be in a position to comment further until the investigation has been completed."

Any more bad publicity for Collymore could mean an even hastier exit from Filbert Street than had been expected. Manager Peter Taylor has already placed the former England striker on the transfer list, after Collymore demanded an improved contract and turned in a performance against Everton which Taylor called "unacceptable for a professional footballer".

But ironically Collymore's latest outburst came just as the Leicester boss was ready to offer his striker the hand of friendship. At the same time as Collymore was making his first competitive start for Leicester this season, Taylor was speaking on a local radio forum of his wishes to have a fully focused Collymore as part of his squad.

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to editor@footballunlimited.co.uk

fields.headline: Speaker candidates issue electoral statements
fields.trailText:
17 October, 12.30pm: MPs were today receiving electoral statements from seven candidates for speaker of the House of Commons, in a break from tradition designed to bring more openness into the contest.
Special report: parliament
fields.body:
MPs were today receiving electoral statements from seven candidates for speaker of the House of Commons, in a break from tradition designed to bring more openness into the contest.

But the frontrunners in the contest are understood to have refused to produce "manifestos" or to take part in a hustings arranged for October 23, just hours before MPs vote. Labour backbencher Gordon Prentice said he had sent the seven statements out to all MPs yesterday and that they should be receiving them today.

Mr Prentice invited all candidates to submit the statements and attend the hustings after failing in a bid to have the procedures for the election changed.

Traditionally, a handful of candidates for speaker have "emerged" after behind-the-scenes discussions, and MPs have been expected to vote without being given any details of their respective programmes.

But Betty Boothroyd's announcement in July that she would step down the day before the Commons returns from recess led to an unprecedented field of at least 13 hopefuls coming forward, accompanied by demands from MPs for a more modern and open contest.
