webTitle: Robinson's poisoned dart is aimed at Tony Blair

fields.headline: Robinson's poisoned dart is aimed at Tony Blair
fields.standfirst: The loan is a non-story, but the political agenda behind his memoirs isn't
fields.trailText: Politics suffers from chronic over-interpretation. People in my trade are rich in every kind of knowingness. We never like to be caught short of insightful cynicism. In everything there must be connections.
fields.body:
Politics suffers from chronic over- interpretation. People in my trade are rich in every kind of knowingness. We never like to be caught short of insightful cynicism. In everything there must be connections. As a matter of professional habit, we run the risk of outlining patterns that don't exist, endowing politicians with powers they do not have and bonds they do not recognise. It is important to be wary of seeing too much - but also, it must be said at the same time, of seeing too little.

Money is a frequent source of conspiratorial excess. Appearances matter here, which is why the rules about the disclosure of political money are very tight. But the story of Geoffrey Robinson's huge loan to enable Peter Mandelson to buy a house in 1996 has been shaped by heated exaggeration of its meaning. Now that Robinson has told the story again, we find an account that offers little disagreement with the version Mandelson has always given. Yet it is seized on as a revelation fit to change the course of history.

The story is simple. Mandelson wanted a better house. Robinson wanted to help him get it. They had a relaxed conversation, which concluded with one man taking up the other on his vague, fraternal offer. Now that more poisoned water has passed under the bridge on which bitter armies have camped, it becomes a matter of dispute who said exactly what to whom before the other replied. But the human truth - that here were two political friends chatting their way towards a common venture - is intelligible from both men's stories. They virtually agree on it. That Mandelson ought to have disclosed it when he took over the Department of Trade and Industry is obvious, but it's another matter and was dealt with at the time both left the government.

What we have here is blurry good faith translated, in new political circumstances, into hard-edged accusation. What is really noticeable is the fuzziness a certain kind of rich man can have about money. Just as nobody has a conclusive memory about the loan, neither Robinson nor No 10 seems entirely certain whether he did or didn't give a few hundred thousand to the Blair, as well as the Brown, pre-election offices.

Five years ago, there was a chaotic imprecision about rights and obligations which could perhaps only be generated by a political party and a plutocrat ready to do anything to help it. But imposing a sinister shape on this is a task keenly taken up by the right-wing press who paid a fortune to get Robinson to write what he did, and then spun it into the unmade charge that Mandelson is a liar.

So much for over-interpreting: a charitable word, in the circumstances. Though money and the home loan are pretexts, there is an element of simple vengeance here. Robinson was sore about what happened to him, and doubly sore when Mandelson returned to government while he remains under investigation for his business practices. Dripping with condescension, he toured the studios yesterday to offer his former friend avuncular advice on how to be a better minister, expecting us to take seriously the hypocritical pretence that he is delighted to see Peter back in the cabinet. All too plainly, he is disgusted, and doesn't mind what help he gives Labour's political enemies by trying to destroy the Northern Ireland secretary's reputation.

We come, therefore, to what does need cynical analysis, which is the political agenda that lies half-obscured behind this. Robinson's own origins, it is worth recalling, lie in the heartland of old Labour. He was a practising aide to Tony Benn before Blair or Brown had been heard of, a believer in industrial intervention, an embryonic businessman-cum-MP who bought the entire programme of the Wilson government in the 1970s. Insofar as he had the philosophical bent which he now derides Mandelson for lacking, that is where it came from.

Nothing wrong with that. And, having first run Jaguar, he went on to make the fortune that enabled him to become a lavish patron of New Labour in its turn. In political belief he turns out to have been pretty flexible. Like many others, he has blown with the wind. But some of his instincts persisted until much more recent times, and set him at odds with secretary of state Mandelson on the matter of industrial intervention. As paymaster general, and one of Gordon Brown's Treasury colleagues, he proposed schemes for intervening both in Rover and the coal industry which the arch-New Labourite then at Trade and Industry could not fully accept. There were rows between them, though it must be doubted whether Brown was his ally in these cases.

Another field of argument was and is Europe. The undemanding benefactor of the party and many of its top people turns out to be an anti-European. Known as a sceptic in the 70s, he now describes any policy calling for more European integration as "momentously wrong". From his minor government post he was a sleeping if not active partner in an attitude of mind that opposes entry into the euro in the foreseeable future.

An important part of the first excerpt from his book, reiterated in the interviews, is the contention that only Mandelson has set Blair against Brown on this and other matters. The Mephistophelian depiction of his enemy, bumbling and even well-intentioned though it affects to be, thus reaches a nadir of malignity. Also of untruth. The notion that Blair needs Mandelson to tell him what to think about Europe is as fatuous as the parallel insinuation that any minister who objects to a decision fixed up between Blair and Brown is, outrageously, "reopening" an issue.

This, I think, is the harbinger of something bigger. While Blair doesn't have to be told what his Europe policy should be, undermining Mandelson is a sure way of making that policy harder to carry forward. It is becoming plainer that a Blair-Brown fissure on the euro could become a determining, destructive feature of post-election Labour politics. From being a contest between jealousies and ambitions rather than principles and policies, the dynamic of New Labour could well take on the ideological factionalism of the 60s and 70s - which is where Geoffrey Robinson came in.

He won't play much part in the repeat performance. As a politician, he never reached anything like the heights his talents once seemed fit for. But every jilted courtier has a poisoned dart to shoot, and he has now shot his. The loan, seized on by the interpreters, is a non-story. But the anti-euro possibilities, chewed over with relish by the anti-Europe press, will further whet the appetite of editors and Labour politicians who want to see Mandelson's political corpse served up on a plate.

On reflection, I withdraw the sentence with which I began this piece. There's more going on than meets the eye of those who follow only the money. In politics, the agenda is always political. Here, its target is a sizable chunk of Blair.

fields.headline: Fumadores cada vez más jóvenes
fields.standfirst: The EU spends 100 times more to subsidise tobacco firms than on smoking prevention.  Eulàlia Furriol finds out what youngsters think
fields.trailText: The EU spends 100 times more to subsidise tobacco firms than on smoking prevention. Eulàlia Furriol finds out what youngsters think.
fields.body:
Los jóvenes españoles empiezan a fumar cada vez más temprano en España. El veinticinco por ciento de las mujeres de quince a dieciocho años fuma habitualmente. Y una de cada cuatro fumadoras ya tenía adición al tabaco cuando cumplió los catorce años. Entre los hombres de quince a dieciocho años hay un quince por ciento de fumadores. Y uno de cada cinco ya fumaba antes de los catorce años.

La Unión Europea (UE) destina diez millones de euros a prevenir el tabaquismo. Y la misma Unión Europea también destina más de mil millones de euros a subvencionar el cultivo de tabaco. En España el Gobierno declara su interés en hacer campañas contra el tabaco. Pero el Estado español también tiene otros intereses en el tabaco: es el propietario del ochenta por ciento de la empresa que transforma el setenta por ciento de la producción nacional.

Un grupo de alumnos de la escuela Súnion, de Barcelona, se reúnen para hablar de tabaco.

Por qué fuman los jóvenes? Por qué cada vez más pronto? Fumas tú?

Marc Nuez (14 años): Los jóvenes fuman porque fuman los amigos. Yo empecé a fumar el verano pasado. Todos los amigos fumaban y me decían que lo probara. Al final lo probé y me enganché. De momento no me he planteado dejarlo.

Mercè Pardo (14 años): Los jóvenes empiezan a fumar cada vez más pronto por presión social. Fumar queda bien. El que fuma parece mayor, más atractivo y más fuerte. Yo fumo esporádicamente pero puedo vivir sin fumar. Prefiero no engancharme, porque ahora parece atractivo pero después, pasada la adolescencia, es un palo.

Amaya Díaz (14 años): Los más jóvenes ven a los alumnos del curso superior que fuman y ellos también se apuntan. Por eso los fumadores son cada vez más jóvenes. Yo también fumo. El año pasado fumaba mucho porque mis padres me prohibían fumar. Ahora ya no me lo prohiben y fumo menos.

María Sais (12 años): Los jóvenes creen que si fuman son más importantes. Muchos de mis amigos fuman. Yo lo he probado pero no me ha gustado.

La Unión Europea decidió prohibir la publicidad de tabaco a partir del año 2001. Sin embargo, el Tribunal Europeo de Justicia ha anulado esta decisión. Crees que se debería prohibir la publicidad de tabaco?

Marc: La publicidad es engañosa. Venden el tabaco como algo bueno cuando en realidad no lo es, pues el tabaco mata. Pero yo no prohibiría la publicidad de tabaco. Al final la gente si quiere fuma.

Mercè: No. La publicidad influye pero no obliga. La mejor prevención es informar. Si tiene mucha información puede llegar a la conclusión de que no es bueno fumar. De este modo el joven puede escoger. Tampoco se puede pretender convencer a los jóvenes con imposiciones.

Amaya: Yo obligaría a los anunciantes a poner una advertencia de forma muy visible en sus anuncios. La publicidad influye pero si uno no quiere no fuma.

Clara Corbella (14 años): Entonces es como decir: "Compra. El tabaco mata". Las campañas contra el tabaco no sirven para nada. Hay muchas charlas sobre el tema, pero muchos jóvenes dicen: "Yo paso de esto. Fumo porque quiero". Es para ellos un signo de superioridad. La última decisión depende de uno mismo.

La Unión Europea subvenciona al mismo tiempo las campañas contra el tabaquismo y plantaciones de tabaco. Cómo explicas esta contradicción?

Marc: En realidad el Estado no tiene intención de que no fumen los jóvenes. Yo, por ejemplo, tengo catorce años y no tengo problemas para entrar en un estanco y comprar un paquete de cigarrillos. Subir el precio del paquete, como han hecho en Estados Unidos, tampoco sería una solución. Yo pago 310 pesetas por un paquete de tabaco en el estanco. Y por la misma marca los vendedores ambulantes del metro cobran doscientas cincuenta pesetas. Si suben los impuestos iré más a menudo a los pasillos del metro a comprar tabaco ilegal. No conozco el tema muy bien, pero me han dicho que el peligro de fumar no es el tabaco sino los productos que añaden para hacer los cigarrillos, como alquitrán y nicotina. Quizás lo mejor sería no añadir estos productos.

Mercè: Existen muchos intereses económicos. En realidad el Estado no quiere que la gente deje de fumar. Hay muchas personas que hacen dinero con esto. El Estado, por ejemplo, cobra impuestos con la venta del tabaco.

Clara: Yo invertiría más dinero en investigar cómo el tabaco puede ser menos perjudicial para la salud. De este modo la gente podría seguir fumando pero sin hacerse tanto daño.

Glosario/Glossary

apuntarse to join (in)

una charla a discussion, chat

dejarlo to give it up

engancharse to become addicted

un estanco shop with licence to sell tobacco and stamps

es un palo it's a pain

fumar habitualmente to smoke regularly

perjudicial harmful

pretender to try to

queda bien it looks good

webTitle: New England all set for New Zealand

fields.headline: New England all set for New Zealand
fields.standfirst: England's women are getting ready to fly out to New Zealand for the seventh World Cup, which begins on November 29. Tanya Aldred argues that they're better prepared than ever
fields.trailText: Congratulating England's selectors on their squad for a World Cup is not the done thing. A snort or snigger is usually more appropriate. But in the case of England womens final 14, a big round of applause is needed. The selectors have rustled up a side with just that heady mix of youthful talent and hard-nosed experience that their male counterparts have at times found elusive.
fields.body:
Congratulating England's selectors on their squad for a World Cup is not the done thing. A snort or snigger is usually more appropriate. But in the case of England womens final 14, a big round of applause is needed. The selectors have rustled up a side with just that heady mix of youthful talent and hard-nosed experience that their male counterparts have at times found elusive.

Seven of the current squad (Charlotte Edwards, Barbara Daniels, Jane Cassar, Melissa Reynard, Kathryn Leng, Clare Connor and Clare Taylor) played in Englands last World Cup game - the semi-final against New Zealand at Chennai on Boxing Day 1997, which they lost by 20 runs. But the team should look very different this time. They are considerably fitter and better prepared. They are also fully aware of what they are letting themselves in for: they didnt win a game in Australia and New Zealand last winter.

Gone are the lumberers, the Ian Austinettes who didnt look so much pie-throwers, as pie-eaters. The squad has an average age of 24, which includes three teenagers. (The England mens World Cup squad of 1999 had an average age of 30.) Englands fielding, so outclassed when Australia were here in 1998, and at times last winter, should no longer be an embarrassment.

England will be relying on their pace attack of Lucy Pearson and Clare Taylor to make early breakthroughs on the slow, low wickets of New Zealand. But they will also need their batsman to perform with more pizzazz than they did last winter - not a difficult proposition. Their confidence was shot to pieces after that tour but intensive coaching and a relatively successful summer under the captaincy of Clare Connor has fostered a more confident spirit within the squad. And Barbara Daniels and Charlotte Edwards, the team talismans, rediscovered their form against South Africa.

The unlucky four from the provisional squad of 18, who will be spending their winter glued to the web or spitting tacks, are Leanne Davis, Jackie Hawker, Laura Newton and Laura Spragg.

England squad in full
Clare Connor (captain), Melissa Reynard (vice-captain), Jane Cassar (wicket-keeper), Sarah Collyer, Barbara Daniels, Charlotte Edwards, Laura Harper, Dawn Holden, Kathryn Leng, Lucy Pearson, Nicki Shaw, Claire Taylor, Clare Taylor, Arran Thompson

Tanya Aldred is assistant editor of Wisden Cricket Monthly. To read her previous column, in which Lucy Pearson says England can win the World Cup, click here

webTitle: Addison Lee sets up dot.com delivery service

fields.headline: Addison Lee sets up dot.com delivery service
fields.trailText: 8.45am: The courier firm Addison Lee has set up a new service to handle dot.com deliveries, writes Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
The courier firm Addison Lee has set up a dot.com delivery service, Addison Lee Fulfilment, only days after Urbanfetch.com and BagsofTime.com were forced to shut up shop.

ALF has teamed up with M-box, the fulfilment company that works with Express Dairies, Parcelforce, Spar and Costcutter, to be the remaining piece of M-Box's national delivery network.

M-box has built up a network of existing fulfilment companies and has begun trials with "a dot.com, a retailer and a manufacturer".. Trials are expected to extend over Christmas with the full-blown commercial services expected to go live in the new year.

Addison Lee has a network of 550 vehicles - one of the UK's largest courier fleets - and handles more than 45,000 transactions each week.

Liam Griffin, general manager at Addison Lee, said: "We're keen to explore the opportunities offered by the internet. It's no secret that there are scores of e-commerce websites out there which need to be backed up by fast and reliable delivery. Together with M-box, we believe Addison Lee is in a good position to explore these opportunities and play its part in the e-commerce revolution."

fields.headline: Charles 'should have married black woman'
fields.trailText: The Prince of Wales should have been told to marry a black woman, according to the vice-chairwoman of the commission that produced last week's controversial report on race in Britain.
fields.body:
The Prince of Wales should have been told to marry a black woman, according to the vice-chairwoman of the commission that produced last week's controversial report on race in Britain.

Lady Gavron, of the Runnymede Trust, a race relations think tank, said: "It would have been great if Prince Charles had been told to marry someone black. Imagine what message that would have sent out."

She said that the royal family sent out the wrong message about Britain: "They're a symbol of our unmeritocratic tendency and, of course, they're all white. It is part of a very unattractive hierarchy"

She added: "Anything hereditary is completely anachronistic and illogical: you wouldn't have an hereditary cricket team."

The Runnymede Trust says it has received hate mail and racist telephone calls since the report on the future of multi-ethnic Britain was published last week. The report was criticised for suggesting the term British should be dropped because it is overlain with "racial overtones".

But Lady Gavron, wife of publisher and Labour Party backer Lord Gavron, insisted she was still proud to be British.

"Lots of people are proud to be British, but what we were trying to say is that there are some people who don't want other people to be British and that's racist" she said.

webTitle: Not quite news: Crying over spilt milk

fields.headline: Crying over spilt milk
fields.standfirst: Toxic milk, wild parrots and long lost library books
fields.trailText: Toxic milk, wild parrots and long lost library books.
fields.body:
No use crying
A chemical alert in Colne, Lancashire, gave police plenty to laugh about when the white liquid leaking from an unmarked container turned out to be nothing more toxic than milk.

An anonymous caller rang the police to say chemicals were leaking out of a plastic container, not knowing the true contents. Police immediately called out the fire brigade to deal with the suspected chemical leak.

Shopkeepers watched on in amusement as a full emergency response unfolded in front of their eyes. David Richard, manager of Whitesides Butchers, said: "When it dropped off the trailer everyone in the shop saw it and knowing it was milk we were laughing and saying 'Quick get a bucket and fill it up'."

Station Officer David Gilligan arrived with two fire engines to witness a scene of milk and mirth. Mr Gilligan said: "They had found out that the 'chemical' was milk so I immediately called off the incident support unit which had been summoned from Accrington - but a paramedic ambulance still turned up."

The farmer responsible was issued with a fixed penalty notice.
Colne Times

The great escape
Police are urging members of the public to be on the lookout for a flock of exotic birds after two parrots escaped from their owners' houses in north Shropshire.

They are worried that a colony of parrots will breed in the wild from the African greys who fled their roosts in Wem and Whixhall within a week of each other.

"We are concerned that if we don't catch them quickly enough we might have a colony of parrots living wild in the Wem area," said Inspector Martin Whitelegg.

Meanwhile an exotic looking green parrot has turned up in a garden in nearby Market Drayton.

"I couldn't believe my eyes," said shocked Teresa Thomas-Boakes.

"I looked out of the window and a green bird was feeding in my garden."
Shropshire Star

The longest loan
Staff at a Newcastle library were relieved when a book amnesty brought in several long lost volumes.

The first, however, was the longest and most lost of all - it had been on loan for over 33 years.

The book - entitled Early Public Libraries - disappeared from the shelves at Byker library in February 1967. That branch closed while the book was on loan so the mystery reader returned it to the replacement East End library.

In normal circumstances there would have been a £722.70 fine to pay.

"In some cases people just forget to bring books back," said Library information manager June Biggins.

"Or it gets to a stage when fines mount up and they can no longer afford to pay them or are too embarrassed to bring them back."
Herald and Post

Letter of the week
While driving along Ashmeads in Chalford I noticed a rather large black animal sitting in the middle of the road. This was from approximately 50/60 metres away and all I thought of at the time was that this animal had better move by the time I get to it. When I was about 20 metres away I began thinking that this animal was neither a cat nor a dog because of its sheer size and stature.

It was at this point that the animal leapt on to the steep bank in one clean move and quickly disappeared into the woods. It was rather a quick move, but as it made its escape, I noticed a long, curved, smooth-ended tail which convinced me that what I had seen was a big, black wild cat!

There was a house opposite, Ashmeads House, and I actually spoke to the man who was house-sitting for his father. I initially asked him if there were any big, black dogs in his house or indeed in the local area. He told me that his father's dogs were in kennels that week, and that he wasn't aware of any other dogs nearby. He seemed rather surprised when I told him what I had seen but hopefully he believed me.

I am interested to know if anyone else has spotted a black cat in the area opposite Oak Hill Wood. I would love to hear from anyone who can solve the mystery!
Claire Banks, Stroud
Gloucestershire Echo

webTitle: French politics: When will Tiberi spill the beans?

fields.headline: When will Tiberi spill the beans?
fields.standfirst: The embattled Paris mayor is now a fearsome loose cannon in French politics, writes Jon Henley in Paris
fields.trailText: The embattled Paris mayor is now a fearsome loose cannon in French politics, writes Jon Henley in Paris.
fields.body:
How many beans does Jean Tiberi have, and when will he decide to spill them? The embattled mayor of Paris, kicked out of his party last week for rejecting its decision to appoint a new candidate for the 2001 local elections, is now a fearsome loose cannon in French politics.

Few would make any great claims of originality or vision for the diminutive grey-haired Corsican, a Gaullist RPR (Rassemblement pour la République) party militant since practically the first hour and Jacques Chirac's loyal lieutenant at Paris town hall during the 18 years the president spent there as mayor.

Handpicked by Chirac to succeed him after the 1995 presidential poll, Tiberi has proved a competent if uninspired mayor, getting things done in the capital with energy and commitment but lacking the stature - both physical and ideological - that Parisians would like to see in their civic leader.

Inevitably, Tiberi has also got himself caught up in a few corruption scandals. He came under fire for allowing his children to occupy big council-owned apartments in chic Left Bank streets for knock-down rents. His son, once employed by Air France, was paid a million francs by the airline over three years while he was acting as a ministerial aid.

Tiberi's wife faces a retrial over a now infamous 36-page report that she wrote for one of her husband's close RPR allies in a Gaullist-run local council outside Paris. Xavière Tiberi was paid £20,000 for the report, which turned out to be stuffed with spelling mistakes and largely copied from a textbook.

And Jean Tiberi himself, a judge confirmed last week, remains very much under investigation in the so-called HLM, or council-housing, scandal - part of the vast and many tentacled corporate kickback scam by which Chirac's RPR party funded itself back in the 80s and early 90s and which now threatens to engulf the president himself.

It would have been more or less impossible for Tiberi - a man of whom Chirac once reportedly said "would jump through a window if I asked him" - not to have been aware of what exactly was going on at Paris town hall during the years it was turned into an RPR machine that catapulted Chirac into the presidency of the Republic.

Maybe the RPR party should have borne that in mind when it decided that - with the Socialists showing every sign of being in a position to win the capital for the left for the first time since the Paris Commune - it needed a rather more heavyweight candidate for the March 2001 mayoral race.

The man it eventually chose was Philippe Séguin, a former party chairman and portly RPR grandee who is currently running neck and neck in the polls with the Socialist candidate, a hardworking local councillor called Bertrand Delanoë who was one of the first French politicians of any standing to admit he was homosexual.

But the RPR has not treated Tiberi very kindly. Indeed, he would contend that it has treated him downright shabbily. At an extraordinary Paris branch meeting last week he was voted out of the party of which he has been a member since it was founded 25 years ago, and denied any central support in the re-election campaign he is still determined to run.

"I am being made a scapegoat, and I am not happy about that," he said after the meeting. "I am surprised, saddened, hurt and disgusted. At my age, after all I have done for this party and for Paris, the way the RPR party has treated me is completely and utterly unacceptable. This is more, far more, than treachery."

As long ago as 1997, Tiberi's wife was wondering in her private diary for how much longer she and her husband would be expected to take the flak for President Chirac and his RPR prime minister of the time, Alain Juppé, over past goings-on at Paris town hall.

Now, Tiberi himself has more than sufficient motive for telling his story. He is already threatening to do so, and unless his silence is bought by an RPR party that comes to its senses and realises what a danger the mayor of Paris really is, he seems perfectly ready to fire the first shot.

"I will not give in," he said last Friday. "It is a question of politics but above and beyond that, of honour. I have things to say. And if, one day, rightly or wrongly, I say them, I will not disguise them. I will not imply, I will state. My friends in the RPR should remember that..."

webTitle: T-Online in £4.5m Tennis Masters sponsorship deal

fields.headline: T-Online in £4.5m Tennis Masters sponsorship deal
fields.trailText: 11.45am: T-Online is to sponsor the ATP Tour's Tennis Masters Series in a deal worth DM16m (£4.5m) a year, writes Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
German internet giant T-Online is to sponsor the ATP Tour's Tennis Masters Series in a deal worth DM16m (£4.5m) a year.

T-Online will pay DM4m to sponsor the three remaining events in the 2000 series, before making a final decision on whether to sign a three-year sponsorship deal.

Under the terms of the deal, T-Online will operate the German site for the ATP Tour, while the T-Online portal will get a live feed of scores and other features from the Masters Series site.

A spokesman for Deutsche Telekom, T-Online's parent, refused to give further details.

The deal was negotiated by Swiss marketing firm ISL Worldwide, which last year agreed to pay $1.2bn (£0.78bn) for the 10-year marketing, broadcast and licensing rights to the Masters Series and online and other rights to the ATP Tour.

The Masters Series, a nine-tournament series of men's tennis played around the world, is the ATP Tour's most prestigious event.

fields.headline: Rumours Unlimited
fields.standfirst: All today's gossip plunged into a blind trust to avoid compromising situations
fields.trailText: Alan Shearer is being lined up to be England's next manager but one, reports the Mirror. The paper claims that Howard Wilkinson wants Shearer to work in harness with the next England manager so that he can take over in two seasons time.
fields.body:
Alan Shearer is being lined up to be England's next manager but one, reports the Mirror. The paper claims that Howard Wilkinson wants Shearer to work in harness with the next England manager so that he can take over in two seasons time.

But who will be the actual next England manager? Sven-Goran Eriksson perhaps? Not according to the Daily Mail, who quote the Lazio manager as saying: "I've never thought about coaching an international side because I've never had an offer. If an offer comes, I'll think about it. But I don't know what England need because I haven't looked into their problems."

Meanwhile Gianluca Vialli could be set for a shock return to football - with Nottingham Forest. The Mirror reports that Vialli's close friend David Platt wants Vialli to join the backroom staff at the City Ground and also resurrect his playing career.

Arsene Wenger has played down the rumours linking Arsenal with a £20m move for Juventus midfielder Edgar Davids. "We have some money in the club at Arsenal, but not that much," said Wenger.

But Arsenal are likely to sign the Georgian international defender Zurab Khizanishvili, according to onefootball.com. They quote the 19-year-old centre-half, who says: "Arsenal contacted Lokomotiv last week. I heard that Arsene Wenger watched the Italy v Georgia game in Ancona and then invited me to come to England. This is a great honour for me."

Christian Panucci has been released by Chelsea, the Daily Mail reports. They claim the Italian international, originally signed on loan from Internazionale until the end of the season, will fly home immediately. However the Mirror reckons Panucci is keen to stay in England.

Aston Villa have accepted Middlesbrough's £7.5m bid for Ugo Ehiogu, according to the Daily Mail. And Ehiogu could be joined by Zvonimir Boban. Planet Football suggests, however, that the 32-year-old Milan playmaker - who has already turned down a move to Chelsea - wants to return to his beloved Croatia.

Where will Manchester City reject (and world footballer of the year) George Weah go next? The Daily Mail reckons Bologna have already shown an interest, while onefootball believe that Marseille or Major League Soccer are more likely destinations.

Crystal Palace will complete the signing of £1.5m-rated Latvian striker Andrejs Rubins later today, onefootball reports.

Newcastle are lining up a move for Barnsley's Darren Barnard. The Daily Star says that Bobby Robson was at Oakwell this weekend to check on the 28-year-old Welsh international, and left impressed.

Preston are hoping to take Liverpool reserve striker Erik Meijer on loan to ease their mounting injury problems.

Celtic striker Mark Burchill is ready to make his loan move to Birmingham City permanent, says Teamtalk. "More than likely, I am here to stay if the manager wants me. That is the intention," says Burchill.

Alan Cork has replaced Bobby Gould as manager of Cardiff. Owner Sam Hammam said: "Alan is the Field Marshall and Bobby is the Minister for Football. Alan will be responsible for picking the first team, while Bobby will be responsible for all other aspects of the club."

webTitle: Queen and Pope back closer church links

fields.headline: Queen and Pope back closer church links
fields.trailText: The Queen and Pope John Paul II have met in private at the Vatican today and backed moves to bring the Anglican and Catholic churches closer together. They also discussed the troubles in Northern Ireland and Third World debt relief.
fields.body:
The Queen and Pope John Paul II have met in private at the Vatican today and backed moves to bring the Anglican and Catholic churches closer together. They also discussed the troubles in Northern Ireland and Third World debt relief.

The 24-minute talk between the two forms the centrepiece of the Queen's four-day state visit to Italy and is the first time they had met since the Pope's visit to Britain in 1982.

Since then, little progress has been made towards unifying the different Christian traditions, although both hold it as an ambition. The two leaders had prepared speeches on the subject, but rather than read them they handed the texts to each other when they met in the Vatican library.

"I trust we shall continue to advance along the path which leads to Christian unity," the Queen's speech said. For his part, the Pope assured the Queen that "there can be no turning back from the ecumenical goal."

The Queen also stressed progress made toward peace in Northern Ireland in the conflict involving Roman Catholics and Protestants. "We are most grateful for your help and support for this process," she said.

The 80-year-old Pope appeared physically frail, albeit mentally alert, and at times the Queen seemed concerned for his health. She observed Vatican protocol and wore black with a veil. But, in a concession, she wore a three-quarter-length skirt and jacket rather than a full-length dress.

The Queen also stressed progress made toward peace in Northern Ireland in the conflict involving Roman Catholics and Protestants. "We are most grateful for your help and support for this process," she said. The 80-year-old Pope appeared physically frail, albeit mentally alert, and at times the Queen seemed concerned for his health. She observed Vatican protocol and wore black with a veil. But, in a concession, she wore a three-quarter-length skirt and jacket rather than a full-length dress.

webTitle: Queen and Pope will speak out for Ulster peace

fields.headline: Queen and Pope will speak out for Ulster peace
fields.trailText: The Queen and the Pope are expected to make an historic declaration in support of the Northern Ireland peace process when they meet in the Vatican today.
fields.body:
The Queen and the Pope are expected to make an historic declaration in support of the Northern Ireland peace process when they meet in the Vatican today.

Senior diplomats in Rome expect the 30-minute private meeting to result in an attempt to bolster the Good Friday agreement and reinforce the search for peace in the province. They are also expected to discuss progress towards Christian unity between the Protestant and Catholic churches.

Pope John Paul II heads the church to which almost all nationalists and republicans in Ireland at least nominally belong, and the declaration is thought likely to go further than the normal exchange of diplomatic pleasantries between heads of state.

A British Vatican diplomat said: "The Pope has been very supportive and helpful without being too triumphalist. The Vatican has been sensitive to Unionist opinion."

The Queen arrived in Rome last night for her four-day state visit, accompanied at some distance by up to 3,000 Arsenal supporters - dubbed hooligans by the Italian press - for tonight's Champion's League second round match with the local club Lazio.

The royal British Airways chartered flight arrived hours before the soccer fans at Rome's Ciampino Airport, and to a rather warmer welcome.

But her dresses, in 10 garment bags labelled "the Queen", were dropped by two airport porters, sliding to the ground from a hanging rail.

She will attend a banquet at the British ambassador's residence tonight.

The royal party was escorted by a mounted cavalry procession to the Quirinale palace where the Queen and Duke of Edinburgh are staying as guests of 79-year-old Italian president, Carlo Azeglio Ciampi and his wife Franca. Security surrounding the visit has been stepped up as a result of the Middle East crisis.

Speculation about the visit has been intense in the Italian media. But only a few hundred gathered in the twilight outside the palace last night to wave plastic union flags as the Queen's convoy swept through.

The Italian press has been speculating for days not only about the royal dress sense - a slightly dowdy, pale peach outfit and brown hat to review the presidential guard at the palace yesterday - and about the Queen's taste in food (no garlic or long strands of spaghetti) but also about who would receive an invitation to last night's presidential banquet at the Quirinale.

La Repubblica said yesterday it was a pity that the flamboyant Oscar-winning film actor Roberto Benigni, star of Life is Beautiful, had declined an invitation: "It is such a shame because if he had grabbed the Queen in a hug he would surely have created a stir and made world headlines."

Another newspaper, Il Tempo, produced a heavily manipulated photograph showing the Queen apparently in the process of hugging the Duke of Edinburgh and noted that for her visit to Milan later in the week, she will be staying in the same £4,000 a night hotel suite occupied last year by Phil Collins and George Clooney. The Italian government will be footing that bill.

Corriere della Sera more soberly noted: "If anyone finds the Queen cold with few compliments for Bel Paese and its inhabitants, try to be understanding. Her Majesty is working and has not come here on holiday."

Indeed she is, paying her third visit to Italy as a means of celebrating ties between the two countries, in business where trade is worth £18bn a year and in defence where both countries have cooperated over Kosovo.

The Vatican meeting will be the Queen's third encounter with the Pope, but her first since his visit to Britain 18 years ago. The Queen also met Pope John XXIII during a visit in 1961 and as Princess Elizabeth in 1951, Pius XII, now forever tarred for his wartime neutrality. Her Majesty is said to have told her advisers: "I have met a lot of popes in my time."

webTitle: BBC claims Radio Times most profitable magazine

fields.headline: BBC claims Radio Times is Britain's most profitable magazine
fields.trailText: The Radio Times is Britain's most profitable magazine, according to the BBC, reports Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
The Radio Times, which this week celebrates its 4,000th issue, is Britain's most profitable magazine, according to the BBC.

BBC Worldwide says that in 1999 it generated £32.6m from advertising and £56m from its cover price. The magazine sold 1.25m copies according to the last ABCs.

Radio Times's birthday coincides with unprecedented competition in the TV listings sector. Although the magazine is still the second best-selling magazine in the UK, it faces competition from newcomers such as H Bauer's TV Choice - launched this year.

In the latest ABCs, Radio Times was outsold by IPC Media's What's on TV, which sold 1.7m copies. Radio Times has seen a 10% decline in circulation since the 1999 ABCs, when it sold 1.39m copies.

TV listings magazines are scrambing to establish their brands on new digital TV and online platforms. Radio Times last month announced a joint branding deal with personal video recorder manufacturer TiVo, which will give its brand prominence on the platform and allow it to point viewers towards BBC programmes.

IPC is understood to be talking to a number of digital television manufacturers.

fields.headline: Témoin - Olympics
fields.standfirst: Benjamin Varonian, gymnast, describes winning a silver medal at the Sydney Olympics
fields.trailText: Benjamin Varonian, gymnast, describes winning a silver medal at the Sydney Olympics
fields.body:
Je n'arrive toujours pas à y croire: moi, champion olympique ? C'est un rêve qui devient réalité. Après la satisfaction d'avoir été sélectionné, je ne m'attendais pas à un tel exploit ! Mon but était de faire une bonne compète, de vivre un moment extraordinaire et de pouvoir dire: j'y étais.

Le plus dur dans une compétition de cette envergure, c'est de se qualifier pour la finale. Même si je n'avais pas eu de médaille, j'aurais été content et fier de moi.

Avant l'épreuve, j'essayais de me calmer et de parler d'autre chose, histoire de détendre l'atmosphère. Lorsque je me suis présenté, j'avais l'impression d'être paralysé. Et puis, je ne sais pas comment, j'ai exécuté, sans fautes, mes enchaînements. J'étais soulagé d'avoir réussi. En attendant ma note, j'étais anxieux, excité: 9,787. Je me suis dit : C'est gagné . J'allais devenir champion olympique !

Sur le podium, j'étais très ému, avec la foule qui m'applaudissait et le drapeau français qui s'élevait. Jamais je n'oublierai ce moment. Depuis, je n'ai toujours pas remis les pieds sur terre !

Cette médaille, c'est LA consécration. Elle récompense dix années d'investissement personnel et d'efforts, des milliers d'heures de travail, de galères, de peines et de joies.

Depuis ma victoire, je suis assailli par les journalistes. Je suis la star du moment. . . et j'adore ça. Mais je reste lucide. Je me suis fait un nom, et ce sera grâce à beaucoup de travail et de rigueur que je demeurerai en tête d'affiche.

webTitle: Two Fat Ladies, Clarissa Dickson Wright in the country

fields.headline: Out of the frying pan...
fields.standfirst: The surviving half of the Two Fat Ladies, Clarissa Dickson Wright, has left the kitchen to explore another of her passions on TV: the countryside. She tells Hadley Freeman  how she and her friend Sir John Scott plan to change our view of rural Britain
fields.trailText: The surviving half of the Two Fat Ladies, Clarissa Dickson Wright, has left the kitchen to explore another of her passions on TV: the countryside. She tells Hadley Freeman how she and her friend Sir John Scott plan to change our view of rural Britain.
fields.body:
The atrium of this London hotel is polished and very, very smooth. It is filled with loud American accents and businessmen in suits. The packs of pinstripes part to reveal, arm in arm, a brown-haired woman with a voluminous skirt and a middle-aged man in brown cords and a tweed jacket.

She is Clarissa Dickson Wright - surviving half of the Two Fat Ladies, rector of Aberdeen University, columnist for the Scotland on Sunday, owner of two cafes and one bookshop, former barrister, recovered alcoholic and now television champion for rural Britain. He is Sir John Scott, a hill farmer from Scotland, and her childhood friend. Angered by what she calls "the un-believable ignorance most people in this country have about the countryside," they have filmed a TV series presenting their view of real rural Britain.

"When it comes to the countryside on television," says Clarissa, getting into her familiarly strident mode, "it's all this stultifying sentiment. Those endless Pet Rescue programmes, and things like that. I know a cameraman who worked on one of those programmes and he was describing this bit when a hedgehog was being chased and they rolled the hedgehog down the slope ten times to get the shot. The hedgehog then died and they had to bring in a substitute hedgehog, and this is meant to be 'Oh isn't this sweet.'"

Clarissa and the Countryman is a picaresque tour of the British Isles, with Dickson Wright and Scott celebrating aspects of rural life from wildfowling in Norfolk to coursing in the Lancashire marshes. Clarissa, a self-described townie, who lives in the small Scottish town Musselborough, and Sir John ("Johnny" to Clarissa, she is "Clarrie" to him) are unequivocal about the intentions and importance of the programme. "There has been nothing on television about the countryside since the early 70s, when media attention became entirely urban orientated," says Johnny. "The gulf [between the urban and the rural] then grew and the politicians started to use it to their advantage."

For too long, the British countryside has been presented either as "full of toffs getting their rocks off", as Clarissa puts it, or hopelessly backward - a tedious dichotomy between To the Manor Born and Cold Comfort Farm. More importantly, the difficulties facing the rural community today are very real. Scott's lambs, for example, are bought from him for £10 each, fattened up and sold for £14 a kilo in the supermarkets. Whether Dickson Wright and Scott's venture will rectify matters, though, is questionable.

In Two Fat Ladies, Clarissa and Jennifer Paterson, who died last year, were as much an anomaly on television themselves as their creamy heavy cooking was at the end of the last decade. Their deep-fried dollop of plain-speaking common sense, harked back to a pre-low fat, pre-stylised, airheaded celebrity age - and who could resist that? More than four million people watched it in the UK, almost 70m worldwide. Understandably, the BBC has stuck to a familiar formula with Clarissa's new series: once again, we see Clarissa plus friend making unusual stops around Britain, presenting a very traditional view of the country. But she is impatient with such comparisons.

"Well, apart from the fact that one was going out and getting wet and wearing different clothes, this is totally different," she says, with a particularly stentorian intonation. "Also, Johnny and I have real friendship."

"But weren't you friends with Jen..." I am not even allowed to finish the question. "No, that was invented for television. We were like the Spice Girls. It was a very amiable working partnership, but it wasn't friendship."

Indeed, that pairing always seemed based on a shared body-size and mutual love of cooking. Clarissa always came across as the saner sidekick to Jennifer's verbal wanderings, full of rolling r's and sudden increases in volume ("Pour HALF a pint of CREAM in ...")

Johnny and Clarissa have a very real friendship. They finish one another's anecdotes and look into each other's eyes. "The thing about Clarrie," he says, looking at her across the table, "is that she has the unique ability to squeeze every drop of pleasure out of the day, and ensures that everyone around her enjoys it as much as she does." She looks down at the tablecloth, smiling. Later, when the photographer asks them to pose near a large plant in the lobby, they swat each other with the leaves and make shadow animals on the wall.

The forthrightness of Dickson Wright can be a joy. When asked which programme she enjoyed making more, her unhesitating answer is, "This one," a reply devoid of any bland PR tact. She recently took Jamie Oliver to task for advertising Sainsbury's without shopping at the supermarket himself. "We all know now he did it just for a handful of silver, don't we?" she grins. Johnny is equally forthright. For example, what does he think of vegetarians? He smiles slyly. "Very sad." They both laugh delightedly. The American businessman at the table next to us picks nervously at his melon.

But such frankness can work against them. Few people are so vehemently pro low-fat cooking that they would be offended by Clarissa's cooking, but many have stronger views on the subject of hunting and bloodsports. She claims to be unconcerned. "Well, if the BBC get cold feet over this, Discovery, ABC or somebody else would probably recommission it."

Clarissa's pro-hunting views are well known, and have already been criticised. In their book, which accompanies the series, Johnny describes a protestor shouting at Clarissa: "One fat lady's dead. One to go." So are they prepared for more inevitable criticism when the series is aired? "I think what we're doing is too important for personal worries to intervene," she says with a breezy wave. "But, yes, I am fully prepared."

Clarissa and Johnny repeatedly insist that all they want is "tolerance", but any questioning or criticism of their views is dismissed as "townie ignorance". She describes how one original member of the television crew was sacked "because she had a fixed set of ideas. They weren't exactly anti ideas but they weren't how it was, and she kept putting everybody's backs up."

In reference to the government's anti-hunting leanings, they are particularly vehement. One of her favourite references, disconcertingly, is to Adolf Hitler: "Hitler was the last man to ban fox hunting, it was the first thing he did when he came to power," Clarissa says, with an emphatic tap on the table. "It was about regulating something he didn't understand. OK, his second act was a little more serious, but this government is messing with things they don't understand and don't want to because they are paid not to." (Clarissa and Sir John argue that the £1.1m donation from the International Fund for Animal Liberation to the Labour government is "payment for legislation".)

At the end of the interview the recorder is turned off and both relax. Picking up on my accent, they talk briefly about Americans:"We met a lot of Americans in our travels who described hunting as their idea of Heaven. Wonderful people." After a warm peck from Clarissa and a gentlemanly handshake from Johnny, Clarissa lowers her chin and raises her eyebrows imperiously at me. "Be fair," she calls out, in a matronly tone of voice. "That's all we ask, you know."

fields.headline: Communists make a comeback
fields.standfirst: The successor to East Germany's ruling party has a new leadership team - and one more committed to reform than anyone had grounds to expect, writes John Hooper in Berlin
fields.trailText: The successor to East Germany's ruling party has a new leadership team - and one more committed to reform than anyone had grounds to expect, writes John Hooper in Berlin.
fields.body:
Six months ago, the Party of Democratic Socialism (PDS) seemed destined for the scrap heap of history. Andre Brie, one of its most influential thinkers, was close to despair. The party, he declared, was in "deep crisis".

The PDS, which emerged from the wreckage of East Germany's communist party, had just learned that the man most responsible for giving it a role in the politics of post-reunification Germany was leaving his post in disgust. Gregor Gysi, an eloquent, charismatic lawyer who led the PDS in parliament, threw in the towel last April after losing the latest in a string of bruising encounters with Marxist hardliners.

Though not overall head of his party, Mr Gysi was its media star and seemed to represent a communism that had learned from the mistakes of the past. His departure thus not only robbed the PDS of a vote-winning personality, but also appeared to condemn it to electoral suicide.

Mr Gysi announced he was going after trying and failing to get the party to change its policy of opposing all UN-led military missions. Soon afterwards, the PDS's leader, Lothar Bisky, let it be known that he too was stepping down.

After a party conference in the eastern city of Cottbus last weekend, things look very different. Without the bitter struggle many had feared, the PDS has given itself a new leadership team, and one more committed to reform than anyone had grounds to expect six months ago.

Gabrielle Zimmer, the 45-year-old former interpreter chosen to replace Mr Bisky at the top, is even on record as saying that she never considered herself a true communist. Both Ms Zimmer and Roland Claus, also 45, who had earlier been elected head of the parliamentary party, have stressed that their aim will be to draw the PDS closer to the mainstream.

The party they lead matters for several reasons. Germany's proportional representation system gives considerable weight to smaller groups, provided they can get over the five per cent hurdle set for representation in the federal lower house. The Greens, who are the junior partners in the present federal coalition government, and the liberal Free Democrats, who were the junior partners in the last one, both fall into this category, along with the PDS which managed 5.1 per cent at the last general election in 1998.

Moreover, Germany's highly decentralised administration means that parties with geographically concentrated support can wield great power through the country's mighty regional administrations. And since the regional administrations decide the composition of the Bundesrat, the federal upper house, regional power in Germany translates directly into national influence.

The Christian Social Union (CSU), Bavaria's Christian Democratic movement, is a case in point. It has more than half the vote in its home region and, in the past, it has exerted a decisive influence on federal administrations led by the right.

fields.headline: Surfcontrol's revenues soar
fields.trailText: 11.15am: The internet software company, Surfcontrol, reported revenues well ahead of expectations today, writes Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
The internet software company, Surfcontrol, got the thumbs up from analysts this morning when it reported revenues well ahead of expectations.

Surfcontrol said it was confident of a successful year, despite first quarter losses of almost £13m.

The firm, whose filtering software helps companies block employees' access to porn, gambling and other internet distractions, reported revenues of $6.7m (£4.5m), up from $2.3m (£1.5m) last year. Pre-tax losses rose to $19.4m (£12.7m), up from $1.4m (£900,000).

Revenues in the crucial internet access control division grew by 49% to $5.8m (£3.8m).

The company is continuing to invest heavily in sales and distribution and product development continues across the board, particularly across new platforms such as mobile telephones, Windows 2000, Unix and Linux.

Surfcontrol's chief executive, Steve Purdham, said: "Strong demand, expansion into new geographical markets and our focus on taking our products to the relevant markets in a timely manner, have resulted in a performance that has exceeded our high expectations."

fields.headline: ONdigital subscriber numbers rise 13%
fields.trailText: 10am: Digital terrestrial pay-TV operator ONdigital has increased its subscriber numbers by 104,000 or 13%, writes Jason Deans.
fields.body:
Digital terrestrial pay-TV operator ONdigital increased its subscriber numbers by 104,000 - or 13% - in the third quarter of 2000 and had 878,000 customers by the end of the September.

By October 16, the Carlton/Granada joint venture had 896,000 subscribers. In the previous quarter, May-June, ONdigital's subscriber numbers increased by 101,000 - or around 15% - to 774,000.

ONdigital also reported that 20,000 customers had signed up to its ONnet internet portal in the first two weeks since it launched on September 18. In that time, ONnet users made more than 12m ad impressions and a further 17 brands, including beeb.com and Radio Times have joined the portal.

Stuart Prebble, ONdigital's chief executive, said: "In less than two years we have built a business with close to a million customers. We've more than doubled our subscriber numbers in the last year and we believe we are in good shape to continue strong growth in the all-important last quarter of 2000."

fields.headline: Forgan reveals BBC news move fiasco
fields.standfirst: Why I quit by Liz Forgan
fields.trailText:
9.45am: The former BBC radio boss, Liz Forgan, has branded the decision to move the Today programme out of central London as a waste of licence payers' money, writes Lisa O'Carroll.
Why I quit by Liz Forgan
fields.body:
The former BBC radio boss, Liz Forgan, has branded the £41m decision to move the flagship Today programme out of central London as a waste of licence payers' money.

Speaking for the first time about her decision to quit the BBC, Ms Forgan reveals how hard she battled to stop the move of BBC radio journalists from their historic home in Broadcasting House to new White City offices.

She says the west London stage six was a "mad place" for the Radio 4 Today programme. And she says claims, made at the time, that the move would save the BBC up to £10.5m a year were "unbelievable".

She describes a crunch meeting of the board of governors in which she and the BBC news chief executive, Tony Hall, clashed directly. Hall claimed the move was vital and would strengthen the BBC's journalism. "I said it was inimical to pluralism and the integrity of each radio station's distinctive sound, that White City was a mad place to site the Today programme.It was also obvious - even before a brick was laid - that the site was far too small," Ms Forgan said.

The former managing director of network radio had a distinguished career at the BBC and was considered a front runner as a future director general.

She had the whole-hearted support of journalists who were bitterly opposed to the move to west London. The Today presenters, John Humphrys and James Naughtie, complained they would not be able to persuade senior politicians to make the trek to White City.

In an extraordinary revelation, Ms Forgan describes how Hall and John Birt, then BBC director general, kept the budgets and figures relating to the move secret.

Ultimately, she said, the board of governors was put in an impossible decision. The move became a symbol of corporate purpose with Birt and Hall digging in their heels as the opposition to their plans grew.

"Faced with the insistence of their director general, the whole thing had become an issue of confidence. It was a choice between losing a managing director and losing a director general," she says.

"Having lost the argument, I had no alternative but to resign," she adds.

Five years on, BBC bosses are admitting their mistake and considering switching radio journalists back to Broadcasting House. Ms Forgan says she takes "disappointingly little pleasure" in reading reports that vindicate her stance.

She adds: "I am afraid that no one will ever take responsibility for this wasteful corporate mistake. And they ought to."

webTitle: ITV launches one-off Nine O'Clock news

fields.headline: ITV launches one-off Nine O'Clock news
fields.trailText: ITV tonight launched a one-off Nine O'Clock news just 24 hours after the BBC switched its flagship bulletin to 10pm writes Lisa O'Carroll.
fields.body:
ITV tonight seized the opportunity for another attack on the BBC by launching a one-off Nine O'Clock news just 24 hours after the corporation switched its flagship bulletin to 10pm.

News chiefs at ITV decided to go ahead with the ten minute bulletin mid-afternoon to cover the rail crash in Hertfordshire.

One executive said ITV bosses were determined to do everything in their power to kill off the BBC's Ten O'Clock News.

"There was an opportunity here to demonstrate how responsive we can be. This is one in the eye for the BBC," said one.

webTitle: The TV renaissance of Peter Bogdanovich

fields.headline: Orson Welles was his lodger, his movies were classics - so how did Peter Bogdanovich end up in The Sopranos?
fields.standfirst: Jason Kerrigan  on a tale of murder, bankruptcy and a fatal dose of pride
fields.trailText: Jason Kerrigan on a tale of murder, bankruptcy and a fatal dose of pride.
fields.body:
In his prime during the 1970s, Peter Bogdanovich felt that The Godfather and Chinatown were directing assignments he could refuse, Cybill Shepherd was the lover for whom he should abandon his wife and newborn child, and only time seemed to separate him from legendary status in Hollywood. But then he fell. "I felt that by the mid-70s I'd blown it," says Bogdanovich, now 61, sitting in a deserted Thai restaurant on Manhattan's Upper West Side. "William Friedkin had blown it, Robert Altman went into eclipse, one flop after another, Coppola went crazy, even Raging Bull didn't do any business. Everybody kind of blew it in varying shapes and sizes."

Since those glory days, the acclaimed director of The Last Picture Show and Paper Moon has become an outcast in the movie community, reduced to making low-brow TV movies. He has endured bankruptcy twice, the brutal murder of his lover and, after marrying her young sister, the disdain of America's perennially-affronted tabloids.

Now, despite his tale of misery and woe, Bogdanovich is in the process of staging an ambitious, if tentative, comeback. With a recurring role in The Sopranos, the celebrated TV series about the New Jersey mafia, he has reclaimed at least part of the lustre that once made him a high-profile figure. Playing an analyst to the psychiatrist treating the drama's mafia don, he has a small but pivotal comedic role in the nonchalantly violent show that has become one of the most popular in America. Bogdanovich is pleased, if typically calm when discussing his part in the series that excitable critics have described as the most significant addition to American culture in 25 years. Not least because he is able to act again: "After the second day of shooting, David Chase [Sopranos creator] called me and asked me if I'd acted before. No one seemed to have been aware that I had been trained as a kid by Stella Adler. I have been acting since I was 15 years old and I enjoy it now as much as I ever did."

Bogdanovich removes his trademark tinted glasses, concentrating on the opinions he will share. His deliberation might be practiced, adopted after an early career faux pas when he compared his talent - rather than his sharp professional decline - to that of Orson Welles. "I don't judge myself on the basis of my contemporaries," he told the New York Times. "I judge myself against those I admire - Hawks, Hitchcock and Welles. I don't think I'm anywhere as good as they are, but I think I'm pretty good."

Welles remains an enormous figure to Bogdanovich. Down on his luck in the 70s, the corpulent legend lodged with Bogdanovich for two years in a spare room at the young director's enormous Beverly Hills mansion. The two spent many hours discussing films, the movie business and how to stay at the top. Normally stoic, Bogdanovich laughs fondly when discussing his mentor, recalling how Welles's mistress would appal him with her guttural language and dirty jokes.

After the bubble burst on his career, few of Bogdanovich's enemies in the industry mourned his demise, the same reaction many had had to Welles's decline. Ironically, directors like Welles and John Ford were friends from his early days as a film critic in New York and as a writer at Esquire magazine alongside a young Tom Wolfe. With his two Oscar nominations for The Last Picture Show and the success of Paper Moon and What's Up, Doc? those old acquaintances congratulated Bogdanovich as he and peers such as De Palma, Spielberg, Lucas and Coppola redefined Hollywood for their generation.

But as the young directors flourished and their hedonistic appetites increased accordingly throughout the 70s, falls from grace were inevitable. Bogdanovich's particular nemesis arrived on August 14 1980. Actress and former Playboy centrefold Dorothy Stratten had her head blown off by her estranged husband Paul Snider. He then had sex with her corpse before shooting himself in the head. Stratten had been the love of Bogdanovich's life. They had become a couple less than a year earlier, after meeting in Hugh Hefner's Los Angeles mansion. He made her the star of his film, They All Laughed, and appeared to be moulding her as his protege in the same way he had with a young Cybill Shepherd.

But her death left him a devastated wreck. Faced with the further revelation that 20th Century Fox were not keen to push hard on the film's marketing, the impassioned, still grief-stricken Bogdanovich bought the film negative from the studio and set about doing the job himself. The catastrophic box office performance of They All Laughed cost Bogdanovich $5m and ultimately sent him on his first trip to the bankruptcy court. "It was career suicide," he said.

Seeking comfort in the others who loved Stratten, he then began paying for her mother Nelly and sister Louise to make regular trips from Canada to his 19-room home in California. The nature of Bogdanovich's relationship with the teenage Louise, who was 12 when her sister died, has remained a subject of much debate and legendary gossip. Bogdanovich married her eight years later in Vancouver. They are still together and living in a small apartment just a few streets away from the childhood home he shared with his mother and painter father on Manhattan's Upper West Side.

"I married Dorothy's younger sister and I think there was a great deal of controversy because everybody has to talk about something. But I think what I did is not so unusual because it all boils down to the old cliche, which is to ask your lover, 'Are there any more at home who are just like you ?' As it happened there was. The whole thing was a mess and it wasn't good for anybody, but especially for Louise because she was so young. It was very ugly, especially after I criticised Hugh Hefner for his magazine's role in Dorothy's death and he came back at me about Louise.

"Dorothy's murder sent me reeling for a long time," he says. "That event triggered a lot of reactions in me and I had to question everything in my life. I certainly didn't think I'd ever direct another picture. In fact, I eventually had to because I went bankrupt. The death is with Louise and I all the time. But that is okay. We deal with it. Now I'm steadier and taking every day as it comes."

Beneath the humble exterior lurks an auteur's ego. He is still driven with the same passion as before, and plans to direct several new projects. New Hollywood has given him its stamp of approval. Just as the young pretender Bogdanovich came to the rescue of Welles when Hollywood abandoned him, he himself has been championed by Quentin Tarantino: the Pulp Fiction director offered to let Bogdanovich stay at his Los Angeles home when his financial problems overcame him, and has agreed to act in a new comedy about a film director haunted by ghosts of his past, written and directed by Bogdanovich. "Quentin is a friend and we were ready to start shooting last year," says Bogdanovich. "We had $15m in financing and were ready, but I felt the script wasn't quite right. So I've put it on hold until I've rewritten it sufficiently."

The ghost project, along with The Cat's Meow (a comedy about Charlie Chaplin and William Randolph Hearst in the 1920s) and a script based on three stories by Robert Graves have buoyed Bogdanovich's confidence enough to give him real expectations for the future. "I won't ever get back into the Hollywood loop," he concludes. "But I want to be back in the position of making personal, yet not private films. I don't want to be a gun for hire. I'm just not comfortable with that."

 The Sopranos, Channel 4, Thursdays, 10.30pm.

webTitle: Hague makes pledge on press freedom

fields.headline: Hague makes pledge on press freedom
fields.standfirst: William Hague yesterday promised a "real" freedom of information act if the Tories win the next election, reports Jessica Hodgson.
fields.trailText: William Hague yesterday promised to make councils take decisions in public and guaranteed a "real" freedom of information act if the Tories win the next election.
fields.body:
William Hague yesterday promised to make councils take decisions in public and guaranteed a "real" freedom of information act if the Tories win the next election.

Speaking to the Society of Editors' conference in Cardiff, the leader of the opposition tried to align the Conservatives as allies of the press, following the Labour government's public retrenchment from its pre-election pleges of "open government".

Mr Hague attacked the Freedom of Information Act and the Local Government Act as examples of legislation that were systematically undermining press freedom.

He told the audience he found it "hugely ironic, though not in the least bit surprising, that a government that came to power promising a revolution in open government, and a sweeping Freedom of Information Act, has in reality succeeded in introducing new curbs on the press".

He also promised that under the Conservatives, an information commissioner and not ministers should have the final say over whether the release of a piece of information was in the public interest.

webTitle: BBC launches two new kids' magazines

fields.headline: BBC launches two new children's magazines
fields.trailText: 8am: The BBC is launching two new children's magazines, writes Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
The BBC is launching two new children's magazines and grouping its existing titles in a business unit called Learning Together from next Monday.

Magic Key, which is linked to a BBC children's programme, is aimed at teaching children key reading and writing skills, while Number Time will use number rhymes, magic tricks and puzzles to help children learn maths. The BBC said that 12 months' subscription to the titles will cover the National Curriculum requirement for maths and literacy.

The magazines will be grouped together with BBC Worldwide's existing titles, BBC Learning is Fun! and BBC Tell Me Why, and will be given a major marketing push in schools and shops.

The launch is likely to attract further criticism from commercial publishers and broadcasters, who are concerned that the BBC is cross-promoting its commercial magazines from licence fee-funded programmes.

fields.headline: BBC1 makes good start - but ITV wins night
fields.trailText: 10.45am overnights: The launch of BBC1's new schedule saw One Foot in the Grave beat Millionaire and the new 10pm news outrate last week's 9pm bulletin - but ITV won the night on share. By Jason Deans.
fields.body:
It was first blood to BBC1 last night, as the channel's new schedule kicked off with One Foot in the Grave beating ITV's Who Wants to be a Millionaire? and the new 10pm news bulletin comfortably outrating the average audience for last week's 9pm bulletin.

One Foot in the Grave managed the rare feat for a BBC1 show of besting Millionaire, averaging 10.2m from 9pm against the first half-hour of the 60-minute special edition of ITV's gameshow, which took 9.4m, according to unofficial overnights.

In its second half, Millionaire climbed to a quarter-hour high of 11.1m and averaged 10.2m overall. It beat BBC1's The Royle Family, which nonetheless turned in best ever figures of 8.4m.

The first ever BBC1 10pm news averaged 5.9m, against The Frank Skinner Show's 6.9m on ITV. In its last week, the old 9pm news had averaged 5m, with 5.2m last Monday. The BBC1 9pm news had averaged 5.1m this year, but 6.1m in the four weeks of the autumn season to date.

However, ITV won the peaktime schedule overall on share thanks to an extraordinary performance by Coronation Street with 15.1m, a 63% share against BBC1's Crime Squad.

Last week at 10pm the last ever Monday night Panorama drew 4.2m, while The Frank Skinner Show took 5.3m.

More to follow...

webTitle: HHCL scoops £5m Industry Standard Europe launch

fields.headline: HHCL scoops £5m Industry Standard Europe launch
fields.trailText: 10.15am: HHCL & Partners has picked up the £5m launch task for the Industry Standard Europe - the weekly internet news magazine. By Jade Garrett.
fields.body:
HHCL & Partners has picked up the £5m launch task for the Industry Standard Europe,the weekly news magazine devoted to the internet economy.

The award-winning US magazine is expanding into Europe. Its launch will be backed by a national marketing campaign aimed at building the brand.

HHCL & Partners has created a multimedia campaign, including a series of print and outdoor advertisements that will run in the Financial Times, as six-sheet posters in stations and on taxi panels. Meanwhile, an online campaign will be handled by I-level. All advertising kicks off tomorrow.

The campaign will also have a heavy ambient element, including the distribution of personalised postcards to five target audiences: the City, dot.com start-ups, MBA and business students, media agencies and ad agencies.

The publication is entering the European market at a time when internet and related technologies are becoming global business stories.

fields.headline: BBDO lands $250m Cingular Wireless
fields.trailText: 10.30am: BBDO Worldwide New York is understood to have picked up the $250m consolidated account for Cingular Wireless, writes Jade Garrett.
fields.body:
BBDO Worldwide New York is understood to have picked up the $250m (£163m) consolidated account for Cingular Wireless - formed through the merger of SBC Communications' and BellSouth's wireless divisions.

BBDO beat rival roster agencies WestWayne and GSD&M - the agency that, during the review, handled a print campaign introducing the Cingular Wireless name.

The two companies announced in May their decision to combine their wireless phone businesses to create the second largest player in the US wireless market.

The combined company is estimated to generate revenue of more than $10.2bn and have 16.2m subscribers.

webTitle: You Bet Your Life - week nine, the expert's view

fields.headline: You Bet Your Life - week nine, the expert's view
fields.trailText:
Current totals (from their initial £100 kitties): Scott Murray = £115.87

Sean Ingle = £99.77

Paul MacInnes = £70.00

Football Unlimited punters collective = £68.15.
fields.body:
Current totals (from their initial £100 kitties): Scott Murray = £115.87

Sean Ingle = £99.77

Paul MacInnes = £70.00

Football Unlimited punters collective = £68.15.

Scott Murray

Arsenal v Aston Villa: Villa to win £5 @ 5/1 I couldn't really disagree with this bet. 5/1 does look a fair price for an in-form side playing a side whose mind may not be fully on the game. But away wins are pretty hard to come by in the Premiership and away wins at Highbury are rare indeed.

If I were going to have a bet on this match I think it would have been Villa on the Asian handicap. With Villa priced at 11/10 getting a ¾ goal start, a win or a draw would have been good enough for a fair profit and even the final 1-0 to Arsenal result meant only half stakes were lost. Though obviously a much shorter price than the 5/1 on a Villa win this is, in my view, better value. The increased chance of winning more than compensates for the decreased payout. As a general rule if I want to oppose a home team I will look to the Asian handicap rather than backing the away team to win, but obviously this is a judgement call.

The important thing about this bet is that it does at least demonstrate, yet again, that Scott is thinking about bets in terms of value and if he continues like this he should still be in profit at the end of the season.

Sean Ingle
£2 Trixie (three doubles and one accumulator = £8 in total) on Sunderland v Chelsea: number of goals 0 or 1 @ 13/5; Leicester v Manchester United; number of goals 0 or 1 @ 14/5; Southampton to beat Everton @ 3/1

I'm prepared to give Mr I the benefit of the doubt as regards his intentions, I'll even excuse him his unhealthy attachment to multiples, but likening me to Mao Zedong! Is that strictly fair?

At least Mr I's selections show none of his usual favourite backing tendencies, they all look fairly reasonable and well argued to me. If I had one quibble it would be with his bet on Southampton. As I said when discussing Mr Murray's bet, away wins are hard to come by in the Premiership. To my eyes the bet to have was Southampton on the Asian handicap. You could back Southampton at 10/11 with a half goal start, the equivalent of laying a very poor Everton at 11/10. The price is worse but the value, I believe, is better.

I don't want to go on about the folly of multiples again. But I will. Had Mr Ingle had three singles instead of a trixie he would in fact have won money (only one of his selections won but at greater than 2/1). Had he managed to get two winners he would have won almost as much betting singles as he would for his trixie. It is only in the unlikely event of getting all three right that the trixie really pays off. To me it seems clear that it is well worth trading in this chance of a big win for the much greater chance of a small one. Perhaps someday Mr I will see this too.

The Football Unlimited punters collective: Hitendra Patel, a project analyst from Birmingham

£5 accumulator: Coventry to draw with Tottenham @ 11/5; Bolton to beat Wolves @ 4/6; Watford to beat QPR @ 2/5; WBA to beat Norwich @ 8/13; Brechin to beat Elgin @ 4/5; Liverpool to beat Derby @ 10/11; Newcastle to beat Middlesbrough @ 13/8; Arsenal to beat Aston Villa @ 1/2

Everything I fulminate against week after week is personified in this little eight-fold from hell. Bets based on personal bias, personal circumstance, 'gut feeling' anything indeed but value. Considering the luck of our happy punters in recent weeks it's a wonder it didn't win.

I'm still not convinced Mr Patel actually exists, that this isn't some concoction of Mr Ingle designed to wind me up ('Hitendra Patel' does after all contain all the letters necessary for 'I hate Pat'). Mr Patel, assuming he does exist, got 5 out of 8 selections in, which isn't bad I suppose, but there was never any danger of him winning. Bets like this are the reason you never see a poor bookmaker (as the completely untrue cliché goes). It's a fun bet, risk a fiver to win a grand. Trouble is only one in a thousand will win. If you want fun bets, dear punter, feel free - betting is after all as much about entertainment as it is about winning money - but don't imagine for a moment that your bank roll won't suffer for it. Enough for now, happy punting.

fields.headline: New Media Markets round-up
fields.standfirst: Publication date: October 13.
fields.trailText: October 17: Telewest and NTL are reported to be turning away new channels because of a lack of capacity on their networks.
fields.body:
Telewest and NTL are reported to be turning away new channels because of a lack of capacity on their networks. The Extreme Sports Channel, due to launch on the Astra satellite network later this month, said it had been unable to get onto the Telewest network, despite the fact that UPC, which owns 50% of the channel, is also to take a 25% stake in Telewest.

Home shopping channel QVC is developing an interactive rival to BSkyB's Open...based on its QVC directory service.

ONdigital has failed to identify the reasons for the disappearance from the air of its ONrequest service for three days last week. Canal Plus Technologies, which supplies the operating system, says it believes the outage was caused by a hardware problem.

NMM quotes several senior advertising executives who say the ITC's relaxation of sponsorship rules announced last week do not go far enough. The head of digital at J. Walter Thompson, Jeremy Davis, says sponsors should be allowed to get involved in endorsing their brands.

And video-on-demand provider Video Networks is reported to have signed a deal with BBC Worldwide allowing it to show BBC educational programmes on demand. The company has hired an executive, Lisa Zivoni, to develop its strategy for on-demand educational programming.
