fields.headline: Teletext pumps £15m into rebranding drive
fields.trailText: 8.30am: Teletext is ditching its archaic, blocky graphics and spending £15m on a new branding campaign, writes Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
Teletext is ditching its archaic, blocky graphics image and spending £15m on a new branding campaign in a bid to reposition itself as a cross-platform media business.

As part of a new "digital multi-platform strategy", the news provider is launching an SMS text messaging news service that can be personalised via the Teletext.co.uk website. Teletext is also developing further personalisation to work across the internet, Wap and digital TV.

Mike Stewart, managing director for Teletext, said: "This is an exciting time for Teletext. We know that 48% of the UK population are already Teletext viewers, but this is the first time we have moved from a 'passive' relationship with our viewers and asked them to take an 'active' decision to make Teletext their information provider of choice on a wider range of platforms."

Simon Curry, head of marketing,, added: "The aim of the new marketing campaign is to maintain that trust whilst encouraging consumers to have a more involved relationship with the service."

The ad campaign, developed by Delaney Lund Knox Warren, breaks on October 30 across TV, print and outdoor.

webTitle: Comment: Liz Forgan on BBC radio at White City

fields.headline: There and back again
fields.standfirst: Five years ago I resigned when the BBC decided to move radio out of central London. Now I reveal why. By Liz Forgan, managing director of BBC Radio from 1993 to 1996.
fields.trailText: Five years ago I resigned when the BBC decided to move radio out of central London. Now I reveal why. By Liz Forgan, managing director of BBC Radio from 1993 to 1996.
fields.body:
On August 30 1995 the BBC governors held a special meeting requested by one of their own managing directors (me). There was only one item on the agenda - the proposed move of the BBC's radio journalists from Broadcasting House down the M40 to White City at a cost of £41m. The move, to a purpose-built, state-of-the-art news centre in which all the BBC's journalists across radio, television, satellite and online would be congregated, was a pet project of the then director-general, John Birt, and his head of news and current affairs, Tony Hall. It was bitterly opposed by almost everyone in radio, journalists or not.

Rows of this kind at the BBC usually take place in dark corners, not in the full light of a formal governors' meeting but this issue raised such fundamental questions that I wanted the governors to hear both sides of the story before a final decision was made. To his credit, John Birt agreed.

Tony Hall told the governors that centralisation was essential to meet the challenges of technological change; that it would strengthen BBC journalism; and save £9.5m-£10.5m a year. I said it was inimical to pluralism and the integrity of each radio station's distinctive sound, that White City was a mad place to site the Today programme, and that the figures were unbelievable. It was also obvious - even before a brick was laid - that the site was far too small.

The worst damage, I feared, would be to Radio 4. Broadcasting House, in the heart of central London, was easy for interviewees to reach. Who would be willing to toil down to Shepherd's Bush at 7am to face Jim Naughtie? The dread sound of the "down the line" interview would become the norm, to the detriment of one of the BBC's most important programmes. And while it was clearly sensible to centralise the collecting of the raw material for news, it was impossible to meet the needs and agendas of all the BBC's different audiences - from Radio 1 to the Nine O'Clock News - with the same amorphous and interchangeable troupe of journalists producing the finished programmes.

John Birt had, with great courage, brought radical reforms to the BBC. Everything was subjected to minute scrutiny of costs, management and strategic aim. The exception to such long overdue rigour was this costly and controversial proposal to yank all radio journalism out of its home and into a forced marriage with television.

The ostensible gains were huge financial efficiencies. But no one apart from John Birt and Tony Hall was ever allowed to see the detailed figures. I never met anyone else who believed them for a minute. Stage Six, as the new journalism factory was called, was more than a new office. It was a physical symbol of corporate purpose. Practical arguments about the needs of programmes and programme-makers were secondary.

The governors were in an impossible position. Several declared private support for radio's case but, faced with the insistence of their director-general, the whole thing had become an issue of confidence. It was a choice between losing a managing director and losing a director-general. Quite understandably, they chose the former.

Having lost the argument I had no alternative but to resign, but I was determined not to become a stick for enemies of the corporation to beat it with. For the past five years I have refused to discuss my resignation or to utter a critical syllable about the BBC, which I value and admire passionately.

But what I thought was water under the bridge has suddenly turned into a whirlpool. The BBC is now reported to have discovered serious doubts after all about the suitability of White City for a journalistic centre and is said to be considering reversing the whole damaging episode. There is no official announcement yet but architects are apparently looking at the possibility of scrapping Stage Six and making Broadcasting House the new home of BBC journalism - this time moving TV to radio rather then vice versa.

My staff were disappointed in me for keeping silent publicly when I left. No doubt the BBC will be angered by my writing this after all this time. The criterion in both cases is the same: whether any purpose would be served by speaking out. In 1995 I had had a perfectly good opportunity to put my case and it was rejected. There was neither sense nor justification in banging on. But now - aside from a sense of vindication which is giving me disappointingly little pleasure - there is a real issue to be raised.

I am sure the BBC will produce elegant demonstrations of how essential it was at the time to press ahead with the Stage Six plan only to reverse the whole policy five years later. But I am also sure that no outsider will ever be allowed to know the real cost - in money, morale and programme quality - of either the original move or the eventual move back. What is more, I am afraid that no one will ever take responsibility for this wasteful corporate mistake. And they ought to.

 Liz Forgan was managing director of BBC Radio from 1993 to 1996

There was neither sense nor justification in banging on. But now - aside from a sense of vindication which is giving me disappointingly little pleasure - there is a real issue to be raised. I am sure the BBC will produce elegant demonstrations of how essential it was at the time to press ahead with the Stage Six plan only to reverse the whole policy five years later. But I am also sure that no outsider will ever be allowed to know the real cost - in money, morale and programme quality - of either the original move or the eventual move back. What is more, I am afraid that no one will ever take responsibility for this wasteful corporate mistake. And they ought to.  Liz Forgan was managing director of BBC Radio from 1993 to 1996 liz.forgan@virgin.net

webTitle: ONdigital signs games deal with Two Way TV

fields.headline: ONdigital signs games deal with Two Way TV
fields.trailText: 9.45am: ONdigital will add Two Way TV's games service to its interactive area from January next year, reports Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
ONdigital has confirmed it will add Two Way TV's games service to its interactive area from January next year.

The Two Way TV channel which is already running on NTL and Telewest digital - albeit in the interactive areas and not yet as a standalone interactive channel - will replace the ONgames One service. The contract will run for five years. Two Way TV expects to begin testing its enhanced TV "interactive gameshow" model towards the end of the year.

Two Way TV will enable ONdigital users to play puzzles and quiz games, and other games being created from recently acquired formats such as A Question Of Sport, Mastermind, Antiques Roadshow, Crystal Maze and ITV's Comedy Awards.

ONdigital expects to have more than one million homes signed up by the time the service launches next year.

Ian Parkinson, head of business development (Interactivity) at ONdigital, said: "Coming on the heels of the ONnet launch, the addition of the Two Way TV channel is yet another example of ONdigital's exciting developments in interactivity."

webTitle: Push for Middle East accord  goes into second day

fields.headline: Push for Middle East accord  goes into second day
fields.trailText: Efforts to reach an agreement in the Middle East  continued  for the second  day, with US President Bill Clinton shuttling between Israeli Prime Minister Ehud                                   Barak and Palestinian leader Yasser Arafat at the Egyptian                                   resort of Sharm el-Sheikh.
fields.body:
Efforts to reach an agreement in the Middle East continued for the second day, with US President Bill Clinton shuttling between Israeli Prime Minister Ehud Barak and Palestinian leader Yasser Arafat at the Egyptian resort of Sharm el-Sheikh.

After a few hours of sleep, Mr Clinton conferred with the host, Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak, this morning for 20 minutes.

"We look forward to a productive and intensive morning of talks," the White House press secretary, Jake Siewert.

Despite the intensity of the drive to achieve a minimal goal - a ceasefire - White House spokesman PJ Crowley declined to claim progress. He said the marathon talks "reflect the determination of the president to work through these issues."

As Mr Arafat left his hotel to begin the talks on Tuesday, reporters asked him whether there had been any progress. "Not yet," he said.

"What we are looking for is the honest and accurate implementation of what has been signed," Mr Arafat said, referring to past agreements between the Palestinians and Israelis.

An Egyptian official, Nabil Osman, said the seven leaders participating in the summit would gather together again later today.

The discussions, lasting more than 14 hours yesterday and today, prompted Clinton to extend his stay rather than depart last night as planned.

Beyond the immediate goal of a ceasefire in the more than two weeks of conflict between Israeli forces and Palestinian rioters, Mr Clinton wanted to see a date set for a resumption of once promising peace talks between Barak and Arafat.

"We cannot afford to fail," Mr Clinton said as he joined Mr Mubarak and the five other world leaders at a golf club in this Red Sea resort in an effort to restore calm to the West Bank, Gaza and Israel. Besides the United States, Israel and the Palestinians, the participants represent Egypt, Jordan, the United Nations and the European Union.

Israeli officials were downbeat. Foreign Minister Shlomo Ben-Ami dismissed Mr Arafat's demands for an international probe of the causes of the violence.

"All the emphasis on inquiry committees is a total waste of time, a search for an alibi. If the Palestinian people are really dissembling, then their leadership must put an immediate end; to the violence," Mr Ben-Ami told Israeli television.

Some of the meetings were described as tense and heated. In fact, Saeb Erekat, a senior Palestinian negotiator, confirmed that he had accused the Israeli minister of being a murderer.

Mr Siewert said there were no eruptions of angry words in any of Mr Clinton's meetings. "People have been straightforward, focused on solutions and not finger-pointing," the spokesman said.

He added the timing of Mr Clinton's return to Washington was undecided. "We haven't made a plan for after this," he said as Mr Clinton conferred with Mr Barak.

webTitle: Liz Hurley apologises to US actors' unions

fields.headline: Hurley says sorry to US actors' unions
fields.trailText: 9.45am: Elizabeth Hurley has apologised to US actors' unions after she was accused of strike-breaking by appearing in a commercial for Estee Lauder. By Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
Elizabeth Hurley has formally apologised to the striking actors in the US and promised to make a "significant contribution" to their coffers after she was accused of strike-breaking by appearing in a commercial for Estee Lauder.

The move is a last-ditch attempt by Ms Hurley to improve her image in Hollywood as her new film, Bedazzled, opens in the US. Posters promoting the comedy in Los Angeles have been scrawled with the word "scab" while talk show host Howard Stern repeatedly criticised her in his show on Monday.

Ms Hurley has been a high-profile target for the actors' unions since they discovered in July that she had performed in a non-union shoot for a perfume ad. Her insistence that she was not aware of the strike at the time only seems to have angered her accusers more.

But Ms Hurley's latest attempts to pacify the unions seem unlikely to get her off the hook and the Screen Actors' Guild, the main actors' union, has said she will still have to appear before a trial board to account for her actions.

The dispute, which has been going on for over five months, began when advertisers said they were planning to change the way they pay actors, proposing a single up-front fee. Until now, actors have been according to how often the ad airs.

A number of celebrity actors have added their support to the strike, boosting its profile and putting additional pressure on the advertising industry. George Clooney, Tom Hanks, Paul Newman and Susan Sarandon have all given their support, either financially or by giving speeches.

fields.headline: Today's media stories from the papers
fields.trailText: THE GUARDIAN
fields.body:
THE GUARDIAN

The BBC has defended its decision to move Panorama following news that the programme has lost a quarter of its usual viewers in its new slot. (p7)
The City pages carry the story that magazine publisher Future Network yesterday admitted the black hole in its accounts was £1m more than first expected. (p27)
And G2 carries an interview with the television presenter Clarissa Dickson Wright, in which she talks about her new show, Clarissa and the Countryman. (p4)
Liz Forgan, former director of BBC radio, tells for the first time why she had to leave over the move of BBC radio out of central London. (p20)

THE INDEPENDENT

The Independent reports that Reuters is expected to unveil plans to float its Instinet electronic dealing platform some time in the first half of next year. Chief executive Peter Job will unveil the plans in a third-quarter trading statement on Friday. (p19)

MEDIA SECTION
The section carries a report on investigative journalism which, says the paper, has become rare as the media has focused its attention on showbusiness and social affairs. (p8)
And a piece about the latest national newspaper figures focuses on the fate of the Express. (p8)
An interview with Jane Procter, former Tatler editor and now head of Peoplenews.com, reveals that the company plans to "empower people" through gossip. (p9)
Tim Luckhurst, former Scotsman editor and one-time Today employee, stands up for the beleaguered Radio 4 news programme. (p9)
Paul Bainsfair, chief executive of ad agency TBWA, writes about the threat to advertising posed by TiVo. (p9)

THE FINANCIAL TIMES

The FT carries a story about the battle for viewers between BBC1 and ITV - a day later than everyone else. (p3)
And James Harding writes about industry opposition to the government's plans to bring together telecoms and broadcasting regulation. (p30)

CREATIVE BUSINESS
The main feature is an interview with Waheed Alli, managing director of Carlton Productions, on his plans for the broadcaster. (p8)
The paper also carries a report on the launch of internet magazine Industry Standard Europe. (p4)
There is a feature about the implications of loosening TV sponsorship rules. (p4)
And the newspaper page carries a report on the success of the rich lists, now published by the Observer, Mail on Sunday and Sunday Mirror, as well as the Sunday Times. (p14)

THE DAILY TELEGRAPH

Loyd Grossman is quitting Masterchef after a decade of presenting the BBC1 show. His departure follows the BBC's decision to switch Masterchef to BBC2. It will instead be presented by the chef Gary Rhodes. (p8)
Telegraph readers voted Lastminute.com the internet's worst travel site at the 2000 Telegraph Travel Awards. (p9)
The paper's advertising column looks at how the BBC is getting up the noses of everyone from advertisers to publishers, and reports on the decision by the European Court of Justice to overturn the EU ban on tobacco advertising. (p38)

THE TIMES

The Times reports that Vivendi's 22.7% stake in BSkyB could be folded into Sky Global Networks, News Corporation's global satellite television business. (p28)

THE DAILY MAIL

The Mail carries a story about Panorama's switch to Sunday evening costing it 1m viewers and quotes a BBC spokesman as saying the show got a larger share of the audience than usual. (p25)

THE MIRROR

Loyd Grossman is quitting Masterchef after a bust-up with BBC bosses, the Mirror reports. The paper quotes Mr Grossman as saying the BBC's plans to move the show to BBC2 and axe Junior Masterchef are "moronic". (p1)
And the Mirror reveals that TV's Royle Family have been banned from smoking. In a rare display of political correctness on the popular show, Granada is preventing chain smoker Denise, played by Caroline Aherne, from so much as mentioning cigarettes in front of her new baby. (p15)

THE SUN

The Sun reports that Davina McCall, best known for presenting Big Brother, is to make her acting debut in a new ITV sitcom, Sam's Game. (p3)

AND FINALLY
The Daily Star reports that Big Brother stars Andy and Sada revealed their sex secrets to the world yet again when they snuggled up in bed together to launch National Sex Week. Andy, now an MTV presenter, said the lack of sex on the show reflected the conservative nature of the British. (p4)

fields.headline: Eshun to edit Hot Air
fields.trailText: 8.30am: Ekow Eshun, the former Arena editor and Late Review commentator, is to edit the in-flight magazine, Hot Air, writes Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
Ekow Eshun, the former Arena editor and Late Review commentator, is to edit John Brown Publishing's award-winning in-flight magazine, Hot Air. At the same time he is to launch a brand consultancy called Bug with the former Face editor, Richard Benson, and Miranda Sawyer.

But neither Andrew Hirsch, chief executive of John Brown Publishing's contract arm, or John Brown himself, would confirm the appointment.

Mr Eshun confirmed that he had taken on the editorship of the magazine, which is published four times a year for Virgin. He commented: "The prospect of taking on a magazine that's read by such a large constituency is really exciting, especially when you're competing with so many other in-flight media."

Mr Eshun said he was also involved in launching the Bug consultancy, which plans to give branding advice to companies. He said: "A lot of the time, modern companies don't really take account of the way people feel about brands."

He noted that brand consultancy had become more challenging with the growth of anti-brand consciousness. "The whole business of consulting people takes on a whole different aspect," he said. "But it's important to recognise that subversion is not just related to brands. It's an essential part of culture, and it's legitimate to talk to companies about this. As journalists, we're asked these questions the whole time. Addressing this doesn't mean you're selling your soul".

Mr Eshun will continue to contribute to BBC2's Late Review and write for newspapers and magazines.

BA's High Life, published by Premier Magazines, and Hot Air, have been credited with improving the dowdy image of the in-flight sector.

fields.headline: Panasonic hopes to suck up sales with interactive TV ads
fields.trailText: 8.15am: Panasonic is launching what it claims is the world's most advanced interactive TV advertising campaign, reports Jade Garrett.
fields.body:
Panasonic is launching what it claims is the world's most advanced interactive TV advertising campaign.

The campaign, which has been designed by Open's in-house design team, will run for four weeks from 19 October to 15 November.

A series of 30-second ads for Panasonic's range of vacuum cleaners will enable subscribers to Sky Digital (available in nearly 4m homes in the UK) to buy Panasonic's icon vacuum cleaners using their TV.

If already registered with Open, then viewers will be able to enter their access code. A blue button on the TV screen will take the purchaser to the Argos or Comet shop area. Delivery of the goods is then made direct to the purchaser's door.

Cyril Wood, managing director of Panasonic Consumer Electronics UK, said: "We expect to learn a great deal from interactive advertising and believe customers and advertisers will appreciate the sophisticated possibilities offered by this new medium.

"With Interactive TV services on digital broadcasting becoming more widespread throughout Europe and US, and due to start in Japan from the beginning of December, the timing is right to start exploring the real benefits of interactive TV advertising."

Media is planned and bought by Universal McCann.

fields.headline: Channel 5 launches online sales arm
fields.trailText: <B<8.15am: Channel 5 has announced the launch of Channel 5 Interactive, its new online sales service, writes Jade Garrett.
fields.body:
Channel 5 has announced the launch of Channel 5 Interactive (C5i), its new online sales service.

The venture, backed by the RTL Group and United News & Media, will not be limited to the UK market. Through C5i's involvement with the IP-web.net, it will be able to offer a European presence to its clients.

Paul Curtis, C5i's chief executive, said: "By avoiding the traditional internet sales house idea we feel we have established something more focused and dynamic - the first UK internet sales agency.

"We want to establish a network of clients whose interests are represented to the advertising community by dedicated account handlers. Not only that, we want to establish a set of advertising propositions that advertisers can cherry-pick to meet specific marketing objectives."

Nick Bampton, sales director of C5i, added: "Our business is maximising revenue for our publishers and advertisers. It is our belief that we can best do this by providing advertising solutions, which are relevant and focused - always with the advertiser in mind. Our core values of integrity, transparency, open-mindedness, and belief in partnership ensure that this vision is consistent throughout the entire team."

Unlike others in the online advertising sales market, C5i will offer bespoke advertising solutions - to publisher and advertiser alike - rather than blanket selling of internet impressions. The agency plans to represent a small number of large publishers, sold to key advertisers, fulfilling detailed advertising briefs.

fields.headline: Reuters puts Greenhouse float on ice
fields.trailText: 8am: The turbulent performance of hi-tech shares has forced Reuters to put the flotation of its internet incubator fund on ice, writes John Cassy.
fields.body:
The turbulent performance of hi-tech shares has forced Reuters to put the flotation of its internet incubator fund on ice, but the news and information group could yet press ahead with a listing of Instinet, its electronic trading platform, before the end of the year.

A partial flotation of Instinet could see Reuters maintain a majority stake yet at the same time give the brokerage a currency with which to play a part in the consolidation of the world's stock markets and to incentivise and retain staff.

A fundraising would also allow investment in new technologies and the development of its trading platform. Analyst have valued Instinet at £2bn-£4bn.

Shares in Reuters closed 13p higher at £11.76p as dealers positioned themselves for an imminent announcement.

Chief executive Peter Job is likely to come under pressure to clarify the position of both possible floats when Reuters reports third-quarter results on Friday.

Mr Job, in conjunction with advisers at investment bank Credit Suisse First Boston, has been looking ways to tap the value of both Instinet and its internet investment vehicle Greenhouse Fund. However, withering enthusiasm for in ternet investments has persuaded Reuters to put a listing for Greenhouse on hold until the first quarter of next year.

Greenhouse was set up in 1995. It was given $20m (£13.7m) to invest in emerging-technology companies.

By the end of 1999 the stakes Greenhouse held in quoted companies had soared to £438m, a jump fuelled by the burgeoning value of internet stocks. Its valuation has been put as high as £3bn but that is likely to have receded with the sell-off of technology shares.

However, the market may be more receptive to a partial flotation of Instinet, which provides equity and fixed-income brokerage for institutional investors and brokers.

A boom in trading volumes on the Nasdaq market at the start of the year has fuelled revenue growth and the US equities business now accounts for nearly 80% of Instinet's revenues.

The world's stock markets are jostling for position to get to the forefront of consolidation which analysts believe will lead to the creation of just two or three global stock markets. If Instinet was listed it could use its shares to swallow smaller rivals.

Analysts predict group revenues for the three months to the end of September to rise to about £840m from £764m the previous year.

However, withering enthusiasm for in ternet investments has persuaded Reuters to put a listing for Greenhouse on hold until the first quarter of next year. Greenhouse was set up in 1995. It was given $20m (£13.7m) to invest in emerging-technology companies. By the end of 1999 the stakes Greenhouse held in quoted companies had soared to £438m, a jump fuelled by the burgeoning value of internet stocks. Its valuation has been put as high as £3bn but that is likely to have receded with the sell-off of technology shares. However, the market may be more receptive to a partial flotation of Instinet, which provides equity and fixed-income brokerage for institutional investors and brokers. A boom in trading volumes on the Nasdaq market at the start of the year has fuelled revenue growth and the US equities business now accounts for nearly 80% of Instinet's revenues. The world's stock markets are jostling for position to get to the forefront of consolidation which analysts believe will lead to the creation of just two or three global stock markets. If Instinet was listed it could use its shares to swallow smaller rivals. Analysts predict group revenues for the three months to the end of September to rise to about £840m from £764m the previous year.

fields.headline: Future admits an extra £1m missing
fields.trailText: 8am: Future Network, the magazine publisher, yesterday admitted the black hole in its accounts was £1m more than first expected, writes Julia Snoddy.
fields.body:
Future Network, the magazine publisher, yesterday admitted the black hole in its accounts was £1m more than first expected.

The firm last week announced it had discovered discrepancies in the accounts of its French subsidiary Future France, initially thought to total £3.2m.

After an investigation by Deloitte & Touche into the accounting irregularity, the company found sales and operating profits since 1998 had been overstated by £4.2m.

Future Network said it was "satisfied that the problem is now fully accounted for".

The mistake, it was said, was caused by inaccurate recording of sales.

"At a promotional level the impact is reasonably large, but on a business level it is not large," the company said. It disclosed last week that no staff had been suspended and there appeared to be no cause to notify police.

The results of the investigation were announced alongside the news that Future Network's American side of the business will publish a magazine for Xbox, Microsoft's new future-generation video game console.

The deal means the company will now publish magazines for leading competitors Microsoft and Playstation .

Chris Anderson, chairman and founder of Future Network, yesterday described the Microsoft agreement as: "Certainly the most wide-reaching games magazine licence ever signed."

Analysts are estimating that the deal will bring in net revenues of £100m over the next five years.

The contract is initially for three years and also allows the company to distribute a DVD containing game demos with the magazine, produce an official website and e-mail newsletters.

Future Network's share price yesterday rose 5p to 440p.

webTitle: What use for a second-hand newspaper?

fields.headline: What use for a second-hand newspaper?
fields.standfirst: Notebook Rush of media mediocrities
fields.trailText: Funny ol' business, newspapers. Even the textbooks are contradictory - one chapter will talk about cash cows carrying priceless opportunities to leverage a core brand; another will witter on about ageing consumer profiles, declining circulation and the threat to margins posed by new technology. And then, when an important one comes up for sale, we get a veritable orgy of speculation over who might buy it.
fields.body:
Funny ol' business, newspapers. Even the textbooks are contradictory - one chapter will talk about cash cows carrying priceless opportunities to leverage a core brand; another will witter on about ageing consumer profiles, declining circulation and the threat to margins posed by new technology. And then, when an important one comes up for sale, we get a veritable orgy of speculation over who might buy it.

Yet not since the death of Robert Maxwell have we had the sort of media baron scrum that has developed so quickly at the base of Lord Hollick's Blackfrairs headquarters of Express Newspapers.

United News & Media might blame Merrill Lynch, the investment bank, for publishing a break-up valuation for the group that included a superficially "affordable" figure for the Express titles - £75m to £100m.

No surprise then that the Barclay brothers - who are now probably best referred to as the Barclay family since, with his father and uncle now approaching their 66th birthday, Aidan (David's son) is now running the show - lobbed in a bid at the bottom end of expectations.

No surprise either that Cliff Stanford, who made £30m or so from the sale of Demon Internet to Thus, the hapless telecoms group, might also be interested. New money always tries to buy its way into old-money respectability, no?

Then there are the Hinduja brothers, Srichand and Gopichand. Their interests range from banking to cable television and they clearly have the money to play this sport, although those who profess to know them well in the Square Mile say they just cannot believe that a national British newspaper would even rank in their top 50 of "interesting available assets." Time will tell.

The rest of the field amounts to predictable padding. David Montgomery, we must assume, was deadly serious last year when, having been ousted from Mirror Group, he let it be known to friends that he was seeking private equity to take the red-top titles private. So he must be doubly serious now on the Express front, with the reported backing of 3i and HSBC, even if the shape of the Mirror's share price graph during Mr Montgomery's tenure looks a little odd during presentations to credit committees.

Finally, as things stand, there are the odd rumours about Phil Hall, the former News of the World editor, who is now working with Max Clifford, the publicist, advising Mohamed Al Fayed, the owner of Harrods. Rumours of a Hall-led buyout backed by an American venture capital firm have been circulating for weeks - leading to all the usual Fayed conspiracy stories.

Whatever their financial credentials, this is not, by any measure, a blue-chip list of bidders. But Lord Hollick cannot have expected any more. He is trying to sell a stable of second-class newspapers, after all.

This is probably why the United boss has spent the previous two years stamping violently on any suggestion that he might be in sales talks.

Now the story has been printed, in the interests of both United shareholders and the Express business clarifying the future ownership should be an absolute priority.

Euro neglect

Was it our hero's on-stage pronouncements or noises off that hit the euro yesterday? Certainly Wim Duisenberg (Mr Euro himself) must bear a portion of the responsibility by questioning the effectiveness of foreign exchange market intervention to cope with an externally generated shock. The head of the European Central Bank is right, of course. No point in hurling vast sums of money at the forex market with the Middle East in flames, for example. The only effect would be to provide euro holders with an inexpensive exit strategy.

But - as usual - whatever Mr Duisenberg's logic, his understanding of markets appears suspect. Having been caught out once, the forex market is nervous about intervention. So nervous indeed that yesterday afternoon a large buy order out of Frankfurt was mistaken for the central bank heavy cavalry, sparking a (temporary) euro-rally.

Yet dealers are still looking to sell the euro. Some are already predicting a fall to 80 cents. So why draw attention to the limits of the intervention option at times of extreme stress? Or indeed to the issue of intervention at all? In such circumstances silence is golden.

But Mr Duisenberg is not entirely to blame. The credibility of the intervention threat rests heavily on the presence of the US among those lining up to smack the market's collective wrist. The market is beginning to get an idea that the Bush camp is unenthusiastic (to put it mildly) about intervention while the Gore team is seen as only slightly less cool towards the idea of selling dollars. Hardly the sort of thinking that will underpin the struggling euro, either.

webTitle: 1m viewers lost as BBC shifts Panorama to Sunday 'graveyard' slot

fields.headline: 1m viewers lost as BBC shifts Panorama to Sunday 'graveyard' slot
fields.standfirst:
MediaGuardian.co.uk
Special report: the future of the BBC
fields.trailText: The BBC yesterday defended its decision to schedule Panorama in a "graveyard" Sunday night slot, after the programme at its new time lost a quarter of its viewers in a week.
fields.body:
The BBC yesterday defended its decision to schedule Panorama in a "graveyard" Sunday night slot, after the programme at its new time lost a quarter of its viewers in a week.

A report on the third world production practices of Nike and Gap, the first Panorama to air at the new time, drew 3.2m viewers. The previous Monday's edition on the Omagh bombing was watched by 4.2m, about the same as the other two Monday night editions of the latest series.

The BBC's flagship current affairs series has been forced to move to Sunday nights, against the wishes of its journalists and production staff, to make way for the main evening news at 10pm.

A BBC spokesman pointed out that Panorama's rating on Sunday was only 0.4m below the programme's 3.6m average for all editions since the start of the year. "We are happy with the way it went. It takes a while for viewers to get used to the new time."

Peter Horrocks, the BBC's head of current affairs, said in an article for the Scotsman yesterday that the BBC would review the move if viewing figures fell drastically. The first BBC Ten O'Clock News went on air last night on an evening of intense competition between BBC1 and ITV. The BBC has packed the first week of the new schedule with trusted hits: the first 9pm-10pm slot was filled by the start of a new series of One Foot in the Grave and The Royle Family. They were up against an hour-long special of ITV's quiz show Who Wants To Be A Millionaire?

Tonight, BBC1 screens the terrestrial TV premiere of the movie Men in Black against A Touch of Frost on ITV.

Lorraine Heggessey, controller-designate of BBC1, said yesterday the news had been moved to 10pm because its ratings would have "dwindled" at 9pm.

 Radio 1 announced yesterday that it has appointed its first political reporter. Polly Billington, 32, will report for Newsbeat and the station's website.

fields.headline: Zinc to create Mr Kipling website
fields.trailText: 8am: Mr Kipling is to take his exceedingly good cakes onto the internet by hiring an agency to set up a website for the brand, writes Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
Mr Kipling is to take his exceedingly good cakes onto the web in a bid to become more consumer-friendly.

Manor Bakeries, which makes Mr Kipling cakes, has become the latest in a line of well-known advertisers to turn to the net as a marketing device.

The manufacturer has hired digital agency Zinc to create a website dedicated to the brand. The site will go live next February, featuring information on diet and nutrition, as well as a customer feedback area. The site address will appear on Mr Kipling packaging, advertising and promotional materials.

Hazel Cawthorne, Mr Kipling's brand manager, said: "We want to give consumers the best access to the brand and see the website as the perfect route to do this. The site is going to be an enjoyable and interactive journey for our consumers."

Georgia Hall, managing director of Zinc, said: "Zinc is delighted to be working with the Mr Kipling team to develop such an exciting and established brand digitally."

webTitle: Hollick in talks over sale of Express titles

fields.headline: Hollick in talks over sale of Express titles
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: Lord Hollick's United News & Media yesterday admitted for the first time that it is in talks about the sale of its Express newspaper titles.
fields.body:
Lord Hollick's United News & Media yesterday admitted for the first time that it is in talks about the sale of its Express newspaper titles.

The group issued a terse three-sentence statement to the Stock Exchange confirming that it had received "a number of unsolicited offers for the Express Group" and, as a public company, "is obliged to consider these offers".

The Labour peer has previously insisted that the Daily Express, Sunday Express and Daily Star were not for sale. However, after approaches from potential suitors, it is thought he is now willing to sell the papers for £120m.

Three approaches are known to have been made so far, with the highest bid coming from the billionaire Hinduja brothers and lower offers from the Sunday Business- owning Barclay twins and David Montgomery, former chief executive of the Mirror.

The Hinduja brothers, Srichand and Gopichand, are understood to have made direct contact with Daily Express editor Rosie Boycott and her deputy Chris Blackhurst yesterday.

United's admission that the papers were on the block prompted other potential bidders to emerge. Cliff Stanford, founder of Demon Internet and chairman of internet hosting firm Redbus Interhouse, said he might be interested. "It's certainly something worth looking at," he said.

Richard Desmond, whose Northern & Shell group publishes OK! magazine, has been mentioned as a possible buyer of the Star. Harrods boss Mohamed Al Fayed expressed an interest in the past but is no longer thought to be interested.

The bid by the Hindujas, who are British citizens, comes a month before the two discover whether they are to be indicted on bribery charges in India. They deny the charges.

Yesterday they submitted an indicative offer of £100m to advisers Dresdner Kleinwort Benson. The Barclay brothers have submitted £75m. The bids have flushed out other potential buyers. Former Mirror Group boss David Montgomery is thought to have held talks with Lord Hollick about an offer backed by HSBC and venture capital group 3i.

Last night United's shares closed up 20p at 755p.

fields.headline: Duisenberg remark drags down euro
fields.standfirst:
Bundesbank chief says element of surprise is lost
A HREF="http://www.guardianunlimited.co.uk/EMU/">Special report: economic and monetary union
fields.trailText: The euro fell to within a whisker of its all time low against the US dollar yesterday after comments by the head of the European Central Bank were taken by the markets as ruling out any immediate support for the beleaguered currency.
fields.body:
The euro fell to within a whisker of its all time low against the US dollar yesterday after comments by the head of the European Central Bank were taken by the markets as ruling out any immediate support for the beleaguered currency.

In an interview with the Times newspaper, Wim Duisenberg said it would be inappropriate for policymakers to step into the markets in response to the current bout of nerves over political developments in the Middle East.

But in stark contrast to Mr Duisenberg's willingness to talk about intervention, the head of the Bundesbank, Ernst Welteke said last night that central bank operations in the market to support currencies only worked if policymakers did not discuss them. His comments are likely to be seen as a rebuke to Mr Duisenberg who has gained a reputation for unsettling the markets with his comments on the currency.

Asked by journalists on the chances that the United States would help the ECB again halt the euro's decline, Mr Welteke said: "Interventions belong to the monetary policy toolbox of every central bank, but they can only be successful if one doesn't talk about it."

His remarks helped stabilise the euro at around 84.8 cents in late trading yesterday after a sell-off in the wake of Mr Duisenberg's interview.

Traders who had been watching nervously for any signs that leading industrial nations were considering intervention, took the ECB head's comments as a signal that a repeat of last month's coordinated action by the Group of Seven leading economies was not on the cards.

Dealers dumped the currency, sending it as low as 84.58 cents to the dollar at one point, just a fraction above its low of 84.4 cents hit before the G7 intervention last month.

"Basically it's very clumsy. Intervention as a weapon relies on the element of surprise. If you remove that then it's not surprising that the exchange rate suffers," said Eckhard Schulte, an economist at Dresdner Kleinwort Benson.

But Commerzbank currency analyst Nick Parsons said Mr Duisenberg's comments represented an excuse to sell the euro. "I don't think [they] were a reason to do so."

With the euro nearly three cents lower than its level on the day the G7 intervened, Tony Norfield at ABN Amro warned that the "recovery pill" in the form of the central bank intervention last month had worn off. "We are back to square one."

fields.headline: Here come the super majors
fields.standfirst:
Crude may be $32 a barrel but oil company mergers are driven by increasing risks
Special report: the petrol war
fields.trailText: Crude prices bubbling at $32 per barrel and the spectre of fuel shortages triggered by the Middle East crisis would not seem the obvious backdrop to further retrenchment in the oil industry. But Texaco's surrender of its independence in a $35bn deal with Chevron to build the world's fourth biggest oil major shows that competitive pressures continue to grow.
fields.body:
Crude prices bubbling at $32 per barrel and the spectre of fuel shortages triggered by the Middle East crisis would not seem the obvious backdrop to further retrenchment in the oil industry. But Texaco's surrender of its independence in a $35bn deal with Chevron to build the world's fourth biggest oil major shows that competitive pressures continue to grow.

The creation of super majors such as BPAmoco, ExxonMobil and TotalFinaElf has raised the bar by which the investment community judges these integrated companies which pump oil from the ground, refine it, market it and pump it back into cars.

The financial performance of both Chevron and Texaco has been relatively lacklustre compared to the huge gains in profitability made by BP Amoco which has been able to squeeze out costs.

Big can be beautiful when it comes to raising cash and spending it on keeping the bank of oil reserves up. With players moving into the deeper waters of the US Gulf or politically turbulent areas such as West Africa or the Caspian Sea, risks are great, drilling costs high and the technology for firming up tricky reserves expensive. But Texaco and Chevron also find themselves competing against newcomers for the attention of investment bankers.

A new breed of rivals has been created over the past 24 months through privatisations, such as that of PetroChina, government sell-downs such as Petrobras of Brazil and spin-offs such as Conoco. A measure of how highly some of the new entities are regarded was given last week when Merrill Lynch's global oil team unveiled its list of preferred stocks - led by Petrobras.

Meanwhile Texaco trades at a discount to other major internationals with a price/earnings ratio of 10.6% compared with an average of 16.6% for its peers.

It has exploration potential in Brazil and West Africa, but production volumes are expected to be flat for two years, the Equilon and Motiva joint ventures with Shell have performed poorly and its Asian downstream joint venture with Chevron, known as Caltex, has been struggling.

Meanwhile Chevron has its own interesting upstream opportunities in Kazakhstan and West Africa and should increase its production this year by nearly 2.5% but its price/earnings ratio on the basis of 2000 earnings is also only 12.3%.

And others in the market are building their future. There has been mounting speculation that national champions in Italy (ENI) and Spain (Repsol) are said to be poised to tie the knot in an effort to increase their profitability and standing in the market. Royal Dutch/Shell is likely to pounce on BGI once it takes on a separate stock listing in London next week and has been trying to buy other smaller players such as Fletcher Challenge in New Zealand.

It was sub-$10 per barrel crude prices that started the merger and acquisition ball rolling two years ago as oil majors desperately sought ways of increasing profits by reducing overheads.

BP triggered a scramble for size by taking over Amoco of the US and then bought Arco and Burmah Castrol in quick succession. Exxon, the world's largest publicly-quoted oil group kept itself ahead in the size stakes by scooping up Mobil.

The only group that stood apart from the takeover frenzy was Shell, which initiated massive internal restructuring, closing offices, chopping jobs and trimming costs. Just as these moves got under way the oil price trebled as Saudi Arabia and the Organisation for Petroleum Exporting Countries slashed output.

A host of other factors - most recently the latest Palestinian uprising - have kept oil in the $35 range, filling the coffers of the oil majors and forcing them to consider huge share buybacks and other schemes to offload some of their profits. And higher prices look here to stay. The centrepiece of the Merrill Lynch presentation was a thesis that there had been a paradigm shift in the fundamentals of the oil price: the Brent blend average price of $18 over the last decade will be left behind, they say, towards an average close to $23.50 meaning higher profitability for everyone.

But as oil companies become ever larger through merger and acquisition, there have been growing signs of concern amongst the regulators. BP Amoco ran into ferocious opposition with the federal trade commission in the early stages of its Arco takeover and was forced to hive off assets in an effort to appease the civil servants. Chevron and Texaco may have to dispose of several refineries and hundreds of petrol stations to get their deal accepted.

Then there is the fee-making instincts of the investment banking community, which has already made money by building up these new industrial goliaths. At least one London bank was willing to predict privately last night that it would soon be time to start breaking up the super majors to take advantage of small but potentially lucrative opportunities for their now sprawling empires.

webTitle: Comment: On the brink of another oil crisis

fields.headline: We're on the brink
fields.standfirst:
The 1973 oil crisis took us by surprise, causing sudden panic. So will the coming one

Special report: the petrol war
fields.trailText: Are we in danger of experiencing another world oil crisis, like that of 1973 - which quadrupled the price of oil, unleashed a wave of high inflation, and turned the world upside down? The world financial markets are so far not too worried: but for anyone who studied that earlier shock closely the resemblances are still disturbing.
fields.body:
Are we in danger of experiencing another world oil crisis, like that of 1973 - which quadrupled the price of oil, unleashed a wave of high inflation, and turned the world upside down? The world financial markets are so far not too worried: but for anyone who studied that earlier shock closely the resemblances are still disturbing.

The basic cause of the shock in 1973 was a conjunction of a world oil shortage with a confrontation between Israel and the Arabs. The western nations, particularly America, were consuming cheap oil as if there were no tomorrow, becoming still more dependent on foreign producers, led by Saudi Arabia. When the Arab-Israel war broke out in 1973 the Arab producers boycotted oil to western countries - which in turn precipitated the shortage and huge price hikes.

The crisis took the media and the governments almost totally by surprise The American government had been warned over the previous years that the Saudis would find it hard to resist a boycott, but President Nixon in the run-up to a presidential election could not risk offending Israel. Most oil companies remained complacent until the shock happened: then it created a sudden panic, generating desperate demand, queues for petrol and hectic bidding for oil which forced the price still higher.

Does that sound familiar? Of course much has changed in 27 years. Today the Arab oil-producers are less dominating and less greedy, as they realise the danger to themselves of extorting too high a price. There is no danger of a military war against Israel comparable to the threat of Egypt and Syria when they invaded in 1973. Most of the world's oil comes from countries outside Opec, including Britain; and most countries have contingency plans against a shortage. "The west is now much better able to withstand an oil shock," the Financial Times assures us.

Yet the similarities remain. The Americans have been consuming oil as recklessly as they were in 1973: their roads are full of new gas-guzzlers, the huge "utility vehicles" like mini-tanks which loom above the road, intimidating the smaller cars, and consuming a gallon every 10 miles. Stretch limos, golf buggies and speedboats compete in guzzling oil with no thought of the conservation movements of the 80s.

The American government and media have largely lost interest in understanding Arab and other third world oil-producers, which loomed so large in the 70s and early 80s. And during the presidential elections neither candidate dares either to sympathise with Arab grievances, or suggest that Americans should conserve oil, or pay more for it.

The Europeans have been less wasteful, but still complacent. The rapid increase of the world oil price in the past two years, which should have been seen as a warning of a coming shortage, has led only to a clamour to reduce taxes and bring the price down. The British have now still fewer alternatives to the private car, with a failing railway network and decaying public transport for commuters.

It is only high oil prices and the fear of potential shortage which compels countries to conserve fuel and press forward with other forms of energy and transport. But the British, like the Americans, are becoming still more dependent on cars and oil.

In the meantime Asian and Latin American consumers are joining in the demand for unlimited cheap oil, without the prospect of unlimited supplies. While huge new reserves are opening up in central Asia and Africa, they all have their own political risks, in dangerous and remote parts of the world. The most accessible new oil remains in Arab countries which have their own quarrels with the west, including Iraq which now has huge new potential oil supplies.

The key oil producer, which holds the balance, remains the most problematic of all: Saudi Arabia. While the Saudi monarchy is ostensibly pro-American, dependent on American military and security support, they are becoming more worried by their own fundamentalists and dissidents who bitterly resent their government's subservience to the Americans, all the more since they rescued them from Saddam in the Gulf war 10 years ago.

The hijacking of a Saudi plane on Saturday by Saudi dissidents was a reminder of the vulnerability of the kingdom, where the greed and corruption of the royal family and the ignoring of human rights have caused a groundswell of resentment from fundamentalists, Shi'ites and exploited foreign workers. The demonstrations inside Saudi Arabia in support of Palestinians have been a reminder of the dangers of a pro-western policy. The lack of reliable reports in the media from inside the kingdom - there are no foreign correspondents there - is hardly reassuring: in Saudi Arabia, no news usually means bad news.

It is true that America and Israel have an overwhelming military might in the Middle East. But terrorists and suicide-bombers can still lead to body-bags - which is what politicians in both countries dread most. The damaging of an American destroyer by a small rubber dinghy, killing 17 sailors, is a powerful reminder of the fragility of a superpower in the face of Arab anger and dedicated terrorists.

While the Arabs are militarily weaker, the popular Arab anger appears much greater than in previous crises: not only among Palestinians, but among Arabs inside Israel who are more threatening to the Israeli population; and among the neighbouring Arab people who feel bitterly frustrated by the impotence of their governments.

So the basic ingredients of a crisis which could extend from the Middle East to the world, remain in place as they were in 1973: a wave of Arab resentment, a hardline Israeli attitude, and American politicians preoccupied by presidential elections. They are all set against a background of a potential oil shortage which could be precipitated by a single country - whether by Iraq, Iran or eventually Saudi Arabia itself, pressed to dissociate itself from pro-western policies.

The western countries and Israel cannot afford to be complacent on the basis of their economic strength and military superiority in the face of these political dangers. For popular anger can very quickly be translated into terrorism, and into effective pressure on governments to use their ultimate weapon of withdrawing oil supplies.

The western complacency and public ignorance which were so dangerous in the early 70s are back with us again. And oil, which has been been left to the specialists and companies over the past 20 years, can once again become an arbiter of world power.

 Anthony Sampson is the author of a book about the oil industry, The Seven Sisters

webTitle: Seven hour spacewalk spruces up the space station

fields.headline: Seven hour spacewalk spruces up the space station
fields.standfirst: Special report: space exploration
fields.trailText: Two spacewalking astronauts working with a crewmate inside shuttle Discovery attached a new docking port to the international space station yesterday.
fields.body:
Two spacewalking astronauts working with a crewmate inside shuttle Discovery attached a new docking port to the international space station yesterday.

The clearances were tight, and Jeff Wisoff and Michael Lopez-Alegria floated alongside the space station, calling out instructions, as Koichi Wakata gently nudged the docking port into place with the space shuttle's robot arm.

"Wow. This is just outstanding," one of the spacewalkers said when it was over. "Definitely," was the reply.

It was the second and final space station piece to be installed during the 240-mile high construction mission. An aluminum framework holding antennas and motion-control devices was attached to the station on Saturday and wired up by another pair of spacewalkers on Sunday.

Wisoff and Lopez-Alegria encountered problems as soon as they floated out the hatch. At first, their power drills wouldn't loosen the four latches holding down the docking port in Discovery's cargo bay.

"Who's scripting this, anyway?; one of them asked.

Once the latches were freed, Japanese astronaut Wakata lifted the 2,700-pound docking port on the end of Discovery's robot arm and positioned it on the space station.

The spacewalkers, one on each side, sounded like moving men as they advised Wakata during the final 1 1/2 feet: "Go in 3 inches, pitch up 1 degree, turn one-quarter of a degree to the left."

"OK, coming in," Wakata finally called out.

The spacewalkers' eyes proved invaluable. A short circuit knocked out a camera on the end of the robot arm Saturday.

The docking port will be used by space shuttle Endeavour when it delivers huge solar panels in December and by Atlantis when it carries up the American lab Destiny in January.

The spacewalk ended up lasting seven hours, a half-hour longer than planned.

"Fantastic job today, guys," astronaut Leroy Chiao said from the cockpit.

Two more spacewalks are planned, on Tuesday and Wednesday. The astronauts will depart from the space station on Friday. And if all goes well, the next crew to dock, on November 1, will be the station's first residents.

fields.headline: No sell-out, says Rover
fields.standfirst:
Share handout for 5,500 workers is riposte to reports of sale to foreign rival

Special report: Rover in crisis
fields.trailText: MG Rover, the embattled British car group, is to give shares in the company to all 5,500 employees next month as a signal that it intends pressing ahead with its plans to forge an independent future as a volume car-maker.
fields.body:
MG Rover, the embattled British car group, is to give shares in the company to all 5,500 employees next month as a signal that it intends pressing ahead with its plans to forge an independent future as a volume car-maker.

Repeatedly rejecting reports that the group is to be sold to a foreign buyer and that non-executive directors are demanding an emergency board meeting to clarify MG's future, senior directors said yesterday that employees would be given 35% of the company's equity "within the next four to five weeks".

John Parkinson, sales and marketing director, said on the eve of the British Motor Show in Birmingham: "There's no division between the main board and the non-executives on the supervisory board and complete unanimity about the business plan.

The board is meeting on October 27, it's a regular meeting and there's no special item on the agenda."

Under the share ownership scheme, the four founders of the Phoenix consortium that bought Rover from BMW for £10 in May - including chair man John Towers - will end up with 40% of the equity. The remaining 25% will be given to MG Rover dealers.

Mr Towers, a former Rover chief executive, has been accused of planning with his three fellow partners to sell the group to a rival manufacturer, reported to be Malaysia's Proton, and to make up to £8m in the process.

Mr Parkinson and fellow director, Rob Oldaker, responsible for product development, rejected the accusation, pointing out that Proton had told the Kuala Lumpur stock exchange that it was not interested in an equity deal with the British car maker. MG Rover admits it was approached by another manufacturer - cited as Proton in union circles - six weeks ago about a collaboration deal on a new medium-sized car to be launched in 2004 and talks are continuing.

"Someone wants to put two and two together and make five out of it ," said Mr Parkinson.

He said the group would have to decide by spring next year whether to join with a partner in developing a replacement for the R25 and R45 or build the new car on an existing platform, most probably the R75 - designed by BMW and now being built at MG Rover's Longbridge plant near Birmingham.

"Our preferred route is collaboration because it brings economies of scale and reduced component costs but both options will be evaluated."

Mr Oldaker said the group was working on a number of collaboration deals, including the possibility of making cars under contract on the assembly lines put in by BMW at Longbridge for 150,000 new Minis a year. These are idle now the Mini is being built at BMW's Oxford plant.

But both directors made plain that the key to the company's future lies in a range of "raw but high-performing" models under the MG badge, which are due to provide 25% of the group's annual output of between 200,000 and 250,000 vehicles a year by 2004.

Three MG saloons, based on the existing R25, 45 and 75 models, are to be launched next year with more powerful engines and a complete restyling - and MG is to take part in next year's Le Mans 24-hour endurance test with an engine supplied by another manufacturer.

webTitle: Inside Story: Minitel, the original on-line system

fields.headline: Vive le Minitel
fields.standfirst:
It was the original online system that in the 80s made France the envy of its neighbours. And although they are starting to embrace the internet, the French are still in love with their antiquated little black 'box'. Stuart Jeffries reports on the relaunch of a Gallic invention

Net news
fields.trailText: It was the original online system that in the 80s made France the envy of its neighbours. And although they are starting to embrace the internet, the French are still in love with their antiquated little black 'box'. Stuart Jeffries reports on the relaunch of a Gallic invention.
fields.body:
France Télécom has just launched its most expensive publicity campaign ever. It spent 30m francs (£3m) on radio and TV ads to promote Minitel, that aged Gallic precursor of the internet. What on earth is it thinking of? In an age of Wap phones and Palm Pilots, an ugly little box with chunky on-screen text that makes Ceefax look elegant could hardly have a future worth such an investment. Surely the French would do better to let Minitel go the way of the dinosaurs?

Minitel is a creature of the 80s and now seems as dated as mullet hairdos and Bananarama. But France Télécom will not let Minitel die. Instead, it insists that the system has a bright future: there are 7m Minitel-compatible terminals in France now, and 8.5m will be able to use the relaunched Minitel by 2003. This is thanks to new software that enables Minitel's services to be accessed on PCs and Macs. The result, perhaps inevitably, is called the i-Minitel.

But what, exactly, is Minitel? When it was first launched in 1982, a Minitel terminal consisted of a small monitor with a keyboard and a telephone link. These little "boxes", as they're still called, were distributed free with normal telephone service by France Télécom. At the time, Minitel seemed like the last word in communications technology and the French were properly proud of it. Minitel was first used as an online Yellow Pages.

In François Mitterrand's France of the 80s, Minitel was a symbol of the country's technological virility. As much as the then president's so-called grands projets - the Opéra Bastille, La Défense, the Bibliothèque Nationale and IM Pei's pyramid at the Louvre - Minitel showed that France was a thoroughly modern place. It must have been particularly pleasing for French patriots to look across the Channel and witness the failure of Prestel, Britain's long-defunct version of Minitel. You remember Prestel, don't you? Thought not.

From these beginnings, Minitel went from strength to strength. It quickly became linked to other central databanks. It was a newspaper, a mail-order service, a ticket agency, a railway and airline bookings office, an online bill-paying service, an encyclopaedia - all at once.

Minitel hardware evolved over the years, including a desktop computer version and even a laptop, but all had French keyboards, which to qwerty-fixated Anglo-Saxons was rather irritating. What's more, it is still operated in the same way as it was back in 1982. Arguably, for a long time after Minitel should have been ditched, the French stayed with relatively expensive, limited and non-international communications technology. And, while the French had been the envy of their neighbours during the 80s because of Minitel, in the following decade they were derided for not keeping up with the communications revolution.

In May this year, a survey by the IT consultancy CMG of 250 companies in Britain, France, Germany and the Netherlands, showed that France had succeeded in knocking the UK into second place in the European e-commerce stakes. fields.headline: 'Explosive' NHS plans revealed
fields.standfirst: Special report: the future of the NHS
fields.trailText: Labour's favourite thinktank is considering plans to hand over the running of NHS hospitals to the private sector as an experiment to see if commercial firms can deliver better value for money and more effective care than the public sector.
fields.byline: Larry Elliott, John Carvel  and Charlotte Denny
fields.body:
Labour's favourite thinktank is considering plans to hand over the running of NHS hospitals to the private sector as an experiment to see if commercial firms can deliver better value for money and more effective care than the public sector.

Doctors and nurses would be transferred to private sector employment as part of a radical blueprint for the health sector being examined by a high level commission set up by the Institute for Public Policy Research.

According to confidential drafts seen by the Guardian, private firms would no longer be confined to providing an cillary services such as cleaning and catering in NHS hospitals, but would also be allowed to provide the full range of clinical services. Officials at the Treasury and the Department of Health have been kept in touch with the commission's work, although Whitehall sources yesterday sought to distance the government from the plans.

One commission member admitted yesterday that allowing the private sector to run medical care facilities paid for by the taxpayer would be "politically explosive" in the run up to an election. The director of the IPPR, Matthew Taylor, said the commission's final report would not be ready until Christmas. He added the ideas put forward for health were an attempt to "think imaginatively" about the boundaries between the public and private sector.

Under the scheme, the government would continue to provide the funding for all hospitals and care would remain free at the point of delivery, but a pilot scheme would be set up to see whether privately-operated hospitals were more effective than those run in the traditional manner."We are definitely not talking about the privatisation of the NHS," Mr Taylor said.

However, unions have already denounced the suggestions from a group on the commission looking at core public services. Paul Marks, Unison's national secretary for health, said: "What the commission is suggesting is a dangerous experiment. Unison has always warned that PFI [the private finance initiative] is a staging post to privatisation of the NHS. There is increasing evidence that PFI is a costly failure and there is no need to include staff in schemes.

"A recent opinion poll, carried out by MORI for Unison, showed that 77% of the public do not want health care delivered for profit. It is essential that the government categorically rules out these plans and reassures the public that the NHS is safe in its hands."

The working party said the commission should "recommend that public-private partnerships be seen as contracting for a specific outcome and an appropriate package of ser vices to deliver this. The set of services included within the PFI should be expanded to include both core clinical or support (clinical) services, such as radiology, x-ray etc".

It adds: "The best way to evaluate the potential for reconfigured hospital services would be through including, within a hospital PFI, an 'operate' function that included management of clinical services - with staff transferring to private sector employment. A carefully designed pilot project should take place where the health authority, as part of its health improvement plan, identifies a need for new-build hospitals to meet health needs, or where substantial refurbishment of existing hospital facilities together with a re placement of management is needed."

With an election campaign perhaps only six months away, officials at the Department of Health were cool about running with the idea of privately-operated NHS hospitals.

A department source said it had no involvement in the IPPR exercise and ministers had not seen a copy of the draft report.

"We always read IPPR stuff with interest, but don't always agree with it," the source said. "The government's proposals in respect of NHS reform were set out in the NHS plan [published in July]. We don't expect to go beyond that."

fields.headline: Northern lab gets £10m
fields.standfirst: Special report: north-south divide
fields.trailText: A leading science laboratory in Cheshire is to receive a £10m consolation prize after losing a big contract in a dispute which sparked allegations that the government was accentuating the north-south divide.
fields.body:
A leading science laboratory in Cheshire is to receive a £10m consolation prize after losing a big contract in a dispute which sparked allegations that the government was accentuating the north-south divide.

In March, ministers appeared to bow to pressure from sponsors, including the French government and the Wellcome Trust, that the new £500m Diamond x-ray synchrotron machine should be housed at the Rutherford Appleton laboratories in Oxfordshire rather than at the Daresbury laboratory near Runcorn.

Scientists and politicians in the north claimed the decision threatened jobs and Daresbury's long-term future.

The £10m goes to a consortium working on research developing from the human genome project. The funding is part of a £26m package of funds drawn from existing budgets aimed at nine science projects in the north-west of England involving the laboratory and five universities in Liverpool, Manchester and Salford.

"This funding will help underpin the north-west's scientific strengths," said the science minister, Lord Sainsbury, during a visit to Daresbury yesterday.

The decision was welcomed by the laboratory's managers, although unions representing more than 550 staff feared it would not safeguard jobs.

fields.headline: Orange pulls out of licence auction
fields.standfirst: Special report: e-finance
fields.trailText: Mobile phone company Orange yesterday pulled out of the government's auction of broadband fixed wireless licences, the technology that provides fast internet services to desk top computers.
fields.body:
Mobile phone company Orange yesterday pulled out of the government's auction of broadband fixed wireless licences, the technology that provides fast internet services to desk top computers.

The news came amid uncertainty about the timing of the auction, which was provisionally supposed to begin yesterday.

Orange, which is expected to be floated on the stock market early next year, said it was looking at a number of broadband access technologies.

"At this stage it is too early to say which type of technology we will ultimately use," Orange said in a statement.

Explaining the decision an Orange spokeswoman said: "The reason we have withdrawn [from the auction] is that it is not commercially viable for us."

The company, which is owned by France Telecom, said that broadband services remained "core to the Orange vision".

The company's withdrawal leaves 11 companies bidding for some 42 licences, and the process is expected to raise around £2bn - just a fraction of the money generated by the auction of third-generation mobile phone licences earlier this year.

A new date for the auction will have to be set to allow time for the resolution of a number of "pre-qualification" issues, according to a Department of Trade and Industry spokesman.

He declined to specify what the issues were but said that there were "details which needed to be cleared up".

Once that had been done the auction could get under way, he said, adding that the DTI was hopeful the process would be able to start within the next few weeks.

The timetable of the auction had not been influenced by the Orange decision to withdraw, he added.

fields.standfirst: Special report: e-finance
fields.trailText: BT bids for UMTS licence | No offer for Compel | e-quisitor agrees funding | Business Internet Survey
fields.body:
Italian deal Britain's BT remains committed to bidding for an Italian UMTS licence through the Blu mobile phone consortium, a BT spokesman said. He was responding to a report in La Repubblica which said participation of Blu in the auction is at risk because most of its shareholders refuse to finance the operation.

Bid denial UK-owned Specialist Computer said it had no current intention of making an offer for Compel Group . The news comes just over a week after Computacenter said it was no longer interested in bidding for Compel.

Funding The AIM-listed e-quisitor , established to build a group of profitable information-oriented businesses, said it has agreed a funding facility with Barclays Acquisition Finance in Leeds of £25m on a six-year term. A £2m working capital facility has also been agreed.

webTitle: Real IRA blames Provisionals for murder

fields.headline: Real IRA blames Provisionals for murder
fields.standfirst: Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: The dissident Real IRA yesterday vowed to avenge the assassination of its Belfast leader Joseph O'Connor amid growing fears a murderous republican terrorist feud was poised to erupt in west Belfast.
fields.body:
The dissident Real IRA yesterday vowed to avenge the assassination of its Belfast leader Joseph O'Connor amid growing fears a murderous republican terrorist feud was poised to erupt in west Belfast.

The Real IRA, responsible for the Omagh atrocity which killed 29 people in 1998, is blaming the mainstream Provisional IRA for his murder outside his mother's home on Friday. The Continuity IRA, the other hardline republican group dedicated to overthrowing the Good Friday agreement, agreed and said it too was on a war footing.

The Sinn Fein, including party president Gerry Adams, insisted the Provisional IRA was not responsible, citing a dispute between the two dissident groups. The party usually asserts it is distinct from paramilitaries by insisting it cannot to speak for them.

But Sir Ronnie Flanagan, the RUC chief constable, confirmed that police were investigating whether the Provisional IRA was involved. Two murders of Catholic drug dealers this year were linked to it.

O'Connor, 26, who had three young sons, was shot at least five times in the head as he got into a car in Ballymurphy, heartland of the Provisional IRA. Two hooded gunman had approached the car on foot.

Suspicions that the Provisional IRA killed O'Connor piled pressure on the first minister, David Trimble, leader of the Ulster Unionists, ahead of his crucial meeting of his party's ruling council on October 28. His critics cited it as reason to pull out of the power-sharing executive, where Sinn Fein has two of the 12 places.

O'Connor's mother, Margaret, had no doubts the Provisional IRA was to blame. She said: "They were seen. People saw them with their masks on and with their masks off. They are a known unit within the Ballymurphy district."

Her father, Francisco Notorantonio, 66, a retired taxi-driver, was murdered in October 1987 in one of the most controversial murders of the Troubles. Army handlers of a loyalist mole are said to have ordered Mr Notorantonio's shooting to protect an IRA double agent, Steak Knife.

O'Connor's widow, Nichola, believed that, although the Provisional IRA was involved, his murder was more down to a personal feud than a sanctioned operation. His funeral is likely to take place tomorrow, and will signal a massive intelligence-gathering operation.

The Real IRA said it had identified Provisional IRA volunteers involved in the attack. It had so far resisted attempts to provoke it into violence, and accused mainstream republicans of colluding to maintain a British presence in Ireland.

The Real IRA said: "Our volunteers will be protected, and at a time and place of our choosing, those guilty of this offence will be dealt with accordingly. This is not an idle threat. Nor should it be interpreted as a signal for indiscriminate attacks on innocent republicans loyal to the provo leadership."

fields.headline: Ebookers says its sales are up by 16%
fields.standfirst:
Net news
Special report: e-finance
fields.trailText: Ebookers.com yesterday saw a much needed rise in its share price as the online travel agency reported third quarter results with sales 16% ahead of market forecasts.
fields.body:
Ebookers.com yesterday saw a much needed rise in its share price as the online travel agency reported third quarter results with sales 16% ahead of market forecasts.

The shares went up by 8% on the Neuer Markt, to close at €8.1, as the company reassured investors that it was on course for profitability by early 2002. The share price is, however, still down about 80% on its all time high, after speculation about cash difficulties.

Dinesh Dhamija, chief executive officer of Ebookers, which raised $45m in July, said the company would break into the European business travel market within the year.

"We will be moving into business travel as soon as possible and we will certainly be looking to buy a company in Italy", Mr Dhamija said.

The company, which has expanded into 11 European countries, yesterday announced that sales, of £23m, had risen more than three and a half times, compared to the same period a year earlier.

Pre-tax loss, excluding stock compensation, was £7.2m and Ebookers has£36.7m in the bank, money to be used until profitability is achieved.

The number of registered users at the end of the third quarter was 740, 000, up from 500,000 at the end of the previous quarter.

According to Ebookers, losses have peaked and are on a downward spiral. The marketing and branding on the whole has been done, so costs are going down. "It is becoming a more stable business", Mr Dhamija said.

The firm also generates revenue from Ebookersfinance.com, which is on the Ebookers site and is run by Moneygator.com.
