Dinesh Dhamija, chief executive officer of Ebookers, which raised $45m in July, said the company would break into the European business travel market within the year. "We will be moving into business travel as soon as possible and we will certainly be looking to buy a company in Italy", Mr Dhamija said. The company, which has expanded into 11 European countries, yesterday announced that sales, of £23m, had risen more than three and a half times, compared to the same period a year earlier. Pre-tax loss, excluding stock compensation, was £7.2m and Ebookers has£36.7m in the bank, money to be used until profitability is achieved. The number of registered users at the end of the third quarter was 740, 000, up from 500,000 at the end of the previous quarter. According to Ebookers, losses have peaked and are on a downward spiral. The marketing and branding on the whole has been done, so costs are going down. "It is becoming a more stable business", Mr Dhamija said. The firm also generates revenue from Ebookersfinance.com, which is on the Ebookers site and is run by Moneygator.com.

webTitle: Middle East: Bitter summit sinks into sand

fields.headline: Bitter summit sinks into sand
fields.standfirst:
Screaming matches in Egypt as another boy is shot dead in clashes
Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: Screaming matches in Egypt as another boy is shot dead in clashes
fields.byline: Suzanne Goldenberg in Sharm el-Sheikh and  Ian Black in Jerusalem
fields.body:
The emergency summit to claw back the Middle East from the brink of all-out war last night degenerated into frosty silence punctuated by screaming matches.

As both sides traded live fire in the West Bank and Gaza, and a 13-year-old Palestinian boy shot in the head in Bethlehem was pronounced clinically dead, negotiators could not even agree on an agenda yesterday, let alone who should hold fire.

Israeli officials reported "a sharp and bitter" session of foreign ministers, including a slanging match between the Israeli foreign minister, Shlomo Ben Ami, and Saeb Erakat, the chief Palestinian negotiator.

Mr Erakat told Israel: "You are talking at us with guns." Mr Ben Ami retorted: "Save that for CNN", pounded the table and walked out. He only returned accompanied by the US secretary of state, Madeleine Albright.

"Until now, there is no progress," said Yasser Abd Rabbo, a senior Palestinian negotiator. "The atmosphere is not improving."

Meanwhile, scores were wounded in clashes yesterday. The fiercest incident was at Rafah, near the Egyptian border, where a Palestinian policeman was killed and two Israeli soldiers wounded.

The unnamed Palestinian boy was reportedly hit in clashes near Rachel's Tomb, outside Bethlehem.

Negotiations were expected to continue late last night but must end by noon today, when President Clinton, part of a galaxy of world leaders and se nior international diplomats whose arrival in Sharam el-Sheikh underlines the urgency of the situation, has to return to Washington.

Yesterday's steep rise in violence underlined the great gamble of the summit: a failure to broker a ceasefire could drive the conflagration far beyond the West Bank and Gaza.

Despite more than 11 hours of coddling by the leaders and diplomats, Israel and the Palestinians drew no nearer to an agreement to end the carnage.

Instead, Israel's prime minister, Ehud Barak, and the Palestinian leader, Yasser Arafat, remained locked in recrimination, revisiting the atmosphere of hatred and suspicion that ruled the region before the two sides embraced the path of peace seven years ago.

The two leaders did not hold one-on-one meetings, channelling their frustrations through Mr Clinton, who met each man twice, and the summit host, the Egyptian president, Hosni Mubarak.

"I saw Mr Barak on television and he was full of venom, intransigence, and cruelty," said Nabil Shaath, a senior Palestinian negotiator. "He still talks like an occupier."

Arab governments were said to be threatening to link progress on the Israel-Palestine dispute to a threat to lift sanctions against Iraq, seriously eroded in recent weeks. This would pose a serious problem for the US and force it to choose between two issues of vital importance.

Yesterday's standoff defied efforts by Mr Clinton, the United Nations secretary general, Kofi Annan, the European Union's Javier Solana and the leaders of Jordan and Egypt.

All spoke of their fears of a deepening confrontation.

"We should not give it all up for what has happened in the last few weeks, and what has happened in the last few weeks reminds us of the terrible alternatives to continuing to live in peace, and to continuing the peace process," Mr Clinton said.

The kernel of yesterday's dispute lies in Mr Barak's insistence that Mr Arafat halt the violence by reining in Palestinian policemen and the tanzim, the armed cells of his Fatah organisation, which have opened fire on Israeli soldiers.

The Palestinians are adamant that Israel yield first by rolling back its tanks positioned outside luxury flats in Ramallah and in other West Bank cities. Mr Arafat also wants Israel to lift a closure on the West Bank and Gaza, which has cut off his people from jobs in Israel that are a lifeline.

Those demands are unthinkable for Mr Barak, who is facing intense domestic pressure to take a tough stand against the Palestinians. "Mr Barak is fed up with Arafat," said Nachman Shai, an Israeli spokesman.

The two sides remain no closer on reconciling Palestinian demands for a full-scale international investigation into the violence.

That demand wrecked a summit earlier this month between the Israeli and Palestinian leaders in Paris.

Yesterday, Mr Barak was willing to concede only a modest fact-finding committee under US auspices.

In Beirut, the secretary general of the Lebanese Hizbullah group, Sheikh Hassan Nasrallah, said that an Israeli in their hands was a Mossad officer seeking to penetrate their ranks. He said Elhahan Tenenbaum had been lured to Lebanon and seized there, not in Switzerland, as previously reported. He had travelled to Beirut from Brussels on a false foreign passport.

But Israel continued to insist the man was a private individual who had no connection with the Mossad. The Israeli media has been told there are legal restrictions on reporting the case.

webTitle: Bush's ideal day: 9 to 5 and a two-hour lunch

fields.headline: Bush's ideal day: 9 to 5 and a two-hour lunch
fields.standfirst: Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: As a workaholic president of a workaholic nation, Bill Clinton will fly anywhere, anytime, to try to broker a peace deal. There is nothing he likes better than to stay up all night conferring with White House policy wonks. Like his boss, Al Gore promises to work 24 hours a day, seven days a week if he becomes president.
fields.body:
As a workaholic president of a workaholic nation, Bill Clinton will fly anywhere, anytime, to try to broker a peace deal. There is nothing he likes better than to stay up all night conferring with White House policy wonks. Like his boss, Al Gore promises to work 24 hours a day, seven days a week if he becomes president.

George W Bush, on the other hand, prefers a regular two-hour lunch break, likes to wrap up his day's business by 5pm, and reckons on getting plenty of rest and "private time".

If the polls are right and Mr Bush captures the White House on November 7, then not only will some of the policies of the Ronald Reagan era enjoy a comeback - the famous Reagan attention span, or the lack of it, will return to the Oval Office too.

A survey of Mr Bush's work schedule published yesterday reveals a man who dislikes meetings that last longer than 10 minutes, who reads little, who rarely bothers himself with policy, and who spends most of his short working day at photo opportunities and ceremonial occasions.

More than 900 pages of Mr Bush's daily schedules as governor of Texas reveal a politician who typically does not start work until 9am, who likes to finish the morning's business at 11.30, who takes two hours for lunch and a three-mile run in what he calls "private time", and who will not plan any office engagements after 5pm.

In his autobiography, Mr Bush writes that "by far the most profound" decision he ever takes is whether to allow another Texas execution to go ahead. The schedules show that what he fails to mention is most of these decisions - he has allowed 145 executions since becoming governor - took less than 15 minutes.

Mr Bush's aides say his style is to assert broad principles rather than engage in the details, to delegate, and to focus instead on being an effective networker and communicator.

It remains to be seen how far he will be able to maintain his preferred routines if he becomes president. As his best friend, Doug Hannah, puts it, Mr Bush has "an attention span of about an hour".

fields.headline: Mandelson inquiry may be reopened
fields.standfirst: Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: Elizabeth Filkin, the parliamentary standards commissioner, is poised to reopen her files on Peter Mandelson's £373,000 home loan in the wake of Geoffrey Robinson's renewed charges yesterday that the Northern Ireland secretary solicited the cash from his now estranged friend.
fields.body:
Elizabeth Filkin, the parliamentary standards commissioner, is poised to reopen her files on Peter Mandelson's £373,000 home loan in the wake of Geoffrey Robinson's renewed charges yesterday that the Northern Ireland secretary solicited the cash from his now estranged friend.

The Conservatives accused Mr Mandelson of being a "divisive" influence on Tony Blair's government and, more damagingly, said that the former paymaster general did give large sums - probably in excess of £100,000 - to Mr Blair's "blind trust" before the 1997 election.

Downing Street dismissed the renewed ruckus as "pretty flat broth" as the Daily Mail's second extract from Mr Robinson's book, The Unconventional Minister, today focuses on the feud between Mr Mandelson and Mr Robinson's patron, Gordon Brown, over Europe and the single currency. Senior MPs and Labour officials urged Mr Blair to bang heads together to restore discipline.

But Mrs Filkin's decision, prompted by a complaint from the former Tory trade spokesman John Redwood, could rebound more on Mr Robinson than on Mr Mandelson because his own book suggests that he has changed the evidence he gave to parliament after both men were forced to resign in 1998 when the Guardian disclosed the secret loan.

At the time, he appeared to back up the former trade secretary's claim that he had been offered - rather than solicited - the huge loan to buy a £465,000 home in fashionable Notting Hill, west London.

Though he yesterday denied calling Mr Mandelson a liar, the millionaire MP told Radio 4's Today programme: "There is very clearly, however, a marked difference of opinion between the ac counts that he has given [and mine]".

MPs on the Commons standards and privileges committee are divided over the new claims, with Martin Bell, the anti-sleaze independent, expressing alarm about "contradictory accounts", and Labour's Dale Campbell-Savours dismissing the claims for a fresh inquiry as "absurd".

William Hague declared the government to be "rife with cronyism and cover-ups", and challenged Mr Blair to back a fresh Commons inquiry; to confront Mr Mandelson and sack him a second time if he admits to lying; and to explain the discrepancies on the blind trust payments.

Lady Jay, who chaired the blind trust before it was shut down in 1997, stood by her 1998 statement that no money was received from Mr Robinson. Lord Merlyn Rees, another trustee, endorses that claim.

In a significant move last night, Mr Brown distanced himself from his old colleague. "Mr Brown has made clear on numerous occasions, both to Geoffrey Robinson and in public, that it was not appropriate to write this book," said the chancellor's spokesman.

Apart from an attack on Mr Mandelson from the leftwing MP Diane Abbott, there was little Labour support for Mr Robinson's decision to go public. Few MPs expect Mr Mandelson to go. Even Mr Robinson, who has killed any chance of returning to office, claimed he bears him "nothing but goodwill".

In interviews yesterday, and repeated in today's Daily Mail, Mr Robinson, a sceptic about the euro, complained that Mr Mandelson repeatedly tried to undermine Mr Brown's cautious stance on UK membership of the single currency.

Yet the chancellor's statement pointedly praised his rival. "Mr Mandelson has been doing - and will continue to do - an excellent job as secretary of state for Northern Ireland," Mr Brown said.

Mr Redwood urged Mrs Filkin to cross-examine both MPs this time. Last time, only Mr Mandelson gave direct evidence.

Mr Redwood's colleague David Heathcoat-Amory is asking the committee when it meets next Tuesday to consider whether Mr Mandelson breached parliamentary privilege by giving false evidence.

Mrs Filkin can go ahead with an inquiry without the committee's permission, though it does not have to accept her report.

webTitle: Majority regard cannabis as no worse than drink

fields.headline: Majority regard cannabis as no worse than drink
fields.standfirst: Special report: drugs in Britain
fields.trailText: A clear majority of British voters believe that using cannabis is no worse than smoking or drinking, according to the latest Guardian/ICM opinion poll.
fields.body:
A clear majority of British voters believe that using cannabis is no worse than smoking or drinking, according to the latest Guardian/ICM opinion poll.

The survey also shows that the overwhelming majority also believe that smoking dope should not remain a criminal act in Britain. Some 43% even go so far as saying that its personal use should be legalised completely - a far higher proportion than previously recorded on Guardian/ICM opinion polls.

The findings confirm the view that a change has taken place in British public opinion about the future legal status of cannabis and that Ann Widdecombe was out of tune when she proposed replacing a policy of police cautions with a mandatory £100 fixed penalty fine. Only one in five voters believes that possession of cannabis should remain a criminal offence.

Opinion is most pro-cannabis among the 25 to 34 age group, some 50% of whom believe its personal use should be legalised. Two-thirds of this age group believe that smoking cannabis is no worse than smoking tobacco or drinking alcohol. This is higher than even the 65% of 18-24 year olds who subscribe to the same view. Indeed, the only age group to disagree with this proposition is the over 65s some 49% of whom were against. Even among these "grey voters" one in three agrees that cannabis is no worse than alcohol or tobacco.

Despite the fact that politicians in recent days have contrasted the experience of middle class youngsters at university with what goes on in "the real world" of inner city council estates, there is little difference in view across social class about cannabis law reform. Some 45% of DE voters - the unskilled and unemployed - think it should be legalised as do 44% of AB voters - the professional classes.

The poll does however show a clear divide between those who want to see the decriminalisation of cannabis but are not yet prepared to see it fully legalised. While 22% said they believed the personal use of cannabis should remain a criminal act, some 30% said the police should not make prosecution a priority and it should effectively be decriminalised. The issue has polarised opinion with only 4% of voters saying they had no opinion on the matter.

The findings of this poll, combined with weekend surveys also showing large majorities for decriminalisation, will put Tony Blair and Jack Straw under further pressure to reassess the government's policy on drugs.

The next opportunity will come when Home Office ministers give evidence to the Commons home affairs select committee on why they dismissed within hours of publication the Police Foundation report on cannabis published in March. The report, which included two chief constables among its membership, recommended that prison should no longer be used for cannabis possession.

Some 4,500 people were imprisoned last year after being convicted of cannabis charges.

webTitle: Life in Great Budworth, with no cause for alarms

fields.headline: Life in Great Budworth, with no cause for alarms
fields.standfirst: Special report: policing crime
fields.trailText: At least until 3pm, when the narrow lanes suddenly throng with bullish 4x4 vehicles on the school run, the streets of Great Budworth in Cheshire are almost silent. A few couples enjoy a quiet half in the pub, at the top of the village street an elderly man weeds through his flower bed, but most of the low, leaded windows on the half-timbered chocolate-box houses are dark.
fields.body:
At least until 3pm, when the narrow lanes suddenly throng with bullish 4x4 vehicles on the school run, the streets of Great Budworth in Cheshire are almost silent. A few couples enjoy a quiet half in the pub, at the top of the village street an elderly man weeds through his flower bed, but most of the low, leaded windows on the half-timbered chocolate-box houses are dark.

Inside you can see televisions, videos and microwaves; no doubt there is a fair amount of jewellery tucked away in this affluent commuter village, 25 miles south of Manchester. But almost none of the cottages has a lock on its windows, and only a couple have burglar alarms. This is not a community, it seems, that lives in fear of crime.

"I think people feel more secure in the country," says Jane Perry, 32, who lives in the nearby village of Marston but has come to Budworth for a quiet drink. "There's less opportunity to steal things." Her husband Danny, a builder, agrees that burglary is not much of a worry. "We have dogs, and we do lock everything, obviously, but in 10 years we have never had a problem in our house."

The villagers of Great Budworth neatly illustrate the paradox in the way rural crime is perceived. They say they are surprised to learn that burglaries are falling in rural areas, that they would have thought crime was on the up. But then, come to think of it, they can't remember having any trouble themselves.

Sue Scott's husband's family has lived in the village for decades. "I'm not too concerned," she says. "I feel that I'm rather protected here." She has never felt the need for an alarm on her home - her neighbours, after all, are watching the house if she is out. "We keep an eye on each others' homes. Everyone is close to their neighbours."

But despite Great Budworth's picture-postcard appearance, all is not entirely idyllic. Break-ins may not concern the residents unduly but car crime, they agree, is more of a problem. Mrs Scott's car and that of her next-door neighbour were broken into last year. One man, sipping Guinness in the pub, admits that he came to the village partly to see if a man he suspects of breaking into his van is around. A local shopkeeper confesses to alarm about raids on his till.

Mrs Scott's father-in-law, Alan, is tending her garden. At 80, he lives alone on a farm in nearby Frodsham, and keeps a double-barrelled shotgun in the house. "I bought it 20 years ago thinking that there might be problems with crime. It was just to scare people." He has never had to use it, but says: "It might come in handy some time, I suppose."

A local shopkeeper confesses to alarm about raids on his till. Mrs Scott's father-in-law, Alan, is tending her garden. At 80, he lives alone on a farm in nearby Frodsham, and keeps a double-barrelled shotgun in the house. "I bought it 20 years ago thinking that there might be problems with crime. It was just to scare people." He has never had to use it, but says: "It might come in handy some time, I suppose."

webTitle: Desperate fight to stop spread of Ebola virus

fields.headline: Desperate fight to stop spread of Ebola virus
fields.standfirst: International effort mobilised as toll mounts in Ugandan epidemic of horrific disease that has no cure
fields.trailText: Ugandan officials yesterday threatened to use force to prevent anyone leaving three areas of the country stricken by an outbreak of deadly Ebola haemorrhagic fever as an international effort was mobilised to contain the epidemic.
fields.byline: Anna Borzello  in Kampala and  Sarah Boseley
fields.body:
Ugandan officials yesterday threatened to use force to prevent anyone leaving three areas of the country stricken by an outbreak of deadly Ebola haemorrhagic fever as an international effort was mobilised to contain the epidemic.

As the World Health Organisation put the death toll at 43, including three nurses, worrying signs emerged that the epidemic might be spreading. There is no treatment for Ebola, whose victims rapidly bleed to death. Because it is highly infectious, the only hope of stopping an outbreak is isolating victims and their contacts.

Until the weekend, the victims had been restricted to a 20-mile radius of the northern Ugandan district capital of Gulu, which is 225 miles north of the capital, Kampala. However, since Saturday new cases have been reported outside the original area of infection.

"Four cases have been reported in neighbouring Kitgum district, while five people have been admitted to hospital from Pece, a suburb of Gulu town which was not affected before," said Lt Col Walter Ochoro, who heads a taskforce set up to combat the disease.

More worryingly still, two cases of Ebola have also been reported in Atiak and Amoru, two congested camps north and west of Gulu that are home to tens of thousands of people displaced by the insurgency in the region.

Oladapo Walker, Uganda's WHO representative, said: "This is a problem but we just have to do the best that we can under the circumstances.

"If we are able to quickly isolate the reported cases in the camps we should be able to contain it very quickly. But if we are not able to isolate the reported cases in the camp very quickly, that is a serious business."

Lt-Col Ochoro said that all schools in the affected areas had been ordered closed and residents were told they could not leave except for medical attention.

"We hope we will not have to use force but we are determined to beat this," he said.

International aid workers and scientists are converging on the area to support the Ugandan effort and study the disease.

The WHO has sent two Ebola experts to Gulu and two more, one epidomologist and one specialist in barrier nursing, are due to fly in today.

A public education programme has been launched, advising local people to stay away from infected people and to suspend cultural practices, such as burial rights, that might inadvertently spread the disease.

Until now, Gulu's two hospitals, which are underfunded and overstretched, have been struggling to deal with the epidemic. A shipment of medicines has been provided by the WHO, as well as protective clothing in the form of goggles, face masks and aprons.

Ebola is what is known as a filovirus - the only known virus family that scientists are profoundly ignorant about. The first filovirus infection to be identified was of the Marburg strain in 1967, when laboratory workers in Marburg, Germany were taken ill. The source of infection was identified as green monkeys imported from Africa for use in research.

Monkeys appear to have been the source of the virus in each outbreak of Ebola, which first appeared in the Democratic Republic of Congo. It was named after the river Ebola. Since then, there have been outbreaks in Sudan, Zaire, Cote d'Ivoire and the Gabon in Africa.

A filovirus named Ebola-Reston was identified in monkeys in Manila awaiting export and among monkeys in quarantine in the US. A laboratory worker in Britain became ill when he pricked his finger on an infected needle in 1976.

So far all the major out breaks have been relatively easily contained. Never before has there been an epidemic in such a densely populated area as Gulu.

Laboratory experiments have shown that the virus can be transmitted through water particles in the air, although it is more likely that people become infected by eating monkeys or touching infected animals or humans.

Nobody has yet established what happens to the virus between epidemics. The last outbreak, in the Gabon, was in 1996.

webTitle: Labour back in front by 5 points

fields.headline: Labour back in front by 5 points
fields.standfirst: Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: Labour has sustained permanent damage as a result of the fuel crisis, with its long-term opinion poll lead cut from 10 to five points, according to the latest Guardian/ICM survey published today.
fields.body:
Labour has sustained permanent damage as a result of the fuel crisis, with its long-term opinion poll lead cut from 10 to five points, according to the latest Guardian/ICM survey published today.

The results, showing Labour back in front of the Tories by 40% to 35% in the first of the regular monthly opinion polls after the party conference season, will bring some immediate relief in Downing Street.

But closer study of the underlying polling shows that the Tories have consolidated their 35% share of the vote and are no longer "flatlining" at around 30%, where they had been stuck for seven years.

The five point lead, which follows two weekend polls giving Labour leads of two and seven points, is nowhere near as safe as Tony Blair would like six months away from a possible general election.

The prime minister is no longer the net asset to Labour that he was: 42% see him as arrogant, and his ratings for being "in touch" and "having lots of personality" have also taken a sharp tumble. His biggest asset is that nearly half the electorate see him as experienced.

On policy, Labour remains on track in every area except for the health service. Significant numbers of voters say they can see improvements in their own family finances and in their children's education. They still marginally believe Labour is more competent on the economy and fighting crime than the Tories. But only 13% believe any real improvement has taken place on the NHS.

A clear majority of the public believe that using cannabis is no worse than smoking or drinking, and 43% believe the time has come to legalise the drug.

ICM interviewed a random sample of 1,001 adults by telephone from October 13-16. Interviews were conducted across the country and the results weighted to the profile of all adults.

fields.headline: Sudden, mysterious and deadly
fields.trailText: Ebola virus is one of the most mysterious and deadly known to humankind. It kills its victims as swiftly as it appears. Often they die within 48 hours from internal haemorrhaging that leads to bleeding through every orifice.
fields.body:
Ebola virus is one of the most mysterious and deadly known to humankind. It kills its victims as swiftly as it appears. Often they die within 48 hours from internal haemorrhaging that leads to bleeding through every orifice.

Since the virus was identified in 1976, nearly 800 of the 1,100 people infected have died. Because there have been only a few epidemics very little is known about the disease, which appears to be transmitted to humans by monkeys living in the jungles of Africa and Asia.

There is no treatment for Ebola haemorrhagic fever, which is so infectious that even taking and analysing blood samples to establish a diagnosis is extremely hazardous. So is nursing the victims, who must be kept in isolation. Medical staff have to wear gloves, gowns and masks which must be disinfected after use.

"It is a really nasty disease. It is like watching someone dissolve before your eyes," said Barbera Kerstiens, a Belgian doctor who worked on Ebola during an outbreak in Congo two years ago.

Ebola strikes suddenly. The first signs may be a sudden fever, weakness, muscle pain, headache and sore throat. Vomiting, diarrhoea and a rash may follow. Then the kidney and liver start to fail. Before long, internal bleeding begins and blood starts to gush from ears, eyes, nose and mouth. To have any hope of survival, patients need intensive care support and fluid, because they rapidly dehydrate.

fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText: Macbeth/Distant Voices, Still Lives/Excalibur/The Thin Red Line
fields.body:
Macbeth

(Orson Welles, 1948)

8am, 2pm, Sky Cinema

A weird tilt at Shakespeare with Welles as scriptwriter, star and director. It was filmed in three weeks on the cheap, and it shows in the wobbly scenery; but this is no dull stagebound rendering. With Welles' imagination swirling and John L Russell's dark and shadowy photography, this is the Bard as vivid, if flawed, cinema.

Distant Voices, Still Lives

(Terence Davies, 1988)

8pm, FilmFour

With his highly acclaimed The House Of Mirth now on general release, it's a good time to revisit Davies's debut: an emotionally devastating account of his own youth in postwar Liverpool, where he was abused, like the rest of his family, by a brutal father (Pete Postlethwaite). There is little plot and the characters are rough-hewn, but Davies tells all with conviction through images of power and beauty. It's a testament to humanity, and an extraordinary labour of love to his family: "My mother said, He's told the truth', which I have," Davies said.

Excalibur

(John Boorman, 1981)

8pm, Sky Cinema

Boorman seems to have got lost in the mists of time with this confusing version of the Arthurian legend. The narrative is all but engulfed by whizz-bang visuals. However, the images are often brilliant, there are savage battles, curious sex (armour-clad Nigel Terry roasting by the fire with Helen Mirren), and Nicol Williams' Merlin is so dotty he seems genuinely to appear, bemused, from another dimension.

The Thin Red Line

(Terence Malick, 1998)

10.15pm, Sky Premier

Malick, the mystery wrapped in an enigma of American cinema, returned from a 20-year self-imposed exile to make this, only his third feature, and most of Hollywood flocked to enlist. His adaptation of James Jones's novel is set during the savage battle for Guadalcanal in the Pacific during the second world war - a semi-mystical meditation on men in battle that builds a collage of (often voiced-over) thoughts and feelings amid scenes of terrifying brutality, committed on an island of stunning beauty.

webTitle: Crime falls 10% but fear is still on the rise

fields.headline: Crime falls 10% but fear is still on the rise
fields.standfirst:
Figures are the best for 9 years - and rural areas have some of the lowest

Special report: policing crime
British crime survey
Home Office crime reduction site
fields.trailText: The overall crime rate has fallen by 10% in the last two years, with striking falls in most key categories. But people remain stubbornly fearful they will be targeted, a major study reveals today.
fields.body:
The overall crime rate has fallen by 10% in the last two years, with striking falls in most key categories. But people remain stubbornly fearful they will be targeted, a major study reveals today.

Reductions in burglaries - by 21% - and car theft and violent crime contributed to a drop in the total number of incidents to 14,716,000, the lowest for more than nine years.

Robberies rose by 14%, though this may be a statistical blip due to an increase in attacks on a small number of 16-year-olds.

The figures, published in the biennial British Crime Survey, were hailed by the home secretary, Jack Straw, who has been under pressure from the Tories all year, particularly since the conviction of Tony Martin, the Norfolk farmer who shot and killed a teenager who had broken into his home. Despite the furore surrounding his case and claims that rural crime is soaring, the survey shows crime in the countryside has fallen consistently since 1995.

People in rural communities are much less likely to be burgled or become the victim of violence, researchers found. Predominantly rural areas like Wales, the south-west and East Anglia, experienced some of the lowest levels of all types of crime.

Mr Straw said the fears of people in isolated rural communities could not be dismissed and insisted the government would not be complacent. But the figures give him a strong defence to claims he has been unsympathetic to the plight of country folk. "The problem is that although the chances of being a victim are less than in urban areas, people nevertheless feel more vulnerable because they have fewer neighbours and police response times are likely to be longer than in urban areas," said Mr Straw.

He added: "People are becoming less and less tolerant of crime. There are changes, particularly in the tolerance levels of violent crime, which is leading to more reporting."

Mr Straw also pledged that the encouraging figures would not affect his determination to increase police numbers, which have fallen since Labour came to office.

The survey, compiled by the national centre for social research and the office for national statistics, is regarded as the best indicator of trends because it tests public experience through a sample of more than 19,000 people aged 16 and over.

Police crime figures always show much lower rates because forces do not record every incident reported to them. Some crimes are not reported at all because the victim regards them as too trivial.

Although there is a huge difference in overall totals between the BCS and the police, both indicate crime rates are falling.

More secure

Improvements in home security and effective targeting of repeat offenders by the police is thought to have been responsible for the fall in the number of burglaries; the total number fell to 1,284,000 from 1,628,000.

The 15% fall in the number of stolen vehicles and a 16% drop in the number of thefts from vehicles probably reflect a commitment by manufacturers to make new cars more secure.

Although the overall number of violent crimes in England and Wales dropped by 4% between 1997 and 1999 to 3,246,000, including falls in assaults and woundings, the BCS identified rises in two specific areas. "Stranger" violence, where the victim and attacker do not know each other, rose by 29%. In more than half of these cases, the offenders had been drinking and the victims were almost all men.

Robberies also rose, but Paul Wiles, research director at the Home Office, cautioned against reading too much into the figure. Because robbery is relatively rare, the rise had been driven by reports from 15 teenagers. "The 14% increase would be reduced to 2% without the contribution of the 16-year-olds. While these incidents might be viewed as bullying, they do meet the legal criteria of robbery."

The survey concluded that men aged 16 to 24 and single mothers are the most likely victims of crime.

The BCS highlighted, though, problems the government has in changing perceptions of crime. One third of the people sampled believed crime rates had risen between 1997 and 1999, and one in 10 were so concerned about being targeted that it affected their quality of life.

Although identifying reasons for falling crime is an inexact science, the Home Office believes the booming economy and more focused policing strategies have been important factors.

Mr Wiles said the trend had been reflected in other European countries and the US and thought it was possible there had been a cultural change which had led to crime "simply becoming a less fashionable pursuit for high risk age groups".

fields.headline: Go-it-alone EMI prospers
fields.trailText: The bureaucrats in Brussels may have blocked its marriage with Warner Music but life as a single company is looking bright for EMI, home to acts like the Spice Girls and Robbie Williams.
fields.body:
The bureaucrats in Brussels may have blocked its marriage with Warner Music but life as a single company is looking bright for EMI , home to acts like the Spice Girls and Robbie Williams.

Yesterday, EMI shares, which hit their lowest point of the year last week, shot up 20p to 510p, as investors looked at the group's strong release schedule and concluded that it is on target to meet, or even exceed, its full-year profit forecasts (currently grouped around £253m).

Radiohead (an EMI band) has just seen the follow-up to its spectacularly successful OK Computer shoot to the top on the US Billboard chart, while the new record from Robbie Williams is riding high in Britain. The Spice Girls are due to release a new album next month and before EMI's fiscal year ends new records are expected from the Beatles and Janet Jackson. To cap things off, Garth Brooks, the world's biggest selling solo artist, is not ready for retirement. In an interview given last week Mr Brooks indicated that he has three more albums in him - good news for EMI shareholders if not fans of country & western.

Meanwhile, another company that prefers to be known by three letters was also mounting a recovery. Building on last week's gains, ICI ended 3p better at 377p assisted by rumours that a big asset disposal could be on the way.

Apparently, ICI is close to selling a large chunk of its loss making bulk chemicals operation, specifically detergent business Crosfield, Klea, its next generation CFC outfit and Chlor-chemicals.

Traders were taking the speculation seriously because it stemmed from a paragraph tucked away in a research note published by Schroder Salomon Smith Barney.

Schroder's team of chemicals analysts outlined their belief that the sales were "close". Although the team said ICI was likely to receive low prices for the assets, traders said the market was likely to greet any news on disposals positively. Dogged by fears about the size of its debt mountain and the safety of its dividend going forward, anything that generates cash is likely to find a warm welcome among ICI's shareholders.

Building on Friday's impressive gains, blue chips closed higher for the third consecutive session again with telecom stocks Vodafone , up 5p to 262.75p, Energis , 36.5p better at 714.5p, and Colt Telecom , 100p stronger at £19.05, leading the way.

The FTSE 100 closed the day 76.1 points better at 6,285.7, assisted by the absence of any further troubles in the Middle East. The Techmark added 30.90 points to 3,447.04.

The FTSE 250 closed up 74.2 to 6,478.9 with Canary Wharf , which moves up to the blue chip index today, falling 11.25p to 558.75p. The property group's place in the FTSE 250 is being taken by semicondutor maker Telemetrix, which rose 37.5p to 500p.

Elsewhere, Trafficmaster , the in-car navigation systems, shot up 57.5p to 624.5p on talk that a big contract is in the pipeline.

In the small-cap world Mayflower , the truck and bus maker where former prime minister John Major is a director, ended 0.5p lower at 85.5p, after its house broker lowered its earnings forecast for this year by 15% and for next by 17%. It played down bid speculation.

CSFB attributed the earnings downgrades to the weak US market for Mayflower's products and deferred orders in Britain. It described the possibility that John Harvey, a mysterious investor who has amassed a 5% stake, would lead a bid or a management buy-out as "unlikely".

Dealers are keeping a close watch on second-tier drug companies this week amid expectations of interest from US investors. Schroder Salomon Smith Barney is hosting a big healthcare conference in New York this week and Celltech , 38p to £13.33, Cambridge Antibodies , unchanged at £34.50, Smith & Nephew , off 2p to 275p, Oxford Glycoscience , up 45p to £23.57p, and Biocompatibles , up 13p to 349.5p, are all scheduled to present.

Traders were taking the speculation seriously because it stemmed from a paragraph tucked away in a research note published by Schroder Salomon Smith Barney. Schroder's team of chemicals analysts outlined their belief that the sales were "close". Building on Friday's impressive gains, blue chips closed higher for the third consecutive session again with telecom stocks Vodafone , up 5p to 262.75p, Energis , 36.5p better at 714.5p, and Colt Telecom , 100p stronger at £19.05, leading the way. The FTSE 100 closed the day 76.1 points better at 6,285.7, assisted by the absence of any further troubles in the Middle East. The Techmark added 30.90 points to 3,447.04. The FTSE 250 closed up 74.2 to 6,478.9 with Canary Wharf , which moves up to the blue chip index today, falling 11.25p to 558.75p. The property group's place in the FTSE 250 is being taken by semicondutor maker Telemetrix, which rose 37.5p to 500p. Elsewhere, Trafficmaster , the in-car navigation systems, shot up 57.5p to 624.5p on talk that a big contract is in the pipeline. In the small-cap world Mayflower , the truck and bus maker where former prime minister John Major is a director, ended 0.5p lower at 85.5p, after its house broker lowered its earnings forecast for this year by 15% and for next by 17%. It played down bid speculation. CSFB attributed the earnings downgrades to the weak US market for Mayflower's products and deferred orders in Britain. It described the possibility that John Harvey, a mysterious investor who has amassed a 5% stake, would lead a bid or a management buy-out as "unlikely". Dealers are keeping a close watch on second-tier drug companies this week amid expectations of interest from US investors. Schroder Salomon Smith Barney is hosting a big healthcare conference in New York this week and Celltech , 38p to £13.33, Cambridge Antibodies , unchanged at £34.50, Smith & Nephew , off 2p to 275p, Oxford Glycoscience , up 45p to £23.57p, and Biocompatibles , up 13p to 349.5p, are all scheduled to present.

webTitle: Egyptian resort swaps tourism for diplomacy

fields.headline: Egyptian resort swaps tourism for diplomacy
fields.standfirst:
World leaders hold crisis talks at 'Camp David of the Arab world'
Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: The Americans swept in like a firestorm yesterday, descending on the Egyptian resort of Sharm el-Sheikh with all the brawn of the world's last remaining superpower.
fields.byline: Suzanne Goldenberg and  Brian Whitaker in Sharm el-Sheikh
fields.body:
The Americans swept in like a firestorm yesterday, descending on the Egyptian resort of Sharm el-Sheikh with all the brawn of the world's last remaining superpower.

An occasional site for Middle East conflabs, Sharm el-sheikh is a bizarre mix of high stakes diplomacy and cheap package tourism. The two decades that have passed since Israel's withdrawal from the Sinai peninsula have brought a wholesale transformation to what was once a simple Bedouin village.

Known for its pristine sands and crystal clear coves teeming with fluorescent tropical fish, the Sharm of today is the region's equivalent of the Costa del Sol. It is especially popular with Italian package tourists, who arrive on direct charters from Rome and Milan.

At the Hyatt hotel the delegation bedded down in 300 rooms, including 18 for CNN and other television crews. Italian tourists were bundled out of their rooms, with their bags half-packed. The press secretary of the US embassy in Tel Aviv was also evicted at 2am yesterday morning.

Security was tight. In the US entourage, a Clinton double rode in the black limousine. The real US president exited from a lowly jeep.

At 4pm there was a flurry of excitement when President Clinton, accompanied by about 20 people, took a five-minute stroll around the golf course. At 100-yard intervals between the stubby palm trees were shorter stumps: motionless security men in suits.

The Israelis arrived with their own baggage, principally the posse of spin doctors on the prime ministerial aircraft, who distributed lurid pictures from nearly three weeks of bloodshed and factsheets on the dangerous Hamas bombers freed from Palestinian jails last week. They also handed out videos of incendiary sermons from the imam of a Gaza mosque.

An honour guard clad in white lined the route from the airport - their backs to the road and their eyes resolutely fixed on the desert horizon.

But as the prime minister, Ehud Barak, drove to the summit centre - the Jolie Ville hotel - US and Palestinian flags were visible but not the Israeli star of David. During the last few days of tension, the Egyptian official press has returned to the language of the 1970s, before there was a peace agreement with Israel, referring to their neighbour as the "Zionist entity".

During a three-way meeting with Mr Barak and the United Nations secretary general, Kofi Annan, King Abdullah of Jordan said that more than a fortnight of killing in Israeli-occupied territories had badly shaken the forces of peace.

"We must build the peace camp anew among all the states including mine," the Jordanian ruler said, according to Israeli officials.

The isolation of the place makes it easy to forget the bombs, bullets and stones that were the official reason for calling this summit - though many Arab journalists believe the real motive was to upstage the Arab summit, due to be held in Cairo this weekend.

Many believe that Mr Mubarak has ambitions to turn Sharm into the Middle East's own Camp David.

Four years ago it hosted a summit attended by 29 world leaders, again in response to a wave of violence - a series of anti-Israeli suicide bombings which killed 62 people.

In September last year, Israelis and Palestinians signed a West Bank land-for-security agreement and earlier this month the US secretary of state, Madeleine Albright, met Mr Arafat in Sharm. Mr Barak had refused her invitation.

The demands

Israelis

Short term

 Arafat to order immediate halt to violence

 Re-arrest of Hamas militants freed from jail

 Repair of desecrated holy sites

Long term

 Secure and internationally recognised borders, including permanent control of Jordan valley

 Demilitarisation of any independent Palestinian state. No foreign alliances to be allowed

 Jewish settlements to be allowed to stay in West Bank including two near Jerusalem, one near Hebron

 Jerusalem to remain Israel's united capital but symbolic Palestinian sovereignty could be granted over parts of east Jerusalem outside the Old City.

 Binding agreement on final end to Israeli-Palestinian conflict and pledge to forgo any future claims

Palestinians

Short term

 International inquiry into violence

 Israel to pull forces back from Palestinian-controlled areas

Long term

 Independent sovereign state: goal of PLO since it accepted the idea of a state alongside Israel in 1974. Territorial contiguity between West Bank and Gaza, currently separated by Israeli territory. Control of own borders and air space

 Capital in Jerusalem: seen as historic capital of Arab Palestine and site of Muslim holy places on Haram al-Sharif in Old City

 Return of refugees. Over 3m Palestinians living in diaspora outside Israel and the occupied territories to have the right to return home or receive compensation for property lost in 1948

 Full control of water resources, currently exploited by Israel

Yasser Arafat's office
Ehud Barak's office

Palestinian National Authority
Egyptian presidency
Hamas

webTitle: Ofwat thinks again on price cuts

fields.headline: Ofwat thinks again on price cuts
fields.trailText: Philip Fletcher, the new water industry regulator, is to reconsider harsh price cuts imposed by his predecessor, Sir Ian Byatt, after three companies claimed that Ofwat had underestimated their costs.
fields.body:
Philip Fletcher, the new water industry regulator, is to reconsider harsh price cuts imposed by his predecessor, Sir Ian Byatt, after three companies claimed that Ofwat had underestimated their costs.

Mr Fletcher, the director general of Ofwat, said that he would reexamine the costs of Anglian Water, Welsh Water and Tendring Hundred, a water only company based in Manningtree, Essex, which have had to introduce price cuts of up to 10% this year.

The three companies claimed that Ofwat had underestimated the impact of customers switching to meters following the government's ruling that water companies had to provide meters to domestic customers without charge.

Industry sources said customers could save up to £100 per household on an annual bill of about £250 by switching to meters.

Anglian, which has been offering free meters for more than four years, now has almost half its 1.8m domestic customers only paying for the water they use.

When Ofwat announced its final price rulings last year, Anglian told the regulator that his metering estimates were too low.

A company spokesman said: "They told us to come back if the reality was different. In fact our customers are switching at three times the rate forecast by Ofwat."

He said the decision to ask for a review had not been influenced by the recent competition commission ruling that price cuts for Mid Kent Water and Sutton and East Surrey Water had been too onerous.

The latest price regime, which came into effect at the beginning of April, has forced water companies to lay off staff and slash costs.

webTitle: Strong pound forces Sony to axe 400 jobs

fields.headline: Strong pound forces Sony to axe 400 jobs
fields.trailText: Sony, the Japanese consumer electronics firm, is to axe 400 jobs in South Wales in a restructuring operation to offset the punishing strength of the pound against the euro.
fields.byline: Jonathan Watts  in Tokyo  and Charlotte Denny
fields.body:
Sony, the Japanese consumer electronics firm, is to axe 400 jobs in South Wales in a restructuring operation to offset the punishing strength of the pound against the euro.

The company said yesterday that the lay-offs were part of a plan to refocus its Pencoed plant on more sophisticated products, such as digital televisions, for which the company believes it can get a better price in world markets.

"We are preparing the plant for the future," a company spokesman said.

Sony is the latest Japanese manufacturer to express concern about the pound's strength against the euro.

"This is bad news and shows that the pound's volatility outside the euro is really starting to bite," said Lord Simon of Highbury, vice-chair of Britain in Europe, the pro-euro lobby group.

Yesterday's announcement is the second recent blow to the region. Corus (formerly British Steel) said last week that that it was cutting 200 jobs at its Port Talbot plant.

The Pencoed factory employs 1,900 people. This is the first time in Sony's 29-year history in the UK that it has had to lay off shopfloor workers.

webTitle: Blair calls in IT titans to give Africa a chance

fields.headline: Blair calls in IT titans to give Africa a chance
fields.standfirst: Net news
fields.trailText: Tony Blair is preparing for an ambitious partnership with some of the world's top IT companies to ensure the benefits of the information revolution reach developing countries by using new technology to train teachers in Africa.
fields.body:
Tony Blair is preparing for an ambitious partnership with some of the world's top IT companies to ensure the benefits of the information revolution reach developing countries by using new technology to train teachers in Africa.

Encouraged by the response to informal soundings of a wide range of firms, the prime minister aims to establish a resource bank containing pledges of equipment, staff, software licences and goods and services, such as CD-Roms.

Experts from the public and private sector will then match donations to training schemes across the continent.

Cisco Systems, Marconi and Richard Branson's Virgin empire have all seconded staff to the small team, led by Owen Barder, Mr Blair's economic private secretary, preparing the project for its formal launch.

Peter Mckenzie Smith, Marconi's director of education, said: "In principle, we are very happy to look at these requests when they come through. Companies are often keener to contribute skills and experience to programmes of this kind rather than money."

The prime minister believes that education is the long-term key to tackling poverty and economic development, with teachers vital in delivering the benefits of new technology to poor children.

The Imfundo project - named after the South African Ndebele people's word for acquiring knowledge - is at the forefront of the government's drive to bridge the so-called digital divide, a subject moving rapidly up the international development agenda. Policymakers fear that, unless they intervene, living standards in developing countries will fall even further behind those in rich industrialised nations.

At their annual summit in Okinawa in July, G8 leaders announced the formation of a "dot.force", a team of IT experts comprising two representatives from each country, which will advise politicians on the steps needed to bridge the digital divide.

Britain's representatives are the government's e-envoy, a slot recently vacated by Alex Allen, and Vernon Ellis, managing director of Andersen Consulting. Dot.force's first meeting is due to be held at the end of November in Japan, when members will begin drawing up an action plan.

Among the various ideas which the UK is expected to float are funding the establishment of public information terminals where the poor can access the internet cheaply, and subsidising the reduction of import tariffs on hi-tech equipment currently taxed as a luxury item.

Imfundo, based at the department for international development, has piloted projects in Rwanda and Gambia and is aiming to expand into a total of five or six African countries over the next four years.

Although it has yet to issue a direct appeal for donations to the resource bank, sources close to the project said the response to informal approaches had been encouraging.

Steve Love, Virgin's secondee to Imfundo, said: "We fully support the project and the concept of the resource bank and we greatly value the way that we have been consulted about the whole idea."

It is thought that the Imfundo team is preparing a prospectus to be sent to potential donors soon.

Mr Mckenzie Smith said that as well as being a worthwhile project in its own right, involvement in Imfundo could help extend the company's profile, offer good opportunities for staff development and open new markets.

fields.headline: Edf buys Powergen plant for £400m
fields.trailText: Powergen is selling one of Britain's biggest power stations for almost £400m to London Electricity, a subsidiary of the French state-owned electricity firm Electricité de France.
fields.body:
Powergen is selling one of Britain's biggest power stations for almost £400m to London Electricity, a subsidiary of the French state-owned electricity firm Electricité de France.

The sale of the 30-year-old 2,000MW plant in Cottam, Nottinghamshire, will help towards its target of reducing debt by £1bn.

The company, in the process of buying Kentucky-based LG&E Energy Corp for $3.2bn (£2.2bn), is also keen to move away from UK power generation to focus on supply and international acquisitions.

Ed Wallis, chief executive of Powergen, said: "We continue to make progress with the remaining UK and international asset sales and expect to make further announcements before the end of the year."

Bruno Lescoeur, chairman and chief executive of London Electricity, said: "This acquisition is a further step towards achieving our ambition of becoming a major player in the UK energy industry."

Analysts were pleased with the value of the deal. "This is a good outcome for Powergen," said one. "They have achieved good value for shareholders."

The sale, which is subject to EC approval, means Edf will be supplying power to around 3m homes and businesses in Britain as it also owns Sweb, based in south-west England.

Edf already supplies around 6% of UK electricity through an undersea cable from France. In March it paid US-based Enron $700m for the Sutton Bridge gas power station and also has a 13% stake in a 1,000MW gas turbine plant in Essex. A spokesman said all 166 employees at Cottam would be taken on in the deal, which should be finalised by the end of the year.

But yesterday's announcement is likely to spark complaints from the UK industry that other European markets remain practically closed off to British competitors.

fields.headline: At this price?  Intechnology
fields.trailText: At a time when valuations of technology stocks are taking a battering it seems almost perverse to tip for further growth a share that is positioned bang in the middle of that sector and has already risen in value by 12 times since listing as a cash shell in March. Last night it closed at 317.5p.
fields.body:
At a time when valuations of technology stocks are taking a battering it seems almost perverse to tip for further growth a share that is positioned bang in the middle of that sector and has already risen in value by 12 times since listing as a cash shell in March. Last night it closed at 317.5p.

However, Intechnology, the AIM listed data storage specialist, has weathered the storm better than most and some shrewd investors believe there is considerable value still to be had from the shares.

Intechnology is run by Peter Wilkinson, the serial entrepreneur behind Planet Online, Freeserve and Sports Internet. The management team is made up of many of the same people who founded Planet Online and the business is valued at around £438m.

In the year to March 2000 turnover was £101m and pre-tax profit £5.7m. Intechnology is made up of Mr Wilkinson's computer reselling business Storm, a data storage division and what the company claims is a unique network back-up product called VBak.

The latter two divisions are the most interesting. Data storage is a hot investor area, while companies are increasingly looking to back-up their systems remotely and outsource management of their internal private systems.

Finding a direct competitor to Intechnology in Britain is difficult. Hosting company Telecity is expanding quickly and valued at around £900m. Intechnology is currently a bigger operation with 275,000sq ft of hosting space and six centres opening in Europe by December 2001.

The closest comparison to the Intechnology is an American firm called Data Storage Networks. It is currently valued at £6bn, despite having lower revenues and a smaller product count than the British firm. Last year it lost around $120m and had a turnover of $30m.

Intechnology reports interim results early next month and a move to the full market seems inevitable. Worth buying before then.

webTitle: Foetus designed to bar inherited illness

fields.headline: Foetus designed to bar inherited illness
fields.standfirst: Special report: the ethics of genetics
fields.trailText: A Spanish couple has become the first to have children "designed" by researchers in the lab to prevent disease in a third, unborn generation.
fields.body:
A Spanish couple has become the first to have children "designed" by researchers in the lab to prevent disease in a third, unborn generation.

This latest step in the ethical maze created by the combination of test tube baby technology and genetics is another dilemma for Britain's assisted reproduction regulator, the HFEA, already struggling to cope with the rapid pace of technological change.

The father of the children, who were born in May, suffers from the disease haemophilia, which prevents blood clotting.

Haemophilia is an inherited illness, tied to a defective gene. Males do not pass the disease on to their children, but if they have a daughter, the daughter becomes a carrier, and can pass haemophilia on to her sons.

In a successful attempt to forestall that, doctors from the Universitat Autonoma de Barcelona and researchers from the Cefer Institute of Reproduction made sure the embryos to be implanted in the mother's womb would only grow into boys.

What makes the case unusual is that, had the mother given birth to girls, they would have been perfectly healthy - only the hypothetical future grandchildren were at risk.

The case was complicated by the fact the father had been infected with the HIV virus and Hepatitis C from a blood transfusion 18 years ago. Scientists were able to "wash" his sperm to clear it of the virus.

In cases where a mother is a haemophilia carrier, couples undergoing test tube baby treatment, or IVF, can already have their embryos genetically tested before they are implanted in the mother's womb to pick out any with haemophilia. This is allowed in Britain.

But what is not permitted by the HFEA is to choose the sex of a baby to prevent a daughter being born who might then pass the disease on to her sons when she grew up and had children of her own.

webTitle: After a nightmare week, Israel fights back in the war of words

fields.headline: After a nightmare week, Israel fights back in the war of words
fields.standfirst:
Team tries to justify strength of response
Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: Stung by international criticism of its iron-fisted response to Palestinian violence, Israel is fighting back by cranking up its own propaganda machine. As the peace process hangs in the balance, battle-hardened spin doctors have been drafted in to help the Jewish state regain the initiative it lost at the start of this crisis.
fields.body:
Stung by international criticism of its iron-fisted response to Palestinian violence, Israel is fighting back by cranking up its own propaganda machine. As the peace process hangs in the balance, battle-hardened spin doctors have been drafted in to help the Jewish state regain the initiative it lost at the start of this crisis.

Correspondents in Jerusalem were yesterday shown video film - first broadcast on official Palestine TV- of last Friday's sermon by Sheikh Ahmed Abu Halabiya, who called on the faithful in a Gaza mosque to "slaughter" Jews everywhere.

The prime minister, Ehud Barak, took the transcript to the Sharm el-Sheikh summit to prove Israel's point that Yasser Arafat is breaching the 1993 Oslo peace agreement by encouraging hateful "incitement" against Israelis and Jews. Palestinian sources said, however, that the preacher was a fanatic who had been arrested after the sermon.

Mr Barak flew to Egypt with heavyweight officials and diplomats poised to explain Israel's case to the hundreds of journalists attending the summit. Officials in Jerusalem concede that the first week of the unrest was a PR nightmare, which peaked with the televised killing of a 12-year-old Palestinian boy in the arms of his helpless father - one of more than 90 Arabs to die so far.

To counter that, Israel is focusing on pictures from last Thursday's lynching of two soldiers who blundered into the West Bank town of Ramallah, and accuses the Palestinians of destroying most of the footage taken on the scene. "What we lost with the picture of the boy in Gaza we regained with the lynch," one senior Israeli admitted. Shimon Peres, the former prime minister, put it candidly: "When one small child is killed, you lose the war. Explanations are not important."

Leading the information effort is Nahman Shai, government spokesman during the nerve-racking days of the Gulf war in 1991. Mr Shai's excellent English and deep understanding of the media are a powerful combination, though it is far from clear whether he can shift the international perception that Israel, rather than the Palestinians, is the main culprit in this crisis. Mr Shai is certainly a match for articulate, telegenic Palestinian spokespeople like Hanan Ashrawi and negotiator Saeb Erakat. But his emphasis on rebuttal may be too defensive and detailed.

"The problem is that today's media industry is so fast that no one in the world has the time or the interest to check out information given by the Palestinians," he said. Part of the new approach is to equip Israeli soldiers with video cameras so that the film can be shown to justify their reaction, which the government insists is always in response to specific threats.

Israel says troops have had to use live fire because Palestinians have fired out of crowds and in ambushes. But even some Israeli journalists have doubts about the official version of events.

On October 6 the Israel Defence Forces (IDF) spokesman announced that soldiers at the Netzarim junction in the Gaza Strip had fired twice at Pales tinians who had thrown a gas canister. The spokesman described this response as "restrained." But four Palestinians were killed and 24 injured that day. "Very partial reporting by the IDF is intended to create the impression that it is a matter of fighting between two more or less equally matched armies," said Amira Hass, the Haaretz newspaper correspondent.

Mr Shai admitted that it was a mistake by the army to have initially denied that soldiers had shot the 12-year-old Muhammad al-Dura at Netzarim junction. "The child's death was a horrible and tragic story," he said. " In general, I believe it is better to admit a mistake and apologise for it, if necessary, than to deny something that will later damage one's credibility."

webTitle: 4,000 jobs to go as Chevron takes over Texaco

fields.headline: 4,000 jobs to go as Chevron takes over Texaco
fields.standfirst:
Chevron-Texaco merger site
Chevron announcement
Texaco factfile
fields.trailText: Chevron, the US oil group is to axe about 4,000 jobs in a cost-cutting drive following its $35.6bn (£25.4bn) takeover of rival Texaco. The heaviest job losses are expected at Texaco's headquarters and in the exploration businesses.
fields.byline: Jane Martinson  in New York and Terry Macalister
fields.body:
Chevron, the US oil group is to axe about 4,000 jobs in a cost-cutting drive following its $35.6bn (£25.4bn) takeover of rival Texaco. The heaviest job losses are expected at Texaco's headquarters and in the exploration businesses.

The companies say they can make annual cost savings of at least $1.2bn within nine months of the merger.

Chevron shares fell almost 5% after the deal was confirmed yesterday as traders focused on regulatory concerns. The fall wiped about $2bn from the initial value of the all-share deal.

Texaco shares rose almost 4%, on the news, to more than $57, still below the implied offer price. Chevron will also assume nearly $8bn of debt.

US and European regulators are expected to launch inquiries into the latest merger in an industry already dominated by a handful of global companies. ChevronTexaco will be the world's fourth-largest oil company in terms of reserves after Exxon Mobil, BP and Royal Dutch Shell.

Dave O'Reilly, Chevron's chief executive, sought to allay anti-trust concerns in the US yesterday by suggesting that a more competitive company would be better for consumers. As rising oil prices and supply fears continued to haunt the industry, he said that the combined group would be "better able to contribute to the nation's energy needs".

The decision by the two US giants to merge has refired speculation about other potential corporate deals including a long-awaited takeover bid for BG International by Royal Dutch/Shell.

The Anglo-Dutch oil major, one of the top three oil players, already looks ready to spend up to £2bn buying up joint-venture downstream operations with Texaco.

Texaco is expected to be forced by regulators to hive off its interests in the Equilon and Motiva enterprises created in 1998 by the combination of the US refining and marketing interests of Shell and Texaco.

Shell last night confirmed it had started discussions with Texaco about "restructuring" the joint ventures but declined to comment on a buyout.

BGI takes its first step on the London stock market as an independent company on Monday when it is separated from the other former British Gas interests, Transco and Lattice.

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: Accor and Granada Compass have halted talks over Accor's acquisition of Forte's hotel division, Accor said.
fields.body:
Granada and Accor end talks

Accor and Granada Compass have halted talks over Accor's acquisition of Forte's hotel division, Accor said.

"The recent discussions have not led to a satisfactory agreement between the two parties," the company said.

"For Accor, any major acquisition representing decisive industrial interest should imperatively contribute to the rapid growth of earnings per share and be financially balanced.

"Accor reiterated the position it has held in the past: a major acquisition is not indispensable. Its strategy of balanced growth has for the past seven years produced double-digit growth in its financial results and the current forecasts for the group are excellent," the statement said.

Venture capital spend rises

Venture capital investment rose dramatically last year but "substantial sums" still remain available for investment in start-up businesses, according to a survey by 3i and PricewaterhouseCoopers.

The survey, which the two firms said was the first such research, found that the equivalent of 0.5% of global gross domestic product was invested in venture capital last year, or $136bn (£97bn).

BSkyB appoints Freudenstein

BSkyB has named Richard Freudenstein in the newly created position of chief operating officer.

Mr Freudenstein, 35, is being promoted with immediate effect from general manager, a post he had held since November last year. He will report directly to BSkyB chief executive Tony Ball.

EC warns Visa over charges

The European commission said yesterday that it had sent a legal warning to Visa International, alleging that the credit card company's "interchange fee" was a restrictive collective price agreement.

The interchange fee is paid by the retailer's bank to the cardholder's bank for each card transaction. It is set by San Francisco-based Visa International and amounts to an agreement between the member banks of Visa, the commission said.

"In the commission's view, Visa International has not so far put forward any convincing reasons showing that the interchange fee fulfils the cumulative conditions for an exemption under the EU antitrust rules," the commission added.

EasyJet plans flotation

Britain's easyJet yesterday officially announced plans to float on the London Stock Exchange, becoming the second European low-cost carrier to take on industry leaders in the skies and on the market.

Floating 25% of easyJet will help raise the funds - analysts' initial estimates value the airline at around £500m - for 32 new Boeing 737-700s the carrier has ordered to support its expansion plans over the next decade.

It will also help the airline - which is pausing for breath this year after five years of steady growth - build a warchest for future acquisitions and will allow chairman Stelios Haji-Ioannou to offer 1,400 staff shareholdings in the firm.

fields.headline: Eurostar steals march on airlines
fields.trailText: Eurostar yesterday announced it had stolen a decisive lead over airlines by grabbing 63% of the travel market between London and Paris, adding that it would break even by 2003.
fields.body:
Eurostar yesterday announced it had stolen a decisive lead over airlines by grabbing 63% of the travel market between London and Paris, adding that it would break even by 2003.

The cross-Channel service linking London with Paris and Brussels said that it expected to improve revenues by about £40m. It said sales volumes had risen by 11% from 5.3m to 5.9m during the third quarter. Its sales and revenue growth are better than for the same period last year.

David Azema, Eurostar's chairman and chief executive, said the company had increased revenues by 10% to £327.4m in the third quarter. A similar increase in the final quarter would produce a total for the year to £440m.

Mr Ezema said: "The results show that Eurostar is continuously strengthening its market position. The service is successfully attracting business across a wide spectrum from day trippers to regular business travellers."

The company lost £150m last year. It was launched in 1994 with optimistic forecasts that 15m passengers a year would be using it by the millennium, but it only achieved half that total.

Its improvement is being put down to better marketing in which it has offered deals for day travellers while keeping a premium service for business people.

On the Brussels route, volumes were up by 10.5% with a gain of market share by 4 points to 46%. On the London to Paris route, volumes have increased by more than 10%, with market share rising one percentage point to 63.4%.

webTitle: British human rights campaigner to be freed from Burma

fields.headline: British human rights campaigner to be freed from Burma
fields.trailText: After more than a year in solitary confinement, beatings and the threat of serving out a 17-year sentence in one of Burma's most notorious prisons, Briton James Mawdsley, is to be deported home.
fields.body:
After more than a year in solitary confinement, beatings and the threat of serving out a 17-year sentence in one of Burma's most notorious prisons, Briton James Mawdsley, is to be deported home.

Mr Mawdsley, 27, a Catholic human rights campaigner and university drop-out, has made it his life's mission to campaign against human rights abuses in Burma, one of the world's most repressive regimes.

He was arrested just over a year ago for carrying pro-democracy leaflets.

Last night the Foreign Office minister John Battle announced that the Burmese ambassador had informed him of Mr Mawdsley's imminent release and deportation to Britain. He is expected to arrive at the end of the week.

Mr Mawdsley has been kept in solitary confinement in Keng Tung prison in a remote part of Burma, 400 miles from Rangoon. His mother, Diana, a retired nurse who has been allowed to visit him occasionally, said that while she had been worried about her son's health and deteriorating eyesight, she supported him in his struggle.

Mr Mawdsley, the younger son of an educated middle class Lancashire family, had left university to campaign and was arrested when he entered Burma illegally from neighbouring Thailand in August 1999 to distribute 250 copies of his "Letter to the People of Burma".

The leaflet condemned the military junta and called for the immediate release of the pro-democracy campaigner Aung San Suu Kyi, who won a landslide victory against the junta 11 years ago and has been held prisoner ever since. During his trial, Mr Mawdsley refused to recognise the court.

His father, David, said that his son had used his imprisonment to highlight the continuing oppression by the military regime and its brutal purges against the Shan, Karen and Karenni peoples.

He said last night: "I'm de lighted. I'm choking up on this news. All the family are phoning each other up madly. It's just overwhelming, fantastic. It just shows the Burmese junta will listen when international pressure is strong enough.

"I'm so grateful to all the major bodies like the UN, and all James's supporters have been fantastic. It's such a relief."

The prisoner's twin brother, Jeremy, serving with the armed forces in Germany, said: "It's fantastic news. But it's one of those moments that I'd really like to see before I believe it as the Burmese junta like to play morale breaking games.

"He went out there to highlight the ethnic massacres perpetrated by the junta and he will want to remind everyone of that when he finally gets home."

During the last year Mr Mawdsley's case attracted high profile support, including that of the Catholic peer Lord Alton of Liverpool and a number of US congressmen.

In statements - mainly is sued through his parents - Mr Mawdsley has attacked the British government for refusing to follow the US lead of banning investment in Burma.

Mr Battle said last night that the Burmese ambassador, Kyaw Win, had informed him that James was to be deported. "I am relieved that the Burmese regime has recognised that there is no justification in keeping James in prison and has decided to deport him as soon as possible."

There are 1,200 political prisoners in Burmese jails.

fields.headline: The evil that women do
fields.standfirst:
When the Lord Chief Justice hinted last week that Myra Hindley might one day go free, the reaction was inevitable. John Upton explains why she has become the face of the nation's deepest fears

Special report: Human rights in the UK
fields.trailText: When the Lord Chief Justice hinted last week that Myra Hindley might one day go free, the reaction was inevitable.  John Upton explains why she has become the face of the nation's deepest fears.
fields.body:
Last week in an interview with the New Statesman, Lord Woolf, the Lord Chief Justice, made a series of comments concerning the newly in force Human Rights Act and the fate of a murderer convicted of two killings in the 1960s. Understandably, given his position within the legal establishment, his remarks were bland and noncommittal. Yet they have provoked immediate and intense public reaction. The reason for this sudden enthusiasm for the finer points of criminal sentencing practice is that the prisoner is Myra Hindley, still public enemy No 1 after all these years.

Last year, Hindley lost her appeal against her "life meaning life" sentence in the House of Lords; she is now looking to the European Court of Human Rights to overturn that ruling. The judgment of the House of Lords is an interesting example of the way the British judiciary present their deliberations as if part of some quasi-scientific process. It is salutary to see how an impressive turn of phrase can disguise the extent to which political views and entrenched social positions are liable to cloud their decisions. The proceedings rumble on towards Strasbourg but it is difficult not to feel that in many ways the strictly legal aspects of Hindley's case are now of secondary importance.

Hindley now stands, in the worst possible way, above the law. Her case has become the focus for our moral, political and cultural anxieties. The Moors murderers are one fixed bearing in a sea of relativist notions. Everyone knows what to think about Brady and Hindley: that they are bad. We derive a moral certainty from them which time has done nothing to wear away. Successive home secretaries have used her to shore up their own authority and there is no better illustration of the extent to which we feel free to manipulate her image than the Marcus Harvey painting exhibited three years ago as part of Sensation at the Royal Academy. The infamous photograph - bouffant peroxide hair, heavy-jawed, overweight face - was reproduced in paint using the palm prints of children. Of arguable artistic merit, its deeper significance lay in the fact that it demonstrated our eagerness to accept her decades-old mug-shot as pure art, detached from the current reality of her situation.

This institutionalisation has led to the denial of Hindley's individuality with the consequence that injustices perpetrated against her are easier to accept.
