webTitle: Britain becoming more equal, voters say

fields.headline: Britain becoming more equal, voters say
fields.trailText: For the first time since Tony Blair took office a majority of voters see Britain as becoming a fairer and more equal society under New Labour, according to the Guardian/ICM state of the nation poll.
fields.body:
For the first time since Tony Blair took office a majority of voters see Britain as becoming a fairer and more equal society under New Labour, according to the Guardian/ICM state of the nation poll.

An overwhelming majority of voters say that under Labour their family finances and the education system have improved or stayed the same. However, the national health service remains this government's achilles heel. Only 13% of voters believe the NHS has improved since Mr Blair came to office and 34% think it has got worse.

The poll shows that on what Downing Street spokesmen repeatedly refer to as the "fundamentals", Labour is perceived, with that exception of the health service, to be doing a good or adequate job, but that the Tories are rapidly closing the gap.

For example, two years ago Labour had a nine-point lead on the question of which party would produce the most successful economic policies, with a split of 35% Labour and 26% Tory. Now that has narrowed to only one point with 32% naming Labour and 31% the Conservatives.

But in some areas the Tories have failed to make any progress. The Conservatives were traditionally seen as the party of law and order - a reputation they lost in the mid-1990s after the crime rate had doubled. Now Labour leads on fighting crime by 22% to 17%. This is not by any means an overwhelming en dorsement of the record of the home secretary, Jack Straw, with 56% saying they do not know which party has the best anti-crime policy. But it shows that Labour has continued to neutralise the Tories on one issue where political tradition says they should be scoring highly.

Mr Blair can also take comfort from the fact that the voters do believe that they are living in a more modern democracy and in a more equal society than before Labour came to power at the 1997 general election. Nearly two-thirds of adult voters believe that New Labour has modernised Britain's political system and for the first time more than 50% believe it is also becoming a fairer society.

The state of the nation poll shows some notable changes in the past two years. The biggest shift in opinion has been over attitudes to food. More people now think it is becoming safer to eat, compared with two years ago when a majority felt it was getting less safe; but that was at the height of concern over BSE and a fatal E. coli outbreak in Scotland.

In addition, fewer people are prepared to say that the government should put more emphasis on environmental policy even if it means penalising car drivers. In 1998 some 66% agreed with this statement; now the figure has fallen to 54%, although polling during the petrol crisis suggests that a different result is produced if people are asked directly about their views on petrol prices.

Otherwise public opinion has remained relatively stable. Most people think fighting inflation is more important than reducing unemployment, the trade unions should not be given a bigger say in the running of the economy and they resist the idea that Britain should have a closer relationship with the European Union.

 ICM interviewed a random sample of 1,001 adults aged 18 and over by telephone between October 13 - 16. Interviews were conducted across the country and the results have been weighted to the profile of all adults.

fields.headline: General denies leading Bosnian slaughter
fields.trailText: The Bosnian Serb general accused of masterminding Europe's worst atrocities since the second world war yesterday claimed he was emotionally attached to the very people his troops are said to have massacred five years ago.
fields.body:
The Bosnian Serb general accused of masterminding Europe's worst atrocities since the second world war yesterday claimed he was emotionally attached to the very people his troops are said to have massacred five years ago.

Launching his defence at the Yugoslav war crimes tribunal in the Hague, General Radislav Krstic argued that his upbringing showed that he was hardly the type of man to indulge in the ethnic cleansing of Muslims.

Gen Krstic is accused of playing a leading role in the wholesale slaughter of at least 7,500 Muslim men and boys in the now infamous enclave of Srebrenica in the summer of 1995.

It was supposed to be a UN safe haven but the 100-strong Dutch military unit of peacekeepers there to protect the largely Muslim population abandoned the town and its unfortunate inhabitants to the advancing Bosnian Serb army.

Mr Krstic - whose 15,000 strong unit, the Drina Wolves, is said to have played a pivotal role in the ensuing massacres - is the highest-ranking Bosnian Serb military officer to go on trial in the Hague. He is charged with genocide and crimes against humanity.

The prosecution has already shown pictures of mass graves in fields overflowing with corpses and bones, and has claimed that Gen Krstic and his men tried to cover up the atrocities by later exhuming the bodies and burying them elsewhere.

But Gen Krstic protests his innocence and pins the blame on his superior, General Ratko Mladic, who is still at liberty somewhere in the former Yugoslavia. Prosecutors have shown footage of Gen Krstic entering Srebrenica alongside Gen Mladic.

In an attempt to portray himself as a man untouched by ethnic hatred, Gen Krstic, 52, yesterday described how he found the breakup of the former Yugoslavia "horrible" and said he was "emotional" when Muslim and Serb soldiers had to part company to form separate opposing armies.

Dressed in a dark suit and wearing gold-rimmed glasses, Gen Krstic limped to the witness stand.

"We all went to school together, socialised together and had great respect for each other," he said of the Muslim soldiers. "We hoped we would see each other again and hoped we would work together again."

He then claimed he had as sumed command of the Drina Wolves almost two weeks after the Muslim enclave had fallen to the Bosnian Serbs. His lawyer also argued there was a parallel chain of command "concealed" from the general.

However, the killings took place between July 11 and July 17 1995, and prosecutors have already produced a copy of a decree signed by Gen Mladic showing that Gen Krstic took charge of the Drina Wolves on July 13.

Gen Krstic's lawyer was yesterday adamant that he would prove that this was not the case. "We will prove that Gen Krstic and the lower-ranking officers did not stain the honour of Serb officers. We will prove that with documents of the VRS [Bosnian Serb Army]."

The Srebrenica massacres are viewed as the worst atrocities of the 1992-95 Bosnian war and have been described by UN judges as a scene from hell written on the darkest pages of human history.

The Bosnian Serb wartime leader Radovan Karadzic - also indicted for war crimes but like Gen Mladic still at liberty - has singled out Gen Krstic for praise, calling him "a great commander" who did "an extraordinary job".

The war crimes case is a real test for the UN since it has so far failed to secure a genocide conviction. Gen Krstic faces life imprisonment if the final verdict, due in the first half of next year, is guilty.

fields.headline: A Country Diary
fields.trailText: Somerset
fields.body:
Somerset

"A mixed plantation on an ancient site, with diverse vegetated banks and hedgerows" was what the official survey said. And a buzzard was circling with intent above one of those vegetated hedgerows as the owners led the way to the cleared ride that runs eastwards through their magical 14 acres. Autumn sun came out and filtered through at a low angle in spaces where some clearing had been done.

The wood was recently classified as both an Ancient Woodland and a County Wildlife site; he explained the flora and she the fauna. Amongst the wildlife, barn owls, increasingly vulnerable with their low flight to motor cars as the shrinkage of hedges and verges drives them towards roadways, find an ideal, safe hunting-ground in the cleared ride. Roe deer and squirrel are other inhabitants, and the sandy humps and hollows of a badger sett cover some 4 acres.

Evidence of tree-growth round many entrances suggests 200 years of badger residence, and the practised eye spots the shiny bases of trees where badgers have regularly rubbed against them, and a recreational area beaten flat by generations of play. Amongst the growth of oak, ash, chestnut, maple, birch and beech, there is work to be done.

One side of the ride must be cleared of bramble and low scrub each year, and regular thinning is needed to let in light and prevent overshadowing of herbs and grasses. After last year's thinning the spring growth of wild daffodils doubled. There is too much conifer, and more sycamore than is thought good, though we all felt that one particularly fine, mature specimen was too magnificent to be marked for the axe.

fields.headline: Serb leaders 'stole $100m'
fields.standfirst: Special report: Serbia
fields.trailText: The ousted Yugoslav leader, Slobodan Milosevic, and his associates are criminals who have stashed at least $100m (£69m) in purloined funds abroad, German intelligence agents claim.
fields.body:
The ousted Yugoslav leader, Slobodan Milosevic, and his associates are criminals who have stashed at least $100m (£69m) in purloined funds abroad, German intelligence agents claim.

"Considerable evidence indicates Milosevic and his entourage constitute an [organised crime] structure and are engaged in drug dealing, money laundering and other criminal acts," said a German report obtained by Reuters yesterday.

The briefing document for ministers by the German Federal Intelligence Service (BND) alleged that the sum thought to have been diverted - estimated to be "at least three-digit millions of US dollars" - could not have been obtained legally.

Mr Milosevic's private assets extended to Russia, China, Cyprus, Greece, Lebanon and South Africa, the BND assessment said. In Switzerland, it estimated his holdings at $100m.

The report named 11 Yugoslav businessmen - in banking, the media, telecommunications, energy, tobacco and trade - with especially close relations to Mr Milosevic.

"The near total occupation of key economic posts by Milosevic followers opened opportunities for illegal capital transfer for personal enrichment and financing for political plans, weapons purchases, as well as camouflage for criminal activity, [and] drug trade," it said.

The group dabbled in black market currency transactions, it said.

webTitle: Milosevic allies sign up for slice of cabinet

fields.headline: Milosevic allies sign up for slice of cabinet
fields.standfirst: Special report: Serbia
fields.trailText: The allies of Yugoslavia's former president, Slobodan Milosevic, finally signed up yesterday to an agreement for a new coalition government to run Serbia until early elections on December 23.
fields.body:
The allies of Yugoslavia's former president, Slobodan Milosevic, finally signed up yesterday to an agreement for a new coalition government to run Serbia until early elections on December 23.

The deal ended a week of obstruction by the Socialist party, the dominant group in the Milosevic regime. The 18-party alliance of the new president, Vojislav Kostunica, had threatened to bring hundreds of thousands of protesters back on to the streets if the Socialists tried to block change.

The general strike and mass protests that brought down Mr Milosevic on October 5 are now known as the Bulldozer Revolution because the machines were used to smash their way into the state-run radio and TV headquarters and the federal parliament.

Mr Kostunica's allies in the Democratic Opposition of Serbia (DOS) said they would bring the bulldozers back if the Socialists - the largest party in the Serbian government - refused early elections.

Under the deal for an early poll, which the DOS is confident of winning, the Socialists will retain the post of Serbian prime minister in the transitional government.

But the prime minister will have to act in consensus with two deputy prime ministers. One will be from the DOS and the other from the Serbian Renewal Movement of another opposition figure, Vuk Draskovic, who said the deal meant "the end of Serbia as a country of organised terrorism".

The Serbian police, information, justice and finance ministries are to be shared between appointees from the Socialist party and from the DOS.

The nationalist hardliner Vojislav Seseslj, who holds a large block of seats in the Serbian parliament, refused to take part.

The deal should restore some of the momentum that seemed to be lost last week when the DOS failed to consolidate its original victory of late September.

Mr Kostunica has also been slow in appointing a prime minister for the Yugoslav Federation and a new Yugoslav government, partly because of disagreements with Milo Djukanovic's government in Montenegro. He has not changed the army high command or the minister of defence; both were loyal to Mr Milosevic.

The deal made no mention of what happens to the Serbian presidency. The president, Milan Milutinovic, once a Milosevic crony, has also been indicted for war crimes.

The next step in Mr Milosevic's fight for political survival will come on November 25 when his Socialist party holds an emergency congress to discuss its defeat. The may well be a push for him to resign

fields.headline: Answer me
fields.standfirst: Getting personal with... Holby City's Jeremy Sheffield
fields.trailText: Getting personal with... Holby City's Jeremy Sheffield
fields.body:
Full name: Jeremy Sheffield

Have you ever adopted a pseudonym and if so, why?

Yes, for on-line chat rooms.

Have you ever lied about your age and if so, why?

Yes, for reasons above.

How would you describe yourself in a lonely hearts ad?

Dancer and doctor seeks new guile nymph for thorough examination.

What was the last illegal thing you did?

I had sex in a public place.

What was the last kind-hearted thing you did?

Made my flatmate a cup of tea.

Who's the nicest person you've ever worked with?

Jane Brand my agent.

What are the initials of the most unpleasant person you've worked with?

IJ

Has a critic ever made you cry?

Only because of their lack of imagination.

What would you advertise without a fee?

Absolutely nothing.

What would you never advertise?

Organised religion.

What wakes you up screaming at four in the morning?

Good head.

What takes you to a "happy place"?

A happy pill.

 Jeremy Sheffield is in Holby City, Thursday nights on BBC One.

fields.headline: Unhappy families
fields.standfirst: Last night's TV:  Nancy Banks-Smith
fields.trailText: One Foot In The Grave/The Royle Family/Coronation Street
fields.body:
Last night BBC1 fired off a double-barrelled blast of comedy, One Foot In The Grave and The Royle Family.

This touching faith in laughter was instantly undermined by One Foot In The Grave, where an instructor was teaching Victor Meldrew's tormented neighbour, Patrick, how to be happy. "Regular laughter not only lifts our spirits, it stimulates the diaphragm, assisting our breathing and so relieving our stress. So, with lots of gusto, ha, ha, ha!"

Cut to Victor, who is reading about a comic who killed himself. And got a bad review for it. "Arts critic, Marjorie Quayle, is unimpressed by the comic's final caper. The sudden death of orthodontically challenged Larry Hackett by plummeting from a tall building fell as flat on its face as the man himself."

(Very much the same sort of thing once happened to Ned Sherrin. On leaving the stage door, he fell headlong in the darkling street. As he lay there in the gutter thinking thoughts he could not utter, two passers-by remarked acidly, "Well, it's funnier than anything he did in the show.")

As this is the last series of One Foot In The Grave and, like Larry Hackett, Victor has to die, you wonder nervously how he will shuffle off this mortal coil. Look, it won't be a boa constrictor, will it? The BBC, who are of a religious bent, say Meldrew will meet his Maker, but, surely, that would be his scriptwriter, David Renwick? This is too surreal an idea even for this highly surreal series, where last night Moira Stewart's vibrations loosened a false leg and Patrick's dachshund, which Victor once mistook for a telephone, lost its voice.

Victor Meldrew seems to me to be made in his creator's image. Bill Cosby bought the American rights to One Foot In The Grave and changed it into just another warm-hearted Cosby show. David Renwick watched this process with, he said, "An increasing sense of despair and grim inevitability." Now, I'll say "Sense of despair and grim inevitability" and you say the first name that comes into your head. Exactly.

This series is the last bottle in the cellar, something to be savoured. I just wish the audience didn't laugh so loudly over the lines. As Wodehouse once said, and I hope you're not accusing him of being a grump, "I could have endured televison with more fortitude if they had not laughed so much all the time."

Nobody laughs in The Royle Family except the Royle family. This is a celebration of the mundane which every so often soars very sweetly and suddenly on the wings of popular song. There was the time when Joseph, the speechless neighbour, suddenly sang every last verse of I'll Take You Home Again, Kathleen. Or when Denise and her father, equally terrified by her labour, sat on the bathroom floor listening to a crystalline chorister singing Pie Jesu. And last night Dave, who has taken over all maternal duties except breast feeding, sang to his baby son "You are my sunshine, my only sunshine. You make me happy when skies are grey. You'll never know, dear, how much I love you...."

No natural function goes unmentioned in The Royle Family, from Denise's leaking nipples to Dad's piles and then, out of this earthiness, comes the sudden song. When Dave sang "You are my sunshine", he was changing the baby's nappy.

Like most families, the Royles don't exactly talk to each other. They communicate by rubbing their antennae or by telepathy. This week Darren, master of the monosyllable, turned up. "When's your Kenny due out of nick, Darren?" "Don't know." "Is he coming back here to live?" "No, he can't." "Yeah, it's best not to." What, you wonder wildly, scrabbling for a fingerhold on the cliff face of this exchange, has Kenny done? They all know so they don't have to mention it.

In Coronation Street (ITV) Linda's homicidal relatives, the Sykes, have surfaced like creatures from the black lagoon. fields.bodyText: Last night BBC1 fired off a double-barrelled blast of comedy, One Foot In The Grave and The Royle Family. This touching faith in laughter was instantly undermined by One Foot In The Grave, where an instructor was teaching Victor Meldrew's tormented neighbour, Patrick, how to be happy. "Regular laughter not only lifts our spirits, it stimulates the diaphragm, assisting our breathing and so relieving our stress. So, with lots of gusto, ha, ha, ha!" Cut to Victor, who is reading about a comic who killed himself. And got a bad review for it. "Arts critic, Marjorie Quayle, is unimpressed by the comic's final caper. (Very much the same sort of thing once happened to Ned Sherrin. On leaving the stage door, he fell headlong in the darkling street. fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: File On 4/Life Before Birth
fields.body:
In December 1998 the severed heads of four telephone engineers, three British and one New Zealander, were discovered near a remote village in Chechnya. The men had earlier been kidnapped from their guarded compound on the final day of their contract in Grozny. In File On 4 (8.0pm, Radio 4) Nick Hawton asks what precautions their employers had taken and what led such a small firm as Granger Telecom to bid for the £190 million new telephone network in Russia's breakaway republic.

A long-term BBC Radio project investigating the human life cycle is launched by Connie St Louis. The initial three programmes, Life Before Birth (9.0pm, Radio 4), examine people's knowledge of what happens to all of us in the womb. Such information was a complete blank until modern medical techniques recently pierced the veil. Now it is clear that experiences during gestation can have a lifelong effect. Pregnant women, mothers, and clinicians offer their differing perspectives.

fields.headline: Bullets over Merseyside
fields.standfirst: Director Dan Reed's violent new drama for Channel 4, Shooters, was inspired by the brutality he discovered in one of our poorest inner cities. But is he trying to portray real lives, or just cause a fuss? By  Fiona Morrow
fields.trailText: Director Dan Reed's violent new drama for Channel 4, Shooters, was inspired by the brutality he discovered in one of our poorest inner cities. But is he trying to portray real lives, or just cause a fuss?
fields.body:
"I'm interested in brutality and violence," says film-maker Dan Reed. "And in how people who live outside cosy, genteel, 'normal' lives manage to get by without the protection that most of us are accustomed to."

Reed is talking about Shooters, his new film which premieres on Thursday at the Sheffield International Documentary Film Festival, and which threatens to take audiences closer to some of the more violent parts of Britain than anybody has ever managed before.

The project started off simply enough. "I wanted to make a film about a 1995 gangland murder in Liverpool. But I was warned off it," Reed explains.

Although this made him abandon the idea of concentrating on the murder and its aftermath, he was still keen to make a film portraying the lives of people who grew up in the area where such events happened. However, few wanted to talk on camera. "I didn't want a procession of faceless silhouettes," he says. "It wouldn't have satisfied me. I want to make films that look good."

He also rejected the idea of just dramatising the world he wanted to portray. "At the moment, television drama seems to me incredibly unimaginative, with its potted ideas, gestures and mannerisms. It's lost the connection with real life." So he came up with a possibly unique solution - an improvised drama, based on the stories of the people he'd been talking to - and with them playing the fictitious characters themselves. "I wanted to tie it back to an authentic reality. It was important to me that the characters should be based on the people who were going to be in the film." These men knew about Liverpool's underworld, although there is no suggestion that they had been involved in serious crime, or the 1995 murder itself.

In preparation, Reed spent a year talking to the men he wanted to involve. "A lot of them are terribly interested in movies," he says. "They re-enacted them in their real lives, or even passed off recycled film scenes as their own experience. Fortunately, though, I'd seen the films too."

Once Reed had gained the men's trust and convinced them he wasn't an undercover policeman, he began to discuss how they were going to tackle the filming. "I had to be honest. I told them I wasn't going to glamorise them - it wouldn't be a film about men with flash cars. This was a film which would depict the grim reality in which they live."

Of course it wasn't just these "people with an alternative moral code" - as he describes them - that Reed had to keep on board. "Channel 4 took a big leap in the dark, too. We couldn't be sure that any of the guys would even turn up on the first day of shooting."

He also had to worry about possible tabloid press attention for what he was doing. "I'm unperturbed about the News Of The World getting hold of it, because there are no skeletons in my cupboard. I told the people involved in the film that there was no money in it for them. I'm worried that someone will take a phoney story to the papers about the project - when we were in Liverpool there were rumours about huge payments I was supposed to have made."

But what, does he feel, was the motivation for these men to appear on camera? "I think they couldn't quite believe that I was there asking them to do it," says Reed. "But they also felt that they belong to a part of the country that's been misrepresented by the media for too long."

He is bracing himself for a strong reaction from his film-making peers when the film premiers. "There will be a degree of bafflement," he admits, "and lots of questions as to who these people are, but I hope that most people will recognise the integrity behind my desire to show the consequences of violence."

He rejects any charges that he is exploiting his subjects for his own aggrandisement. "It's nothing overtly attention-seeking," he argues. "In fact it's just the opposite. The question is whether it's valuable to have films on television which engage with different ways of life. These people exist, and they're more prevalent and powerful in our society than most of us would ever imagine."

Hilary Bell, the Channel 4 commissioning editor overseeing the film, is sending out a clear message about what she considers to be its prime driving motivation. "I think it's a very moral film, with a clear documentary purpose - to examine how the surge in both cocaine and gun use has changed the business of crime in England's major cities. I'm not saying that these people are angels," says Bell, "but they don't hold convictions for serious violent crime."

And, like Reed, Bell doesn't seem too worried about the controversial reception that might be lying around the corner for Shooters. "I don't have sleepless nights about it," she says. "How does it go? Fasten your seatbelts - it's going to be a bumpy ride..."

 Shooters will be screened at the Seventh Annual Sheffield International Documentary Film Festival on Thursday at 9.30pm and Friday at 10pm. Tel 0114-275 7727 for details. It will be shown on Channel 4 next month.

fields.headline: Passport control
fields.standfirst: Who's in town, and why
fields.trailText: Who's in town, and why
fields.body:
Insider dealing... Get ready for a cruel exposé of Hollywood's airbrushing of real life, as Emmy-winning investigative journalist Lowell Bergman arrives in the country later this week. Immortalised by Al Pacino in corporate drama The Insider, Bergman - who, in the harsh light of reality, resembles his alter-ego about as much as you'd expect your average fiftysomething reporter to - is on his way to appear at the Sheffield International Documentary Festival, where he'll give a Channel 4 interview this Friday before returning to the States...

Calling Mr Tibbs... Meanwhile, prepare yourself for Sidney Poitier, arriving in London as of Monday to promote his autobiography The Measure Of The Man. And, in contrast to the dreary backslapping/ stabbing of most celebrity memoirs, you've got to hand it to the man in question, what with his being the first black actor to win an Oscar, and the former Bahamian ambassador to Japan.

The bald truth... Oh, and if you overhear a lilting guitar refrain straight from the South African townships in the next few days, that'll be sanctions-busting Paul Simon, girding himself for three consecutive nights at the Hammersmith Apollo, starting next Monday. Whether he'll be performing selections from his ill-fated musical The Capeman (sample review: "like watching a mortally wounded animal") remains, as yet, unclear.

Ol' Blue Eyes, Jr... Which just leaves time to mention Tina Sinatra, spawn - as you might expect - of the late Frank. Over on Monday to plug her book My Father's Daughter, the little minx is promising a host of "revealing and shocking" insights into pops, although given the kind of material that's already public knowledge, you have to wonder what she could possibly mean...

webTitle: Arts: Rachel Whiteread's Holocaust Memorial in Vienna

fields.headline: Making memories
fields.standfirst: Rachel Whiteread's work - her resin cast of a Victorian house, her proposed plinth for Trafalgar Square - has always sparked controversy. As she prepares to unveil her Holocaust Memorial in Vienna, she talks to  Adrian Searle
fields.trailText: Rachel Whiteread's work - her resin cast of a Victorian house, her proposed plinth for Trafalgar Square - has always sparked controversy. As she prepares to unveil her Holocaust Memorial in Vienna, she talks to Adrian Searle.
fields.body:
Next week, Rachel Whiteread's Holocaust Memorial will be unveiled in Vienna's Judenplatz. The memorial is a kind of library, its proportions based on a typical room in a building facing the square. Standing on a raised concrete dais, the memorial's outer surface is covered in what appear to be thousands of books, spine inwards, so that what one sees are the edges of the covers and the closed pages. A mute memorial, in other words, for the People of the Book. The doors to this library are sealed shut. Around the dais is a frieze of names, of the camps and sites where the genocide took place. On one face is a commemoration to the 65,000 Austrian Jews who perished. The inscription is in German, Hebrew and English.

Whiteread's memorial has been subject to the intrigues and arguments of the city's commercial, political and religious interests. It has raised criticism on all fronts - from the fact that Whiteread is neither Jewish nor Austrian, to its possible negative effect on local trade and complaints about the loss of parking spaces for the square's residents. What was once a congested thoroughfare is now a pedestrianised oasis of calm.

"I'm really looking forward to seeing the memorial being absorbed into the city," says Whiteread, "to seeing it in guide books. I'm wondering how they'll describe it."

The refurbishment of Judenplatz includes access to the underground remains of the synagogue that originally stood there, and a refurbished Judaic centre for the ultra-orthodox Misrachi community, which will contain a Holocaust museum. "It was always clear that the archaeological remains of a former synagogue, which burned to the ground in 1421, lay under the site. Our initial proposal took it into account," says Whiteread. "There were also disputes within the Jewish community about the nature of the memorial itself. But you can't make public sculpture by consensus. Nevertheless, the work is a political animal: the elections are coming up."

As the far right, xenophobia and anti-semitism re-emerge in Europe - synagogues burning in Paris, the rise of the Vlaams Blok in Belgium - Whiteread's memorial is likely to become a conspicuous target. "There's going to have to be 24-hour security of some sort. The surface has some anti-graffiti stuff on it. We've also cast extra books for the surface. If someone sprays a swastika on it we can try to scrub it off, or the books can be moved to break up the sign. A few daubed swastikas would really make people think about what is happening in their society, their culture. I certainly don't want to encourage it, but if it happens, it happens." The defacement would signal something, just as the graffiti on Whiteread's House, her 1993 cast of an entire Victorian house in a condemned terrace in London's east end - "WOT FOR", "WHY NOT" and "Homes for all - black and white" - registered the temperature of local feeling.

Part of the inspiration for the memorial came from the second world war bunkers in Normandy. "It is a library, but it looks like a bunker," Whiteread says. "Even the excavations underneath are bunker-like. It is also very brutal. I was thinking of brutalist architecture. But essentially, I tried to make something sombre and poetic. I've since been asked to make several other memorials but I've turned them down. I'm not in the memorial business."

Since being awarded this public commission in 1996, Whiteread has completed an acclaimed transparent cast of a rooftop water tower in New York, which stood on the skyline with other water towers, advertising signs, satellite dishes and aerials. "It was about trying to make something which almost wasn't there. In certain light conditions it is almost invisible. People haven't been able to find it. I like that. It's being relocated to the roof of the Museum of Modern Art now, a very different context.

"There were people who wanted to buy the water tower and take it to California, but I was adamant that it should stay in New York," she continues. "When I made House I had a couple of offers to chop it into sections and re-erect it somewhere else. I've got a few chunks from it, like bits of the Berlin Wall. They're meaningless. Displacing things is odd."

Whiteread's sculpture for the plinth in Trafalgar Square - a translucent resin replica of the plinth itself, to be mounted, inverted, atop its granite twin - should have gone on view this month, but has been held up because of technical problems with the resin cast. She is preparing a major travelling exhibition for the Guggenheim museums in New York, Berlin and Bilbao next year, when she will also hold a retrospective exhibition at the Serpentine Gallery in London, scheduled for May.

"I wanted to make something architectural for the Guggenheim, to relate to Frank Gehry's building in Bilbao and to the Frank Lloyd Wright building in New York. I decided to use my own architecture. I'm casting an apartment, which was in part of the building I've just bought in the east end." This building was also once a synagogue, a fact that Whiteread finds oddly circular and propitious.

She is casting a series of rooms, "with the spaces between the walls, the plaster and lath, so one will have glimpses through the slats of the lights, the plug sockets, the switches. Everything will be there, but you won't be able to see all of it. We had to work out how to remove the cast without destroying the room. It took four months to figure out how to do it." The sculpture, a descendant of Ghost (1990) and House, is technically complex; it uses a plaster developed for the Disney corporation to make fake rock faces. The resin she used for Water Tower was derived from a compound used in film special effects.

All this to make things which are, she insists, true to their original form. Forms that - from the spaces around staircases, to abandoned flats, bookcases and light fittings - have an understated resonance. Her sculptures, in other words, are as much about their anonymous past in the everyday world, and their future as loci of memory and symbolism, as they are about objects, materials, planes and masses.

"I've been casting floors for the Serpentine Gallery show - again from the synagogue - in metal," says Whiteread. "The idea is that they'll be rusted then waxed, and you can walk on them, so the raised parts will get polished by visitors' feet. Of course it refers to Carl Andre: it's a kind of double-double memory."

Whiteread's role in the production process of the work at times appears as much about management and quality control as it is the hands-on efforts of the traditional sculptor. "It is hard to persuade the technicians not to prettify the elements. I give them something to cast that looks like a piece of crap and they try to make it look nicer. They can't believe I want it just the way it is. I'm also working with a local architectural cast iron foundry. They had no idea of what I'm doing or why. Then one day someone recognised me, and everyone turned and said: 'You're that woman who made House.' "

When the controversy about House was at its height, Whiteread would sit in her car at a little distance from the sculpture, looking at the crowds who came to see it through a tear in a newspaper. As with the Holocaust Memorial, she wanted to keep her distance from the brouhaha. But fame catches up with you. She's even been mistaken for Charlie Dimmock by the star-struck. We recently found ourselves in a dingy Hackney strip-tease pub (don't ask why), where girls gyrated beneath a gorgeous, but filthy, Victorian ceiling. On their way out, a group of punters yelled, "Good on yer, Rach", while a stripper on her break came up to ask for advice on getting into art college.

She is rooted in London. "We've got a place in the countryside, miles from anywhere. I toyed with casting a valley, doing this ugly cast from nature. But I'm very grounded, and so is my work. I like the grittiness of the east end. And the idea of being a social butterfly never appealed."

 The Holocaust Memorial opens on October 25 in Vienna.

She is preparing a major travelling exhibition for the Guggenheim museums in New York, Berlin and Bilbao next year, when she will also hold a retrospective exhibition at the Serpentine Gallery in London, scheduled for May. "I wanted to make something architectural for the Guggenheim, to relate to Frank Gehry's building in Bilbao and to the Frank Lloyd Wright building in New York. I decided to use my own architecture. I'm casting an apartment, which was in part of the building I've just bought in the east end." This building was also once a synagogue, a fact that Whiteread finds oddly circular and propitious. She is casting a series of rooms, "with the spaces between the walls, the plaster and lath, so one will have glimpses through the slats of the lights, the plug sockets, the switches. Everything will be there, but you won't be able to see all of it. We had to work out how to remove the cast without destroying the room. It took four months to figure out how to do it." The sculpture, a descendant of Ghost (1990) and House, is technically complex; it uses a plaster developed for the Disney corporation to make fake rock faces. The resin she used for Water Tower was derived from a compound used in film special effects. All this to make things which are, she insists, true to their original form. Forms that - from the spaces around staircases, to abandoned flats, bookcases and light fittings - have an understated resonance. Her sculptures, in other words, are as much about their anonymous past in the everyday world, and their future as loci of memory and symbolism, as they are about objects, materials, planes and masses. "I've been casting floors for the Serpentine Gallery show - again from the synagogue - in metal," says Whiteread. "The idea is that they'll be rusted then waxed, and you can walk on them, so the raised parts will get polished by visitors' feet. Of course it refers to Carl Andre: it's a kind of double-double memory." Whiteread's role in the production process of the work at times appears as much about management and quality control as it is the hands-on efforts of the traditional sculptor. "It is hard to persuade the technicians not to prettify the elements. I give them something to cast that looks like a piece of crap and they try to make it look nicer. They can't believe I want it just the way it is. I'm also working with a local architectural cast iron foundry. They had no idea of what I'm doing or why. Then one day someone recognised me, and everyone turned and said: 'You're that woman who made House.' " When the controversy about House was at its height, Whiteread would sit in her car at a little distance from the sculpture, looking at the crowds who came to see it through a tear in a newspaper. As with the Holocaust Memorial, she wanted to keep her distance from the brouhaha. But fame catches up with you. She's even been mistaken for Charlie Dimmock by the star-struck. We recently found ourselves in a dingy Hackney strip-tease pub (don't ask why), where girls gyrated beneath a gorgeous, but filthy, Victorian ceiling. On their way out, a group of punters yelled, "Good on yer, Rach", while a stripper on her break came up to ask for advice on getting into art college. She is rooted in London. "We've got a place in the countryside, miles from anywhere. I toyed with casting a valley, doing this ugly cast from nature. But I'm very grounded, and so is my work. I like the grittiness of the east end. And the idea of being a social butterfly never appealed."  The Holocaust Memorial opens on October 25 in Vienna.

fields.headline: Lights of the desert
fields.standfirst: Involving 336 fluorescent lamps and six ex-army barracks, Don Flavin's Untitled (Marfa project) is dazzling
fields.trailText: Involving 336 fluorescent lamps and six ex-army barracks, Don Flavin's Untitled (Marfa project) is dazzling.
fields.body:
Some very unusual things happened in west Texas last week. For one, the weather switched from temperatures in the 90s to an onslaught of snow and wind that froze the trees and cacti into glassy ice structures. The other events were no less spectacular, if less unexpected. Some 1,400 people attended the annual open house weekend held by the Chinati Foundation in Marfa, a town of approximately 2,500 inhabitants set high in the Chihuahuan desert. Although some of the events were unravelled by the tempestuous weather, the inauguration of Dan Flavin's Untitled (Marfa project) dazzled all the more brilliantly.

One of three works to be completed posthumously (he died in 1996), it is Flavin's largest work and ranks among the most ambitious large-scale works of the 20th century. It is in good company, too. The Chinati Foundation, created by Donald Judd, a dominant figure in minimalist art throughout the past 30 years, is committed to installing and preserving works of art, often too large, fragile or complex to be held in normal museums. Judd also wanted to give substantial showings of a few artists' work rather than the myriad museum anthologies sparsely covering too many artists.

In order to realise this vision, Judd bought 340 acres of land just outside Marfa in 1979 with the assistance of the Dia foundation. The site's existing buildings once formed a US military camp, and met Judd's need for large, functional spaces. A line of U-shaped barracks is flanked by rectangular mess halls. Two artillery sheds dominate the site and house Judd's series of 100 aluminium boxes, made specifically for the site.

Flavin drew up plans for work at Chinati during the 1980s, but due partly to the expense and scale of the project, and partly to some complicated wrangling between Judd and Flavin in their last years, it has taken until now to realise the plans.

Like much of the work at Chinati - the foundation has housed pieces by Ilya Kabakov, Claes Oldenburg, and Richard Long - Untitled (Marfa project) utilises the space and permanence afforded by Judd's vision. Six barracks have been converted to house 336 fluorescent lights in four colours. Each building has its windows blocked out, bar the two that are farthest from the lights. At the top of each wing of the U-shape, the building is divided into two corridors by a wall that slants at 76 degrees to the floor. The sides of the corridors also slant.

The fluorescent lights, always two different colours backing up against each other, form blockades, either at the ends of these corridors or in the middle. You enter each building at a distance from the lamps, where the light is benign. Up close the light is stringent, the stripes falling at the same angle as the walls, recalling a shaft of sunlight or rain. There is a simple sequence: pink and green lamps are used in the first two buildings, yellow and blue in the third and fourth, and all four colours in the last two. The colours carry distinct sensations: the pink is kitsch, the green is similarly artificial but has a stranger, more sonorous tone; the blue is sky blue when you look directly at the lamps but deepens to an ultraviolet in the darkened corridors. The yellow modulates to amber from its buttercup lamp.

The repetition that is involved in seeing all six buildings, entering all 12 wings, sharpens your awareness of the size and proportion of the buildings, and provides an interesting response to Judd's own work at Chinati. Where Judd's use of aluminium in the 100 box structures plays with the light passing through the wall-to-floor windows, Flavin's work restricts the natural light and favours instead the play of fluorescent light against white walls. Where Judd's installation encompasses the surrounding landscape, Flavin directs the viewer towards the enveloping artifice.

The contrasts and compliments that pass between the works at the Chinati Foundation testify to Judd's curatorial foresight. And that there are plenty of serendipitous aspects to viewing the work at Chinati, not least the weather, makes the arrival of Flavin's new work an all the more captivating experience.

 For details of guided tours of the Chinati Foundation, call 001 915 729 4362.

webTitle: Arts: Napoleon hits the London stage

fields.headline: Tonight, Josephine
fields.standfirst: As Napoleon hits the London stage,  Stuart Jeffries  offers 10 tips to make your musical life of a historical figure a triumph
fields.trailText: As Napoleon hits the London stage, Stuart Jeffries offers 10 tips to make your musical life of a historical figure a triumph.
fields.body:
1. Ideally, your subject should be small and French. Napoleon and the Hunchback of Notre Dame have been done. Sartre: The Philosopher Toad merely awaits the casting of a sufficiently ugly lead who can sing. But beware. Jacques Chirac: The Musical wouldn't work. He's too big. Technical difficulties still beset a successful production of Jacques Cousteau: Underwater Wonderland. So be careful.

2.Try to be small and French and write a musical about someone who is also small and French. Hats off, then, to Charles Aznavour for writ ing a musical about Toulouse-Lautrec. But, as a new unauthorised biography reveals, Lautrec wasn't short at all - he just walked around on his knees to get sympathy and to better pleasure Montmartre's off-duty prostitutes. The dirty beast!

3. Your lyrics should concern the triumph of the human spirit. Here are a few of the lyrics I submitted to Francesca Zambello when I heard she was staging a musical about Napoleon. Astoundingly, she didn't use them. This, for instance, is the upbeat number Napoleon sings on the eve of the Battle of Borodino: "Don't you know that Corsican/ Means 'Course I can...'" A real showstopper, that. And there was another, called The Little Man Who Got Real Big, sung as Napoleon crowns himself emperor.

4. Don't worry if your hero/heroine is an evil git. Audiences eat evil up with a spoon. There's a play about the life of Robespierre on in Paris at the moment, which forestalled production of my musical treatment, Who Wants To Be Maximilien Robespierre?

5. Play up your hero's physical imperfections. Consider making Richard III sympathetic. Think of "that deaf, dumb and blind kid" Tommy. "You know, Tommy wasn't a historical figure," I hear you cavil. Shut up. After all, consider point six.

6. Historical accuracy is not essential. In my Full Nelson, for example, he wins the Battle of the Nile, rushes down the Suez Canal and then helps Norman Schwarzkopf win the Gulf War. The grandstanding finale has Horatio expiring on the deck and realising - too late! - his deep psychic wound.

7.Geographical implausibilities are things only critics such as Michael Billington will notice. Yes, Mike, the Tigris may well not be navigable by 19th-century British sailing ships and probably would have been destroyed by Iraqi helicopter gunships or whatever hi-tech weaponry British companies sold Saddam before hostilities commenced. But what you forget is this: nobody cares about that stuff.

8. Don't forget about sex: "Ivan, you're terrible/But you're great in bed/Though I know you'd rather/Lay waste to peasants instead."

9. Include cats. The new Edgar Allan Poe musical, for instance, does: "The cat on my shoulder has got a nerve/Frankly, she's an impediment to my oeuvre." Anything that involves women dressing up in cat suits and wriggling their wee catty nosies will be a surefire hit. That principle has governed the creation of Sexy Sox, my frank musical analysis of Clinton's moral incontinence as seen from a cat's perspective. Songs include: I Did Not Have Sex With That Woman and Nobody Calls Me Pussy (Let's Go To War!) - the last a duet between the President and Sox. If anyone could help me with how to develop "Monica's my moniker. And I'm feline, feelin' fine" I'd really appreciate it.

10. The problem with the modern historical musical is that it isn't played for laughs. You can change that.

 Napoleon opens at the Shaftesbury Theatre, London WC2 (020-7379 5399), tonight and will be reviewed in tomorrow's paper.

fields.headline: Sidelines
fields.body:
There is surely no headier thrill than to be immortalised in prose by one's beloved. How great, then, must be Zoe Ball's joy at some of the lyrics on her partner Fatboy Slim's new album. One track, Talking About My Baby, includes the tender phrases: "I like to sit and watch her walk in hotpants and no brassiere on. She's shaking like two balloons in a hurricane." The romance of it! He speaks for a generation of men eager to liken their ladies' embondpoint to a shrivelling piece of plastic. But we have consulted a meteorological expert who attests that balloons are unlikely to survive for long in strong winds, unless reinforced with a special polymer mix. One can only hope Zoe's balloons are shaking behind a sturdy windbreak.

This week, Sidelines is mostly feeling cold. In an attempt to combat said chill, the preferable option would be to (a) purchase a jumper of reasonable thickness and (b) wear said jumper in front of imaginary log fire, surrounded by puppies, or while ambling through a well-appointed park, kicking at crispy leaves with imaginary paramour. This cosy scenario is ruined, however, by the fickle mistress that is fashion and in particular by the return of those two most heinous clothing concepts: batwings and shoulder pads. We must protest at this wholesale 80s revivalism. Try keeping warm in a puffball skirt. Try wearing one and not having horrendous school disco flashbacks (I haven't forgotten, Leanne). The shops are full of Things Our Mothers Made Us Wear, interspersed with Things She Wouldn't, because she had a more holistic sartorial overview than we did back then. Don't betray your younger self; refuse to play along.

Liz Hurley is delighting in the single life. "When you're going out with a boy, they always insist on eating dinner," she tells one tabloid. "But if you're by yourself, you can go back to your room and just eat pretzels and drink wine - and I can eat in bed. Hugh hated sleeping in crumbs, but if it was up to me I'd sleep in crumbs and an inch of dog hair." Crumbs, we will allow. They are, after all, a natural exfoliant. But dog hair? There's a reason why the puppies in the above jumper scenario are imaginary - real live dogs are over-eager and yappy, with excessive saliva production. In contrast to cats, which are perfect. That said, Sidelines must make a nod to even-handedness. We realise that such mean definitives come from the simple fact that there are two kinds of people in this life: dog people, and better people.

One in 10 respondents to a survey on a medical website thinks life is not worth living, it was reported yesterday. Many feel unappreciated and dissatisfied at work and at home, while a quarter see no hope for the future. Thesurvey included over 80 questions exploring participants' emotional wellbeing. Which probably took a good while to fill in. Which leaves one pondering whether the whiney interviewees are likely to be worth living with. The glass is half full if you say it is, gang.

According to a survey for Loaded magazine, most men would prefer a kebab to sex after 10 pints of beer. Which is fortunate because a survey for Sidelines has discovered that most women would prefer keyhole surgery without anaesthetic to sex with a man who's just drunk 10 pints of beer.

webTitle: Sir Ralph Halpern a father at 61years of age

fields.headline: How's your old man?
fields.standfirst: As Sir Ralph Halpern becomes a father at the age of 61,  Dennis Barker, who had a child at a similar time in life, offers some expert advice
fields.trailText: As Sir Ralph Halpern becomes a father at the age of 61,  Dennis Barker, who had a child at a similar time in life, offers some expert advice.
fields.body:
I have some words of what I have no doubt will be much-needed advice for Sir Ralph Halpern, who has just become a father at what some people would consider the over-ripe age of 61.

As I discovered after I became a father at roughly the same age, the first piece of advice - very difficult to accept for a man like Sir Ralph who has been used to making things happen - would be that what you expect and want to happen won't happen and that you must learn to rejoice in that fact. Being older should help you in this.

When our Eleanor was born, an old friend predicted: "She will please you more than anything in the world has pleased you, and wind you up more than you have ever been wound up before." Both predictions have proved to be true.

Neither my wife Sarah nor I were absolutely brilliant at school, but we found no particular difficulty in swotting where required and generally got good results almost as a matter of course, neither of us being diverted from this by any strenuous expertise on the sporting field. As a writer, I naturally expected Eleanor to share these characteristics, to be mediocre at maths, uninterested in things physical and a master at handling English.

In fact, up to now, she has been tenacious at swimming and other sporting activities, more of a natural at maths than I ever was, rather hesitant about sentence structure and shy about expressing herself, a complaint from which I have rarely suffered.

At one recent "presentation" day at her school, when pupils did their own thing in front of assembled parents, nannies and well-wishers, most pupils read out poems or prose they had composed for the occasion. Eleanor's act was walking across stage on her hands, to general wonderment (as I would like to think) - or at least consternation.

No doubt a younger parent would be bothered by such an apparent betrayal of the genes, and would seek to persuade the child into becoming something different from what she was. No doubt Sir Ralph, as an entrepreneur, will expect his child to be of an energetic and calculating disposition, interested in only what delivers the gravy.

But he will have wasted his mature years if he does not see by now that human beings tend to turn out better if they are helped to be themselves rather than being put into a corset of their young parents' aspirations. If Sir Ralph's child wants to go out to the developing world as a missionary, that is a fact he should take better at 80 than at 40.

That may sound a bit pious as well as facetious. But I would maintain that an older father is more likely to find in his child what is there partly because he is more perceptive but also because he is less energetic and therefore more studiedly lazy. Laziness can be a great boon in fathering. It leaves more energy for when it is really needed - such as when matters of health and education are to the fore or when the child is in any sort of real predicament. You may miss the fact that your child is unhappy or otherwise in a mess if you are too concerned that his or her scuffed shoes let your own reputation down, which you are more likely to do at 25 than 55.

In the main, bringing up children consists essentially of a watching brief to make sure it does not bump into too much of life's furniture while they work out what sort of person they are and successfully act on it.

When you see young parents in waiting rooms, playgrounds or other public places, shouting at or manhandling their children as if they were disagreeable objects rather than different human beings who are trying to make their way through life, you immediately realise that the reduced energy of maturity is easily compensated for by the understanding and creative laziness of age. The older father has the advantage of being too far separated in age from his child to be a competitor.

Younger parents tend to be harder on their children's mistakes than is really necessary because such mistakes are a reminder to the parents of their own mistakes only a few years previously. I am too far away from the gauche wilfulness of my own childhood - and too kindly indulgent to that long-gone under-sized child trying to become a human being worthy of respect - to be made insecure by its repetition in the sometimes explosive self-assertion of my powerfully affectionate and powerfully self-willed daughter. In trying only to curb the self-will by making every event a contest, a younger parent might also curb the affection.

There is only one sadness that cannot be compensated for. That is the fact that it is unlikely that one will still be here to see what the child will be like as an adult, to enjoy adult conversation and to give what help one can. This sadness can be passed off with facetiousness ("At least I won't have to pretend to listen to her boyfriends' political views") but it inevitably presents at times something of a black cloud to any older father.

Perhaps the answer for Sir Ralph is that he should prepare and leave behind written evidence that his child was loved and will always be loved. It is love in the first seven years that is crucial to the later adult feeling of being in a welcoming world. And the older father is perhaps in a better position clearly to express that love, at the time or even posthumously, than a younger parent who is preoccupied by his ranking in office politics and squash.

No doubt Sir Ralph, as an entrepreneur, will expect his child to be of an energetic and calculating disposition, interested in only what delivers the gravy. But he will have wasted his mature years if he does not see by now that human beings tend to turn out better if they are helped to be themselves rather than being put into a corset of their young parents' aspirations. If Sir Ralph's child wants to go out to the developing world as a missionary, that is a fact he should take better at 80 than at 40. That may sound a bit pious as well as facetious. But I would maintain that an older father is more likely to find in his child what is there partly because he is more perceptive but also because he is less energetic and therefore more studiedly lazy. Laziness can be a great boon in fathering. It leaves more energy for when it is really needed - such as when matters of health and education are to the fore or when the child is in any sort of real predicament. You may miss the fact that your child is unhappy or otherwise in a mess if you are too concerned that his or her scuffed shoes let your own reputation down, which you are more likely to do at 25 than 55. In the main, bringing up children consists essentially of a watching brief to make sure it does not bump into too much of life's furniture while they work out what sort of person they are and successfully act on it. When you see young parents in waiting rooms, playgrounds or other public places, shouting at or manhandling their children as if they were disagreeable objects rather than different human beings who are trying to make their way through life, you immediately realise that the reduced energy of maturity is easily compensated for by the understanding and creative laziness of age. The older father has the advantage of being too far separated in age from his child to be a competitor. Younger parents tend to be harder on their children's mistakes than is really necessary because such mistakes are a reminder to the parents of their own mistakes only a few years previously. I am too far away from the gauche wilfulness of my own childhood - and too kindly indulgent to that long-gone under-sized child trying to become a human being worthy of respect - to be made insecure by its repetition in the sometimes explosive self-assertion of my powerfully affectionate and powerfully self-willed daughter. In trying only to curb the self-will by making every event a contest, a younger parent might also curb the affection. There is only one sadness that cannot be compensated for. That is the fact that it is unlikely that one will still be here to see what the child will be like as an adult, to enjoy adult conversation and to give what help one can. This sadness can be passed off with facetiousness ("At least I won't have to pretend to listen to her boyfriends' political views") but it inevitably presents at times something of a black cloud to any older father. Perhaps the answer for Sir Ralph is that he should prepare and leave behind written evidence that his child was loved and will always be loved. It is love in the first seven years that is crucial to the later adult feeling of being in a welcoming world. And the older father is perhaps in a better position clearly to express that love, at the time or even posthumously, than a younger parent who is preoccupied by his ranking in office politics and squash.

fields.headline: No: 1742
fields.standfirst: Prince Kretzulesco
fields.trailText: Prince Kretzulesco
fields.body:
AKA: Ottomar Rudolphe Vlad Dracula.

Age: A bit long in the tooth.

Wait a minute, did you say... Dracula? Oh yes. Kretzulesco is the last living member of the famous Dracula clan. And he's coming to Britain.

W ... w ... why? For the past six years, the prince has lived in the small East German village of Schenkendorf, by turns attempting to forge a living in catering, entertainment and antique dealing, and by opening his home as a tourist attraction. However, he has now been hounded out by superstitious locals who have attempted to torch his castle, graffitied neo-Nazi slogans and swastikas on the walls, and delivered death threats.

What kind of death threats? He hasn't specified, but one suspects it was a bit more serious than a few cloves of garlic shoved through his letterbox.

So he's pulling up stakes and moving to Blighty? Well, he also has the option of a monastery in Bavaria. But the Prince believes that "Britain has lots of castles and old stately homes which could benefit from being turned into a Dracula home".

Hasn't he got more important things to be doing? Such as?

Oh, y'know, sleeping in coffins, nibbling young maidens on the neck, that kind of thing ... Actually, these days he's too busy with his charity work. He recently fronted a campaign by the German Red Cross to encourage people to give blood.

Please tell me you're joking. Oh no, I'm deadly serious. The Germans made donations in droves after his campaign for the Red Cross. Now the Prince hopes we will be equally bitten. I mean smitten.

But isn't he worried about BSE? Surely you mean a steak through the heart?

Do say: "Caped crusader."

Don't say: "Where the hell's Buffy when you need her?"

fields.headline: Flood crisis in Italy's north
fields.trailText: Battered by relentless rainstorms, rescuers were hunting last night for people trapped in Alpine villages hit by the mudslides and floods unleashed by days of rain across Switzerland and northern Italy.
fields.body:
Battered by relentless rainstorms, rescuers were hunting last night for people trapped in Alpine villages hit by the mudslides and floods unleashed by days of rain across Switzerland and northern Italy.

Thousands were evacuated by helicopter as bridges, roads and houses were swept away in torrents that plunged some communities into medieval conditions. At least 10 people in Italy have died in recent days, with a further 10 reported missing. Fifteen people are missing, feared dead, in Switzerland.

Sniffer dogs detected a woman trapped under six feet of debris in the Swiss village of Gondo, near the Italian border.

"The rescuers heard knocking sounds and, later, also cries. We hope she is still alive," said a police spokesman, Markus Rieder. Rescuers were still trying to get her out as dusk fell.

A dozen residents are believed to have died after a dam burst above Gondo two days ago, destroying a third of the village in less than 10 seconds.

Emergency units remained on alert as searches continued for two people caught in a mudslide near Stalden village. A woman whose car was swept away on the road leading to the Great St Bernard pass was found dead. "We've never seen the Rhne like that," said one resident. "It's the flood of the century."

At the disaster scene, the Swiss president, Adolf Ogi, said: "Once again, we must recognise how powerful the forces of nature can be."

Ten of the confirmed dead were in Italy, which yesterday declared a state of emergency in the Piedmont and Valle d'Aosta regions. Towns were expected to stay cut off from the road, rail and telephone network for days.

Economic activity in Italy's industrial north-east ground to a halt. Turin's airport and most of its 29 bridges were closed when the Dora Baltea river burst its banks, swamping main streets in more than two feet of water.

An army of 6,500 rescue workers battled to restore power and evacuate communities threatened by swollen rivers and lakes.

Helicopters helped to ferry 3,000 people from isolated villages. About 50 people were lifted from rooftops in the Valle D'Aosta region, where five died on Sunday: an 85-year-old man who drowned in his basement: a girl, seven, who died when her Gypsy camp was flooded; and three sailors on a merchant ship anchored in the port of Savona who were swept overboard by a giant wave.

The Italian government set up a crisis centre in Rome, pledged £30m in immediate aid and urged motorists not to travel north.

Rescuers said more bodies would be found when the rainfall eased - expected to happen today - and the floodwaters began receding.

The Turin-based La Stampa newspaper called the floods a national disaster which had returned communities to the middle ages: "It is not just the houses destroyed and the lives lost. The all-embracing communications network created by the most modern techniques has been torn apart by five days of driving rain."

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: The hungriest countries in the world are Somalia, Haiti and Afghanistan, according to a new measurement used by the UN.
fields.body:
UN lists new state of hunger

The hungriest countries in the world are Somalia, Haiti and Afghanistan, according to a new measurement used by the UN.

Comparing the average calorie intake with the minimum needed to maintain body weight, the UN Food and Agriculture Organisation found that hungry Somalis are missing 27% of the intake they need, with Afghanis and Haitians lacking 26% and 24%, respectively.
AP , London

Riots erupt as prices soar

Anger over spiralling food and transport prices spilled on to the streets of Zimbabwe yesterday when hundreds of people went on the rampage in the capital, Harare.

Teargas was used to disperse mobs in Mabvuku, an impoverished township that is a stronghold for the opposition party, and some witnesses reported gunshots. The mobs were protesting against 30% hikes in staple food prices and a 20% rise in taxi and bus fares.
AP , Harare

Actor plunges to his death

A Spanish stuntman has been filmed falling to his death while attempting to enact a 25-metre suicide leap from a bridge in the heart of Madrid's old quarter.

The actor, Alvaro Burgos Goizueta, 21, was filming the final scene of a comedy called Canicula on Sunday when he leapt from the viaduct wearing a safety harness, which apparently failed.
Reuters , Madrid

French siblings murder trial

Two French brothers went on trial yesterday accused of the rape, kidnap and murder three years ago of four girls on their way home from a dance in Dannes, six miles from Boulogne.

The defendants, Jean-Louis Jourdain and his brother, Jean-Michel, have blamed each other for the killings, which sparked calls for a return of the death penalty in France.
Reuters , Saint-Omer

fields.headline: Lifers in 'two strikes' challenge
fields.trailText: The controversial "two strikes and you're out" life sentence will be challenged today in the appeal court by lawyers for four lifers, who will argue that the way it operates is unlawful under the Human Rights Act.
fields.body:
The controversial "two strikes and you're out" life sentence will be challenged today in the appeal court by lawyers for four lifers, who will argue that the way it operates is unlawful under the Human Rights Act.

The automatic life sentence for a second conviction for a serious offence was a cornerstone of the last Tory government's "tough on crime" criminal justice policy. The 1997 Crime (Sentences) Act lays down that judges must impose a life sentence on anyone convicted of a range of offences - including attempted murder, rape, manslaughter, wounding or causing grievous bodily harm with intent, and robbery with a real or imitation firearm - if the offender had been convicted of another offence on the list.

Lawyers have been awaiting the implementation of the Human Rights Act on October 2 to mount a comprehensive challenge to the automatic life sentence. Judges heartily dislike it because it fetters their discretion to fit the punishment to the crime. A life sentence must be passed if the offender fits the criteria unless there are exceptional circumstances.

Lord Woolf, the lord chief justice, will sit with two high court judges to hear the appeals, brought by Matthew Offen, convicted of robbery with a toy gun, Kristova Okwuegbunam, convicted of manslaughter, Peter McGilliard, serving life for wounding with intent, and Darren Mckeown, sentenced to life for causing grievous bodily harm with intent.

Offen, 36, who has an immature personality and possible learning disabilities, went into a building society branch in Hove wearing carpet slippers and asked for money, brandishing a toy gun and declaring "I'm sorry I have to do this". He was given £800 but a woman customer chased him and took the bag containing the money. He made a full confession to police.

He was given a life sentence on conviction in May 1999 because it appeared he had committed a similar offence in 1990.

His solicitor, Andrew Katzen, said he believed the minimum term or "tariff" his client had been given - 14 months - was the shortest for any lifer. His tariff had expired but he was still in Brixton prison, south London, because of administrative problems.

Okwuegbunam, 33, who is in Belmarsh prison, south London with a tariff of six years, struck his girlfriend during a row. She had a brain haemorrhage and died. He was sentenced to life because of an earlier conviction for rape. Neil O'May, his solicitor, said: "There was no intention to kill or do serious bodily harm. By taking away any discretion from the judge, you take away the justice from the case."

Offen and Okwuegbunam are represented by Edward Fitzgerald QC, who also acts for the Moors murderer Myra Hindley. He will argue that the automatic life sentence breaches the European convention on human rights, incorporated into English law by the Human Rights Act.

Mr Fitzgerald is expected to say that the sentences violate article 3 of the convention - the ban on inhuman and degrading treatment, article 5 - the right to liberty and security of the person - and article 7 - the ban on making a crime retrospective.

Lord Bingham, then lord chief justice, confirmed in a ruling last year that the court was compelled to impose an automatic life sentence for a second serious offence even when the judge felt it would be "unjust to do so in all the circumstances". He predicted that the courts would be asked to give an authoritative ruling on whether the sentence complied with the European convention.

webTitle: Gallery which regenerated canal area up for prize

fields.headline: Gallery which regenerated canal area up for prize
fields.trailText: The spectacular Walsall art gallery, a rare universally popular lottery funded development, yesterday made it on to the shortlist of seven for the top architecture award, the £29,000 Stirling Prize.
fields.byline: Maev Kennedy, arts and heritage correspondent
fields.body:
The spectacular Walsall art gallery, a rare universally popular lottery funded development, yesterday made it on to the shortlist of seven for the top architecture award, the £29,000 Stirling Prize.

The ceremony will be televised live on Channel 4 for the first time in an attempt to give the award the same popular status as the Booker literature or the Turner arts prizes.

Unlike these, however, the professional bookmakers have yet to take an interest. A spokeswoman for William Hill said it had not opened betting. "If we had known a bit more about it in advance we might have, but we do not really have the expertise here to judge it - and we have not been inundated with requests."

One of the judges, who will cast their secret ballots in the hour before the broadcast on November 4, is artist Tracey Emin, who made an unforgettable contribution to a live discussion after the 1997 Turner Prize, ending when she walked out of the studio muttering that she had to speak to her mother.

The £21m New Art Gallery, Walsall, the first major commission for the young design team Caruso St John, has been widely praised as a model of popular modern design - the recorded voice in the lifts is that of local boy and Slade star Noddy Holder - and has been credited with a mini urban renaissance in its formerly run-down canalside district.

It was praised by the Royal Institute of British Architects judges as "almost faultless".

Apart from the Walsall gallery and an office block in Berlin designed by the Anglo-German firm Sauerbruch Hutton - the prize is for "the European building which has made the greatest contribution to British architecture" -all the other shortlisted buildings are in the London area.

The rival lords of the architectural profession, Lord Rogers and Lord Foster, also both made the shortlist. The Richard Rogers partnership was nominated for 88 Wood Street, an office complex of three stepped towers, built beside the tower of a bombed Wren church in the City of London, and Foster and Partners for the Canary Wharf Station on the Jubilee Line extension, praised as "a contemporary cathedral of a space".

The "building with the beret" - actually a sunshade to cut glare - Will Alsop's public library in Peckham, south London, was described by the judges as "extraordinary and innovative". It was built for £4.5m, a fraction of the cost of most of its rivals.

For the first time the public was invited to vote a building on to the shortlist. The London Eye, designed by Marks Barfield, was expected to walk away with this vote, but although the big wheel did make it on to the shortlist, the surprise popular vote was for the Sainsbury supermarket on the Greenwich peninsula, south London, designed by Chetwood Associates, which recently also collected a Royal Institute of Chartered Surveyors building of the year award.

webTitle: It's farewell to the terminally lost visitor at Barbican mark two

fields.headline: It's farewell to the terminally lost visitor at Barbican mark two
fields.trailText: After almost 20 years, the Barbican, the world's most bewildering arts centre, is solving the problem of its notorious signs once and for all - by getting rid of most of them.
fields.body:
After almost 20 years, the Barbican, the world's most bewildering arts centre, is solving the problem of its notorious signs once and for all - by getting rid of most of them.

The problem was underlined yesterday when the consultant hired to rebrand the London complex - after much agonising the Barbican Arts Centre is to become barbican - missed the turn into the car park and got lost on the way to the launch. "Clarity and simplicity," a shaken Jim Northover, of Citigate Lloyd Northover, proclaimed the new motto when he finally arrived.

To date, the London home of the Royal Shakespeare Company and the London Symphony Orchestra, has been an artistic success and a design nightmare. It was opened in 1982, a last-minute design addition shoe-horned into a massive City of London tower block complex begun in the early 1970s. It has three cinemas, two theatres, two galleries, a concert hall and a library (all regularly sending out runners to retrieve terminally lost visitors).

The architects yesterday talked of stripping away layers of unsympathetic alterations. But the barbican's director, John Tusa, standing on a hangover coloured carpet dating from the last stab at reform 10 years ago, defined the arts centre's problems more brutally: "The moment you come in you say ugh!" The centre will get a new logo (cost, £50,000) as part of a rolling £6m programme of updating the public spaces, on top of a £5m revamp for the concert hall to deal with the patchy acoustics and the lighting and ailing air conditioning.

Famously, though, it was the labyrinth of foyers, booking offices, lobbies, staircases, and high, low and mezzanine levels, which caused the havoc - leaving bewildered visitors often queuing at the wrong box office and friends never seeing each other again. This will be tackled by Allford Hall Monaghan Morris, the firm that turned a commission to brighten up the Walsall bus station into an architectural award winner.

Graham Sheffield, the centre's artistic director, with a nervous sideways glance at his colleague, suggested the orienteering had been a generational thing: "The younger generation has far fewer difficulties in locating and enjoying the building."

However, Paul Monaghan yesterday promised "instantly understandable and friendly" spaces. The alarming carpets, the dentist's waiting room seats, the successive waves of lighting fixtures each more dismal than the last, and most of the signs, would go. So, too, the old logo, the four interlocked Bs - an image summing up for many the barbican's problems.
