The alarming carpets, the dentist's waiting room seats, the successive waves of lighting fixtures each more dismal than the last, and most of the signs, would go. So, too, the old logo, the four interlocked Bs - an image summing up for many the barbican's problems.

fields.headline: Elitism row hits Cambridge intake
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: The row about elitism at Oxbridge, stirred this summer by the chancellor, Gordon Brown, may have caused a drop in comprehensive school applications to Cambridge for the first time in 12 years, the university disclosed yesterday.
fields.body:
The row about elitism at Oxbridge, stirred this summer by the chancellor, Gordon Brown, may have caused a drop in comprehensive school applications to Cambridge for the first time in 12 years, the university disclosed yesterday.

The comments, by Susan Stobbs, the admissions director, came after Cambridge published its first table detailing how many places went to state school applicants in 1999. It showed they gained at least 50% of places at half the 24 main undergraduate colleges.

The figures uncovered a sizeable variation with King's taking 79% of its class of 1999 from state schools, compared with 39% at Gonville and Caius and Corpus Christi.

Only Magdalene and St Catharine's gave at least half their places to comprehensive pupils despite having more private school applicants.

Ms Stobbs said that if pupils looked at the figures in isolation, they might be put off applying to the very colleges that were working hardest to attract them.

The row about elitism erupted in May when Mr Brown criticised the rejection of the state school pupil Laura Spence by Magdalen College, Oxford.

Ms Stobbs said: "Our great fear this year is that it will make it harder to achieve what we want because people don't like being used as a political football.

"The average intake from state schools has been going up slowly but steadily over the last 12 years.

"Oxford have announced their number of applications are down and we sense it is the same with us. That would be the first time for 12 years that it was down, although I should stress it is provisional as we don't have the firm numbers yet."

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Hospital bugs to be checked
fields.body:
Hospital bugs to be checked

Every NHS trust in England will have to monitor and reveal levels of infections picked up by hospital patients from next year, the health minister, John Denham, said yesterday. The national audit office says 100,000 patients a year contract an infection and around 5,000 die.

£3m hope for 'lost' Stubbs

A racehorse by the 18th century British animal painter George Stubbs which remained unidentified for 200 years is expected to fetch more than £3m at Sotheby's in London next month. The barely legible inscription reads: "Euston, a dappled grey racehorse, the property of William Wildman, with jockey up in a river landscape."

Incinerator protest ends

Greenpeace activists ended a four day chimney-top protest at the London waste incinerator plant in Edmonton, north London, yesterday because of the cold and hunger. The plant will not be fully operational until the weekend.

Diver dies in Wast Water

A man died after diving into Wast Water in Cumbria yesterday. An inquest into the death of Paul Joseph Gallacher, 33, of Cosby, Leicestershire, was opened and adjourned.

Potter spin-offs for charity

The author of Harry Potter, JK Rowling, is writing two spin-off books to be published for Red Nose Day next March. The book will be called Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them, and Quidditch Through the Ages.

webTitle: 'Torments of hell' endured by acid victim

fields.headline: 'Torments of hell' endured by acid victim
fields.standfirst: Murder trial told accused waited 23 minutes before seeking help after causing his former lover to drink drain cleaner
fields.trailText: The former partner of a popular young hospital doctor caused her to suffer the "torments of hell" after giving her sulphuric acid because he could not accept their relationship was over, a court heard yesterday.
fields.body:
The former partner of a popular young hospital doctor caused her to suffer the "torments of hell" after giving her sulphuric acid because he could not accept their relationship was over, a court heard yesterday.

Andrew Gardner waited more than 20 minutes before calling an ambulance while Karenina Longe, a senior house officer, screamed in agony, the jury was told.

Dr Longe, 27, died in Birmingham's Heartlands hospital, where she worked, the day after going to see Gardner on February 5 this year.

Birmingham crown court heard that Gardner, 41, a former laboratory technician at St Bartholomew's hospital, central London, had beaten the Nigerian-born doctor the previous week and she had ended their relationship.

Stephen Linehan QC, prosecuting, told the court that while Dr Longe had been calm and resolved to get on with her life, Gardner was "not willing to let her go".

When she arrived at the rented house they had shared in the Sheldon area of Birmingham about midday on February 5, he somehow administered the 93%-96% proof acid contained in drain cleaner.

"Nina Longe was murdered. She didn't die by 2.03pm but by that time Andrew Gardner had administered to her a lethal dose of acid. By 2.03pm, she was suffering the torments of hell," Mr Linehan said.

"That acid was burning its way through the walls of her stomach and burning its way into her internal organs.

"It is almost impossible to imagine. But if you had seen or heard her, you would not need to imagine. Andrew Gardner was there. He witnessed it and he heard the agony she was in."

Mr Linehan told the jury that as Dr Longe suffered an "agonising death", Gardner did not telephone for an ambulance for 23 minutes and instead rang a plumber to find out the effects of swallowing acid.

He concocted a story that the doctor, studying for the second part of her Royal College of Physicians exams, had deliberately drunk the drain cleaner to harm herself and had complained of feeling unwell as they made love.

But before the ambulance arrived, he fled to London with her credit cards. He was arrested on February 29, when he told police Dr Longe had taken the acid.

During Mr Linehan's opening speech, the jury of eight men and four women heard a tape of an emergency call between Gardner and an operator with Dr Longe's screams in the background.

In a four-and-a-half-minute conversation, the jury heard Gardner tell the operator: "My girlfriend's done something silly. She's drunk sulphuric acid." Operator: "She's swallowed sulphuric acid?" Gardner: "Yes."

Moments later, the defendant was heard to say: "She's semi-conscious. She's moaning. She just says 'The pain, the pain'. I've just given her some milk. It's OK."

Mr Linehan continued: "What was he thinking in those 23 minutes? She was suffering in agony. Nobody, not even a stranger, would have listened to those cries and not called an ambulance. Nobody but her killer."

The court heard that Dr Longe was born in Nigeria but was sent with her sister to boarding school in Britain. There, she became head girl and gained four A-levels before winning a place to train as a doctor at St Bartholomew's hospital.

Mr Linehan said: "She was a lovely young woman with everything to live for. Her one misfortune was to meet Andrew Gardner. It is really a grotesque understatement to call it a misfortune, as it was to lead to her death."

The lawyer said Gardner used his charm to woo Dr Longe and they started a relationship. He then gave up his job to follow her to Birmingham and they moved in to rented accommodation with his teenage son John from a previous relationship.

But the living arrangements did not work out, as he never found work and spent the time drinking, causing several rows. After he allegedly beat her, she moved back into doctors' quarters at the hospital.

Mr Linehan told the court that it was a "blatant lie" that the popular and intelligent young doctor would have swallowed the acid to commit suicide and deliberately die in torment. The pain would have been immediate and she would have been in no position to invite the defendant to go upstairs and make love.

He said it was unclear how she swallowed the cleaning fluid but it could have been a "last toast" offered by Gardner before they went their separate ways.

The jury was shown photographs of the house and acid staining both on the carpet and sides of the bed in the room where Dr Longe and Gardner used to sleep as well as the plastic bag in which the bottle of cleaner had been kept. Highlighting pictures of the doctor's clothes, Mr Linehan said: "At the time Gardner says she swallowed the acid in a deliberate suicide, she was completely undressed.

"When the ambulance came to collect her and when she got to the hospital, she was wearing that top, pants and these jeans."

Graham denies murder.

The case continues.

Press Association

fields.headline: Internet know-how:  homework
fields.trailText: Homework help or cheeky cheating? Websites for after-school work.
fields.body:
"Please would you send me information on the results I would get when increasing the amount of turns on an electromagnet and why this would happen. I am doing an investigation and need to do it quickly," writes one 16-year-old who seems to be having trouble with GCSE physics coursework, on the website of Homework High.

Are they trying to cheat? They certainly get short shrift from the teacher answering the question: "It is important to understand that I can't give you the answers if you are doing an investigation," reads the reply, which goes on to encourage him to think more deeply about electromagnetism. Homework High pulls off the difficult trick of illuminating a problem rather than entirely solving it.

While the BBC met the early summer demand for revision help with bbc.co.uk/revisewise, Channel 4 has built up a homework service which came into its own at the start of the new school year. So heavy is demand that Homework High teachers are answering around 200 questions a night and hastily installing a new server to cope with the traffic.

While maths, science and French tend to be the subjects which leave pupils stuck, in the humanities and English pupils may be short of ideas rather than uncomprehending. The BBC's history pages are adept at enlivening major events in British history. Simon Schama's series on the history of Britain is backed up by a virtual tour of Housesteads Roman fort, History 2000 events, details of where to find "star objects" in the series (such as Thomas à Becket's casket) and a re-enaction of the Battle of Hastings.

The Delphi oracle at www.classicspage.com usually answers questions about Greek, Latin and classical civilisation (including myths) in 48 hours. If you post a message on the Georesources site the editor, David Rayner, may well be able to reply.

Similarly, although the Explore Parliament site doesn't have an official answer service, it does have a very good glossary and search engine for queries. Science - especially physics - is well served by How Stuff Works which answers and archives questions.

Many parents are unsure how best to help their child with homework. The BBC's Dynamo site advises on supervising small children.

fields.headline: On the web
fields.standfirst: English language
fields.trailText: English language
fields.body:
Language Live

**

Aimed at: KS2

Imaginative ways of helping children to remember the correct use of apostrophes, difficult spellings and grammatical definitions. It's a pity the site is so small.

OED Word of the Day

****

Aimed at: KS4/A-level

Understandably, you can't consult the whole of the OED online unless you have a costly subscription. However, they do release one word a day. Lexicographic fans and those studying etymology will find it compelling, and a complete definition could make a good case study.

Wired style

***

Aimed at: KS4/A-level

With its origins in a book, Principles of English Usage in the Digital Age, this site would make an unusual starting-point for the study of the new lexicon and grammar that has grown up around English on the web. Points are discussed and questions answered.

American Speeches

****

Aimed at: KS3 onwards

This is a US site and the speeches chosen assume a basic awareness of American history. The substantial archive begins in 1895 with a call to educate Southern blacks and concludes with Holocaust survivor Elie Wiesel discussing the "perils of indifference". Sometimes video and audio versions are available, and the teachers' section contains a few pointers. The site is worth a look if you want to investigate the difference between rhetorical and everyday language, or analyse the delivery of a text.

English Resources

***

Aimed at: KS3 onwards

Several of the lesson plans here examine aspects of language use.

A-level English

***

Aimed at: A-level and KS2 onwards

A small site which aims to inspire teachers of English language who want to use the internet, A-level English makes intriguing use of some of the sources available. It also hosts Newswise, a topical news activity.

Lessons from Reuters

****

Aimed at: KS2-3

These reading comprehension lessons from the Reuters news agency are intended primarily for teachers of English as a foreign or second language, but they make useful "filler" literacy hour activities for pupils who finish before the rest of the class, and helpful revision. A free lesson is added every day and saved in the archive. To access the latter you'll need to pay US$30 three times a year.

A World of Words

***

Aimed at: A-level

Links and advice brought together for a first-year undergraduate course at the University of Michigan. The page includes sections on the origins of English, metaphor, linguistics and offbeat sites such as the ChomskyBot. See yourdictionary.com for a more irreverent approach to the language.

Dictionary.com

**

Aimed at: KS3 onwards

Like the OED, Dictionary.com has a word of the day, but Doctor Dictionary is also available to answer questions. "When should the subjunctive be used in English?" elicited more than a hundred replies. Typing in "subjunctive" was more helpful. The site links to an online version of Roget's Thesaurus.

You can find more English language sites at www.educationunlimited.co.uk/netclass or contact Ros Taylor at ros.taylor@theguardian.com

fields.headline: What's in a name?
fields.standfirst: With competition so hot, maintaining a memorable brand image is the recipe for success
fields.trailText: With competition so hot, maintaining a memorable brand image is the recipe for success
fields.body:
Children as young as 36 months old can recognise them. They are everywhere. Their names appear on your clothes. They clamour for your attention from posters and in the magazines you read. They are brands. According to people in marketing, they are a short cut to the meanings behind a product. To their critics, they are a force for bad, turning the world into one bland marketplace.

What is a brand?

Once it was what cowboys burnt into cattle to show ownership. Now the word is more complex. Take denims. They are made from tough material stitched to fit your lower limbs. But call them Levi's and spend millions suggesting that they are jeans chosen by young, sexy, rebellious, attractive people and suddenly you have a brand on your legs. It's not enough that they keep you warm: they must be linked to ideas, hopes and dreams matching the customers' thinking, and self-image.

How do companies match their products to such things?

They do it by using market research such as surveys quizzing people about their attitudes, habits and pleasures. Young people are important to companies. Teenagers spend over £15bn a year and influence how adults spend money. Finding out what make them tick and trying to build this into brands is crucial.

Why do companies spend time and money turning their products into brands?

The answer is competition. Say a company invents something successful, it will soon have competition. If that company can lend its product something extra that makes it different and superior, the product will go on making money.

Customers will develop what is called brand loyalty. There are, say, plenty of chocolate products but only one KitKat -the top-selling confectionery for the past 13 years. What makes this brand different is a mix of familiarity, taste and packaging. Of course, if KitKats tasted disgusting no packaging overcome that problem - so brands must have a real or "core" value to support the other ideas they contain.

What goes into creating a brand?

Marketing. And to understand this word, think of scent. What is a scent? A series of refined odours held in alcohol which people put on themselves. But what those smells come to be linked to as brands illustrates the power of clever marketing.

The name is important. A scent called Oldsox is unthinkable. Price matters -scents are luxuries and so they must not be sold cheaply. Plastic packaging is out - glass and glittery metals in. A scent must not appear on petrol station shelves but in big stores associated with expense. In advertisements, the scent should be linked to a beautiful-looking woman, possibly a star, and those ads need to appear in expensive magazines or on the TV before Christmas. All these things together are called the marketing mix. Get it wrong and a brand is likely to fail.

Do brands go on and on?

Think of Biro and Hoover - both products that were once dominant brands. The presence of some brand names as general words in the language for kinds of product or activity suggests how powerful some brands become. All brands need to be supported because even the best can lose "customer loyalty". "Supporting" a brand takes many forms. One way is "brand extension" - like turning a sweet into an ice cream.

Are brands vulnerable?

Brands rely on image and are vulnerable to sabotage and scandal. It is not cool to think of trainers being made by exhausted child workers earning next to nothing. Protesters opposed to the global domination of certain brands have damaged reputations of products by exposing such practices.

Why are brands important?

Successful brands are worth millions as guarantees of future sales and are included in the value put on companies. Brands are marketed to appeal to our self-images and have become an important way people define themselves. But is it true that who we are is increasingly a matter of what we consume? Do young people need protecting from brands? Should they be banned from our schools?

Curriculum links: citizenship, media studies, English, business studies

Brand.New, an exhibition on the history, development and impact of brands, opens this week at the Victoria and Albert Museum (October 19 to January 14). Entry is £5 for working adults but free to everyone else. Click Brand. New link on the V&A's website:

All these things together are called the marketing mix. Get it wrong and a brand is likely to fail. Do brands go on and on? Think of Biro and Hoover - both products that were once dominant brands. The presence of some brand names as general words in the language for kinds of product or activity suggests how powerful some brands become. All brands need to be supported because even the best can lose "customer loyalty". "Supporting" a brand takes many forms. One way is "brand extension" - like turning a sweet into an ice cream. Are brands vulnerable? Brands rely on image and are vulnerable to sabotage and scandal. It is not cool to think of trainers being made by exhausted child workers earning next to nothing. Protesters opposed to the global domination of certain brands have damaged reputations of products by exposing such practices. Why are brands important? Successful brands are worth millions as guarantees of future sales and are included in the value put on companies. Brands are marketed to appeal to our self-images and have become an important way people define themselves. But is it true that who we are is increasingly a matter of what we consume? Do young people need protecting from brands? Should they be banned from our schools? webTitle: If you ask me...about how to make your daughter work

fields.headline: If you ask me...
fields.standfirst: My 17-year-old daughter has a very lackadaisical attitude towards school. She already behaves like a "student" towards her home, her social hours and her poor parents! I want to give her some slack, but if she doesn't start taking her studies seriously, she might not get to university. Help!
fields.trailText: My 17-year-old daughter has a very lackadaisical attitude towards school. She already behaves like a "student" towards her home, her social hours and her poor parents! I want to give her some slack, but if she doesn't start taking her studies seriously, she might not get to university. Help!
fields.body:
Lucy Peters, sixth form teacher at Fullbrook School in Surrey

It's hard to generalise about which approach to use with laid-back 17-year-olds as they're all motivated in different ways, but my initial response would be to contact your daughter's school to find out exactly how her teachers feel she's getting on. It may be that she is in fact on top of her work.

If her teachers feel that she's not doing enough to achieve her target grades, perhaps the time has come to sit down with your daughter and encourage her to think about her future. Does she hope to go to university? If so, what grades does she need?

Students find it difficult to take responsibility for their own learning, so negotiate with her about what you can do to help, for example offer to buy support texts, provide a suitable study area and maybe offer rewards in return for her agreeing to a routine that includes a balance of studying and socialising, with limited part-time work. Emphasise the ultimate goal of university and the extra freedoms associated with it.

We've found recently that a useful exercise for our sixth form students was to ask them to complete a time study for an average week, encouraging them to realise exactly what proportion they are spending on their studies. If you find that you make little progress with this approach, contact the school again - they really can help and support you.

Ann Limb, Principal of Cambridge Regional College

It's easy to forget how traumatic the transition from compulsory to post-16 education can be, particularly as it involves adapting to a totally independent approach to learning. To assume that this can happen within a few weeks at the beginning of term is rather unrealistic! It's more organic and develops over time.

Many young people actually feel a little abandoned, especially if the move is also to a different environment where new relationships between staff and students have to be established. Parents can also feel neglected and/or anxious about how far to encroach upon their child's "space".

We've tried to overcome this by inviting parents and students to an induction session, where we explain the courses and the expectations/requirements of students. We also give an overview of where their studies could lead them, be it university or employment. This is quite a short period in the student's life, so it can be very motivating to give it a sense of purpose.

Don't be afraid to contact staff if you don't know how to be more involved without encroaching upon your daughter's independence. Parents are extremely important partners in the process of learning.

Dr Mark Hamilton, Radio 1's resident expert on the Sunday Surgery

As a 17-year-old, your daughter is starting to become the adult that she has probably been waiting to become all her teens. So you both need to adapt to communicating on a more adult level.

Voice your feelings as concerned advice rather than a set of commands or demands which you may have used when she was younger. The latter is far more likely to be met with rebellion and/or rejection. Explain that you are simply giving her the facts of the situation as you see them. Yes, she must enjoy herself, begin to exercise her independence and assert her own personality. But point out that far from trying to curtail her freedom by expecting her to work hard before she can play hard, you are simply trying to ensure she reaches university - where she will have even greater opportunity to have fun for at least the next three years! And she can work towards the qualifications which will hopefully enable her to have a fulfilling and rewarding job, and life, in the not so distant future.

You may find that bribery, in some guise or other, works, but this really shouldn't be the sole incentive for your daughter to do well. Ultimately she needs to be motivated by a genuine belief that the ends are worth the means.

Next week's problem: My son is in year eight and hates his new geography teacher, resulting in him bunking off lessons. I went into school to talk things through with the teacher, and it was obvious the feeling was mutual! It's a real personality clash, which is detrimentally affecting my son's education. What can I do about it?

webTitle: Government climbdown over bill shows someone is listening

fields.headline: A little care
fields.standfirst: Government climbdown shows someone is listening.
fields.trailText: Government climbdown shows someone is listening
fields.body:
Uncaring and out of touch are two of the kinder terms that have been used to describe the government in recent months. So it is refreshing to be able to report an instance of a minister listening to public opinion.

The minister in question is John Hutton, minister of state at the Department of Health, and the legislation in question is the Children (Leaving Care) bill, which has already worked its way through the Lords, where it was initiated, and only has the report and final reading stage to go in the Commons. The bill, which makes greater provision for 16-year-olds leaving care, is, for the most part, uncontentious. There was, however, one glaring anomaly; while local authorities had a legal duty to provide accommodation during vacations for care-leavers in higher education, there was no such provision for those in full-time residential further education colleges. Instead, there was merely a moral expectation that local authorities would house further education care-leavers during the holidays.

By any stretch of the imagination this was a blatantly discriminatory piece of legislation. Not only did it contradict the lifelong learning initiatives coming out of the DfEE by implying that the further education sector was second class, it also defied logic. In most cases, an 16-year-old with few, if any, academic qualifications at a further education college is likely to need more support than a well-qualified 18-year-old entering higher education. However, despite strong representations to the Department of Health by John Brennan, director of further education development at the AoC, Mr Hutton remained unmoved.

"At 18, though, these children become legally adults and we believe they should operate in the adult world," he wrote, before going on to reiterate that the local authority would still have discretionary powers to help with education and training which "would be likely to extend to accommodation".

And, despite a comprehensive ministerial grilling at the bill's committee stage, so it remained. Until last week, when a letter turned up on John Brennan's desk in which the minister conceded that the AoC had made a powerful case and that it may not have been "helpful for the bill to refer to vacation accommodation solely in terms of higher education". He went on to say that the relevant amendments would be introduced to the bill.

All of which has been greeted with a mixture of relief and gratitude at Easton College. "We have had a care-leaver on our horticulture course for over a year now," says David Lawrence, principal. "The best vacation accommodation the local authority could come up with was a hostel where there were people with drug and alcohol problems. We didn't feel this was right for him, so our staff gave up their time, unpaid, during the holidays to both supervise and find him work experience so that he could stay on here. The staff have been outstanding, but it's clearly not right that a student's wellbeing should depend on the goodwill of the college, so I'm delighted by the decision."

As is David Gibson, the AoC's chief executive: "It's great that youngsters who have had such horrible expectations in life should be given a chance," he says. "I'm very grateful for what the department has done." A dignified end to an undignified affair.

webTitle: So you want to learn... osteopathy

fields.headline: So you want to learn...
fields.standfirst: osteopathy
fields.trailText: osteopathy
fields.body:
You will be careful? Yes. Just lie still please.

Only I'm a bit nervous about this. Nothing to worry about. I'm just going to push here ...

Yeeeoww. ...There, that's done.

That's all? Try standing up.

Hey! Slowly!

The pain's gone. It's a miracle. How did you do that? It's called osteopathy.

What is it? It's a system of medicine concerned with the musculo-skeletal system (the bones, joints, muscles, ligaments and connective tissue) making up the body's framework. We use our hands to find the underlying causes of pain and to treat disorders. And we use various manipulative techniques to restore function and improve mobility.

You need to be strong! The work is physically quite demanding, although manipulative skills are required rather than great strength.

It's all done by feel? Oh, no. Osteopaths take a detailed medical history before examining how the patient walks, stands and sits. We use hands to examine muscles, ligaments and vertebrae. In some cases, we may use X-rays or other orthodox tests.

Do you do anything after manipulation? We often suggest exercises to change a person's posture and help them stay healthier. If the problem cannot be helped by this treatment, the osteopath may refer the patient to a doctor or another type of therapist.

Are you in the NHS? Osteopaths work in private practice and are increasingly being asked to work as part of mainstream medicine.

What skills do osteopaths need? They obviously require manual dexterity and a genuine desire to help and care for people. An ability to get on with and gain the confidence of their patients is also important.

What qualifications are necessary? Practising osteopaths must be registered with the General Osteopathic Council. That means training at an approved osteopathic school, which requires at least two A-levels in science subjects, plus three GCSEs (A-C) in other subjects. The minimum age to start training is 18.

Suppose you haven't got the A-levels? The British School of Osteopathy (BSO) realises that some adults wishing to train may not have the normal entry qualifications. Highly motivated mature people who can make an invaluable contribution to patient care may be accepted on the course with alternative qualifications or relevant experience. There are also training courses designed for qualified medical doctors, state-registered health care professionals and trained complementary therapists from recognised schools.

Where do osteopaths train? There are eight osteopathy schools in England whose courses lead to registration with the General Osteopathic Council. The London College of Osteopathic Medicine runs a 13-month course which is only open to qualified medical doctors. The Oxford School of Osteopathy has a three-year part-time degree course only for state-registered health care professionals and trained complementary therapists.

fields.headline: Acting rashly
fields.standfirst: Donald Hiscock  confesses his once- a-year itch
fields.trailText: Donald Hiscock confesses his once- a-year itch.
fields.body:
The annual open evening makes me nervous. It brings me out in a rash. I don't want to say where it occurs, but it always comes on at this time of year and reaches a nasty scratching peak on the evening. My wife claims that my trousers are too tight and that I should dispense with the same old suit I wear year in year out on this occasion.

Anyway, I get nervous. I think it is something to do with meeting the parents of prospective students. Sometimes, those I take to be parents are actually the students. It can be confusing. And embarrassing.

There are several types of parent who attend open evenings. With some I can cope with the inconvenience of a minor skin irritation, but others cause me to scratch furtively the moment I see them coming across the room.

There are those who wade straight in with the interrogation about results. Usually, I have done my homework and have rehearsed the answer in my head. However, I am not very good at fabricating the truth.

"Tell them what they want to hear," advises my mate Colin from maths.

"You mean lie?"

I like the parents who tell me what a wonderful job I am doing, nurturing young minds, allowing them to realise their potential and that they would definitely like their son or daughter to be part of a college renowned for its academic reputation. But, actually, I have yet to meet any of this type.

For some it seems obvious that mum and dad have put on their best clothes and persuaded teenage offspring to be seen out with them. Not only that, but they want to talk to a strange man in tight-fitting trousers and pretend that their teenager is not actually there.

"Do you want to ask anything now Astral?" the mother asks.

"No," replies Astral, looking at her watch.

"Take this leaflet about the course," Astral takes it, puts it with all the others and they walk away. One quick scratch and on to the next customer.

And then you just know that the father standing in the background works at a college. He lets his wife do all the questioning while he grunts and pulls faces. He has that look about him. How did I know? And when he walks away to find the only grammatical error on your display of work you realise that it must be his suit.

And it is inevitable that at some point in the evening the lone parent seeks me out and enters my life for what seems like a very long time. This usually happens just as we are closing up for the night. I live in dread of the ones who come clutching a notebook and copy down everything I say. This type of person always finds everything fascinating and often says something like, "Well I wish I could do this course."

Call it tiredness or downright stupidity but I always seem to find myself laughing nervously and saying, "Well you can, we run it as an evening class. Here take this leaflet."

I can hear myself saying it. I mean, I can always hear myself saying it on the night as I am usually the last lecturer left in the room and the college has gone eerily quiet.

Well, I can't pretend these things won't happen again this year. Maybe my wife is right about the suit, but if I keep applying the ointment I am sure I will get through another open evening.

fields.headline: Snap unhappy
fields.standfirst: Photography courses are churning out too many ill-trained students, says  Dunstan Perera
fields.trailText: Photography courses are churning out too many ill-trained students, says Dunstan Perera.
fields.body:
Recently, I had to interview applicants for the post of a photographic laboratory assistant. Out of the 23 I spoke to, none of them knew who invented photography, even though they had all completed a diploma course. The answers to the rest of the technical questions were met with equal ignorance.

The teaching of photography today is in a shambles. The industry can only absorb approximately 2% of the graduates. Teaching institutes are turning out graduates like sausages, attempting to fill up shelves that are already full. Most of these students are badly trained; they have no technical knowledge and are ill-equipped for the real world.

The Btec training programme is even worse. Often the course is taught by an art teacher with hardly any experience or knowledge of the subject and no knowledge of photographic chemistry. No outside lecturers or experts are brought in.

There is a difference between teaching a syllabus and teaching a subject. The excuse I hear from most colleges is the lack of funding. Yet if most of these courses were not there, there would be ample funds for the few who deserve them. Perhaps cutback is not the solution, but "cut it out" is the obvious answer.

Digital technology has started another nightmare for the teaching of photography. Photographers and some teachers are confused by the new technology, and some are horrified. Most students seem to believe that photography developed with digital, and the legacy of 150 years is forgotten or banished to the history books. This is done at our peril. If the current trend continues, photography as we know it will only be practised by two groups: amateurs and photographers in third world countries, where they cannot afford digital technology.

Almost every photographer now uses some form of digital photography in their work. What is produced and retouched with a computer might look clever, but, at best, the images are cold and sterile and, above all, they are beginning to look the same, lacking in style and individuality. Computers are not the Holy Grail, though in the hands of a talented photographer they can be an asset. We did produce great images once, before computers. Those who produce great images will still do it without any digital assistance.

Have photographers killed the goose that laid the golden egg? I strongly feel they have. A frustrated photographer will never make a good teacher. There is no excuse for last year's graduates becoming this year's teachers. Teaching a hobby is a luxury, but teaching a profession is a serious responsibility. Are we spending vast sums of money for teachers and students to indulge in a hobby?

Surely there are far better ways of training the 2% that the industry requires. The best students are left by the wayside, the best teachers are not employed, the best "artists" never win awards and the most discerning courses are never funded. I believe that everyone is entitled to receive the education of their choice, but it is far better to have perhaps one institute producing highly trained and skilled graduates who can be easily absorbed into the industry, rather than a large number of institutes producing unemployable graduates. A change is due, but it has to be a major change - the present system is a waste of money and resources.

 Dr Dunstan Perera is the inventor of the Heliochrome photography printing process.

Digital technology has started another nightmare for the teaching of photography. Photographers and some teachers are confused by the new technology, and some are horrified. Most students seem to believe that photography developed with digital, and the legacy of 150 years is forgotten or banished to the history books. This is done at our peril. If the current trend continues, photography as we know it will only be practised by two groups: amateurs and photographers in third world countries, where they cannot afford digital technology. Almost every photographer now uses some form of digital photography in their work. What is produced and retouched with a computer might look clever, but, at best, the images are cold and sterile and, above all, they are beginning to look the same, lacking in style and individuality. Computers are not the Holy Grail, though in the hands of a talented photographer they can be an asset. We did produce great images once, before computers. Those who produce great images will still do it without any digital assistance. Have photographers killed the goose that laid the golden egg? I strongly feel they have. A frustrated photographer will never make a good teacher. There is no excuse for last year's graduates becoming this year's teachers. Teaching a hobby is a luxury, but teaching a profession is a serious responsibility. Are we spending vast sums of money for teachers and students to indulge in a hobby? Surely there are far better ways of training the 2% that the industry requires. The best students are left by the wayside, the best teachers are not employed, the best "artists" never win awards and the most discerning courses are never funded. I believe that everyone is entitled to receive the education of their choice, but it is far better to have perhaps one institute producing highly trained and skilled graduates who can be easily absorbed into the industry, rather than a large number of institutes producing unemployable graduates. A change is due, but it has to be a major change - the present system is a waste of money and resources.  Dr Dunstan Perera is the inventor of the Heliochrome photography printing process.

webTitle: Illiteracy and innumeracy 'tsarina' launches her campaign

fields.headline: Blitz on basics
fields.standfirst: The government's illiteracy and innumeracy 'tsarina' launches her campaign against Britain's number one social problem.  Nick Tester  reports
fields.trailText: The government's illiteracy and innumeracy 'tsarina' launches her campaign against Britain's number one social problem. Nick Tester reports.
fields.body:
The gulps were audible followed by the sound of chins hitting the conference floor. Could this woman be serious? But yes, that was what the government's new basic skills "tsarina" had just said on a public stage.

She wanted every further education college in the land to recruit an extra 25,000 students each over the next four years as their contribution to the strategy, to be formally announced within weeks, to help the 7m adults with poor or no literacy and numeracy skills. This is now considered to be the country's foremost economic and social problem.

Spearheading the battle to improve reading, writing and numeracy will be the tsarina, Susan Pember, currently principal of Canterbury College, Kent, who has yet to take up her appointment as director of the Department for Education and Employment's new Adult Basic Skills Strategy Unit. But she has already set a personal target of having 750,000 fewer adults suffering literacy and numeracy difficulties by the time her contract ends in 2004.

The £50 million national strategy will enjoy unprecedented levels of money. It will be expected to coordinate and improve existing efforts, presently organised by such bodies as the Further Education Funding Council, Basic Skills Agency and the Further Education Development Agency - and to make sure the emerging Learning and Skills Councils stay on message too.

The national strategy is the direct consequence of last year's powerful Moser Report and an earlier funding council survey. Both revealed disturbingly poor levels of basic skills teaching and, worse, insufficient numbers of people even vaguely motivated to do something about their own plight.

Unpublished inspection findings of basic skills teaching in 54 colleges this year show that over two-thirds of literacy and numeracy lessons - whether as part of discrete courses, vocational programmes or additional learning support - were judged satisfactory. But the Further Education Funding Council chief inspector, Jim Donaldson, who carried out the survey, warns there is a worrying degree of complacency abroad. Colleges, he says, are being "over-generous" in the way they assess their own achievements. Virtually half think they are doing an outstanding job - almost twice the proportion reckoned to be in the same category by funding council. "This," Donaldson says, "at a time when college staff have become much more self-critical.

"We are reaching a turning point in tackling illiteracy and low numeracy. We now know what needs to be done. We have the willingness and the ability to perform the cultural revolution that's so vital. Like Tiger Woods, further education has the best set of clubs in the bag."

It remains unclear whether Ofsted or the new Adult Learning Inspectorate will investigate separately the quality of basic skills teaching in colleges in the way funding council has. But it is certain that the Learning and Skills Council and its 47 local varieties will need to take note of the new strategy, not least because a substantial part of the government's £160m Standards Fund is being earmarked for basic skills.

A "quality initiative" to raise teaching standards through a programme of staff training and organisational development is being led by the funding council until its demise next April. Over 1000 college staff will be invited to training sessions starting next month. A possibly controversial element of this initiative will be the piloting in the new year of a national test that eventually could be taken by all further education students, not just those with basic skills deficiencies. This will be intended to be a national benchmark to help give employers a clearer understanding of potential recruits' abilities.

The basic skills tsarina has been charged with accelerating the delivery of the quality initiative as part of the national strategy. This will set targets, including getting 50% of adults qualified to the accepted standard or above by 2002 (the present figure is 46%) and a 7% reduction in non-learners.

Pember, whose brief transcends the boundaries of government departments, doesn't quibble about the challenge facing her. "We can't have a learning society with 7m not participating. We have set up more learning environments than any country in the world, but students are not coming to us in sufficient droves.

"We need to change people's attitudes to learning, which is really difficult. Learning programmes must be responsive to what people want and when. They must be really exciting."

She also wants to ginger support among employers by trying to convince far more that their profit margins will nose-dive unless they take staff training seriously "and help us assess what needs to be done". An obvious example was enabling cleaners and other caretaker staff unable to read or add up to acquire these skills so they could use the internet to order materials rather than continue to make more costly phone calls.

As far as colleges go, Pember is pushing at a wide open door. The enthusiasm for the task in hand is mutual. Even a reputable institution like Liverpool Community College, given top marks for quality and standards in a recent funding council inspection, is planning to restructure its basic education faculty in order to respond to the tsarina's message. Marie Allen heads a faculty that plans to double to 12 the number of outreach learning centres in the city. She explains: "We need a fresh start. The needs of basic skills five years ago are not those of today."

The secret is to make sure improvements are properly managed and that the illusion of quick fixes is dismissed. And while it is one thing to get more students enrolled on courses, it is more tricky employing lecturers who can actually teach basic skills. "We need to manage staff selection," says Allen. "Some may have a PhD in maths but it doesn't naturally follow that they can teach numeracy."

Annette Zera, principal of Tower Hamlets College, east London, where a quarter of her students have reading difficulties, says the critical issue is building a career structure for part-time lecturers - as well as implementing better management procedures in colleges. "Once we get all these extra learners in, the next problem will be not having enough teachers," she warns. "We need far more basic skills specialists, as well as lecturers who can also teach basic skills."

fields.headline: Without maps
fields.standfirst: Pauline Eyre faces teaching from a wheelchair this year. How will she cope?
fields.trailText: Pauline Eyre faces teaching from a wheelchair this year. How will she cope?
fields.body:
It's the back-to-college season, when teachers gird themselves to tackle new students, new syllabuses, new hoops to jump through.

I'm no different. And yet I am. This autumn, I face the prospect of teaching in a wheelchair.

In June, when I ushered my students for German AS-level into the exam room, I could still get out of a chair to write on the whiteboard. Just. I could still thread my way round students' desks, to offer individual help or paired oral work. Just. And I could still walk into reception to pick up my post. Just.

The new German AS syllabus is providing much food for thought. Like most part-time further education tutors teaching to new specifications, I shall be feeling my way in the dark, largely without support or guidance from line managers, who have loftier considerations to juggle. But, hey, when you teach part-time in further education, you're used to going it alone. I have my syllabus always to hand.

The trouble is, the syllabus for disablement hasn't been written yet. If it existed, believe me, I'd be following it to the letter, doing the background reading, the testing and assessment. I'd be getting outstanding results by now.

I've been going it alone with MS for about 15 years now. It's only in the last two years that the slow fizzling out of my strength has started to impinge on my life, that people have started to look at me sympathetically or look away, and well-meaning folk have said things like, "Well, you still have your brain."

Strange, that. It's not till something denies you your legs, that you realise your brain can be paralysed without them. The battle that I've been waging, shoring up my mind, my capacity as an intellectual, against the ravages of a disease that crumbles away my body bit by bit, demands energy that is rightfully due to my children, my husband, my students. Over the past year they've got used to my tottering gait, first with one stick and then with two. They've adapted to my inability to join in all the activities we used to share. My family good- naturedly fetch and carry for me. My students look the other way when I trip up. They carry the overhead projector about for me.

There seems to be an inordinate amount of lugging equipment around. When I look back at my comprehensive teaching days, before I had my own children, I don't remember hoicking projectors about, moving TVs from room to room, going down two flights of stairs and back up four to find a cassette recorder. Perhaps my vision of the past is clouded or I'm forgetting the further education expectation that you sort it out for yourself. Of course, I've found ways. I bring in my own cassette recorder from home. It's easier than tackling the stairs at college, and I've only broken one by falling over. I come in to college with an hour to spare before an evening class to get what I need. By the time my students come in, with the keenness that only evening class learners can manifest, I'm ready for a sit down, I can tell you.

So. Maybe appearing in a wheelchair will be liberating. Soon, I expect I'll be rolling confidently down the zig-zag one in 12 slope provided as secondary access to the main door of college, calling breezily to other part-time colleagues whose names I don't know, getting them to open doors for me. I'll be blasé about using the lift that fits a wheelchair inside, so long as you don't need to turn and press the lift buttons, the same lift that breaks down more often than I care to think about. I'll be able to tell those full-time colleagues I hardly know, who contort their faces into masks of concern when they see me coming and ask "How are you coping?" where they can stuff their sympathy.

Maybe. The odds are that it won't happen like that. I'll be making it up as I go along, taking it one step, or one wheel-revolution at a time. Much as I like syllabuses, I need to learn to learn without one.

 Pauline Eyre teaches German to evening classes at a Yorkshire college. She was diagnosed as suffering from MS in 1986.

fields.headline: Get in training
fields.standfirst: Industrial skills watchdogs to get more cash. But it comes at a price.  Peter Kingston  reports
fields.trailText: Industrial skills watchdogs to get more cash. But it comes at a price. Peter Kingston reports.
fields.body:
Ministers are to demand substantial improvements in performance by National Training Organisations (NTOs), the bodies which identify the skill gaps in British industry and set standards of competence, in return for a sizeable increase in their funding.

Malcolm Wicks, minister for lifelong learning, will today announce a review of the 75 organisations, which vary enormously in size, clout and the influence they wield in the sectors they cover.

A considerable boost in the numbers of youngsters completing modern apprenticeships will be high on the government wish list in return for more cash. Currently 60% of these training programmes don't get finished.

Every NTO will be required to produce a "workforce development plan" setting out the skills needs in the sector it covers.

Some of the 75 NTOs, which vary enormously in size and clout, will be expected to do more to get themselves taken more seriously by the employers in their industries. And some will have to consider merging to survive.

All of the organisations, whose role is to boost the skills and competitiveness of their sectors, will be required to submit to scrutiny by a government-appointed panel.

Those which don't pass muster risk not having their three-year licence from government renewed. NTOs are the only employer bodies officially recognised by government in their assessments of training and skills needs in their sectors.

Both the education secretary, David Blunkett, and his colleague, Malcolm Wicks, the lifelong learning minister, will have warm words for NTOs when they address the organisations' national council's annual conference in London today and tomorrow.

They will talk up the vital role they believe the organisations have to play in bringing skill levels up to those in competitor economies. For example, if Britain could close the labour productivity gap with Germany it would boost the country's output by £50bn.

Wicks is expected to follow the recommendation in the third report by the National Skills Task Force this summer, which urged government to review its funding to National Training Organisations to ensure they are up to the job of increasing the numbers getting training in their sectors.

The hope among his audience is that he will announce at least a doubling of the £10m that NTOs currently receive.

Ministers will be told of the difficulties facing some of these organisations, set up in the dying days of the last Tory government to replace the 150 Industry Training Organisations.

Many are small - 29 have fewer than five staff - and suffer poor recognition among the sectors they cover.

Barely one in 10 employers "can provide an unprompted description of an NTO", according to Garry Hawkes, chair of the national council.

The biggest NTOs, for instance the Construction Industry Training Board which employs over 1000 staff, cover huge tranches of the national workforce. Between them, the top six account for just under a half of all employees.

The 38 smallest, by contrast, cover a tenth of the workforce.

One remedy for the relative lack of clout of some smaller NTOs would be merger. The Bakery NTO and the Biscuits and Cakes NTO, for instance, might be seen as obvious candidates for union.

Labour's national policy forum document, Building a future for all, presented to its recent annual conference, says that the government will be prepared to use legislation where major skills deficits identified in the development plans are not satisfactorily plugged. Delegates at today's NTO conference will undoubtedly take the chance to ask the minister what exactly the government has in mind.

webTitle: Hong Kong's distance educators set sights on China

fields.headline: Flightpath
fields.standfirst: Hong Kong's distance educators dream of China's millions, says  David Cohen
fields.trailText: Hong Kong's distance educators dream of China's millions, says David Cohen.
fields.body:
The Hong Kong skyline rises out of the harbour like a Manhattan of the far east, its buildings reaching for the stars. For distance educators, though, it's that smudge of hills on the horizon and what lies behind them, in mainland China, that's the altogether more tantalising vision.

And, they are quick to tell visitors, they intend to be there before their British and American counterparts arrive to exploit what most say will be one of this century's great marketing opportunities in distance education. Last week the Global University Alliance launched an online distance learning venture in Hong Kong involving Derby and Glamorgan Universities and institutions in Australasia and the US.

But at the Open University of Hong Kong, administrators feel that they have particularly good reason to be optimistic about breaking into the market - and they offer the story of their own institution as a lesson in how this future might come to pass. When the university opened its doors, in 1989, as many as 100,000 Hong Kong residents turned out for several days in a row, lining up around city blocks for a chance at a post-secondary education.

In the process, they signalled the beginning of Asia's new wave of higher learning. Until that point, fewer than 3% of high-school graduates in Hong Kong had gone on to college. Now, as the Open University begins to market itself to mainland China - where access to higher education is limited - administrators hope for a similarly enthusiastic response.

By some standards, distance learning arrived late in Hong Kong - 20 years after Britain, upon which the model is based. "But when it arrived, it arrived with a vengeance," says Tam Sheung-wai, president of the Open University of Hong Kong. "If there has been a problem, it has been keeping up with the demand."

The trend in Hong Kong, like the rest of Asia, is strongly upward. Vividly diverse in terms of language and culture, Asia is home to the world's most rapidly expanding populations, many of them still rural. This decade, they represent the world's biggest potential market of consumers for higher education.

In Asia, the need for higher education, in one form or another, encompasses perhaps 500m people at a time when personal wealth, mobility, migration and internet usage are also generally increasing.

Analysts say that if Asia were to use conventional solutions to meet current demand, the region would need to increase its spending on higher education by at least 40%. That leaves governments no choice but to look for solutions outside the traditional, elite systems of instruction which are often hundreds of years old - some bequeathed by colonial overlords and others of local origin. In Hong Kong itself, distance is a matter for geography books: here 6.4m inhabitants are crowded into just 380 square miles. The territory is at the other end of the Asian demographic spectrum from western China or rural India, where poor villagers are spread out over large distances.

Hong Kong is the world's second-most densely populated urban centre after Singapore, with some 16,840 people per square mile. Compared with some countries, the percentage of adult students studying by internet and other unconventional modes of higher education in Hong Kong remains pretty low: just 21%, compared with 40% in western Europe and more than 60% in Scandinavia. But unlike Hong Kong's other eight conventional universities, the Open University accepts all comers, or at least as many as it can serve. That policy contrasts with those of older institutions, such as the Chinese University of Hong Kong, which admit only 18% of applicants. "We allow people a second chance," says British-born Richard Armour, registrar at the Open University. Even so, he says, "Second chance doesn't mean second-rate. It can't - not in status-conscious Hong Kong. We would be out of business if it did."

More than 100,000 students have studied at the Open University, about a tenth earning degrees. From offering the most restricted opportunities for higher education, Hong Kong became, in the past decade, "a place where any 18-year-old who can hold a pen can obtain a diploma", in the words of one newspaper editorial.

The growth is particularly evident in business schools. Before the government began examining their credentials, more than 60 fast-track MBA programmes were being offered in the territory, most by offshore institutions based in Britain and Australia, and some with dubious, if any, accreditation. "We became very concerned at some of the overseas offerings, and still are, up to a point," says Ronnie Carr, another Briton at the Open University who is dean of its education and languages department. "Some of these institutions have seen Hong Kong as a good place to cut corners," he adds, "especially given that this is a culture where students like to finish things quickly."

Still, the arrival of the "cowboys", as Carr describes them, was a compliment, of sorts, for Hong Kong. "It showed that this is an ideal society for educational opportunities," he says, mentioning the ease of English-language communication among other cultural characteristics.

Some outside observers say the Open University does have its weaknesses. "If I have anything to say against the Open University," says Cheng Kai-ming, a professor of education at the University of Hong Kong, it is "probably that it hasn't been ambitious enough, especially at a time when whoever truly taps into the mainland-Chinese market will become a very, very significant player in higher education."

In China, a nation of 1.3bn, the number of students working toward a master's degree in business administration this year is just 2,000.

According to the "one country, two systems" concept under which the transfer of rule from Britain to China took place in 1997, for economic purposes the Chinese regard Hong Kong as just another country, albeit one with special cultural ties. But in the past three years the university has pushed to have at least some of its programmes accepted by the Chinese government. Today, more than 1,000 of its students are from the mainland.

For distance educators, though, it's that smudge of hills on the horizon and what lies behind them, in mainland China, that's the altogether more tantalising vision. And, they are quick to tell visitors, they intend to be there before their British and American counterparts arrive to exploit what most say will be one of this century's great marketing opportunities in distance education. Last week the Global University Alliance launched an online distance learning venture in Hong Kong involving Derby and Glamorgan Universities and institutions in Australasia and the US. webTitle: Warwick university and the secret of Smirnoff

fields.headline: Good spirits
fields.standfirst: For years, Warwick University reaped the benefit of the Smirnoff millions on one condition - that they kept it quiet.  Chris Arnot  tells the tale
fields.trailText: For years, Warwick University reaped the benefit of the Smirnoff millions on one condition - that they kept it quiet. Chris Arnot tells the tale.
fields.body:
Warwick was just another newish university until it discovered Smirnoff. Vodka didn't exactly keep it afloat, but it did provide uplifting and continual waves of extra funding. It ensured that the university's greenfield site on the edge of Coventry became home to the first en-suite student residences, one of the most significant business archives in the UK and the biggest multi-arts centre outside the Barbican in London.

No other British university has been fortunate enough to retain a relationship with a private philanthropic foundation over such an extended period. In 35 years, Warwick has received the equivalent of £19m at this year's prices. And all because of Jack Martin, the man who invented such hindrances to clear-headed thinking as the the Bloody Mary, the Screwdriver, the Moscow Mule and the Black Russian cocktail.

Martin's sister, Helen, set up a charitable trust to spend some of the fortune that Jack built. Born in Coventry, he moved to the United States in 1927 and, 12 years later, bought the rights to Smirnoff Vodka for $14,000. By the 1960s, when Warwick was founded, the company was selling 14m crates worldwide.

Helen continued to live at the family home in Kenilworth, a mile or two across the fields from Warwick University, until she died in 1988. By that time, her trust had given away many millions, not only to the university but also to a number of local and national charities. She was an unmarried woman who loved pedigree poodles and classical music. Indeed, she had her own seat in the concert hall at the arts centre. "I met her there only once," says Michael Shattock, who retired last year as the university's registrar. "She was a quiet and unassuming lady who was very anxious that her contribution should have no publicity."

Twelve years after her death, Shattock felt that the time was right to put the record straight, officially, and give credit where credit was due. He has just published a 25-page glossy brochure outlining the history of the Martin family's contribution and the impact it has made on Warwick's development. "What private money gives you is the betterment factor," he says. "It marks you out. What we've got out of this are things which couldn't have been done with state money. It only happens in a few places and it's a matter of luck and the personalities fitting together."

Two very different personalities were key figures in this saga. Jack Butterworth, fellow of New College, Oxford, was about to take up a job as Warwick's vice-chancellor in 1963 when he was invited to address the Coventry Chamber of Commerce. It was there that he met an accountant called Phil Mead, who was a trustee of the Martin family's fledgling charity. Mead was keen on football and would become president of Coventry City. At their first meeting, he told the prospective vice-chancellor: "Universities are like football clubs. You have to be in the first division."

Were he still at Warwick today, Lord Butterworth would be pushing for a European place at the top of the premiership. Back in 1963, he demonstrated some nifty footwork when Mead revealed that the education department had still not responded to the trustees' offer to set up an Anglo-American scholarship fund. Would Warwick like the money instead? It would.

"It was this speed of reaction, informality of style and ambition to support new projects that brought the two sides together so quickly and in such a trusting relationship," Shattock writes. The initial donation of £5,000 was followed by more. Much more. So much more that when they crossed the Atlantic in 1964 and visited the Hopkins (arts) Center at Dartmouth College, Mead apparently said to Butterworth: "I think we'll have one of these."

Ten years later, stage one was opened with a concert conducted by the great American composer Leonard Bernstein. When Butterworth left Warwick in 1985, Shattock took over dealings with the trustees and the university continued to make the most of its good fortune.

The en-suite student residences, for instance, became the basis for a lucrative summer conference trade. Matching £500,000 from the trust and building a modern records centre was enough to persuade BP to choose Warwick ahead of Cambridge to house its sought-after business archives. But developing a reputation for entrepreneurial shrewdness was not to the taste of some academics. "Warwick University Ltd," was the contemptuous label pinned on it by one of its readers, the historian EP Thompson.

"A left-wing fabrication," Shattock retorts. "We've put the money we've generated back into the university." He goes on to say: "Higher education has to be a mixed economy. It's important that the state continues to provide funding, but you can only be a world-class institution if you can continue to attract other resources." Cheers, Jack.

Vices behind vice-chancellors

Bristol University owed its foundation to the munificence of tobacco magnate Henry Overton Wills. After years of attempts to create a university in the city, his announcement of a £100,000 gift provided a charter was granted within two years proved the necessary spur. It was followed by Bristol granting a penny rate to the venture to bring in £7,000 a year. The Wills Memorial Building (right) looks set to outlast Bristol's declining cigarette industry.

The delicious smell of breweries still hangs over Edinburgh, but a more tangible tribute to the demon drink is McEwan Hall (right), where thousands of graduands troop through degree ceremonies each year. When Edinburgh University expanded in the late 19th century, Disraeli's government was prepared to help but not to fund a graduation hall. In 1886 William McEwan, founder of the brewing company, stepped in with £115,000 for the building which he decorated lavishly.

webTitle: The end of Eastern European languages?

fields.headline: Tongue tied
fields.standfirst: Eastern Europe may have come in from the cold, but try finding a course in Polish, Hungarian, Czech or Slovak. And now even Cambridge is abandoning them, says lecturer George Gömöri
fields.trailText: Eastern Europe may have come in from the cold, but try finding a course in Polish, Hungarian, Czech or Slovak. And now even Cambridge is abandoning them, says lecturer George Gömöri
fields.body:
From next year Cambridge University will cease to teach any of the central east European languages to honours degree level. Polish, Hungarian, Czech and Slovak will disappear just when these countries are poised to be incorporated in the European Union.

Last year, after more than 30 years of continuous teaching, Czech and Slovak disappeared from the syllabus - the scholar who taught them finally retired at the age of 83. True, he was only an external lecturer who came up from London once a week, but he taught his subjects efficiently and to general satisfaction.

When the possibility of a replacement came up, the faculty balked; technically it was possible to put Czech at the the top of the faculty posts "requirement" list, but the faculty board decided that there was a subject more important than this Slavonic language - Medieval Spanish. Those who want to learn Czech now have to go to London or Prague - our loss, their gain.

Polish is to follow, for, as it was put at one of the departmental meetings, once Czech is gone, the only Slavonic language taught at Cambridge, apart from Russian, will be Polish - so why make an exception?

Next year Hungarian will also disappear at Cambridge. This I can state with certainty, for since 1969-70 I have been teaching both Polish and Hungarian at the university. I was first employed only as lecturer in Polish, but since I am Hungarian-born and have a degree in Hungarian, the faculty had no objection against my teaching Hungarian if time permitted. I think the results justified the university's cost-free benevolence towards Hungarian. I have seen through finals a number of very talented linguists who (without any Hungarian background) managed to achieve firsts in this beautiful, but little known, language. As no post has ever been established in Hungarian, it counts as a "new need" and the university claims it has no funds to establish a lectureship.

Politically, however, the looming meltdown is not just incorrect, it is disastrous. It now seems likely that by 2004 or 2005 Hungary, the Czech Republic and Poland will be accepted as new members of the European Union. That will mean a new, increased demand for qualified translators and British speakers. Also, it will mean (probably) funds from Brussels for the teaching of those languages.

So why axe Polish and Hungarian now? It boils down to money. I must add that plans to stop teaching both languages after my retirement have been discussed for years and I have left no stone unturned in trying to secure private funds to rescue them. With no success. I have even consulted my MP, Anne Campbell, who wrote to the Secretary of Education. She had a reply which advised the university to turn to Hefce to see whether it was possible to save those languages in Cambridge.

Here I have to mention the little-known fact that, for the past 12 years or so, Hefce has been giving regular support nationally to the teaching of "minority" languages. The University of Cambridge has annually received £18,000 towards the teaching of Polish and £10,000 for Hungarian. Out of this my teaching assistants were paid, but about 90% of the funds went straight into the Treasurer's coffers. Knowing this, I suggested that the university authorities should apply for slightly higher funding for both languages for the following four years, in order to establish temporary lectureships. But the general board decided that as there was no financial guarantee for continuing the teaching of those languages, it was better not even to apply to Hefce.

It is not only that I am personally saddened by the university's decision; I am convinced that it is in the national interest not to axe all central east European Languages at Cambridge. If tradition does not matter, future needs surely call for a rethinking of the university's policies and (possibly) for government intervention in the best interest of the UK.

George Gömöri, Darwin College, Cambridge

David Holton, chairman of the Faculty Board of Modern and Medieval Languages, responds:

It is greatly regretable to the faculty of modern and medieval languages that it has had to cease admitting students to read Czech and Slovak (in which it has never had an established post) and that it lacks resources to continue teaching Polish and Hungarian after Mr Gömöri's retirement in 2001.

At the same time we have successfully branched out from traditional literature-based courses into new and challenging interdisciplinary areas, such as European cinema and literary theory. In some languages, notably Spanish, demand has been increasing.

These developments have greatly increased the pressures on teaching staff, pressures which can only be alleviated by reassigning vacant posts. The reallocation of a post to medieval Spanish is to fill a yawning gap that has existed since the retirement of a professor in the 1980s. It is surely important that Cambridge should have a specialist teacher in a field which, despite its intrinsic relevance to the understanding of the Spanish cultural tradition, is taught systematically at fewer and fewer universities.

Without additional funding, whether from public or private sources, the faculty has a choice between maintaining teaching in languages which attract relatively small numbers of students, or improving the quality and spread of teaching in more central areas.

It is to be hoped that an increased awareness of the contraction of languages other than the "big five" (French, German, Italian, Russian and Spanish - though perhaps only French is immune from attrition) in the modern languages departments of UK universities will lead to serious and urgent national consideration of appropriate remedies - before it is too late.

fields.headline: Risky business
fields.standfirst: Women academics are 'held back by fear of failure'.  Lee Elliot Major  reports
fields.trailText: Women academics are 'held back by fear of failure'. Lee Elliot Major reports.
fields.body:
A fear of failure is preventing women academics applying for research grants as often as their more confident male counterparts, new research will reveal later this year. Signalling the next stage in the drive to improve the career progression of women in universities and research institutes, the report proposes mentoring and training schemes to encourage female researchers to be less risk-averse and compete for more grants.

The eagerly awaited results, due to be released before the end of the year, come from a national survey of academics commissioned by the Wellcome Trust charity and the government's research councils, who commissioned the survey after studies revealed that the low representation of women among grant-winners was due almost entirely to fewer numbers applying in the first place.

Three years ago shockwaves reverberated around the international academic community when an analysis of the peer-review system of the Swedish Medical Research Council uncovered systematic sex discrimination among its mostly male referees. Female applicants for postdoctoral fellowships had to be 2.5 times more productive in research publications than male colleagues to secure the same rating in the competition.

No evidence of sexism emerged, however, from subsequent studies of grant applications in the UK by Wellcome and the research councils. But the biomedical research charity found that only 19% of its grant applicants are female, even though women represent 43% of biomedical academics.

The survey concludes that one of the main factors deterring women from applying for grants is that they are less willing than men to enter competitions where success is uncertain. Women academics take fewer risks than men. Women also hold fewer academic positions to apply for grants in the first place.

While more women than men are now becoming university graduates, few women reach top academic positions. Less than 10% of biological sciences professors are women for example, even though women make up 60% of those UK graduates. Women account for just 7% of professorial-level staff in UK universities as a whole. But it is a Europe-wide problem: a report last month by the European Commission concluded that the number of women in senior scientific positions remains low across the continent. On average, men outnumber women by 20 to 1.

Moves to address the gender issue in the UK now appear to be gathering momentum, however. In its white paper on science this summer the government announced a new study to identify the barriers preventing women from returning to scientific careers after starting a family. It also vowed to have 40% of the members on government science policy and advisory committees female by 2005. (The figure is currently around 25%).

And university appointment procedures meanwhile are set to come under scrutiny after a women academic successfully sued the London School of Economics for sex discrimination when her application for a permanent lecturer post was rejected.

Meanwhile, a series of lectures at the Royal Institution highlighting the achievements of women scientists has been organised this month by its director, Susan Greenfield. Her new series, Women in Science, on BBC2 culminates on October 26 with talks from a panel of four women who have made their mark in the scientific community.

"What is now important is to get more women on strategic and decision making committees," said Dr Nancy Lane, a cell biologist at Cambridge University, and one of the four panelists, "Women need to be involved in the bodies that are dictating policies in universities over the next 10 years."
