fields.headline: Smooth moves
fields.standfirst: Where schools share good ideas
fields.trailText: Learning support at Nailsea School
fields.body:
The shift from primary to secondary school is a seismic one. Children may spend the summer break between the two fretting about new teachers, new classmates, new surroundings. Looking at ways of easing the change is a project that Jean Jameson, head of learning support and special educational needs co-ordinator at Nailsea School, has been working on for the past year.

"Primary school is much more intimate and familiar than secondary school," she explains. "The children suddenly go from having just one or two teachers and classrooms to maybe a dozen. It can be daunting to meet so many different teachers and to have to move around the school at every bell." Her idea for making the transition easier was partly based on an American book about high-school reform. The basic principle, she explains, involves reducing the number of different adult-child interactions by giving year seven groups fewer different teachers. Each class tutor teaches the children in their class, not only for their specialist subject but also for personal, social and health education. The year seven teachers will also receive extra training in counselling skills and student-support strategies.

Working in this way, explains Jameson, doesn't just reduce the stress on the children. It also gives the teachers a chance to get to know their pupils. "In that transitional year, it's an opportunity for the children's needs to be recognised and for them to feel valued and feel that they have become part of the school and that they have kept their identity."

Smoothing the passage in this way helps parents too, she adds. "At parents' evenings, the parents are so upset if they find one of their child's teachers hadn't realised they had a problem such as mild dyslexia. But some teachers might see 500 pupils in a week. The teachers simply can't remember everything about every pupil." However, she says, a year spent getting to know each individual in the new intake can help. "It's a foundation for a good relationship with the pupil. The teacher will have knowledge of strengths and of any special needs - and can pass that on to colleagues."

Jameson believes that this kind of approach is particularly important as modern testing becomes more demanding for pupils, teachers and parents alike. As she was speaking, Nailsea School's new intake of year seven pupils, just five weeks into the term, were taking a cognitive ability test in the hall below, all 240 of them packed in together, following microphoned instructions from the dais at the front of the room. "There is more pressure on children today," says Jameson. "Even in these early stages, there is an ethos of testing; you tell the children not to worry, but they do."

The transition project is backed up by other initiatives. David Turner has special responsibility for induction of new pupils. Himself a former pupil at Nailsea, a comprehensive in a pleasant conurbation near Bristol with around 1,300 pupils, he has spent his entire teaching career at the school and knows the area well. He visits the local primary schools to talk to year six pupils, and there is a programme of visits, activities and workshops for prospective pupils. At the end of the summer term comes "moving up" day, where the junior school pupils come to spend a day at Nailsea, go into their tutor groups, and have their first taste of working to a timetable.

Jameson, helped by a grant from the Human Scale Education organisation, hoped to take the transition scheme even further, and have as much as a third of school time in the first year taken by one teacher. "We'd hoped that each teacher would be class tutor, teach their specialist subject plus PSHE, and teach at least one other subject as well." She was disappointed when prospective parents consulted over a possible pilot scheme on a larger scale said they would prefer their children to have different teachers for every subject right from the start. Perhaps, she says philosophically, the scheme needed more PR.

Which it may yet receive; for initial results this year are promising. The year seven tutor team, says Jameson, is working well together, the pupils have settled in and the atmosphere is very positive. She hopes all will continue to go well, because she believes that a scheme like this can replace something crucial that has been edged out by timetable pressures and the sheer size of modern schools: a sense of community.

"School used to be the first alternative to family," she says. "Children today aren't involved in the human undertones of school life. All the pressures make it so impersonal and institutional now. Even Harry Potter seems old-fashioned when you see what characters the staff are and how all the children know them all; it just isn't like that any more."

webTitle: The diary of a parent governor

fields.headline: On the board
fields.standfirst: The diary of a parent governor
fields.trailText: The diary of a parent governor
fields.body:
No sooner have I found myself "elected" (unopposed) as a parent governor than the first meeting of the governors is upon me. As though this were not ordeal enough, the photocopied letter that arrives (with, as usual, fractionally over 48 hours' notice of the event itself) informs me that as a parent governor I am expected to attend a "surgery" for the preceding hour.

What is this about? Surely, I can't be expected to give anyone advice? For the past two years I've simply been one of the herd of parents doing the school run. In that time, I have visited the school office about three times to settle dinner-money arrears and Lucy's classroom about a score of times, either to hand in the gym kit we left at home or for one of those completely anodyne, scheduled five-minute encounters with Lucy's teacher to hear that "she's doing very well". How can I possibly advise anyone else?

That morning I scan the playground for any sign of my PTA-powerhouse friend Susie - in vain. Her partner Jim tells me she's "on the set" this week. I turn to go but almost bump into the headteacher, Mr Richardson, attired as ever in a brown corduroy suit (he must have half-a-dozen of them, who knows where from?). He greets me with a smile - the novelty of which on his perfectly pleasant but habitually lugubrious face nonplusses me for a moment.

"Hello," he says, brightly. "Congratulations on your election. We're delighted to have you aboard, so to speak."

"Er, thanks. I got the notice this morning - about the meeting on Thursday. Tell me, what is this 'surgery' business?" I ask, trying but failing to keep a note of anxiety out of my voice.

"Oh, don't worry about that," he says confidingly. "The idea is that parents can come and raise concerns with parent governors before the meeting. But no one ever comes - shows we must be doing something right, I suppose."

"Oh. Yes, I suppose so." I am not convinced actually. My unopposed election suggests more a culture of apathy among parents accustomed to a school which, to date at least, has done little to encourage parental involvement. But this hardly seems the diplomatic moment to make such a point.

"Look, I've got to run, but why don't you pop into the office and pick up some material on being a governor. Oh, and ask them about courses too," says Mr Richardson over his shoulder.

By some margin, this is the longest conversation, I realise, I have ever had with the headteacher. All of sudden, I understand one of the key motives for becoming a parent governor - and a mixed motive it is: I have become a "face", someone the school's senior staff need to know and keep on-side.

And by some subtle trickledown process, our Lucy is going to receive slightly more attention, as the daughter of a parent governor, than she would as merely one of the school-yard horde. So much for public service and the voluntary ethic: this is about ensuring maximum educational advantage for one's child within the state sector.

But there is a price to pay. Ten minutes later, I emerge from the school office with a vast and bewildering bundle of guides, circulars, bulletins, regulations, reports, directives, policy statements and handbooks. Mr Richardson's secretary, Joan, who moonlights as clerk to the governors, is vague about the training courses when I enquire. But a faint grin of malicious glee flits across her face when she realises that she can offload a substantial portion of the printed verbiage which is threatening to entomb her in her office.

I struggle off to work, feeling like one of those paperboys who suffer curvature of the spine because of the weight of Sunday supplements. It is clear I could spend the next 24 hours straight reading about the tasks of school governors and the regulations governing them.

My former innocence of my responsibilities now seems blissful: east of Eden, I have entered a kind of acronym hell. For my information (and yours), the DES (Department of Education and Science) changed its name to the DFE (Department for Education) in 1992; in 1995 it changed its name again to the DfEE (Department for Education and Employment). I suppose we should be grateful to New Labour, at least, that it has stuck with that. LEAs (local education authorities) I've heard of. The SDP, too (wasn't that David Owen's lot?) - except that, no, this turns out to stand for school development plan.

Apparently, I have joined not a board of governors but an SGB (school governing body). I will be required to oversee the work of the SMT (senior management team), and to do so will have to suffer PMT. Performance management training, since you ask. After a couple of hours' reading, my head aches, I feel nauseous. It must be time for that "surgery".

fields.headline: The perfect winners
fields.standfirst: Inner journeys as well as travel writing featured in our competition.  Donald MacLeod reports
fields.trailText: Inner journeys as well as travel writing featured in our competition. Donald MacLeod reports.
fields.body:
Nobody seemed to walk anywhere on their perfect journeys, noted Margaret Clark, one of the Piccadilly Press readers who sifted through 1,000 entries for the judges. But the best of these teenage writers certainly did get somewhere, often reaching surprising or shocking destinations, in the second highly successful competition mounted by the Guardian and the publisher.

Michael Palin, ex-Python and globetrotting author, found when he came to judge entries that overwhelmingly the young writers were concerned with inner journeys rather than travel writing. "A lot were private - the story allowed them to say something it wouldn't be easy to say in a class or a crowd. I really was surprised there weren't more descriptions of cities and travel abroad. You need a psychologist to judge these, not a travel writer - it's helped my education no end," he laughed.

Author Rosie Rushton and Joanna Carey, the other judges, were impressed by the writers' ability to reflect on often small details or incidents. "The standard was very high. They structured their sentences to reflect the meaning - jerky, staccato to indicate an intense emotional state, for instance. Some of the sentences were beautifully constructed," said Rosie.

Space and time travel, anorexia and pizza deliveries, an Indian story of thwarted love (complete with glossary) - the range of winning entries was heartening.

Encouraged by the standard of young people's writing, the Guardian and Piccadilly Press are plotting another competition - the Perfect Crime?

The winners whose stories are published in the anthology are: Laura Barnett, Fatema Begum, Dominic Burgess, Leigh Debbage, Nikki Dudley, Laura Gordon, Jennifer Haddon, Michael Hallsworth, Edmund Hunt and Joanna Morris.

 The Perfect Journey? Piccadilly Press, £5.99.

fields.headline: Lest we forget
fields.standfirst: Last week, the number of children killed on a school trip  rose again when two girls were swept away while gorge walking.  Phil Revell  asks what can be done to stop such tragedies
fields.trailText: Last week, the number of children killed on a school trip rose again when two girls were swept away while gorge walking. Phil Revell asks what can be done to stop such tragedies.
fields.body:
Half-term approaches and, for thousands of children, that will mean a school trip. For most parents these trips are routine. But, in the wake of last week's tragic accident in Yorkshire, parents will, yet again, be asking themselves whether their children are safe.

Statistically the answer is a resounding yes. Accidents are mercifully rare and literally thousands of visits go ahead each year without incident. But that will be no comfort at all to the parents of Rochelle Cauvet and Hannah Black, who waved their children off on a geography field trip to the Yorkshire Dales and then, days later, had to face every parents' worst nightmare when police called to say their daughters were missing.

For Sharon Carter, the news reawakened all too recent memories of the police call to her home last June, when she was told of the death of her 13-year-old daughter Gemma on a school trip to France.

"I'm absolutely horrified that it can happen again," she said. Gemma was a pupil at Cockburn High School in Leeds, just a few miles away from the Royds School which organised the Dales field trip. "No lessons seem to have been learnt from Gemma's death," said Carter. In fact, Leeds did issue new guidelines to schools this year, but experts in outdoor education argue that the existence of detailed guidance has failed to prevent tragedy after tragedy and that it's time for some schools to face up to the fact that they do not have the expertise to lead activities in the outdoors.

"This all feels like déjà vu," says Outward Bound's Steve Howe. "I can only hope parents aren't discouraged from allowing their children to experience adventurous outdoor activities; that was certainly the case for a period after the Lyme Bay incident."

The Lyme Bay incident in 1993 was a watershed in outdoor safety. Four Dorset sixth-formers died on what should have been a simple canoeing trip. Tragedy unfolded because two young instructors had been put in a situation beyond their competence. They were not qualified to lead groups on the sea, flares were not carried, and lifejackets worn by the group were not inflated.

Attention soon switched to the running of the St Albans centre the group had started from, and managing director Peter Kite was convicted of manslaughter.

A public outcry ensued. Eventually the government was persuaded to bring in legislation to control the industry.

The result was the Activity Centres (Young Persons Safety) Act, which allowed for the inspection and registration of activity centres. A new inspection authority was created, the Adventurous Activities Licensing Authority (AALA), and the scheme became operational in October 1997.

But, from the very beginning, voices within the industry complained that the government was legislating for the wrong sector. Activity centres had a good safety record, as an inspection by the Health and Safety Executive after Lyme Bay confirmed. Accidents were far more likely to take place on amateur expeditions led by voluntary organisations - and on school trips.

Since Lyme Bay, there have been no fatal incidents involving children at activity centres, but voluntary organisations and schools, which are not inspected, have suffered several avoidable tragedies.

In July 1996 Caroline Dickinson was murdered on a school trip to Brittany. The hostel used by the school party did not belong to the International Federation of Youth Hostels, basic security was lax and Caroline's murderer was able to simply wander in and out of the building.

A year later, 10-year-old Laura Zielinski died on a school trip to Wales. The talented young dancer from the Midlands was paddling in the sea on Shell Island near Harlech when waves carried her away. Teachers with the group had no lifesaving qualifications and had not sought advice about the beach before allowing children into the water. Shell Island's owners told the Guardian at the time that they would have warned against swimming at the spot where Laura drowned, and an activity centre based on the island cancelled swimming activities on the day after a safety inspection ruled that the sea was too rough.

In 1998 three children from St James' School in Bolton died when their minibus crashed in France. The school party had left Lancashire on a coach fitted with seat belts, but on arrival in France the tour operator asked the English driver to use a left hand drive minibus with no seatbelts to take the children up into the mountains. Unused to the vehicle, the driver lost control on a steep, narrow road and the bus rolled down the hill. The inquest was told that the three would have survived had they been wearing seatbelts.

The last 18 months have seen four further deaths, with two fatalities in Snowdonia on scout-led expeditions, the death of 15-year-old Rachel Williams from Penzance on a school skiing holiday and Gemma Carter's death in France.

Some would argue strongly against a culture of safety and security which, they argue, is denying children opportunities for adventure and excitement. Climber Sir Chris Bonington, in an interview in the Times Educational Supplement, railed against the effects of a culture of safety at all costs. "After every crisis," he said, "there are screams to make things safer, but at what cost to education?"

Last year, adventurer David Templeman-Adams told the Royal Geographical Society: "We are becoming a nation of softies ... surrounding our children in cotton wool ... they will not be able to cope with risk when they encounter it as adults."

But the point being missed by these gung-ho adventurers is that deaths have occurred in circumstances which any competent leader would have avoided. Ten-year-old Johnathan Attwell died on Snowdon in circumstances that have led to charges of manslaughter against the scout leader in charge of the group, but the case has yet to be heard.

Rachel Williams was not wearing a helmet, despite a recommendation by the US resort. She hit a tree on the slopes in exactly the same circumstances and at the same resort where singer Sonny Bono died the previous year.

Gemma Carter's death is alleged to have happened after a group of children were allowed to leave the main party and go paddling by themselves. Sixteen months later, Sharon Carter is still awaiting the results of inquiries into the death of her daughter.

He would expect children to be kitted out with helmets and waterproofs and under normal conditions would be quite happy to take a group up the gorge. But normal conditions involve river levels of less than six inches in depth.

Colau saw the school groups on the day, when they looked "wet and bedraggled". It had been raining "bloody hard" that morning and had he been aware that they planned to walk the gorge he would have warned against it. Instead, as a member of the local rescue team, he spent much of last week searching for the bodies.

There is a lot of anger in the area about the waste of life and an equal sense of frustration amongst outdoor professionals who know that the inevitable result of the tragedy will be for parents to shy away from such trips.

Outward Bound is particularly annoyed because several reports referred to the activity as an "outward bound" type adventure. The trust operates four licensed centres across the UK and is incensed that its safety record should be besmirched by association with the deaths.

Along with other providers, the trust would like to see schools and voluntary organisations subject to the same regime of inspection that they themselves have to undergo.

Outward Bound's Steve Howe wonders whether cost savings had any impact on schools. A week in a licensed centre starts at around £200 per pupil. Some school trips are offered for half this amount. Not surprisingly, perhaps, some schools often opt to run activities themselves rather than use a licensed centre.

"There is a real and obvious temptation for teachers to minimise the cost of such courses," Howe said. "That has inherent dangers if it means shortcuts on safety. You can't just assume that because you are a good classroom teacher you have the skills to lead a group in the outdoors."

Keep your child safe: parents' questions answered

Schools trips are hugely beneficial in all sorts of ways and few would want to see them banned. But how can parents be sure that the trip planned for their children is safe?

How do I find out about the details?

Every school trip should involve a pre-trip meeting where parents have the opportunity to ask questions.

The school is running the trip itself. How do I know that it has the knowledge and experience to lead the activities?

Do not accept bland assurances of previous experience. Any leader should have relevant and recent qualifications in the activity planned. Ask whether the school has validated its safety systems with an independent expert. If not, why not?

The school is using a commercial provider. How do I find out more about them?

Any commercial provider offering specified outdoor activities needs a licence from the Adventurous Activities Licensing Authority (AALA). Their website www.aala.org gives details of all licensed centres and the activities they are accredited for. It is possible to run some activities (low-level walking, quad biking) without a licence; in those cases schools need to contact the local outdoor education adviser to check that the centre is safe.

What about going abroad?

Reputable companies that operate abroad, such as PGL, adhere to the same standards as licensed centres in the UK. Other holiday operators, running language tours, for example, do not need a licence. Here parents should ask whether teachers have detailed knowledge of the area they are planning to visit. Most operators offer free trial visits for teachers, but not all schools take up the offer.

What about the journey?

Many trips are made in the school minibus. Parents' group BUSK is concerned about school minibuses and recommends a bus that meets all the latest safety requirements. Longer coach trips are more problematic. Coaches are built for comfort rather than safety, but parents should check that safety belts will be fitted and that teachers will ensure that they are used. Journeys longer than 10 hours should involve two drivers.

How many teachers are required?

Department for Education and Employment guidance offers a general guide for the numbers of adults to children. 1:6 for years 1-3 (5- to 7-year-olds); 1:10-15 for years 4 - 6 (8- to 10-year-olds); 1:15-20 for year 7 up. But ratios also depend on the activity and the location. Abseiling would require a much lower ratio, per haps 1:8-12 for older children.

I'm a governor. What should my school be doing?

Excellent guidance is contained in a DfEE booklet "Health and Safety of Pupils on Educational Visits". Is your school following it? Schools that think they have the expertise to offer adventurous activities should validate themselves through an expert adviser. AALA (029 20 755715) can advise on how to do this, as could the local authority's outdoor education advisor. DfEE guidance can be found at www.dfee.gov.uk.

fields.headline: 'I felt hated'
fields.standfirst: Last week's report into the future of multi-ethnic Britain talked in general terms about how our schools fail black children.  Aaron Dixon, 18, gets personal
fields.trailText: Last week's report into the future of multi-ethnic Britain talked in general terms about how our schools fail black children. Aaron Dixon, 18, gets personal.
fields.body:
Last week, the Runnymede Trust-sponsored Commission into the Future of Multi-ethnic Britain launched its report. Its conclusion that the term "British" has racial connotations dominated the headlines. Less widely reported - perhaps because it was so depressingly familiar - were its findings on education.

In it, the commission provided this thumbnail sketch: "African-Caribbean children start school at five in line with the national average. By the age of 10, however, they have fallen behind . . . At the age of 16 the proportion achieving five higher grade GCSE passes (grades A*-C) is considerably less than half the national average. "

The report gave some pointers to why this may be: the national curriculum fails to emphasise Britain's racial and cultural diversity; teacher training often fails to cover issues of race equality; schools exclude a disproportionate number of black children.

But what about the children behind the generalisations? How does it feel to be one of those British black children who is let down by British schools? We asked 18-year-old Aaron Dixon to tell us. This is his story.

"I liked nursery school. I lived alone with my mum and she taught me to read very young so I was top of the class. I liked learning, and I used to go home and tell mum all about what we'd done each day. I was active and noisy but I was popular, too, and I remember the headteacher, Miss Marsden, seemed to really like me.

I went on to primary school in Muswell Hill, London, but I stayed less than a year because my mum changed jobs and couldn't collect me from school. I was sent to stay in Wolverhampton with my aunt. There, I went to a Catholic primary with a strict regime. The teachers were kind, they really showed you love. I remember one especially - he was safe, he would take me to play golf and was always there if I had a problem. Being taught by him was stimulating; I felt I could move forward and learn at my pace. I was always fairly high up in class.

I only stayed at this school nine months, though, because mum wanted me back in London. So I started at a junior school in Haringey. I didn't find it easy to settle. I wanted to see my dad but he didn't take an interest in me. I became troublesome around this time. When I was nine, mum put me into foster care. She said she couldn't control me. I became disruptive at school - talking in class, mouthing back at teachers when they chastised me and playing tricks all the time. I also became the class joker making other kids laugh.

Part of it was that my head was muddled with what was going on in my life, but also I was so bored in school. My mum had taught me a lot of stuff and I knew so much that we were being taught and I didn't want to sit through listening to it all again. But there was no scope for working separately from the others. I'd start to write an essay and lose interest and screw it up. Science was the one thing that really grabbed me - I wanted to be a rocket scientist and I was desperate for books to read on that. No one gave me any.

My parents were from Jamaica and my mum used to give me books to read about black history - but there was nothing like that at school. It was all Columbus and stuff. I would have liked a black teacher in school teaching about black culture, - once a month, say. It would have been interesting for white kids, too. But all my schools felt like white places where there happened to be black kids who had to fit in.

The school knew that I was fostered and that the placements kept breaking down, and the head was sympathetic. He would sit me down and talk to me and try to help, but I was too far gone at that time. They brought in psychiatrists and social workers but what I really wanted was my mum - I used to cry down the phone asking if I could come home to live but she said no. I don't really speak to her any more.

At 11, I went to a comprehensive in Hornsey. I was happy enough for the first few months because it was a new place and a challenge to find my way in it, but then it became boring just spending all of every day in lessons where I didn't feel I was learning much. I was trouble then, I know - disruptive, loud-mouthing teachers. I was always being sent out of class - it seemed to me that more black kids than white were sent out and there was definitely a feeling in this school that black kids were the most trouble and less likely to learn.

I met up with older boys who were out of class too, and already into crime. They took me under their wing and became like my family. They really cared for me. We would register at school in the morning and then bunk for the day and go down the West End stealing. Nobody at the school said anything even though I was not in class day after day. By the end of the year I had stopped going altogether.

Later, I went on to White Hart Lane comprehensive but I hated that, too. I didn't feel accepted by anyone. I liked English and my English teacher used to let me write stories and give me good marks, but most of the time I just felt hated.

Then one day I was going into the playground to meet my cousin who was coming to see me when I saw a teacher had him on his back and was saying "call the police". I pulled the teacher off and put him against a wall and told him to leave my cousin alone. I was suspended indefinitely for that and sent to a unit for excluded children.

The teachers there treated you like an adult, they were on Christian-name terms and I felt I could talk to them. There were black people as well as white running it and there weren't all the petty rules and regulations like at school. I decided there I'd take the opportunity of the education they were offering. I hadn't done any work for GCSEs so they did basic maths and English with me, but also I did two days in college and I got my GNVQ in health and science.

I had to leave when I was 16 and then I spent all my time in crime. It was soon after that I got caught for robbery and because I had convictions for other petty offences I was sentenced to 18 months at Huntercombe Young Offenders' Institution.

It was the teachers in prison who got me back into education. They encouraged me to do two GCSEs. Jane, who took English, put a lot of time into making sure I did good. I felt she cared, and Stella who taught maths made us laugh so I looked forward to lessons. The person who was the biggest influence, though, was Steive Butler, the head of arts training. She let me spend a lot of time in the recording studio. I took my GCSEs after six months and got a B and a C. I felt really pleased.

When I came out of prison I signed up to do a college course in music technology, web design and video camera work. I got my NVQ in that and was asked to teach other children on a weekend course.

I've also got a job working for Eastern Electricity as a salesman. Life's all right now but I think with a better education there are a lot of things I could have done. So I feel sorry I failed at school, and I feel sorry that school failed me, too."

webTitle: The playground, it seems, is becoming a battleground

fields.headline: On the warpath
fields.standfirst: The playground, it seems, is becoming a battleground - between parents and teachers.  Sophie Radice reports
fields.trailText: The playground, it seems, is becoming a battleground - between parents and teachers. Sophie Radice reports.
fields.body:
A mother of three was jailed for four months last week after she admitted assaulting four teachers at her son's secondary school in the West Midlands. In two disputes over the 12-year-old boy's behaviour, Tina Smith slapped the deputy head, hit the headteacher Charles King and punched another teacher in the face. At the summing-up of the case, District Judge Michael James told her that her "conduct was outrageous. Teachers are entitled to court's protection".

Outrageous certainly, but attacks on teachers by parents and on each other on the school premises are less unusual than the shocked judged might think. Gareth James, head of professional advice at the National Association of Head Teachers, says he has noticed a sharp rise in the number of teachers seeking advice about how to deal with aggressive parents.

"There seems to be an upward trend in challenging and abusive behaviour towards authority in general," he says. "When teachers try to resolve arguments between pupils, particularly in the morning, they can find that they are having to deal with verbal and physical abuse from the parents. Also we find that disputes that originated outside the school are brought into the school grounds by irate parents."

Gina Davidson, 29, whose son is nine, is one of two mothers whose emotions got the better of her one morning a couple of months ago.

"My son had been crying at night about the teasing that goes on at break-time, and when I saw my son's ex-best friend taunting him and his mother just chatting, I sort of pushed her arm to get her attention. I was amazed when she pushed me back and we started to jostle and then almost wrestle with each other."

A letter went round the next day reminding all parents that their behaviour was meant to serve as an example to the children. "We were both pulled in front of the headteacher as if we were school kids and I have to say that I still feel deeply ashamed." Both mothers were told that they would not be allowed on the premises if it happened again, a measure that schools seem to be using increasingly to stop overemotional or aggressive parents coming into the school.

One headteacher who does not wish to be named says she fears that a stern reaction like this does not really help with good communication and adds that "tight security may exacerbate the tension in the playground and the whole unhealthy feeling between teachers and parents of 'us' and 'them'."

In her opinion, "parents are becoming more aggressive towards teachers, perhaps because society is becoming more aggressive generally and we have to try and protect our staff against that. Teachers and headteachers in particular should be as approachable as possible for a parent to make an appointment to discuss problems at an appropriate time, but some parents have just got to realise that because you are standing in a playground it doesn't mean you have to behave like a child."

Educational psychologist Vicky Jones feels that the fact that parents are "standing in the playground" is the key issue here. "If your own memories of school were unhappy, you are far more likely to feel uncomfortable in the playground. When hundreds of children are swirling around you it may well be extremely evocative of your own bad educational experiences and if you are desperate to speak to the teacher and think you are being ignored you may end up feeling very much like an unheard child once again."

Danny, 37, father to a son aged 13 and a daughter aged five, readily admits to finding the school playground extremely stressful and says that it has a lot to do with his own feelings about school.

"When my son first went to school I found myself overwhelmed by powerful and negative feelings - I found it really hard to have to hand him over. All I could remember was the misery I had suffered with a couple of really cruel teachers. I had to go through the whole thing again when my eldest went to secondary school.

"My wife finds it hard to understand but I still get very jumpy and nervous when I am talking to a teacher, as if I haven't grown out of the feelings of disapproval and powerlessness that I felt as a child."

Rose Griffiths, 32, who has two girls aged six and four, did not even have such a bad time at school, but still finds that the whole atmosphere, particularly in the morning, can make her very uptight.

"You have to rush so much and you feel even more stressed if your child is making you slower because they don't want to go to school. It is still only 8.45am, which might just about give you time to have a few words with the teacher before the school bell rings, but some other parent gets there first. You feel terrible having to hand over your thoroughly miserable child to the care of other people, who are probably far too busy to give much time to your individual concerns anyway. No wonder parents seem to lose it sometimes."

My own children's school became like a fortress for a while after the headteacher was physically attacked by a volatile parent. We all moaned about the tight security, making us feel cut off and out of touch, but we also realised that the teachers had a right to protection against the "loony mums" and "aggressive dads" as one member of staff described the more difficult parents.

One day I arrived to pick up my daughter from nursery, only to find two policemen with bullet-proof vests guarding the door. Apparently, a mother who had suffered a nervous breakdown had got fed up with the buzzer system and decided to climb over the gates to get to her children.

She screamed and shouted at the staff when they tried to stop her, which sent them into a state of understandable panic for which they felt they needed professional back-up. Some parents might have accused the school of overreaction, but I felt pleased that both the staff and police had responded so quickly. As one teacher said at the time: "It may seem paranoid, but we don't really care about how it seems. Not only do I feel that we are having to protect ourselves more but that we have a duty, for the hours that they are here each day, to protect children and offer them a sanctuary from the kind of high-level emotion they may be having to deal with at home."

webTitle: The best female violence scene: Me, Myself and Irene

fields.headline: The best female violence scene: Me, Myself and Irene
fields.trailText: Penniless and on the run with Irene (Renée Zellweger), mild-mannered motorcycle cop Charlie (Jim Carrey) stands outside an amusement park, trying unsuccessfully to suppress Hank, the darker side of his split personality. Finally, a glint in his eye signals Hank's arrival. He promptly snatches an ice cream cone from a little girl, and begins to devour it.
fields.body:
Penniless and on the run with Irene (Renée Zellweger), mild-mannered motorcycle cop Charlie (Jim Carrey) stands outside an amusement park, trying unsuccessfully to suppress Hank, the darker side of his split personality. Finally, a glint in his eye signals Hank's arrival. He promptly snatches an ice cream cone from a little girl, and begins to devour it.

"Hey!" the little girl exclaims.

Hank growls in response. The girl runs off, terrified.

"Mommy!"

Irene turns to Hank.

"That's real nice, Hank. Way to keep a low profile."

"It's survival at this point."

They enter the park. Hank suddenly stops, inspiration on his face.

"Hey, I know how to get some dough! Punch me!"

"What?"

"Punch me in the face."

"Why?"

"We'll find the big cheese, tell him I got rolled in the parking lot. He'll hush me with a couple of Benjamins. They don't need that kind of thing on Sugar Mountain. So, come on - rip my head off."

"That's really lame, Hank."

"What, you got a better idea? Come on!"

"It's not going to work."

"Yes, it is going to work. But you got to rock me. Don't give me one of those girly I-don't-want-to-break-a-fingernail love taps, you know? This guy's got to..."

Before he can finish his sentence, Irene high-kicks him in the face, sending him flying backwards, whereupon he tumbles over a railing and disappears down a hill on the other side.

See also: True Romance, Faster, Pussycat! Kill! Kill!

Don't see also: China O'Brien

Pointless trivia: At the age of 10, an enterprising Jim Carrey sent his CV to comedienne Carol Burnett.
